headline: WESTERN RESOURCES IN DEAL FOR 80% OF PROTECTION ONE
abstract: Western Resources Inc will exchange $320 million and its own security operations for 80.1 percent of Protection One Inc (S)

headline: Campbell Soup Chief Says He Will Retire
abstract: David W Johnson announces his retirement as chief executive of Campbell Soup Co; he will be replaced on July 15 by Dale F Morrison; Johnson will stay on as Campbell's chairman until July 31, 1998; senior vice presidents Robert F Bernstock and Basil L Anderson are promoted to executive vice presidents; graph; photo (L)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Philippines to Get Emergency I.M.F. Loan  In an important test of new methods to cope with instability in world financial markets, the International Monetary Fund has for the first time used emergency procedures set up after the Mexican financial crisis to arrange an urgent loan of $1 billion to the Philippines.    The move was an unusual response to the pressure placed on some other Southeast Asian economies since Thailand was forced on July 2 to devalue its currency. $(Page A1.$)

headline: Taiwan Plans to Drop a Fig Leaf; China May Grumble
abstract: Pres Lee Teng-Hui and his Government seem to be moving toward goal of establishing Taiwan as separate nation, not as Chinese territory; ruling party and main pro-independence opposition party join behind plan that would change Constitution to scrap Taiwan provincial government, one of last vestiges of old arrangement under which Taiwan was considered part of China (M)

headline: Dollar Is Off as German Bank Reinforces Its Mark Defenses
abstract: US dollar falls against German mark after German central bank modifies its practice on key money-market rate, giving itself more flexibility to defend lagging currency (M)

headline: H. Upmann is moving to emerge a winner as the premium cigar industry enters a shakeout period.
abstract: H Upmann, Consolidated Cigar Corp's flagship premium cigar, is beginning multi-million-dollar ad campaign intended to make sure it emerges as a winner as white-hot premium cigar industry enters a shakeout period; Marvin Shanken, publisher of Cigar Aficionado magazine, says premium cigar business has almost tripled in last four years; Consolidated Cigar's campaign is by Leibler-Bronfman Lubalin (L)

headline: The style of on-line services may come to matter more than their substance.
abstract: Edward Rothstein Technology column speculates about future of on-line services in wake of news that Compuserve is going to be absorbed by its once rival, America Online; drawing (M)

headline: Data Showing Slower Growth Helps Treasury Bonds to Rally
abstract: US Treasury bonds rally as Federal Reserve enters market as buyer and revises figure for gross domestic product in second quarter showed economy growing at slower pace than previously reported; 30-year bond gains 13/32, to 100 5/32; yield drops to 6.36 percent from 6.39 percent on Sept 25 (M)

headline: For a Choreographer, a Chance to Leap Out of Debt
abstract: Article in periodic series on crossroads of personal finance focuses on choreographer Elizabeth Streb, who won $290,000 MacArthur Foundation grant; Streb wants to use part of grant to make dance more accessible; photo (M)

headline: Stocks Roar Into September, With the Dow Surging 257.36
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average rises 257.36 points, or 3.38 percent, to 7,879.78--its largest single-day point gain ever and its biggest percentage rise in nearly six years; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index surges 28.11 points, or 3.13 percent, to close at 927.58; Nasdaq composite index gains 30.77 points, or 1.94 percent, to 1,618.09; graph (L)

headline: CITIZENS UTILITIES IS PLANNING A REVAMPING
abstract: Citizens Utilities Co will cut jobs, close sales offices and make other cost-reduction moves to save at least $70 million a year in operating expenses; restructuring will reduce second-quarter earnings by $185 million, before taxes; 1997 capital expenditure program will be cut by at least $175 million; stock hits new 52-week low (S)

headline: Concession With Little Immediate Effect
abstract: Analysis of Boeing Co's concession to European Union officials--giving up exclusive 20-year contracts to supply aircraft to American, Delta and Continental airlines in return for approval of Boeing's acquisition of McDonnell Douglas Corp; says industry experts believe agreement will have little practical effect for years to come (L)

headline: Israelis Turn Self-Critical As Mishap Kills Two
abstract: Collapse of makeshift bridge at Maccabiah Games and death of two Australian athletes has set off unusual round of painful soul-searching among Israelis about their attitudes toward order and toward death (M)

headline: Hungary Reluctant to Give Up Secrets of Its Past
abstract: Opening of Office of History by Hungary's Interior Ministry, which keeps files on Hungarians who were spied on during Communist era, is raising questions, instead of ushering in new era of candor about past; historians, citizens and members of governing coalition Government are asking why so few files are available and what could have happened to rest; photo (M)

headline: Boots of Britain Selling Home-Improvement Unit
abstract: Boots Co PLC will sell its AG Stanley Holdings home-improvement chain to London-based venture capital group Alchemy Partners; Boots will take one-time charge of 180 million pounds, about $288 million, on the sale (S)

headline: An Old School Inflation Fighter; Fed Official Resists Notion of a New Era in Economics
abstract: Laurence H Meyer, one of Alan Greenspan's fellow governors on Federal Reserve Board, has emerged as one of most outspoken and influential of those disputing notion that economy has entered new era in which old rules about interplay among growth, unemployment and inflation are becoming less reliable and less relevant; Meyer is subtly but unmistakably challenging some of views held by Greenspan; Fed officials say Meyer's role as intellectual foil for Greenspan has helped invigorate debate within central bank over some of most critical issues of the day; photos (L)

headline: Japan Penalizes Nomura and Big Bank for Payoffs
abstract: Japan's Finance Ministry, in strongest punitive action ever taken against major financial institutions, orders Nomura Securities Co and Dai-Ichi Kangyo Bank to suspend part of operations for rest of 1997 as punishment for making approximately $3.1 million in payments and loans to racketeer, Ryuichi Koike; prosecutors raid Tokyo headquarters of Yamaichi Securities on suspicion that it also paid $670,000 to Koike; penalties are intended to stop illegal dealings, believed widespread in Japan, that threaten to erode credibility of nation's financial markets (M)

headline: MCCAWS BUY 15 MILLION NEXTEL SHARES FOR $232.5 MILLION
abstract: Nextel Communications Inc says that McCaw family has bought 15 million shares for $232.5 million as part of long-term investment plan; family, relatives of Craig McCaw, founder of McCaw Cellular Communications, exercises options to buy shares for $15.50 each (S)

headline: F.D.A. Approves 1st Neurex Drug
abstract: Neurex Corp receives final marketing approval from Food and Drug Administration for Corlopam, a drug for treatment of acute high blood pressure; drug is Neurex's first commercial product (S)

headline: New in ad sales cyberspace, the Softbank Network will cover topics from sports to travel.
abstract: Softbank Interactive Marketing will introduce Softbank Network, which will sell advertising space on smaller, specialized Web sites grouped by content topics; Softbank Network is meant to complement company's Foundation Buy, which handles ad sales for big, popular sites with content of more general interest (M)

headline: Most Contributions Have No Strings Attached
abstract: Letter by Richard J Gerber on Aug 24 article advising donors how to insure that charities use their gifts as intended in light of recent Connecticut ruling that donors have no standing to sue (S)

headline: S.E.C. Is Said to Investigate J. B. Oxford
abstract: J B Oxford Holdings Inc, brokerage firm raided by US and Swiss law enforcement agents this week, is under investigation by Securities and Exchange Commission for its role in possible stock manipulation (L)

headline: Wall Street Is Growing Crazier By the Day
abstract: Recent stock market volatility discussed; could be sign that market is shifting direction or reaction to New York Stock Exchange cut in minimum size of stock price move from 12.5 cents to 6.25 cents; graph (M)

headline: New Twist Makes Corporate Stock Options Even Sweeter
abstract: Handful of major corporations, in new twist on tax deferral game, come up with method of helping executives, directors and valued employees to defer income taxes, often well into in retirement, on profits from exercising stock options; method not only lets those with stock options safely acquire their shares but also permits them to shed them and buy diversified portfolio of other investments without paying taxes for years; question critics raise is whether this new strategy, by making it less costly for executives to dispose of their own company's stock, continues to serve one of central purposes of stock options, which are special opportunities to acquire shares at a set price and benefit from rise in market value (M)

headline: As SFX Deal Is Announced, More Mergers Are Expected
abstract: News about Hicks, Muse, Tate & Furst's $1.2 billion acquisition of SFX Broadcasting propels stocks of many radio companies, including those of Emmis Broadcasting, which has repeatedly declared that it is not for sale, and of Clear Channel Communications, an aggressive acquirer of stations; there is clear sign on Wall Street that more deals are on the way in an industry awash in mergers and acquisitions for more than a year (L)

headline: Fujimori's Scandals Have Peru Seeking Answers
abstract: Peruvians are hopeful Pres Alberto K Fujimori will use annual Independence Day state of the union address on July 28 to allay growing fears that troubled Government is on verge of collapse; his approval rating has plummeted to lowest level in recent weeks amid reports of human rights abuses and documents suggesting Fujimori may not have been born in Peru and is thus not eligible to hold office; photo (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: PEGASUS GOLD INC., Spokane, Wash., is reducing its work force by about 9 percent, or 90 employees.      SPORTS GROUP INC., Atlanta, a bicycle and sports-gear maker, said it hired an investment bank to explore a possible sale of the company. The company is also considering filing for protection from its creditors under Chapter 11 of the U.S. Bankruptcy Code.

headline: Stocks Surge as Dow Passes 8,000
abstract: Graphs and table on Dow Jones industrial average's rise above 8000 mark

headline: Technology Stocks Buoy Nasdaq Index
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average declines 10.91, closing at 8,187.54, while technology stocks continue gains; Nasdaq composite index rises 16.08 points, to 1,621.53; graph on stocks held by largest number of accounts at Merrill Lynch (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: U.P.S. Workers Strike In Battle Over Contract  The sorters, loaders and drivers of the United Parcel Service began walking off the job early this morning after the president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters announced a strike for 185,000 union members at U.P.S. Negotiations had faltered over pensions and the use of part-time workers.

headline: PICTURETEL TO RESTATE RESULTS OF 3 QUARTERS
abstract: Picturetel Corp to restate results from 1996 third and fourth quarters and 1997 first quarter to lower reported profit and revenue; move reflects decision to cancel or defer some revenue from leases of its video conferencing systems (S)/

headline: WARNACO IN STOCK DEAL FOR DESIGNER HOLDINGS
abstract: Warnaco Group Inc agrees to buy Designer Holdings Ltd, maker of Calvin Klein jeans, for $353.7 million in stock (S)

headline: Prices Reach a 2-Month Low For Gasoline and Heating Oil
abstract: Gasoline and heating oil futures prices tumble after surge in inventories; October heating oil drops 1.26 cents, 2.4 percent, to 51.67 cents a gallon (S)

headline: Hapless Crew Of Mir Station Back on Earth
abstract: Commander Vasily Tsibliyev and flight engineer Aleksandr Lazutkin of troubled Russian space station Mir return to earth, after longest, most serious and most highly publicized string of disasters in 11-year history of space station; comments by Pres Boris N Yeltsin and Viktor Blagov, deputy flight director at Mission Control, suggest that Vasily Tsibliyev, the commander, will be held accountable; final judgments on crewmen will have to wait until next week, when other astronauts begin to repair damage to Mir when supply ship rammed into side of science module while Tsibliyev was guiding it; photos (M)

headline: Restaurant Chain Picks Austin Kelley
abstract: Rio Bravo International names Austin Kelley Advertising to handle advertising for its Rio Bravo Cantina restaurants, which had been handled by McConnaughy Stein Schmidt Brown (S)

headline: Clinton Adamant: 3 New NATO Members Now
abstract: As he prepared for next week's NATO summit meeting in Madrid, President Clinton today reaffirmed his intention to limit the first round of NATO expansion to Poland, Hungary and the Czech Republic and suggested that the alliance's position on additional members could be examined in 1999.    Mr. Clinton told European journalists today that only these three countries are economically and militarily developed enough to ''start tomorrow and within a reasonable time meet the same standard of membership militarily that the other NATO countries meet.''

headline: ATLANTA CONCERN BUYS TENNESSEE RESTAURANT OPERATOR
abstract: Port Royal Holdings Inc acquires Krystal Co for $109 million (S)/

headline: Pharmacia Unit And Gray Part Ways
abstract: US consumer health care unit of Pharmacia & Upjohn and Grey Advertising mutually part ways on consumer brand advertising; Jordan, McGrath, Case and Taylor and W B Doner will handle company's advertising (S)

headline: Three-dimensional printing process exploits the different perspectives of left and right eyes.
abstract: Martin Sussman is granted patent for three-dimensional printing process that exploits differing points of view of right and left eyes; Richard Greenberg receives patent for device that captures and stores most recent segment of broadcast, so that push of button will repeat missed information (M)

headline: On a Beach Lined With Ferry's Dead, Haitians Mourn
abstract: UN divers in Haiti continue grisly task of removing bodies from overcrowded ferry that capsized and sank in 100 feet of water just off beach; 200 people are now believed dead, although authorities may never know how many people were on board; photo; map (S)

headline: STONINGTON PARTNERS SEEKS A MAJORITY STAKE IN MERISEL
abstract: Merisel Inc says Stonington Partners Inc offered $152 million for 70 percent stake in the company (S)

headline: After two decades and counting, Procter & Gamble is still trying to exorcise Satanism tales.
abstract: Procter & Gamble Co's inability to kill persistent tales, spread for over 20 years, that its trademark and its executives are linked to Satanism underscores how difficult it is for company to protect its reputation; company is now suing Amway Corp and 11 of its distributors for allegedly spreading stories; some experts hold company's aggressive approach may help perpetuate tales; drawing (M)

headline: Gauging the Bulls in Latin America
abstract: Mutual funds that focus on Latin America discussed; table of recent earnings (S)

headline: More Companies Shorten Summer Vacation
abstract: Auto industry is leading reversal of a European tradition of not working in August by keeping factories open or only partially shutting them down; change largely reflects growing emergence of European companies as multinational players; produced by year-round realities of global economy, many of these companies are finding that they must keep their offices and factories operating at all time, albeit often at a slower pace; shift on summer shutdowns began for most part with car makers, but has been spreading to other industries, including electronics and food processing, that also have extensive overseas operations; graphs; photos (L)

headline: Markets Closed
abstract: Financial and commodity markets in the United States were closed yesterday in observance of the Fourth of July. Government offices, banks and many businesses were also closed. Most foreign markets, however, were open.

headline: Indian Rebels Draw Tens of Thousands to a Rally in Mexico City
abstract: Tens of thousands of Zapatista rebel sympathizers attend rally in Mexico City on Sept 12; Zapatistas call on Government to comply with partial peace accords two sides signed in Feb 1996 and remove army troops from Chiapas (M)

headline: John Itta, 67, Award-Winning Ad Creator
abstract: John Paul Itta, advertising executive, dies at age 67 (S)

headline: MARKET TIMING
abstract: MONDAY  The Agriculture Department reports on the progress of seven crops.    TUESDAY  Mitsubishi Bank/Schroder Wertheim releases its weekly retail sales report.  LJR Redbook Research releases its weekly retail sales survey.

headline: People
abstract: A&E Television Networks names Lyle Schwartz vice president for research (S)

headline: Chairman of LVMH Quits Guinness Board
abstract: Bernard Arnault, chairman of LVMH Moet Hennessy Louis Vuitton, resigns from board of Guinness PLC; move comes just five days after Guinness and Grand Metropolitan criticize Arnault's proposal for three-way joint venture involving drinks activities of the companies (S)

headline: Report Says 3 Executives Misled Texaco
abstract: Independent investigator Michael F Armstrong report concludes that three Texaco executives intentionally misled company lawyers when they withheld documents demanded in discrimination lawsuit against company; executives are former treas Robert Ulrich, former personnel manager Richard Lundwall and former senior asst treas J David Keough (M)

headline: Kurds Fashion Two Identities in a Fearful Turkey
abstract: Turkey's Kurdish population is polarized, with some assimilated Kurds seeing themselves as primarily Turkish and others intractably clinging to their Kurdish heritage and demanding autonomy; more than a dozen Kurdish rebellions have occured since the establishment of the Turkish Republic in 1923, and the current 13-year-old revolt has taken estimated 20,000 lives; map; photo (M)

headline: Growth Slows For Incomes; Spending Up
abstract: Commerce Department reports personal income rose one-tenth of one percent in July, slower pace than in June; consumer spending rose eight-tenths of one percent, suggesting that economic expansion will continue well into 1998; graph (S)

headline: Freelancers Lose Test Case On Electronic Publishing
abstract: Federal District Court Judge Sonia Sotomayor rules that publishers can reproduce articles by freelance writers in some electronic media without their permission or paying them extra; ruling comes in lawsuit, filed in 1993 by group of writers, that was widely viewed as early test of economic rights of freelancers and copyright law in new realm of electronic publishing; plantiffs challenged right of six publishers, including The New York Times Co and Time Warner Inc, to reproduce newspaper or magazine articles on CD-ROM's or electronic data bases--without seeking permission of freelancer writers and without paying them beyond what they were paid for original articles; other defendants were Newsday, Mead Data, unit of Reed Elsevier PLC, which runs Nexis, a data service that provides archives of many news organizations via computer, and University Microfilms, division of Bell & Howell that many years has provided archives of The New York Times and many other newspapers of microfilm (L)

headline: Northwest Air to Buy Back 19% Stake Held by KLM
abstract: Northwest Airlines Corp will buy back 19 percent stake held by KLM Royal Dutch Airlines by year 2000 for between $1.07 and $1.17 billion, ending feud that threatened to unravel profitable trans-Atlantic alliance; KLM will drop two lawsuits challenging Northwest's takeover-defense mechanism, and will reduce number of seats on Northwest's board to one from three; Northwest will obtain seat on KLM's board for first time (M)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent                Previous   Year          Yesterday   Day   Ago               PRIME RATE   8.50   8.50   8.25        DISCOUNT RATE   5.00   5.00   5.00        FEDERAL FUNDS*   5.56   5.34   5.17        3-MO. headline: Coffee Prices Drop as Supplies Seem Ample
abstract: Coffee prices plunge more than 8 percent as supplies flood into exchange warehouses, sign that roasters are well stocked at start of season of peak demand (S)

headline: 30-Year Bond's Yield Hits 5-Month Low in Light Day
abstract: Treasury prices rise for fourth consecutive session, with yield on benchmark 30-year bond dropping to its lowest level in nearly five months; 30-year bond rises 21/32, to price of 100 22/32 to yield 6.57 percent, down from 6.62 percent on July 3; graph (L)

headline: The Peaceful Face-Off in Ulster
abstract: James F Clarity analysis contends that Britain's historic decision to invite Sinn Fein, Irish Republican Army's political wing, to take part in formal peace talks that are to resume Sept 15 has raised hopes for peaceful settlement of violence between Protestant majority and Roman Catholic minority that has killed 3,225 people in Northern Ireland since 1969 (M)

headline: Warning to Broadcasters That Renege on Running HDTV
abstract: Leading members of Congress threaten retribution against broadcasters who they say hoodwinked Congress by promising to broadcast high-definition television on their new digital channels, then reneged once new channels were in hand; although law allows television stations to use their new channels as they please, Sen John McCain and other members say Congress ageed to loan valuable spectrum only after broadcasters promised to use it for HDTV at least part of time; ABC has already said it was leaning toward using its new channels to broadcast lower-resolution, pay-television programs, instead of single high-definition TV show, as has Sinclair Broadcasting Group; both say they see no easy way to make money from high-definition broadcast; Sen McCain schedules hearing of his Senate Commerce Committee on matter (M)

headline: The Wall Street Soothsayer Who Never Blinked
abstract: Profile of Abby Joseph Cohen, chief equity strategist for Goldman, Sachs & Co who has predicted the bull market step by step; says Cohen remains serene about prospects for investors; photo (L)

headline: In the Long-Distance Market, Lean And Mean Just Gets the Door Open
abstract: Declining phone rates are squeezing profit margins for some 800 companies that have squeezed into long-distance phone business since 1984 deregulation; niche long-distance companies that resell network time they buy from others are continuing to surge even as big carriers, their suppliers, begin to stumble; AT&T Corp has seen market share fall to under 50 percent; graphs; photo (L)

headline: Nomura to Spin Off a U.S. Realty Unit
abstract: Nomura Securities Company's US subsidiary will spin off real estate lending unit to pave way for possible sale (S)

headline: Lazard Is Reported to Be Hired As National Westminster Adviser
abstract: National Westminster Bank PLC reportedly hires Lazard Brothers & Co as adviser on possible merger or unit sale (S)

headline: Clinton Cheers Exultant Poles, And Vice Versa
abstract: Pres Clinton, in speech celebrating Poland's new ties to NATO military alliance, tells jubilant crowd in Warsaw that 'Poland is coming home'; Clinton's triumphant visit to Warsaw comes day after conclusion of NATO summit meeting in Madrid where Western alliance invited Poland, Hungary and Czech Republic to join its ranks; Clinton urges Poland to reach out to all its neighbors, including people of Russia; photo (M)

headline: Leap Partnership Gets 2 Accounts
abstract: Chicago and Los Angeles offices of Leap Partnership unit of Leap Group are awarded two accounts with combined billings estimated at $19 million; central region of Daewoo Motor America selects Leap's Chicago office; Los Angeles Department of Water and Power names Leap Partnership's Los Angeles office to handle account, which had been handled by Fotouhi Alonso Agnew (S)

headline: I.B.M. Sets Enhancements For Deep Blue
abstract: IBM plans to announce that its RS/6000 SP computer, same model used to power Deep Blue's May victory over world chess champion Gary Kasparov, has undergone hardware and software overhaul that will make it 58 percent faster (S)

headline: Dividend Meetings
abstract: A partial list for this week.    MONDAY   Crane Co  Gainsco Inc  Genuine Parts Co  Medusa Corp

headline: Congo Misses Deadline In U.N. Investigation
abstract: Congo Republic misses UN deadline for assurances that work of investigative mission probing allegations of atrocities in eastern part of country will not be obstructed (S)

headline: Hoechst Says Profit Fell 62% in Second Quarter
abstract: Hoechst AG says pretax profit in second quarter fell nearly 62 percent, to 1.172 billion marks ($628.5 million) from 3.075 billion marks in same quarter a year ago; sales rose 12 percent, to 14.728 billion marks ($7.9 billion) from 13.114 billion marks (S)

headline: Kodak Earnings Retreated 16.4% in Second Quarter
abstract: Eastman Kodak Co says second-quarter earnings fell 16.4 percent from a year ago; reports earnings of $368 million; stock plummets 11 percent, to close at $68.375, down $8.50; table (L)

headline: UNITED INTERNATIONAL TO SELL CABLE ASSETS IN ARGENTINA
abstract: United International Holdings Inc agrees to sell its Argentina assets, including eight cable television systems and options to buy other properities, to Supercanal Holding SA for $225 million (S)

headline: Gore Urges Moscow to Veto Limits on Minor Religions in Russia
abstract: Vice Pres Al Gore, on second day of visit to Russia, presses Yeltsin Government to reject new bill to protect Russian Orthodox Church against competition from other Christian faiths (M)

headline: BISYS SHARES SLIDE AS BANKAMERICA ENDS BUSINESS DEAL
abstract: Stock of Bisys Group Inc falls 16.6 percent after BankAmerica Corp's mutual fund group ends their business agreement; shares drop $6.50, to $32.625; contract generated about $15 million in revenue (S)

abstract: In percent                Previous   Year          Yesterday   Day   Ago               PRIME RATE   8.50   8.50   8.25        DISCOUNT RATE   5.00   5.00   5.00        FEDERAL FUNDS*   5.44   5.48   5.07        3-MO. TREAS. BILLS   5.13   5.13   5.01        6-MO. TREAS. BILLS   5.19   5.19   5.10        10-YR. TREAS. INFL.**   3.55   3.57   N.A.        10-YR. TREAS. NOTES   6.20   6.22   6.54        30-YR. TREAS. headline: Rebels' Journey Leaves Mexico Confused About Their Role
abstract: Some 1,100 Zapatista rebels in black masks have been visiting Mexico City, reawakening public sympathy for their lagging effort to defend Mexico's Indians from their Chiapas state strongholds; make no progress toward reopening peace talks with Government; visit creates confusion over whether rebels want to continue as guerrilla army or lay down arms (M)

headline: Intel Files a Counterclaim Against Digital Equipment
abstract: Intel Corp files counterclaim against Digital Equipment Corp, accusing company of violating 14 Intel patents that appear to affect every aspect of Digital's business; countercharges are response to lawsuit Digital filed in May accusing Intel of violating 10 of its patents in design of Pentium, Pentium Pro and Pentium II microprocessors (L)

headline: Albanian President Admits Defeat but Won't Quit Yet
abstract: Albanian Pres Sali Berisha, after five years in office that reduced nation to armed chaos, concedes electoral defeat of his Democratic Party, but stops short of resigning as promised; urges supporters to accept result of vote; is backed into acknowledging loss after 54-nation Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe announced that elections, held in presence of foreign troops and monitors, were adequate and acceptable; photo (M)

headline: Gadfly Praises Nuclear Energy Over Wind, Solar and the Rest
abstract: International Atomic Energy Agency director, Gen Hans Blix, says says that atomic energy has to be used more if developing nations are to meet their soaring power demands and world is to have any hope of significantly reducing gases that contribute to global warming; says nuclear safety has been strengthened and the biggest obstacle to it is now public opinion; says most enivronmental groups and some international agencies opposed to nuclear power 'are leading us into dreamland' by calling for renewable sources like solar power, wind energy and biomass (M)

headline: The Price Of Turnover
abstract: Study by Morningstar Inc finds mutual funds with low turnover--those whose holdings are bought or sold infrequently--tend to have higher returns than those funds whose managers trade actively; shows group with annual turnover rates below 20 percent have average 10-year returns that are 1.6 percentage points higher than average for funds with turnover rates of more than 100 percent; table (L)

headline: A Lapsed Law Strips P.L.O. Of U.S. Office
abstract: Palestine Liberation Organization is set to suspend operations at Washington, DC, office at State Department request because Congress left for Aug recess without extending law that lets United States have diplomatic contacts with PLO; Clinton Administration scrambles to keep any diplomatic damage from spilling over to Palestinian peace talks with Israel (M)

headline: In Salmon War, a New Broadside as British Columbia Sues the U.S.
abstract: British Columbia and Canadian salmon fishermen sue United States, Alaska and Washington State, charging breach of 1985 Canada-US treaty governing salmon catch, Federal court, Seattle; seek compensation for Canadian fishermen unable to take their share of salmon; suit is likely to endanger continuing salmon talks (M)

headline: TRAVELERS GROUP SELLS HOTEL TO LOWE FOR $330 MILLION
abstract: Travelers Group Inc sells Hotel del Coronado near San Diego, Calif, for $330 million to Lowe Enterprises Investment Management Inc (S)

headline: What Does It Cost to Send A Teen-Ager to Ninth Grade?
abstract: Three teen-agers, Sarah Lewkowicz in New York, Ryan Foley in Chicago and Marina Cortina in Phoenix, list their back-to-school spending as they enter ninth grade; interviews; photos(S)

headline: North Korea Joins Talks With South
abstract: North Korea sits down for first time with South Korea, United States and China to discuss arranging peace talks to formally end Korean War and ease tensions on Korean peninsula; Clinton Administration officials see willingness to move ahead with talks as sign of desperation over increasingly severe food shortages (M)

headline: French Won't Sell Military Contractor
abstract: France drops plans to sell its 58 percent stake in Thomson-CSF, military electronics company, and will instead make it core of large new military group (M)

headline: NORTHWEST ORDERS 50 JETS AND OPTIONS 100 FROM AIRBUS
abstract: Northwest Airlines Corp formally orders 50 jetliners from Airbus Industrie and takes options for 100 more (S)

headline: Factory Orders Rose in July; Analysts Had Expected Drop
abstract: Commerce Department reports factory orders rose two-tenths of 1 percent in July, to record seasonally adjusted $330.28 billion, after revised gain of 1.7 percent in June; analysts had expected July report to show decline of one-tenths of 1 percent; Labor Department reports number of workers filing for unemployment benefits rose by 2,000 in week ended Aug 30, to seasonally adjusted 326,000; graph (M)

headline: See Spot Run. See Spot Fall. Call Spot's H.M.O.
abstract: Advice on pet health insurance; most deductibles exceed cost of many pets, making insurance economically sensible only for people with strong attachment to animals; some clinics now offer plans that cover preventive care; photo (M)

headline: MARKET TIMING
abstract: MONDAY  The Agriculture Department releases its weekly report on crop conditions.  An earnings report is expected from I.B.M.    TUESDAY  The Treasury Department releases its June budget statement.  Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, delivers his semiannual economic testimony to the House Banking Committee.  Mitsubishi Bank/Schroder Wertheim reports on weekly retail sales.  LJR Redbook Research releases its weekly retail sales index.

headline: Paid to Play, but on the Sidelines
abstract: Many mutual fund managers, resisting trend among domestic mutual funds to remain heavily invested in stocks despite high current prices, are reluctantly building up big cash reserves; are finding it hard to buy stocks at attractive prices; graph; photos (L)(

headline: Recasting Chinoiserie As Modern-Day Chic
abstract: HONG KONG  Whether it be Armani's wide-sleeved silk jackets or Givenchy's brocaded dragon-motif robes, China chic by Western designers perennially reaps applause. Ironically, few Asian labels are known for doing the same, but several Hong Kong-based companies are out to change that.

headline: ITT in Deal for Property Cuba Seized in '61
abstract: Stet International, Italian company, reaches unusual agreement to pay compensation for using property Cuban Government seized from ITT in 1961; Clinton Administration responds by dropping threat to punish company (S)

headline: Ex-Employee Pleads Guilty In Taking of Kodak Data
abstract: Harold Worden, former employee of Eastman Kodak Co, pleads guilty to felony charge of transporting stolen property in a case in which Kodak accused him of taking trade secrets worth millions of dollars and trying to build a business on selling them to Kodak competitors; Worden will serve 15-month prison sentence and pay fine of as much as $53,400; suit contends Worden set up consulting firm, Worden Enterprise Inc, in part as a front for selling stolen documents and recruiting more than 60 Kodak retirees with access to trade secrets (M)

headline: 2 Global Lenders Use Leverage to Combat Corruption
abstract: Article focuses on new policy adopted by World Bank and International Monetary Fund, under leverage with poorer nations is being used to stamp out corruption and promote better governance (M)

headline: Klockner-Werke Shares Soar on Forecast
abstract: Shares of Klockner-Werke soar after it says that its pretax profit will quadruple this year (S)

headline: Leading Index Slowed Pace In 2d Quarter
abstract: Conference Board reports index of leading indicators slowed markedly in the latest quarter, perhaps signaling that any rebound in growth in this year's second half will be modest at best; says second-quarter index rose four-tenths of 1 percent, compared with gain of seven-tenths of 1 percent in Jan-Mar period; graph and chart on index (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: ALZA CORP., Palo Alto, Calif., a developer of pharmaceuticals products, agreed to buy the United States and Canadian rights to several drugs for urinary-tract conditions from Ivax Corp. for $75 million.    U.S. SURGICAL CORP., Norwalk, Conn., acquired the spinal products line of Smith & Nephew P.L.C., a British health care equipment maker, for undisclosed terms.

headline: At Palestinian Papers, Money Is as Elusive As Freedom
abstract: Arabic-language Palestinian newspapers struggle for survival in face of political turmoil, censorship by Israelis, intimidation by Palestian Authority, soaring paper and printing costs and fierce competition among leading dailies; Palestinian press law ostensibly guarantees free press, but self-censorship is often more insidious than official control; editors say toughest challenges are economic; photos (M)

headline: Microsoft Profit Beats Forecasts, but Barely
abstract: Microsoft Corp reports earnings for fourth fiscal quarter rose 89 percent to $1.05 billion from $559 million a year earlier; Sun Microsystems reports fourth quarter earnings rose 94.3 percent to $237 million, compared to $122 million a year earlier (M)

headline: Free vs. Managed Trade: A Question of Goals
abstract: John T Bennett letter discusses Kenneth Lewis July 13 article on free trade (S)

headline: Australians Enjoy a Bullish Market in Wild Camels
abstract: Australia remains only place in world where large numbers of camels still live in wild state; animals were brought to Australia from South Asia and Middle East starting in mid-19th century, initially serving as pack animals for sheep ranches and mining enterprises; population of about 27,000 in 1927 has grown to approximately 220,000, many of which are exported to regions in which they are indigenous; Graham Cannard, camel farmer, comments; map; photo (M)

headline: Salinas: Plenty of Smoke, No Smoking Gun
abstract: Over a year after Carlos Salinas de Gortari left Mexico's presidency, secret Central Intelligence Agency report assured US officials that there was no hard evidence linking him to scandals that had soiled his administration; CIA assessment, dated Dec 27, 1995, raised serious doubts about integrity of Harvard-trained economist whom Washington had once hailed as beacon of new political generation in Latin America (M)

headline: Early Gains In Treasury Prices Wane
abstract: US Treasury market rallies sharply before giving up some of the gains because of worries about the dollar; 30-year bond gains 19/32, to price of 96 26/32, pushing yield down to 6.62 percent from 6.67 percent on Aug 12; graph (L)

headline: Tentative Columbia Accord in Alabama
abstract: Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corp reaches preliminary settlement with State of Alabama over Medicaid billing investigation at Northwest Alabama Medical Center in Russellville (S)

headline: Charles Accompanies Diana Back Home to a Grieving Britain
abstract: Prince Charles accompanies body of former wife, Diana, Princess of Wales, back to Britain to nation convulsed with grief over her death in high-speed car crash in Paris, in which companion, Emad al-Fayed and limousine driver also died and bodyguard was seriously injured; had earlier attended church services near royal holiday estate in Balmoral, Scotland, with sons William and Harry, Queen and Queen Mother; is accompanied to London by Diana's two sisters, Lady Jane Fellowes and Lady Sarah McCorquodale; brief, silent ceremony at Royal Air Force base outside London is attended by Prime Min Tony Blair as simple wooden coffin bearing royal standard is taken from plane by air force guard; body is taken to Chapel Royal at St James's Palace; funeral arrangements to be announced by royal family within day; mourners sob openly in streets of London; throng arrrives outside Kensington and Buckingham palaces; thousands jam St Paul Cathedral for memorial service; Prime Min Tony Blair praises Diana as people's princess, underscoring widely-held view that she succeeded in establishing rapport with ordinary people with skill that has proved elusive to other members of royal family; says nation is utterly devastated and in state of shock; her brother, Earl Spencer, bitterly accuses press of playing direct role in her death by constantly hounding her; body of companion, Emad al-Fayed, 41-year-old Harrods heir, is returned to London and buried after brief Muslim ceremony at Regent's Stret Mosque; Trevor Rees-Jones, surviving 29-year-old bodyguard, remains hospitalized; Paris police say Mercedes limousine crashed into wall of highway tunnel alongside Seine late at night while trying to speed away from photographers on motorcycles; photos (L)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Microsoft to Join Apple In Surprise Partnership  Apple Computer is teaming up with Microsoft in a stunning alliance that could alter the map of the computer industry and help insure the survival of Apple.    Microsoft, whose operating system has long been the dominant alternative to Apple's Macintosh software, will invest $150 million in Apple, and the companies plan to cooperate on sales and technology issues. $(Page A1.$)

headline: MICROSOFT BUYS VXTREME FOR INTERNET AUDIO AND VIDEO
abstract: Microsoft Corporation acquires Internet start-up company, Vxtreme Inc, to let companies send sound and video over the Internet; terms are not disclosed (S)

headline: Staples Merger Is Officially Off
abstract: Staples Inc and Office Depot Inc officially call off their proposed combination after Federal judge granted order this week blocking completion of $4 billion transaction (S)

headline: Seeing Green in a Yellow Border
abstract: National Geographic Society, $500 million-a-year enterprise behind National Geographic magazine, is changing from a traditional, nonprofit monolith into an explorer of an assortmnent of other media, this time for profit; move comes as Gilbert M Grosvenor, last link to society's founding family, has disappeared from daily operations; protest developing over the change is so sustained that it suggests the society may be abandoning what has made it unique all these years, and, in process, been trading in its rather classy image for more commonplace devotion to bottom line; photos; financial graphs (L)

headline: UPN Names TV Executive As President
abstract: United Paramount Network names Dean Valentine, longtime executive with Walt Disney studio, as its new president; Valentine succeeds Lucie Salhany, who will resign this month (M)

headline: U.S. Filter Deal For Bass Family
abstract: United States Filter Corp agrees to buy 50,000 acres of land and their water rights from the Bass family for US Filter stock worth $250 million and warrants to buy further 1.2 million shares (S)

headline: Hutu Families Pay Price in Burundi's Crackdown Against Guerrillas
abstract: Estimated 13,000 Hutu have been forced off their lands by Burundi's Tutsi-dominated army and herded into camp near Buraniro as part of Pres Pierre Buyoya's policy to combat Hutu guerrilla movement; aid workers and diplomats say regroupment camps have been successful military strategy, since it has robbed guerrillas of supply lines and hiding places, and made it harder for them to recruit youths to their cause; photo; map (M)

headline: I.M.F. Says Currency Troubles Will Curtail Growth in Asia
abstract: International Monetary Fund has cut its growth forecast for Southeast Asia, delivering bleak assessment of damage caused by months of turmoil in region's currency markets; over all, IMF says in its global economic outlook, world economy is likely to expand as much as 4.5 percent this year and next and is set for its longest period of sustained growth in at least 25 years (M)

headline: Machine Tool Orders Rose 38.9% in June
abstract: United States orders for machine tools rose 38.9 percent in June from month before, to $894 million, according to joint report from Assn for Manufacturing Technology and American Machine Tool Distributors' Assn; June's gain is fourth rise in last five months, bringing total level of orders in first half of year up 19.7 percent, to $4.4 billion (S)

headline: Stocks Drop on Continued Earnings Concerns
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average closes down 63.35 points, or eight-tenths of 1 percent, to 7,906.71; Standard & Poor's index falls 7.45 points, or eight-tenths of 1 percent, to 944.48, and Nasdaq composite index drops 9.95 points, or six-tenths of 1 percent, to 1,687.41; chart (L)

headline: CORNERSTONE IN $1.06 BILLION PROPERTY DEAL
abstract: Cornerstone Properties Inc, real estate investment trust based in New York, agrees to buy 11 downtown properties in six US cities from pension fund of Dutch Institutional Holding Co of Atlanta, Ga, for $1.06 billion in cash and stock (S)

headline: Gulf Canada to Buy Stampeder Exploration
abstract: Gulf Canada Resources to buy Stampeder Exploration Ltd for stock worth $739 million (Canadian) (US $532 million) (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: A Booming Market In Smuggled Cigarettes  The largest tobacco companies are selling billions of dollars of cigarettes each year to traders and dealers who funnel them into black markets in many countries, according to law enforcement officials and participants in the trade.    In the last decade, the volume of cigarette smuggling around the world has tripled, according to a leading tobacco research organization, reflecting a general surge in cigarette sales abroad, especially for American manufacturers. And while the companies say they have done nothing to encourage the smuggling and do not condone it, industry officials acknowledge that a sizable share of the cigarettes sold overseas pass through smuggling rings set up to evade foreign taxes and sell major brands at a discount. $(Page A1.$)

headline: Name, Resume, References. And How's Your Credit?
abstract: Increasing number of employers are using credit reports as hiring tools, although job applicants are rarely told, and often do not know why they may be turned down for position; Kimberly Dorcik recalls losing out on job because of credit history she says was erroneous; her photo; new Federal law will require employers to inform applicants if credit histories are being used as part of hiring (M)

headline: Coup Halts Lifeline to Cambodia Poor
abstract: Thousands of tiny villages in Cambodia depend for their welfare on wide range of international assistance that substitutes for Government services in country; village of Kvet, with 520 people, is one of many examples of success of broad and idealistic program of international aid that is helping broken country to begin to heal; it also offers glimpse of ways in which withdrawal of aid would affect lives of poor villagers; United States suspended its aid programs temporarily after violent seizure of power by Hun Sen; photo; map (M)

headline: A New On-Line Publisher Promotes Nonfiction on a Pay-Per-Read Basis
abstract: Writer John Franklin, frustrated by increasing difficulty of getting modest-selling nonfiction books published and of keeping them in print, has opened pay-per-read World Wide Web site where readers can choose from works by him and other writers; pieces can be read on screen or printed out; photo (M)

headline: Guinness Profit Climbed 4% in First Half
abstract: Guinness PLC says first-half profit rose 4 percent on higher sales even though strength of British pound sliced 12 million pounds ($19.2 million) from earnings; profit rose to 255 million pounds ($410 million), from 245 million pounds (S)

headline: Pfizer Net Up, but Below Expectations
abstract: Pfizer Inc posts earnings gain in second quarter that falls slightly short of expectations, while Johnson & Johnson Inc reports result that meets analysts' forecasts; Pfizer says earnings rose 16 percent; net income grew to $457 million from $394 million; revenue rose 9.4 percent, to $2.91 billion from $2.66 billion; Johnson & Johnson posts 15 percent profit gain; net income rose to $909 million from $791 million in year-earlier quarter; revenue grew 5.9 percent, to $5.70 billion from $5.38 billion; tables (L)

headline: Kellogg promotes its family of cereals, even the sugary ones, as components of a healthy diet.
abstract: Kellogg Co, wounded by cereal wars, is returning to its time-honored strategy of promoting healthy claims; extensive print campaign boasts that all Kellogg cereal brands--even Froot Loops--are nutritious staples of healthy life style, not simply convenient breakfast foods; campaign was developed by Leo Burnett USA unit of Leo Burnett Co; photo (L)

headline: Frontline of Norway Makes Offer for ICB
abstract: Frontline Ltd of Norway offers about 3.0 billion Norwegian kroner ($400 million) for ICB Shipping AB; ICB directors reject offer (S)

headline: People
abstract: * Ellen Moran, managing partner at the Omaha office of Bozell Worldwide, part of Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt, was promoted to general manager, succeeding Tim Sickinger, executive vice president and general manager, who retires at the end of the month.    * Bruno Asselin, senior vice president and marketing director at Arnell Group Brand Consulting, New York, was promoted to the new position of president. Arnell Group Brand Consulting is the new name of the agency previously known as Arnell Group.

headline: Bonds Slip As Traders Take Profits
abstract: Four-day rally in Treasury securities ends as investors take profits; 30-year Treasury bond loses 2/32, to price of 99 24/32; yield remains unchanged at 6.39 percent; graph (L)

headline: After Microsoft, Apple Computer plans a second reunion, with an ally from '1984' fame.
abstract: Apple Computer Inc may return its American advertising account, with billings of approximately $80 million to $90 million per year, to TBWA/Chiat Day, which handled it from 1983 until 1986, when it was assigned to BBDO West unit of BBDO Worldwide; photo (Advertising column) (M)

headline: Another Try for Bond Fund Ratings
abstract: National Association of Securities Dealers will decide whether to allow use of bond risk ratings in promotional materials; Standard & Poor's is pushing hard to be allowed to sell its risk ratings to funds that could then use them in advertisements (L)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: SPECIAL DEVICES INC., Newhall, Calif., a maker of airbag initiators, said it was not involved in merger or acquisition talks.    TEXACO INC., White Plains, said it had acquired a 24 percent interest in a project under construction at the Anonima Petroli Italiana refinery in Ancona, Italy. Financial terms were not disclosed.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: CYPRESS FINANCIAL SERVICES INC., Cypress, Calif., a debt recovery company, acquired an accounts receivable portfolio valued at $109 million from an unidentified California financial institution. Terms were not disclosed.    SPORTS CLUB CO., Los Angeles, signed a preliminary agreement to acquire the closely held Gold's Gym Enterprises and related companies for an undisclosed price.    RADISSON HOTEL, Visalia, Calif., a 200-room hotel owned by the City of Visalia, is being sold to American Property Management Inc. of Albuquerque, N.M., for $13.85 million.

headline: Roping Them In, With Pomp and Deep-Fried Alligator
abstract: Boom in growth stocks in which Montgomery Securities specializes is enabling money managers to enjoy celebratory abandon of firm's annual investment conference, San Francisco; Montgomery conferences are noted for unabashed excess; photo (M)/

headline: Building an Internet Free of Barriers
abstract: Article by Vinton G Cerf, senior vice president for Internet architecture and engineering at MCI Communications, discusses need to build seamless global communications; for consumer, seamless global communications represents unimpeded, smooth, clear communications among all points within a network and among all networks; drawing (M)

headline: Nasdaq Index Upstages Dow In Its First Close Above 1,500
abstract: Nasdaq composite index crosses 1,500 level for first time, rising 11.69 points to close at 1,502.62; Dow Jones industrial average rises 35.06 points, to 7,921.82, on New York Stock Exchange trading volume of 500 million shares; table (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: COMMUNITY FIRST BANKSHARES INC.,  Fargo, N.D., agreed to acquire 37 branches in Arizona, Colorado and Utah from Banc One Corp., Columbus, Ohio, for about $38 million.    BRISTOL HOTELS AND RESORTS,  Dallas, agreed to buy the St. Louis Holiday Inn-Westport from Craigshare Hotel Co. for $18 million.    RES-CARE INC.,  Louisville, Ky., a disabilities and training services concern, agreed to acquire Bald Eagle Enterprises Inc., a privately owned provider of services to the developmentally disabled. Terms were not disclosed.    REMEC INC.,  San Diego, agreed to acquire privately held Q-Bit Corp., Palm Bay, Fla., for an undisclosed amount of stock. Both make components used in wireless communications devices and military technology.

headline: Schedule of Treasury Auctions
abstract: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week consists of today's regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and sales of 3-year, 10-year and 30-year securities tomorrow, Wednesday and Thursday.    According to traders, at the close of the New York cash market on Friday the rate on the outstanding three month bill was 5.12 percent and on the six-month issue, 5.16 percent. In when-issued trading the 3-year note was offered at a price to yield 5.98 percent, the 10-year bill at 6.15 percent and the 30-year bond at 6.41.

headline: Delivering the Power to the People Is Just a First Step in South Africa
abstract: Eskom, the state-owned power company, succeeds in bringing electricity to half South Africa's households, up from about a third six years ago, but there is no corresponding rise in power consumption; people are too poor to afford appliances, and also too wedded by habit to coal stoves and other devices that do not use electricity; Eskom concludes that electricity does not improve people's lives by itself, but rather in conjunction with better roads, water, jobs and development in general; now believes that only South Africa's next generation will really embrace convenience of electricity; photo (M)

headline: Adidas to Buy Salomon, a French Sports Company
abstract: Adidas AG plans to buy Salomon SA, French sports equipment maker, in transaction that values Salomon at as much as $1.4 billion, and will create world's second-largest sporting goods company (M)

headline: New York Brokerage Firm To Pay $2 Million Penalty
abstract: GKN Securities Corp and 29 of its brokers agree to pay total of $2.125 million in fines and restitution to settle charges by National Association of Securities Dealers that they overcharged customers on stock trades (M)

headline: Federal Agents Step Up Pressure in Columbia/HCA Investigation
abstract: Federal agents, stepping up pressure on potential witnesses in criminal investigation of Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corp, have been making nighttime visits to homes of some of company employees in Florida, trying to persuade them to cooperate with inquiry and provide evidence to Government; Victor Campbell, spokesman for Columbia, says he is unaware of any visits to executives in Florida (L)

headline: Gas Rises as South Swelters; North's Chill Lifts Heating Oil
abstract: Natural gas prices surge after unseasonably hot weather in southern US bolsters demand; unusually cool weather in Northeast lifts heating-oil prices (M)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Table of interest rates on key Government bonds

headline: Economic Scene; Tobacco might thrive with a $1.50-a-pack rise for cigarettes.
abstract: Economic Scene column on Pres Clinton's demand that price of cigarettes should rise $1.50 a pack to deter teen-age smoking; says close look at Clinton's demand suggests that industry could live--conceivably thrive--with such consequences; holds combination of taxes and penalties built into original tobacco settlement totaled 72 cents a pack; Jeremy I Bulow, economist at Graduate School of Business at Stanford University, comments; drawing (L)

headline: All the Sturm und Drang! It's Not Just Umlauts
abstract: Plan to reform German orthography, eliminating umlaut and simplifying spelling, is caught up in legal dispute over whether its introduction in schools infringes on parental rights; some officials see constitutional challenges, upheld by court in one German state and rejected in another, as sign that new orthography will fail; table (M)

headline: Canadians End Blockade In Salmon-Fishing Dispute
abstract: Canadian fishermen end three-day blockade of Alaskan ferry in British Colombia, which was undertaken to underscore their charge that Alaskan fishermen have taken three to four times as much salmon during current season as they are allowed under 12-year-old treaty; US officials and fishermen deny treaty is being violated; photo; map (M)

headline: Soros Closes Foundation In Belarus
abstract: George Soros, American financier and philanthropist, closes his Belarus Soros Foundation, holding Belarus Government crackdown on foundation is part of broader drive to destroy independent society in nation (M)

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.    MONDAY   None

headline: Lufthansa Says Earnings Nearly Doubled
abstract: Deutsche Lufthansa AG says first-half net income almost doubled to 157 million German marks, or $86.7 million, ahead of October sale of Government's remaining 35.7 percent stake in airline (S)

headline: ASPECT STOCK DROPS 24% ON PROFIT EXPECTATIONS
abstract: Shares of Aspect Telecommunications Corp falls 24 percent after analysts cut their earnings estimates because of worries over lagging growth (S)

headline: Tropics in Europe: A Great Bordeaux?
abstract: Europe is sweltering through unusually warm summer, with air pollution and temperature inversions, that may be related to global warming or El Nino, Pacific Ocean current; photo (M)

headline: ORACLE OFFERS $120 MILLION TO BUY TREASURY SERVICES
abstract: Oracle Corp to acquire Treasury Services Corp for $120 million (S)

headline: INVESTORS OF CHECKERS AND RALLY'S PLAN STOCK SWAP
abstract: Largest investors of Checkers Drive-In Restaurants Inc say they will swap 25 percent in Checkers for 42 percent of Rally's Hamburgers Inc (S)

headline: Satellite Gives Mir One More Close Call
abstract: Russian space station Mir came within 500 to 1,000 yards of colliding with United States military satellite, forcing crew, which is struggling to fix central computer, into Soyuz re-entry capsule to prepare for fast getaway if needed; Mir survived without damage; NASA and Russian space officials brush off encounter as minor incident (M)

headline: Appeals Court Upholds Fine Imposed on Trader for Daiwa
abstract: US Appeals Court upholds Judge Lewis A Kaplan's decision to impose $2 million fine on Toshihide Iguchi, convicted Daiwa Bank Ltd bond trader, in sentence that is made contingent on Iguchi's potential for future earnings based on notoriety of his crime (M)

headline: INSIDE
abstract: INVESTING IT/Page 4/  Avis may try harder, but its initial public offering compares poorly with Hertz's. At the Gate, by Reed Abelson.    MUTUAL FUNDS/Page 8/  Fund managers say lower budget deficits count more than terrorist attacks in gauging Israeli stocks. By Kenneth Gilpin.

headline: WESTERN RESOURCES SELLS STAKE IN TYCO INTERNATIONAL
abstract: Western Resources Inc sells its remaining stake in Tyco International Ltd for $572 milion after Tyco beat out Western Resources in takeover battle for ADT Ltd (S)

headline: Protecting America's shores from those Chinese crawfish.
abstract: Economic Scene column on Louisiana's crawfish growers' anti-dumping suit against their Chinese competitors, which is likely to be decided by US International Trade Commission; holds case illustrates core asymmetry built into America's anti-dumping laws; says such laws put Commerce Department in position of setting and enforcing minimum prices when low-cost producer is not American; adds foreigners are held to different standard; drawing (L)

headline: Hope for Congo's Revolution Dissolves Over Old Tensions
abstract: People of former Zaire who welcomed Laurent Kabila's coup four months ago are disillusioned, as foreign-dominated security forces repeatedly crack down on protesters and new Government offers little sense of direction after 31 years of ruinous dictatorship; Kabila, who led obscure guerrilla movement for three decades, is experiencing jarring apprenticeship in rigors of managing large, complex country; photo; map; rebellions smolder in east, tensions persist between neighborhoring countries that helped Kabila, Government has little money to pay soldiers or civil servants and international lenders are demanding accounting of suspected massacre of tens of thousands of Rwandan Hutu refugees; Government especially lacks disciplined force to create order (M)

headline: PHILLIPS-VAN HEUSEN TO CLOSE 150 OUTLET STORES
abstract: Phillips-Van Heusen Corp says it will take $55 million second-quarter charge to close about 150 retail outlet stores and focus more on its branded apparel business; company will also leave sweater-making business, which accounted for $2 million in losses this year (S)

headline: Mutsamudu Journal; Indian Ocean Island Yearns to Retie Colonial Bond
abstract: Residents of Anjouan, part of island group of Islamic Republic of the Comoros, wish to be French colony again, 22 years after voting for independence; island has unemployment of about 90 percent, and rebels fighting to re-tie colonial knot say Government on capital island of Grand Comorehas failed to give it development money over years; successful effort of rebels in beating back Government invasion to quash anti-independence movement noted; maps; photo (M)

headline: World Court Leaves Fight Over Danube Unresolved
abstract: International Court of Justice in The Hague says Slovakia and Hungary had both broken treaty regarding diversion of Danube River for hydroelectric dam; two countries are ordred by court to negotiate in 'good faith' to insure acheivement of objectives of treaty that was written in 1977, during cold war; at issue is diversion of 80 percent of Danube's flow to generate power at new hydroelectric dam in Slovakian town, which prompted Hungary to withdraw its support for project; map (M)

headline: White House Standing Firm On Deadline for TV Switch
abstract: Clinton Administration has committed itself to firm deadline for completing nation's switch to digital television, after lobbyists for broadcast industry managed to work provisions into Congressional budget bills that would allow it to evade or delay significant provisions of Government's plan (M)

headline: Creditors' Plan Stirs Concern Over Kia
abstract: Kia Group creditors say they will control the proceeds from recent asset sales, raising concern that banks will stop the South Korean company from pumping cash into its ailing business (S)

headline: Second Day of Rioting Leaves 80 Hurt in Ulster
abstract: Roman Catholics continue wave of violence across Northern Ireland over British Governments decision allowing Protestant parade to pass through Catholic area in predomonantly Protestant town of Portadown (S)

headline: Rubin Warns of Asia Trade Backlash
abstract: Clinton Administration officials express concern at meeting of international finance ministers in Hong Kong that US is headed toward revival of huge trade deficits with Asia that could provoke backlash in Congress; Treas Sec Robert E Rubin warns Japan not to attempt to crawl out of recession by boosting exports to US, but Japanese executives concede trend is already under way; say they have little choice since biggest market in Southeast Asia is reeling from currency crisis; sudden revival of trade deficits comes at politically inopportune time for Pres Clinton, who is battling in Congress for renewal of his power to strike new trade accords around world; Japan's surplus with US is expected to exceed $65 billion in 1997, roughly 20 percent over 1996 (M)

headline: Croatians Are Accused of Subverting the Peace Accords
abstract: Confidential report, prepared under supervision Bosnian field office of Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe but disavowed by European peace monitors, accuses Croatian Government of subverting Dayton peace accords by financing and essentially ruling Croatian region of Bosnia, amassing millions of dollars in illicit profits, and helping to hide indicted war criminals; lends strong support to those who contend that peace accord is little more than hollow document that has not been put into practice in most of Bosnia (M)

headline: After a Funeral Befitting a Princess, Diana Will Be Buried at Her Family Home
abstract: Funeral service for Princess Diana of Wales, who died in automobile accident in Paris on August 31, will be held on September 6 in Westminster Abbey, followed by internment at ancestral family home in Althorp, Northamptonshire; she will be buried in private ceremony in country church containing remains of 20 generations of Spencers, spanning 475 years; even though arrangements fall outside strict tradition of royal funerals, spokesman for Buckingham Palace emphasizes ritual will contain usual elements of royal funeral and, in particular, elements to reflect affection with which she was held; funeral will be attended by 2,000 invited guests, and will be televised worldwide; map; photo (M)

headline: Hal Riney Names Creative Executive
abstract: Hal Riney & Partners names John Doyle, longtime art director, as one of its two creative executives; Doyle will become executive vice president and share title of executive creative director with Dave O'Hare; Doyle succeeds Steve Sweitzer, who resigned (S)

headline: Airfield Swallowing Potato Fields, in Tiny Bites
abstract: Handful of farmers have succeeded in blocking completion of New Tokyo International Airport in Narita, Japan, for 32 years by refusing to give up land to Goverment; airport moves one step closer to completion as two families agree to talk with Government about selling and renting their land for use by airport; photos; map (M)

headline: ALLIANCE IMAGING TO BE SOLD FOR $258 MILLION
abstract: Alliance Imaging Inc agrees to be acquired by Apollo Management LP, investment firm headed by Leon Black, for about $258 million in cash, options and assumed debt (S)

headline: British Telecom Profit Meets Expectations
abstract: British Telecommunications PLC says its first-quarter profit rose 5.3 percent, to $981 million (S)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent                Previous   Year          Yesterday   Day   Ago               PRIME RATE   8.50   8.50   8.25        DISCOUNT RATE   5.00   5.00   5.00        FEDERAL FUNDS*   5.50   5.36   5.32        3-MO. TREAS. BILLS   4.90   4.91   5.18        6-MO. TREAS. BILLS   5.04   5.05   5.18        10-YR. TREAS. INFL.**   3.55   3.55   N.A.        10-YR. TREAS. NOTES   6.05   6.08   6.81        30-YR. TREAS. BONDS   6.35   6.37   7.02        TELEPHONE BONDS   7.45   7.49   8.04        MUNICIPAL BONDS***   5.43   5.42   5.95          *Estimated daily average, Dow Jones Markets  **Realized dollar amount rises with inflation  ***Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer  Sources: Salomon Brothers and Dow Jones Markets for Treasury's bellwether bonds, notes and bills

headline: Japan Banks Said to Carry $240 Billion in Bad Loans
abstract: Japanese banks are still struggling to rid themselves of bad loans that have plagued them since collapse of real estate market earlier this decade; Finance Ministry says that banks, savings institutions and agricultural cooperatives are carrying 27.9 trillion yen, or $240 billion, in bad loans, most of them linked to property, as of March; this is down only 4.5 percent from last report, six months ago (S)

headline: A Deal Maker's Dream Deal
abstract: Interview with Travelers Group chairman and chief executive Sanford I Weill on Travelers' acquisition of Salomon Inc; Weill says Salomon deal is culmination of lifelong dream to build 'a great financial services company without parallel'; charts; photos (L)

headline: Struggle Over Sallie Mae Sends Message to Boards
abstract: Article on decision of shareholders of Student Loan Marketing Assn to oust management by electing dissident directors of slate of directors; focuses on some lessons to be learned for other corporate boards who choose not to listen to their shareholders; drawing (L)

headline: The Chandlers' Investment In Times Mirror Will Be Cut
abstract: Chandler family, which founded and controls Times Mirror Company, reaches deal with company that will give family more current income and diversify its investments, at cost of cutting its stake in paper; Times Mirror publishes such newspapers as Los Angeles Times, Newsday, Baltimore Sun and Hartford Courant (S)

headline: A report shows how hard it is to break welfare dependency.
abstract: Peter Passell (Economic Scene) says welfare dependency may not be reduced to new levels demanded by Congress under 1996 welfare-reform legislation, even though combination of strong job market and tougher eligibility rules have trimmed rolls by 800,000 in past two years; examines findings of report by Manpower Demonstration Research Corp on Ohio's experiment in keeping teen-age mothers in school; drawing (M)

headline: Ingersoll-Rand to Buy Westinghouse's Thermo King Unit
abstract: Ingersoll-Rand Co will buy Westinghouse Electric Corp's Thermo King division for $2.56 billion in cash (L)

headline: Texaco Is Buying Monterey Resources
abstract: Texaco Inc, seeking to increase its oil reserves in California, agrees to acquire Monterey Resources Inc, oil assets of former Santa Fe Railroad, in stock transaction valued at $1.12 billion; table (L)

headline: Crackdown Bleeds Kenya's Democracy Movement, Killing 7
abstract: Riot policemen crush pro-democracy rallies across Kenya, killling at least seven people and wounding dozens of others in worst political violence in relatively stable country since 1991; widespread protests are major embarrassment to Pres Daniel arap Moi, authoritarian leader who has ruled for past 19 years and has begrudged every move toward more democratic system; opposition leaders say violence has only hardened resolve to press for more constitutional reforms; map (M)

headline: Computer Intruders Disrupt Microsoft Site
abstract: Twice in last two weeks the Microsoft Corp's World Wide Web site has been attacked by unknown computer network intruders; in most recent instance on June 30, the intruders were able to deny access to site for much of the day; on June 20, company's Web site was disrupted by electronic vandals who found flaw in company's Windows NT operating system (M)m

headline: Colombia's Death-Strewn Democracy
abstract: Over 4,000 leaders and members of Colombia's Patriotic Union, legal left-wing opposition party born during 1985 peace talks between leftist rebels and Colombian Government, have been killed since party was born, and killings have picked up with approach of October municipal elections; targets extend to potential supporters; right-wing death squads wage extermination drive in eastern and northern parts of nation, frequently forcing residents to flee; both right-wing paramilitary units and guerrillas have banned free electioneering in areas they control and both sides have declared candidates 'military targets'; map (M)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent                Previous   Year          Yesterday   Day   Ago               PRIME RATE   8.50   8.50   8.25        DISCOUNT RATE   5.00   5.00   5.00        FEDERAL FUNDS*   5.44   5.62   5.14        3-MO. TREAS. BILLS   4.96   4.97   5.18        6-MO. TREAS. BILLS   5.07   5.07   5.38        10-YR. TREAS. INFL.**   3.69   3.61   N.A.        10-YR. TREAS. NOTES   6.26   6.25   7.01        30-YR. TREAS.
