headline: Stocks Keep Advancing; Dow Up 26.71
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average rises 26.71 points, to new high close of 8,088,36, while Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rises 2.58 points, to record 936.56; Nasdaq composite index rises 3.79 points, to 1,567.65; table (L)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: SERVICE EXPERTS INC., -- Nashville, will acquire 22 heating, ventilating and air-conditioning services companies with combined annual revenue of about $44 million.    BEVERLY ENTERPRISES INC., -- Fort Smith, Ark., said its Beverly Health and Rehabilitation Services unit had agreed to buy seven nursing centers in Washington State from Quad C Health Care Centers, of Tacoma, Wash., for $33 million in cash.

headline: VENTURE STORES IS SELLING STAKES IN 49 STORES TO KIMCO
abstract: Venture Stores Inc sells stakes in 49 stores to Kimco Realty Corp for $135 million; Kimco also gets right to buy 21 more properties in next five years; moves are part of by plan by Venture to transform itself from discount retailer to seller of more profitable items (S)

headline: MIDEAST LEADERS TAKING FIRST STEP TO REVIVING TALKS
abstract: Israeli and Palestininian leaders say they expect meeting with US Sec of State Madeleine K Albright in New York on September 29 to revive stalled peace talks, but caution against expectations that new contacts will lead to resumption of substantive discussions; Israeli Prime Min Benjamin Netanyahu tells Cabinet he has detected first preliminary steps by Palestinian Authority to crack down on Islamic terror groups, which he set as condition for continuing diplomatic process; predicts meeting will lead to resumption of committee talks; says he is releasing additional $17 million of money Government has withheld from Palestinians since suicide bombing in July; will allow 8,000 more Palestinian workers back into Israel; Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat and Palestinian Authority step up offensive against militant Islamic organizations; arrest dozens of Hamas leaders in West Bank and Gaza; close 16 Hamas welfare organizations in Gaza that reportedly gave support to Hamas's military wing responsible for suicide attacks (M)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent                Previous   Year          Yesterday   Day   Ago               PRIME RATE   8.50   8.50   8.25        DISCOUNT RATE   5.00   5.00   5.00        FEDERAL FUNDS*   5.44   5.64   5.22        3-MO. TREAS. BILLS   5.10   5.10   5.03        6-MO. TREAS. BILLS   5.12   5.14   5.13        10-YR. TREAS. INFL.**   3.55   3.54   N.A.        10-YR. TREAS. NOTES   6.35   6.32   6.75        30-YR. TREAS. BONDS   6.65   6.62   6.95        TELEPHONE BONDS   7.72   7.68   7.97        MUNICIPAL BONDS***   5.56   5.53   5.92          *Estimated daily average, Dow Jones Markets  **Realized dollar amount rises with inflation  ***Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer  Sources: Salomon Brothers and Dow Jones Markets for Treasury's bellwether bonds, notes and bills

headline: Man Who Built Gatorade Is Hired To Run Pepsico's Biggest Drink Unit
abstract: Pepsico Inc names Philip A Marineau, former Quaker Oats executive who was praised for success of Gatorade but held responsible for decline of Snapple, to replace Brenda Barnes, who is resigning as president and chief executive of Pepsi-Cola North America, company's largest beverage division; Marineau is resigning as president and chief operating officer of Dean Foods Co (M)

headline: Worldcom Called Ready to Buy Compuserve in $1.2 Billion Deal
abstract: Worldcom Inc is expected to buy Compuserve Corp, H & R Block's faltering on-line service, for nearly $1.2 billion in stock (M)

headline: In Prime Minister's Life, A Parable of His Country
abstract: Interview with Prime Min I K Gujral on India's 50th anniversary; he lauds nation's economic and social progress; cites own rise from penury; photo (M)

headline: PC Industry Calls for a Truce in TV Wars
abstract: Computer makers are losing their war with television industry just 3 months after announcing intention to muscle their way into television business by proposing their own standards for new digital era; computer industry leaders have failed to gain support even from others in personal computer business to build digital television receivers into desktop computers; debate was made possible when Federal Communications Commission set rules for digital television broadcasts on Apr 3, and opted to let market forces decide inter-industry argument over technical formats for digital broadcasts; at heart of dispute is question of how new, digital signals will be displayed on television sets, or computer screens (M)

headline: Clinton Warns Europeans of Trade Complaint on Boeing Deal
abstract: President Clinton threatens to go to World Trade Organization if European Union moves against Boeing Company's $14 billion takeover of McDonnell Douglas; he also hints at possible American sanctions against Europeans (M)

headline: MARKET TIMING
abstract: MONDAY  A Federal District Court in Virginia holds a hearing on regulation of tobacco by the Federal Drug Administration.    TUESDAY  The Labor Department reports on productivity in the second quarter, which probably tailed off to just half a percentage point after spurting 2.6 percent in the first quarter.

headline: As Peru's Leader Cracks Down, Opposition Grows
abstract: Opposition to Pres Alberto K Fujimori of Peru grows as Government undertakes repressive campaign to remove all obstacles to insure that he wins unparalleled third term; Government has engineered dismissal of three Supreme Court justices who ruled unconstitutional his efforts to run for re-election, has tapped telephones of prominent citizens and journalists and tried to shut down television station that exposed illegal wiretaps; many observers say Fujimori has lost control of Government to notorious intelligence service and armed forces that have long been foundation of his rule; photo (M)

headline: Despite Taliban Vow, Afghan Opium Production Is Up, U.N. Says
abstract: United Nations International Drug Control Program reports opium production in Afghanistan jumped by 25 percent over past year, with almost all of increase in Taliban-controlled areas, despite pledge by ruling Islamic fundamentalist organization to crack down on poppy cultivation (M)

headline: The Limited May Sell Off Subsidiaries
abstract: Limited Inc is quietly configuring itself in ways that could well include sale or spinoff of some of its core units; Limited has been under pressure from investors for several years to overhaul its women's apparel divisions--the Limited, Express, Lane Bryant and Lerner New York (Market Place column) (L)

headline: Stocks Mostly Fall, Though Dow Is Up
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average ends up 16.26 at 7,906.72; Nasdaq composite index falls 11.76, to 1,536.23, while Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks falls 2.36 points, to 912.94; table (M)

headline: DANAHER MAKES HOSTILE OFFER FOR EXIDE ELECTRONICS
abstract: Danaher Corp announces hostile takeover offer for Exide Electronics Group Inc worth $20 a share, or $200 million (S)

headline: Big Wall St. Banks Gallop In, Guns Ablaze
abstract: Wall Street investment banks are at epicenter of restructuring boom sweeping corporate Europe; advised companies in two-thirds or record $400.6 billion of European mergers and acquisitions in 1996; are cold-calling prospective clients, almost unheard-of tactic in European finance, luring top talent from European banks and introducing hostile takeovers; Europe's biggest banks are beginning to fight back with same tools used by Wall Street banks; graphs; drawing; photo (L)

headline: High Yield and Big Risk With Catastrophe Bonds
abstract: Wall Street investment bankers have come up with new instrument: catastrophe bonds, which lose their value if big natural disaster hits particular area but can also return huge dividends if investor is correct; catastrophe bonds pay three or four percentage points more than comparably rated corporate bonds, but unlike situation with most other bonds, their entire principal can be forfeited to pay insurance claims if hurricane or earthquake hits; recent $3 million investment in catastrophe bonds by Steven Goldstein, who has been handicapping insurance risk for years as executive of New Jersey reinsurance firm, discussed; other recent investment in such bonds also noted; photos; chart details returns or losses to investors (L)

headline: Unrelenting Contraband In Nigeria: Animals
abstract: Undercover probe by World Society for Protection of Animals aide Mike Pugh finds endangered animals readily available for illegal export, Kano, Nigeria; finds Nigerian aides issue export permits in exchange for 'gifts;' map (M)

headline: Dollar Rises Again vs. Mark On Bundesbank Rate Decision
abstract: US dollar rises against German mark for second consecutive day after Bundesbank, Germany's central bank, leaves interest rates unchanged; dollar also benefits from strong recovery in US stocks (M)

headline: EUROTUNNEL SHAREHOLDERS APPROVE BANKRUPTCY PLAN
abstract: Shareholders of Eurotunnel approve $14 billion debt reorganization that concedes almost half the company's capital to creditor banks in key step in averting bankruptcy (S)

headline: For Tuscans, How Can You Copyright Paradise?
abstract: Italy's Tuscany region, known for beautiful landscapes, seeks to develop own 'made in Tuscany' trademark to deter use of Tuscan images in advertising for foreign products; photos (M)

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.    MONDAY   None     TUESDAY   Retail Sales June

headline: Catering to Adults Only Is Becoming Bigger Plus
abstract: Discount shops that sell little but cigarettes are rapidly opening in urban and suburban areas; such outlets now account for 11 percent of cigarette sales, up from about 1 percent in 1992; outlets divert sales from stores frequented by children, but undercut plans to use price increases to discourage smoking; graph; photos (M)

headline: Raisio to Build Plant in Carolina
abstract: Raision Tehtaat Oy AB, unit of Raisio Group and maker of cholesterol-cutting margarine Benecol, has agreed to build sterol plant in South Carolina with Westvaco Corp; sterol is substance extracted from pine wood production and is also key ingredient of Benecol, for which Raisio agreed last month to give exclusive US rights to McNeil Consumer Products, a Johnson & Johnson unit (S)

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: Debt    * California Health Facilities Financing Authority is selling $106.5 million of tax-exempt insured revenue bonds through Goldman, Sachs & Co. The bonds are priced to yield a maximum of 5.48 percent for an issue due in 2027 and 5.38 percent for an issue due in 2017. For the short-maturity serial bonds, the yields range from 3.90 percent in 1999 to 5.10 percent in 2012. The bonds are rated triple-A by Moody's Investors Service and Standard & Poor's.

headline: Team Effort Aimed At P.& G. Duties
abstract: Televest and Wells BDDP, advertising agencies that work for Procter & Gamble Co, have taken unusual step of teaming up to compete for company's consolidated television media assignment, with combined billings estimated at as much as $1.2 billion (S)

headline: For Stock Mutual Funds in '97, A Great Year in Just 7 Months
abstract: Mutual fund investors, seven months into 1997, have already made year second best ever for stock funds; bond funds have also recorded their best year since 1993 (Market Place) (M)

headline: Nickelodeon, the children's cable network, wins viewers, but loses out on ad rates.
abstract: Cable network Nickelodeon has posted higher national average Nielsen rating among children over last year than any other network--even though, as a cable network, Nickelodeon reaches only about 70 million of nation's 98 million homes with television; broadcast networks are still able to charge considerably more for each commercial than Nickelodeon charges; drawing (L)

headline: Ailing Kia of South Korea Plans To Cut Assets, Jobs and Units
abstract: Financially troubled Kia Group of South Korea proposes to shed $6.4 billion in assets, reduce number of its subsidiaries by 80 percent and cut 8,800 job, or nearly 20 percent of its labor force (S)

headline: Lacks Nuclear Proof, North Korean Says
abstract: Hwang Jang Yop, highest ranked North Korean defector, concedes at news conference in Tokyo that he does not have proof that North Korea has nuclear weapons (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: LIPOSOME CO., Princeton, N.J., a pharmaceuticals company, said it would dismiss 137 employees, or 35 percent of its work force.    CONAGRA INC., Omaha, agreed to buy a 51.4 percent stake in ITC Agro-Tech Ltd., a unit of ITC Ltd. of India, for about $26.25 million.    GEOSCIENCE CORP., Houston, a maker of seismic data instruments, agreed to sell its geological software business to Paradigm Geophysical Ltd., a closely held oil exploration technology company, for $19.5 million to $23 million in cash and royalties.

headline: Correction
abstract: Correction of Sept 21 article on state plans for saving for college tuitionc

headline: In Rescuing a Relative, a Helping or a Heavy Hand?
abstract: Marshall Berman letter on Roy Furchgott's Aug 10 article on his effort to take control of finances of and provide care for aged great-uncle, Joseph Nathan Rosolio, who resisted his help (S)

headline: Hyundai Motor Reports 45% Drop in Profits
abstract: Hyundai Motor Co says first-half net profit fell 45 percent; company earned 28.2 billion won ($31.5 million), or 581 won as share, down from 1,150 won a year earlier; sales fell 2.8 percent, to 5.4 trillion won (S)

headline: Cambodia Gets a New Leader, but Hun Sen Still Has the Power
abstract: Cambodia names Min Ung Huot to replace Prince Ranariddh as First Prime Minister in first step toward satisfying international demands for restoration of at least forms of democratic government; coup leader, Second Prime Min Hun Sen, retains power; appointment signifies acquiesence of remnants of Prince's royalist party to coup; Ung Huot says elections will be held next May (M)

headline: Blunt Words By Albright To Players In Mideast
abstract: Excerpts from Secretary of State Madeleine K Albright's address on Middle East policy delivered Aug 6 at National Press Club (M)

headline: The Conservative as Techno-Libertarian
abstract: George Gilder holds telecommunications revolution fueled by explosion of telecommunications bandwidth and rise of Sun Microsystems' Java software programming languange will shake business world, Telecosm conference, Rancho Mirage, Calif; warns technology giants like Microsoft Corp chairman Bill Gates and Government bureaucrats like departing Federal Communications Corp Chmn Reed E Hundt seek to stifle revolution; Steve Forbes co-sponsors event; photo (M)

headline: Prodigy Splitting Itself Into 3 Business Units
abstract: Prodigy Inc is splitting itself into three units to focus separately on its on-line service, international market and software development and licensing; Paul DeLacey, who has been president and chief executive of Prodigy, will become adviser to chairman Greg Carr and remain board member; Russ Pillar is named president and chief executive of Prodigy Internet unit; Inder Gopal is named president and general manager of Prodigy Solutions, unit devoted to developing software and services; Paul Tucker is named president and general manager of Prodigy International (S)

headline: MORE ON THE DEATHS
abstract: List of stories on death of Princess Diana and others in Paris car crash (S)

headline: To Argentines, Judges Are Often Biggest Lawbreakers
abstract: Article on growing public distrust with Argentina's corrupt public justice system, in which judges are often biggest lawbreakers; recent corruption scandals involving justice ministers and pending impeachment trial of prominent judge, Hernan Bernasconi, discussed; photos (M)

headline: Clinton and NATO Chiefs Now Face the Legislatures
abstract: Pres Clinton and other NATO leaders, ending Madrid summit conference, begin battle to win legislative approval for decision to invite Poland, Hungary and Czech Republic to join alliance by 1999; Clinton holds some in United States grossly overestimate cost of enlargement; notes new members will have to assume most of cost; Pres Jacques Chirac says France will not raise its NATO contribution to pay for enlargement; Clinton backs Bosnian Serb President, Biljana Plavsic, in her struggle with predecessor, Radovan Karadzic, indicted war criminal; Gen George M Joulwan, NATO commander, denies peacekeepers deliberately avoid arresting indicted war criminals; NATO leaders sign cooperation accord with Ukraine; photo (M)

headline: U.S. Envoy Sees Role in Cambodia for Asian Foreign Ministers
abstract: US special envoy Stephen J Solarz reportedly has found Cambodian leader Hun Sen willing to allow foreign ministers of Assocation of Southeast Asian Nations countries some role in seeking solution to Cambodia's political crisis (MS)

headline: INSIDE
abstract: List of major stories in Business section y

headline: EARTHGRAINS AGREES TO THE PURCHASE OF COOPERSMITH
abstract: Earthgrains Co agrees to buy wholesale Coopersmith Inc as it seeks to increase earnings by adding more brands and cutting distribution costs (S)

headline: 100 Years Ago, a Dream of Israel: Celebration Caught in Crosswinds
abstract: Recent disputes over money from Nazis and Holocaust victims stored in Swiss banks looms over conference in Basel to mark 100th anniversary of Zionism; hate mail sent to Swiss Jewish Federation vice pres Thomas Lyssy reflects deterioration in Switzerland's relationship with Jews and Israel since Swiss handling of money became issue; photo (M)

headline: WESTERN RESOURCES IN DEAL FOR 80% OF PROTECTION ONE
abstract: Western Resources Inc will exchange $320 million and its own security operations for 80.1 percent of Protection One Inc (S)

headline: Campbell Soup Chief Says He Will Retire
abstract: David W Johnson announces his retirement as chief executive of Campbell Soup Co; he will be replaced on July 15 by Dale F Morrison; Johnson will stay on as Campbell's chairman until July 31, 1998; senior vice presidents Robert F Bernstock and Basil L Anderson are promoted to executive vice presidents; graph; photo (L)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Philippines to Get Emergency I.M.F. Loan  In an important test of new methods to cope with instability in world financial markets, the International Monetary Fund has for the first time used emergency procedures set up after the Mexican financial crisis to arrange an urgent loan of $1 billion to the Philippines.    The move was an unusual response to the pressure placed on some other Southeast Asian economies since Thailand was forced on July 2 to devalue its currency. $(Page A1.$)

headline: Taiwan Plans to Drop a Fig Leaf; China May Grumble
abstract: Pres Lee Teng-Hui and his Government seem to be moving toward goal of establishing Taiwan as separate nation, not as Chinese territory; ruling party and main pro-independence opposition party join behind plan that would change Constitution to scrap Taiwan provincial government, one of last vestiges of old arrangement under which Taiwan was considered part of China (M)

headline: Dollar Is Off as German Bank Reinforces Its Mark Defenses
abstract: US dollar falls against German mark after German central bank modifies its practice on key money-market rate, giving itself more flexibility to defend lagging currency (M)

headline: H. Upmann is moving to emerge a winner as the premium cigar industry enters a shakeout period.
abstract: H Upmann, Consolidated Cigar Corp's flagship premium cigar, is beginning multi-million-dollar ad campaign intended to make sure it emerges as a winner as white-hot premium cigar industry enters a shakeout period; Marvin Shanken, publisher of Cigar Aficionado magazine, says premium cigar business has almost tripled in last four years; Consolidated Cigar's campaign is by Leibler-Bronfman Lubalin (L)

headline: The style of on-line services may come to matter more than their substance.
abstract: Edward Rothstein Technology column speculates about future of on-line services in wake of news that Compuserve is going to be absorbed by its once rival, America Online; drawing (M)

headline: Data Showing Slower Growth Helps Treasury Bonds to Rally
abstract: US Treasury bonds rally as Federal Reserve enters market as buyer and revises figure for gross domestic product in second quarter showed economy growing at slower pace than previously reported; 30-year bond gains 13/32, to 100 5/32; yield drops to 6.36 percent from 6.39 percent on Sept 25 (M)

headline: For a Choreographer, a Chance to Leap Out of Debt
abstract: Article in periodic series on crossroads of personal finance focuses on choreographer Elizabeth Streb, who won $290,000 MacArthur Foundation grant; Streb wants to use part of grant to make dance more accessible; photo (M)

headline: Stocks Roar Into September, With the Dow Surging 257.36
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average rises 257.36 points, or 3.38 percent, to 7,879.78--its largest single-day point gain ever and its biggest percentage rise in nearly six years; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index surges 28.11 points, or 3.13 percent, to close at 927.58; Nasdaq composite index gains 30.77 points, or 1.94 percent, to 1,618.09; graph (L)

headline: Power Broker for the 'Have Mouse, Will Travel' Set
abstract: Article on Bo Rinaldi, executive vice president of Trattner Network, who is one of Silicon Valley's hidden power brokers; says Rinaldi's ascendance is testimony to fundamental shift in the way software is written--and to rising status of people who write it; holds Rinaldi rents out freelance programmers--whether to large companies desperate for software they cannot build themselves or to start-up firms eager for smart people to turn concepts into computer code; says programmers from Rinaldi's stable have helped create dozens of products, including Acrobat from Adobe Systems and Fusion from Netobject, leading software used to build Web sites; photos (L)

headline: Honors
abstract: * Mark Bilfield was named the 1997-98 president of the Western States Advertising Agencies Association, Los Angeles, succeeding Diane Krouse. Mr. Bilfield is a senior partner and group account director at the Venice, Calif., office of TBWA Chiat/ Day, a unit of Omnicom Group, and managing partner of the Persuasion Group unit of TBWA Chiat/Day.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: Sybase Inc names chief exec Mitchell E Kertzman to additional post of chmn (S)

headline: 3 BOMBERS IN SUICIDE ATTACK KILL 4 ON JERUSALEM STREET IN ANOTHER BLOW TO PEACE
abstract: Three suicide bombers evidently acting in concert set off bombs on Ben Yehuda Street, busy shopping promenade in Jerusalem, killing four passers-by and themselves and dealing brutal new blow to the reeling Israeli-Palestinian peace efforts; eight people are severely wounded and about 180 others also hurt; photos; map; chart showing number of Israelis killed in terror attack on civilians in recent years; Pres Clinton says Sec Madeleine Albright will proceed with planned visit to region; in latest attack, bombers reportedly dressed as women in attack similar to even deadlier one five week ago; Hamas group claims responsiblity; Prime Min Benjamin Netanyahu says attack proves that root problem in peace deadlock is Yasir Arafat's failure to combat terrorism; points to Arafat's recent public hugging and kissing of militants; Israeli military restores all curbs on Palestinians that were being loosened following earlier bombing; bombs, packed with nails, nuts and bolts, are set off in heart of modern Jerusalem, in area crowded with Israelis and tourists; dead are two young women, 12-year-old girl and a man (M)

headline: U.S. AND RUSSIANS AGREE TO PUT OFF DEADLINE ON ARMS
abstract: US signs package of arms control agreements intended to break logjam that has stalled ratification of Start 2 in Russia, and among them are an agreement giving Russia another five years--until end of 1997--to dismantle launching systems; launching systems must still be disabled by 2003, and Clinton Administration say new agreements, which include Kazakstan, Belarus and Ukraine as well as Russia, will clear the way for new talks to negotiate further cuts in nuclear weapons in Russia and US; another accord modifies Anti-Ballistic Missile Treaty of 1972, reaffirming prohibition on longer-range defensive weapons and barring US from testing or deploying any spaced-based missile defense system but providing new flexibility for development of shorter-range systems intended to replace weapons like Patriot missiles used in Persian Gulf war; graph (M)

headline: PROFESSIONALS INSURANCE ADDING PHYSICIANS PROTECTIVE
abstract: Professionals Insurance Co Management Group agrees to acquire Physicians Protective Trust Fund of Coral Gables, Fla, for up to $133.3 million in stock (S)

headline: Executive Changes
abstract: KRAFT FOODS, Northfield, Ill., a unit of the Philip Morris Cos., plans to combine its former Maxwell House and Post divisions. The company said the combined coffee and cereals division would be headed by Ann M. Fudge, as executive vice president of Kraft Foods and president of the division. In addition, the company is combining its beverage and dessert divisions. James R. Craigie, 43, general manager of the beverage division, was named executive vice president of Kraft Foods and president of the combined division.

headline: Trend Sweeps London, Paris, New York: Modern, Male, Made-to-Measure: The Great Custom Tailor Revival
abstract: PARIS  On the high end of menswear, one-of-a-kind is where it's at. Not since the 1970s, when rock 'n' roll hit London's Savile Row, have custom and made-to-measure tailoring been such hot fashion commodities.

headline: 2 Targets Reject Bids By French Retail Giant
abstract: Boards of French retailers Casino SA and Rallye SA reject unsolicited offers that were made by Promodes SA; Casino was offered 19.1 billion French francs, or $3.13 billion, and bid for Rallye, which owns third of Casino's shares, was 8.7 billion francs, or $1.43 billion (S)

headline: In computer chip making as in sports, there are times when it's essentially a matter of execution.
abstract: Market Place column on sharply contrasting outlooks for computer chip companies Advanced Micro Devices Inc and National Semiconductor Corp; Advanced Micro Devices shares fell more than 9 percent after company announced it expected a third-quarter loss while National Semiconductor Corp shares gained a similar amount after reporting earnings that exceeded earlier estimates; National Semiconductor reported earnings of $70.1 million in quarter ended Aug 24, compared with loss of $207.6 million in year-earlier quarter; sales rose 6 percent, to $600.8 million from $566.1 million in first quarter of fiscal 1997; table (L)

headline: Treasuries Gain Amid Stock Turmoil
abstract: US Treasury prices rise, amid continued turmoil in stock market; price of 30-year bond increases 10/32, to 98 5/32; yield falls to 6.52 percent from 6.54 percent on Aug 15; graph (L)

headline: FOUNDATION HEALTH SYSTEMS EXPECTS 2D-QUARTER LOSS
abstract: Foundation Health Systems Inc says that it will have second-quarter loss after taking pre-tax charges of $405.9 million, more than expected, to cover costs from April merger that formed company (S)

headline: Mexican Snubs Visiting Head Of Rights Unit
abstract: Mexican Government snubs Amnesty International head Pierre Sane, in Mexico to probe reports of growing human rights abuses; Pres Ernesto Zedillo and other top officials refuse to meet with him (S)

headline: Boeing Concession Averts Trade War With Europe
abstract: Boeing Co wins approval European Commission approval for merger with McDonnell Douglas Corp, averting trade war between European Union and United States; agrees not to enforce exclusive-supplier provisions of pacts with three United States airlines; dispute involved major display of power by European Competition Minister, Karel van Miert, and clear sign that European leaders seek to impose their will on global companies regardless of territorial boundaries; experts say increasing economic globalization makes more such disputes inevitable; graphs (M)

headline: YOUTH SERVICES INTERNATIONAL TO SELL BEHAVIORAL UNIT
abstract: Youth Services International Inc will sell its behavioral services business to Youth and Family Centered Services Inc for $21.7 million (S)

headline: Pedro de Castro Van Dunem, 55; Ex-Angolan Foreign Minister
abstract: Pedro de Castro Van Dunem, former Angolan Foreign Minister, dies at age 55 (S)

headline: First Union Paying $471 Million For Wheat First Brokerage Firm
abstract: First Union Corp, huge Charlotte, NC, banking company, agrees to buy Wheat First Butcher Singer, a brokerage firm in Richmond, for $471 million in stock; Wheat First will be sixth brokerage firm bought by a bank since Federal Reserve broadened powers of banks to underwrite stock and bond offerings at end of last year (L)

headline: With a Living Trust, You Don't Need a Mop
abstract: Adrian Havill article on benefits of revocable living trusts in estate planning; living trusts avoid expensive and time-consuming probate process, while assuring privacy; drawing (M)

headline: A Day in Court for Israeli Who Enraged Muslims
abstract: Article profiles Tatania Susskind, who is being tried by Israeli Government for inciting violence by hanging posters in Hebron that depicted Mohammed as pig; 25-year-old member of Kach movement who emigrated from Russia five years ago is member of select group of loners, driven to hatred and violence by sense that Israel is surrendering to conniving Arab foe; photo (M)

headline: Economic Scene; Some say no to a high-powered drive to revamp patent law.
abstract: Peter Passell Economic Scene article on economist Franco Modigliani's opposition to bid by Clinton Administration and some Congressional leaders to revise patent law; bill, sponsored by Sen Orrin Hatch, would require all patent applications to be disclosed publicly within 18 months rather than when patent is issued, allow challenges to patents under relatively informal administrative procedures, grant limited 'prior use' rights to companies that developed technology independently but failed to seek patent and make Patent and Trademark Office independent Government corporation; drawing (M)

headline: PRICE MUTUAL FUND ACQUIRES A 5.6% STAKE IN PENNZOIL
abstract: Franklin Mutual Advisers, mutual fund run by Michael Price, has taken 5.6 percent stake in Pennzoil Co, making Franklin Mutual the company's second-largest shareholder; Franklin criticized Pennzoil for opposing hostile takeover bid by Union Pacific Resources Group (S)

headline: Sun Microsystems Rejects Suggestions It Give Up Java
abstract: Sun Microsystems Inc lashes out at Microsoft Corp, saying that it will not give up its ownership of Java computer language, as Microsoft and other companies have recently suggested, in order to have it officially certified as international standard; Alan Baratz, president of Sun Microsystem's Javasoft division, contends Microsoft is trying to cripple Java because it is threat to popularity of Microsoft's Windows software (L)

headline: Equity Funds Gallop Past a Big Benchmark
abstract: For first time in many quarters, well over three-fourths of all domestic stock funds are beating Standard & Poor's 500-stock index; so far this quarter, nearly 82 percent of US equity funds are posting better returns than S & P benchmark; only 10.6 percent did so in first quarter, which was one of worst in recent years for actively managed funds; graph (L)a

headline: Yuri Nikulin Is Dead at 75; Beloved Russian Master Comic
abstract: Yuri Nikulin, master comic and one of Russia's most loved actors, dies at age 75; photo (L)

headline: Weak Results Are Reported By News Corp.
abstract: News Corp says full-year results indicated that company lost $238 million in its fourth-quarter, compared with profit of $190 million in quarter a year earlier; profit from operations fell to $142 million from $250 million a year earlier; company says it will buy back as much as $1 billion of its preferred limited-voting ordinary shares (M)

headline: Cray Said to Have Lost Sale Because Offer Was Inferior
abstract: William Buzbee, computing director of National Center for Atmospheric Research, says center decided last year to buy Japanese supercomputers because American manufacturer, Cray Research Inc, could not deliver machines that were fast enough; that decision led Cray, unit of Silicon Graphics Inc, to file complaint that Japanese companies were dumping supercomputers, or selling them below cost, in US; last week, Commerce Department, acting on that case, proposed tough anti-dumping duties against NEC Corp, company that won center's contract, and against other Japanese supercomputer makers; Buzbee, in terse statement before International Trade Commission, says Cray Research lost bidding because it could not show researchers a testable, working machine that met center's performance requirements (L)

headline: 2 Licensed to Offer Dow Jones Contracts
abstract: Dow Jones & Co has licensed Bankers Trust New York Corp and Merrill Lynch & Co to offer financial contracts that will enable investors to make bets on direction of Dow Jones industrial average (S)

headline: E-mail's personal impact makes it a fertile medium for perpetrating hoaxes.
abstract: E-mail has become uniquely fertile medium for transmitting hoaxes and spoofs; as result, E-mail users find they must be increasingly skeptical of messages received electronically; if enough people start to distrust what appears in their E-mail, many of them can be expected to stop using medium altogether (M)

headline: Bessemer Trust and LJH Plan New Hedge Venture
abstract: Bessemer Trust Co will set up Fifth Avenue Alternative Investments LLC in joint venture with LJH Alternative Investment Advisers Inc; venture plans to develop several funds that are themselves blends of different hedge funds (S)

headline: Head of U S West's Cable Unit Resigns Abruptly
abstract: Continental Cablevision founder and chief executive Amos B Hostetter resigns abruptly after US West, which acquired company in 1996, announces plans to move headquarters to Denver from Boston; his top deputy, William T Schleyer, also refuses to make move and will relinquish post; will advise US West as consultant (M)

headline: Colombia Chief Offers Pullback Of His Troops In Bid to Rebels
abstract: Pres Ernesto Samper of Colombia, faced with growing violence from leftist guerrillas who vow to block municipal elections in areas they control, offers to withdraw troops from part of country to lay groundwork for peace talks; maps (M)

headline: U.S. to Give North Koreans Surplus Grain
abstract: US agrees to donate $27 million worth of surplus grain to help North Korea cope with severe food shortages, two weeks after country agreed to join peace talks (S)

headline: A New Leader Outlines His Vision for Hong Kong
abstract: Tung Chee-hwa, Hong Kong's new chief executive, outlines in detail how he plans to lead what has become special autonomous zone of China; Tung lays out vision of Government far more involved in people's lives than old colonial administration; his governmental activism suggests new direction for Hong Kong, one more akin to Singapore, which he says he admires; Tung's address comes on first day of Chinese rule; police allow demonstration by Hong Kong Alliance, group that China has branded subversive, in what may be first test of China's pledge that Hong Kong will be allowed its own distinct form of government; photos (M)

headline: Stream of Grief and Flowers Still Flows
abstract: Hundreds of thousands continue paying respects to Princess Diana in London; endless stream of fresh flowers is added to mountains of old ones in parks surrounding palaces, as well as at Harrods, store owned by father of Diana's companion, Emad Mohamed el-Fayed; Buckingham Palace says it has not yet decided what to do with thousands of cards and written tributes attached to flowers; public is demanding that they be turned over to sons, Prince William and Prince Harry, or placed in museum; photo (M)

headline: S.E.C. Accuses 6 of Defrauding A Swiss Bank and Lehman Bros.
abstract: Securities and Exchange Commission accuses six people of masterminding a scheme involving 'leasing' of shares in small companies; commission says they managed to defraud Swiss bank, Bank Leu, of $3 million, and to defraud Lehman Brothers of $6.5 million; six charged are Charles Anthony Ferracone, James L Erickstein, Gary L Moore, James W Farrell, Jill Hall and Guido Bensburg (S)

headline: Solarz to Tackle Cambodia Issues
abstract: Sec of State Madeleine K Albright, in effort to explore resolution to political crisis in Cambodia, asks forme Rep Stephen J Solarz to travel to region as special envoy (S)

headline: A Washington Memorial? Barbados Sleeps on It
abstract: Group of preservationists and historians presses to have Bush Hill House in Bridgetown, Barbados, where George Washington lived for two months in 1751, declared national monument; efforts have been set back by national pride, politics and race at time when former British colony is engaged in national campaign to find and celebrate own national heroes; map; photo (M)

headline: LAMAR ADVERTISING TO BUY ASSETS FROM OUTDOOR SYSTEMS
abstract: Outdoor Systems Inc to resell to Lamar Advertising $115 million of advertising assets it is acquiring as part of $1 billion acquisition of Minnesota Mining & Manufacturing Co's National Advertising unit (S)

headline: Travel Pain, Stock Gain
abstract: Share prices of airline companies end week higher after carriers reinstate fare increases; diversified stock funds that hold largest concentrations of biggest airline companies are expected to do well this year; chart (M)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent                Previous   Year          Yesterday   Day   Ago               PRIME RATE   8.50   8.50   8.25        DISCOUNT RATE   5.00   5.00   5.00        FEDERAL FUNDS*   5.75   5.52   6.75        3-MO. headline: Malaysia Takes Steps To Strengthen Economy
abstract: Malaysia, in bid to shore up property market and curb widening trade gap, will end its levy on foreigners' purchases of property and will disclose 'tough measures' to cut imports; Malaysia is attempting to reduce widening current-account deficit, which puts pressure on the currency (S)

headline: Executive Changes
abstract: COLGATE-PALMOLIVE CO., New York, named John Reid its chief technological officer, succeeding the late Craig Tate. Mr. Reid had been vice president of the South Pacific region, which included the Colgate businesses in Australia, New Zealand, Fiji and Papua, New Guinea.

headline: Selling A Home? Try Bach
abstract: Janet Ruth Falon comment offers advice on selling one's home; suggests making house appealing by playing good music and baking something, although not brussel sprouts (S)

headline: Top Trafficker May Be Dead, Mexicans Say
abstract: Relatives of Amado Carrillo Fuentes, 41, Mexico's most powerful drug trafficker, reportedly announce his death; officials visit ranch where his mother lives, but fail to find body (M)

headline: All the Sights of the City Just a Mouse Click Away
abstract: Helsinki Arena 2000, which is scheduled to begin service in less than three years, is interactive guide to entire city, with its streets, shops, Government offices, companies and landmarks meticulously reproduced and connected, interactively and audio-visually by way of Internet; city telecommunications engineers, company chief executives and dreamers who put project together are confident that Helsinki Arena 2000 will give one million residents of Finnish capital new concept of bringing people together; photo (M)

headline: Writings by Iran's New President Due to Be Published in U.S.
abstract: Research centers at State University of New York at Binghamton and at Brigham Young University to co-publish first English-language translation of writings and speeches by Mohammed Khatami, Iran's new president; Iranian-born scholars organized venture to spur better United States relations with Iran; Khatami's works warn against confronting West through violence or military struggle (M)

headline: Waste Management Hires Sprint President
abstract: Ronald T LeMay, president and chief operating officer of Sprint Corp, is named chairman, president and chief executive of Waste Management Inc (M)

headline: Coffee Prices at 6-Week High As Shipment Delays Are Seen
abstract: Coffee prices rise to six-week high on fears that Central American and Colombian harvests will not arrive soon enough to replenish low supplies; coffee for September delivery gains 8.25 cents, NY Coffee, Sugar and Cotton Exchange, to $2.02 a pound (M)

headline: Obstacle to Unifying Bosnia: Politicians Who Have Their Hands in the Till
abstract: Western diplomats say political leaders of Bosnia's three mini-states are making millions of dollars for selves and their parties from smuggling and skimming own treasuries; say gains pose strong obstacle to unification; map; photo (M)

headline: Top Executives at Yamaichi to Step Down
abstract: Yamaichi Securities Co is third large Japanese financial company to force its top board members to resign because of accusations they had paid off Ryuichi Koike, admitted racketeer, in widening payoff scandal; Yamaichi says its 11 directors, including chairman, Tsugio Yukihira, and president, Atsui Miki, will step down (S)

headline: G.E. to Sell Back Shares to Broker
abstract: General Electric Co's Capital Services unit will sell six million Paine Webber Group Inc shares back to brokerage firm for $219 million (S)

headline: DLB OIL AND GAS PLANS TO SELL ASSETS TO PAY DOWN DEBT
abstract: DLB Oil and Gas Inc hires Lehman Brothers Inc to help sell some or all of its assets so it can pay down some of its $80 million debt and pursue new acquisitions (S)

headline: ITT in Deal to Sell Half of Desert Inn Casino
abstract: ITT Corp, seeking to thwart hostile takeover bid from Hilton Hotels Corp, agrees to sell half of its Desert Inn casino, Las Vegas, and some adjoining land to Marvin Davis for $150 million in cash and proceeds of $100 million debt offering; ITT to use cash to help finance previously announced $2.1 billion share buyback (S)

headline: MARKETS TIMING
abstract: List of upcoming events affecting financial world

headline: GATX WILL BUY SOME PITNEY BOWES ASSETS
abstract: Pitney Bowes Inc will sell some of assets it leases to other companies to GATX Corp for $460 million in cash as part of company's plan to raise $1 billion to buy back shares (S)

headline: Vote Results In Mexico Confirm Gains By Opposition
abstract: Official results confirm that opposition parties won major share of power in Mexican national elections, bringing new pluralism to country that had been one-party state; Institutional Revolutionary Party (PRI) will have 239 seats in 500-seat lower House of Congress, Party of Democratic Revolution 125, and National Action Party approximately 122; PRI will continue to dominate Senate, but no longer has power to approve any significant legislation without forging alliances with opposition lawmakers (M)

headline: France Telecom Reports 41% Increase in Profits
abstract: France Telecom SA reports net income rose 41 percent, Jan-June, to 8.9 billion francs ($1.45 billion), largely because of gain from asset sale; will begin selling 20 percent stake to public Sept 23 (S)

headline: To American Peacekeepers in Bosnia, Danger Is Just Beginning
abstract: American peacekeeping forces in Bosnia acknowledge that upcoming weeks could be most dangerous and difficult of their six-month deployment; have borne brunt of decision made in Washington to isolate Bosnian Serb leader Radovan Karadzic and promote his rival, Bosnian Serb Pres Biljana Plavsic; map; photo (M)

headline: Small Group Sees Baseball Game Broadcast on High-Definition TV
abstract: Harris Corp, leading manufacturer of professional television equipment, offers first live broadcast of major league baseball game in digital, high-definition television, hoping to stir excitement about new technology; about 300 invited guests see game between Baltimore Orioles and Cleveland Indians at National Press Club which is done up to look like Camden Yards, stadium in Baltimore where game is played (M)

headline: Heat Wave Lifts Corn and Soybean Prices
abstract: Corn and soybean futures prices rise on concerns that dry, hot weather could damage crops (S)

headline: Retirement Complexes Sold
abstract: Marriott International agrees to sell seven Brighton Gardens retirement complexes to Prime Care Two LLC for about $95 million; two of communities are in Winston-Salem and Raleigh, NC, are in operation; others are under construction (S)

headline: Accounts
abstract: * U.S. Air Force Reserve Command, Warner Robins, Ga., to TMP Worldwide , New York, to handle recruitment advertising, which had been handled by HMS Partners, Columbus, Ohio.

headline: Adieu to the Windsors: Love Story of Century Goes on the Block
abstract: PARIS  In yet another drama for the British royal family, a new everything-must-go sale is coming up this fall.

headline: A Settlement With P.L.O. Over Terror On a Cruise
abstract: Palestine Liberation Organization, nearly 12 years after Palestinian terrorists killed disabled passenger, Leon Klinghoffer, aboard hijacked Italian cruise ship Achille Lauro and threw body into Mediterranean Sea, agrees to settle lawsuit by Klinghofer family for undisclosed sum; settlement comes weeks before scheduled trial; both sides describe settlement as amicable, but PLO says it admitted no wrongdoing, continuing to maintain that attack was carried out by renegades acting without knowledge or backing of organization; photo (M)

headline: INVESTMENT FIRM SAID TO BE IN TALKS WITH LONDON GLOBAL
abstract: Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Inc is in talks to acquire London Global Securities, international securities lending firm, for about 100 million pounds ($160 million) (S)

headline: Offers Disclosed In Pennzoil Bid
abstract: Union Pacific Resources Group Inc discloses in filings with Securities and Exchange Commission that it has received offers from third parties that would be interested in acquiring certain assets of Pennzoil Co or participating in joint ventures if Union Pacific's tender offer Pennzoil is successful (S)

headline: Joe Camel, a Giant in Tobacco Marketing, Is Dead at 23
abstract: Joe Camel, cartoon character that became focus of perhaps most intense attacks ever levied against an American advertising campaign, is being dropped by R J Reynolds Tobacco Co, which will replace it with stylized versions of Camel cigarettes' original camel trademark; photos (L)

headline: 3 Executives of Hospital Chain Charged With Medicare Fraud
abstract: Unsealed indictment, handed down before raid on Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corp offices and hospitals, charges three company executives with defrauding Medicare and other Federal programs by overstating expenses at Fawcett Memorial Hospital, Port Charlotte, Fla; executives, Jay A Jarrell, Michael T Neeb and Robert W Whiteside, also oversaw Federal reimbursements at Columbia's other Florida hospitals; photo (M)

headline: Two executives, known for their creativity, are leaving their agencies for new challenges.
abstract: Stephen O Frankfurt, chairman of Frankfurt Balkind Partners, leaves to join Partners & Shevak; Linda Kaplan Thaler leaves Wells Rich Greene BDDP as creative executive to pursue personal interests in advertising and entertainment (M)

headline: Fishing for a Credit Card Offer That Is Worth Keeping
abstract: Several sites on World Wide Web allow consumers to choose specific features they deem important in credit cards; list of Internet addresses; photo (M)

headline: Class Action May Give Green Light To Anti-Smoking Forces in Europe : British Court Allows Major Tobacco Suit
abstract: BRUSSELS  Britain's High Court gave the go-ahead Friday for the country's first class-action lawsuit by cancer victims against cigarette manufacturers, a move that could unleash a wave of American-style litigation against European tobacco companies.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent                Previous   Year          Yesterday   Day   Ago               PRIME RATE   8.50   8.50   8.25        DISCOUNT RATE   5.00   5.00   5.00        FEDERAL FUNDS*   5.38   5.49   5.22        3-MO. TREAS. BILLS   5.10   5.06   5.13        6-MO. TREAS. BILLS   5.13   5.09   5.26        10-YR. TREAS. INFL.**   3.74   3.67   N.A.        10-YR. TREAS. NOTES   6.23   6.19   6.79        30-YR. TREAS. headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: HOME PROPERTIES OF NEW YORK, Rochester, a real estate investment trust, agreed to buy an apartment portfolio in Michigan for $105 million.      FOAMEX INTERNATIONAL INC., Linwood, Pa., a foam maker, agreed to sell its needlepunch carpeting and artificial grass business in Dalton, Ga., to Dixie Group Inc. of Chattanooga, Tenn., for about $33 million.     JITNEY-JUNGLE STORES OF AMERICA INC., Jackson, Miss., agreed to sell 10 grocery stores to Supervalu Holdings Inc., Eden Prairie, Minn., easing regulatory concern over Jitney-Jungle's proposed acquisition of Delchamps Inc. of Mobile, Ala.

headline: 50 West Bank Palestinians Detained in Israeli Dragnet
abstract: Hundreds of Israeli soldiers mount powerful dragnet through West Bank villages around Nablus, detaining about 50 Palestinian men; Palestinians suspect dragnet was aimed at capturing members of Hamas who may be linked to suicide bombings on July 30 and Sept 4; Israeli police say Yaacov Schwartz, an Orthodox Jew who was reported to have been kidnapped by Palestinian guerrillas during visit of Sec of State Madeleine K Albright, has acknowledged that he faked the abduction; Fuad Haidieh, last Arab resident of a house in East Jerusalem into which Jewish settlers moved on Sept 14 returns to reclaim house, which he says he never sold (M)

headline: New Twist on Swiss Accounts: Envoy Sees Her Mother's Name
abstract: Madeleine M Kunin, United States Ambassador to Switzerland who helped persuade Swiss bankers to publish list of dormant World War II-era bank accounts, is suprised to find late mother's name on list; Kunin, whose German-Jewish family fled Switzerland in 1940 in fear of Nazi invasion, files claim; lauds bankers for publishing list; bankers had long insisted that there were few such accounts and that any surviving heirs would know who they were; photo (M)

headline: Profit Is Up 62% At Julius Baer
abstract: Julius Baer Holding AG says first-half profit rose 62 percent; profit rose to 107.5 million Swiss francs ($72 million), from 66.5 million francs a year ago; operating income rose 43 percent, to 419.3 million francs, as commission income, biggest contributor, rose 45 percent, to 216.1 million francs (S)

headline: A Village So Private After a Life So Public
abstract: Princess Diana's final resting place is leafy island in small and sculptured lake in ancestral estate in Althorp, Northamptonshire; site is extremely remote from glare of publicity she both shunned and courted; public is excluded from burial; authorities order air-exclusion zone over estate to prevent photographers and television crews from filming area (M)

headline: Despite Deal, Grim Divorce For Barney's
abstract: News analysis of Dickson Poon's offer to buy Barney's for $205 million and 49 percent equity stake (M)

headline: Presstek comments vaguely about a mysterious settlement.
abstract: Market Place column on Presstek Inc's disclosure that it has agreed to settle charged to be brought by Securities and Exchange Commission; says Presstek does not elaborate on charges and settlement; holds company's stock was one of fastest climbers in mid-1990's and is still trading at more than 100 times earnings; graph (L)

headline: U.S. Urges Arabs and Israelis to Cooperate
abstract: Special US Middle East envoy David Ross urges top Israeli and Palestinian officials to salvage tattered peace negotiations by taking first step of working together to determine who orchestrated two suicide bombings in Jerusalem on July 30; anger continues between both sides, bringing first stone-throwing clashes in months between Palestinian youths and Israeli troops in Ramallah; bombing claims 14th fatality (M)

headline: BOC Reports 1% Rise In 3d-Quarter Income
abstract: BOC Group PLC says third-quarter net income rose 1 percent, to 69.7 million pounds ($110 million), from 69.1 million pounds a year ago; sales dropped 3 percent, to 990 million pounds (S)

headline: Strict Press Laws Govern Any Invasion of Privacy : France No Paparazzi Market
abstract: PARIS  The free-lance photographers who pursued Diana, Princess of Wales, and her millionaire companion shortly before their fatal crash would have found no legal market for their pictures in France.

headline: Basque Web Site Suspended After Protests
abstract: Institute for Global Communications, nonprofit Internet service provider that specializes in working with human rights, peace and labor groups, suspends Web site sympathetic to Basque separatist movement; says it is responding, under protest, to campaign of electronic sabotage that makes it impossible to provide normal E-mail services to users; says it reviews site content to determine whether carrying it is in keeping with its support for nonviolence and human rights; sabotage began after Basque separatist group assassinated politican Miguel Angel Blanco, sparking anger across Spain (M)

headline: A Chateau Divided: Famed Yquem Riven by Family Feud
abstract: Chateau d'Yquem winery in Sauternes, France, is embroiled in acrimonious battle for control pitting Count Alexandre de Lur Saluces against Bernard Arnault of LVMH conglomerate; LVMH bought controlling 55 percent stake seven months ago, solicited by disenchanted members of the de Lur Saluces family; map; photos (Sauternes Journal) (M)

headline: Merrill Buys Barclays Unit
abstract: Merrill Lynch & Co acquires Masterworks division of Barclays Global Investors, unit of British bank Barclays PLC; terms undisclosed (S)

headline: Louis Blaise Inturrisi, Travel and Food Writer, 54
abstract: Louis Blaise Inturrisi, Rome-based travel and food writer, is found dead in his apartment; police say they consider his death a homicide; he was 54 (S)

headline: Valve Maker Deal Gets U.S. Approval
abstract: Tyco International Ltd receives antitrust approval for its $1.3 billion acquisition of Keystone International Inc by agreeing to sell Keystone's waterworks butterfly valve business (S)

headline: Executive Changes
abstract: ELI LILLY & CO., Indianapolis, named Gerhard N. Mayr to the newly created position of president, intercontinental operations.    PEARSON P.L.C., London, named Peter Jovanovich chairman and chief executive of its Addison Wesley Longman educational-publishing unit, effective Sept. 1. Mr. Jovanovich, who is resigning this week as president of the McGraw-Hill Companies' educational and professional publishing group, will replace J. Larry Jones at Addison Wesley. At McGraw-Hill, Mr. Jovanovich will be replaced by Jack E. Witmer, who will report to Harold W. McGraw 3d, president and chief operating officer of the company. Mr. Witmer has been president of Glencoe Press, the nation's largest secondary school publisher, since 1971. Glencoe became part of McGraw-Hill in 1989.    PAN AM CORP., Miami, named James Arpey to the newly created position of chief operating officer.

headline: CHASE TO PURCHASE MELLON CORPORATE TRUSTEE ACCOUNTS
abstract: Chase Manhattan Corp will purchase corporate trustee and agency business of Mellon Bank Corp for undisclosed sum (S)

headline: Mortgage Rates Increase
abstract: Rates on 30-year fixed-rate mortgages climed in most recent week 0.13 percent, to 7.64 percent (S)

headline: 3 Executives Leave A.M.A. Over Sunbeam Endorsement
abstract: Kenneth E Monroe leaves as American Medical Association chief operationg officer and James F Rappel and Larry Jellen as vice presidents in wake of dispute over AMA's ill-fated endorsement deal with Sunbeam Corp; AMA names Lynn Jensen acting chief operating officer; chairman Thomas R Reardon comments on endorsement flap and says board in future must approve and set guidelines for any use of AMA name (S)

headline: Ex-Beauty Queen Slain, a New Riddle in Mexico's Drug Scandals
abstract: Guadalajara police probe murder of former Mexican beauty queen Irma Lizzete Ibarra Navejat, who allegedly brought military officers together with drug lords; killing comes as concern mounts about extent to which army has been corrupted by drug trade (M)

headline: For China's Leaders at Congress, the Plaudits Cascade Down
abstract: Delegates to China's Communist Party Congress praise leadership role of Pres Jiang Zemin and keynote address he gave on Sept 12 (M)

headline: Delta Earnings to Be Below Expectations
abstract: Delta Air Lines Inc warns that its earnings for quarter ended Sept 30 will be below analysts' expectations and down from a year ago on lower revenue (S)

headline: Era Ending For Chile As Pinochet Plans Exit
abstract: Gen Augusto Pinochet, who led 1973 coup against leftist Salvador Allende, announces his retirement next March; 82-year-old general gave up political power in 1990 to democratically-elected Government, but continued as head of army; he is required to step down under Constitution he wrote, but may still assume Senate seat; Pinochet is widely respected in Chile for initiating social and economic changes that led to prosperity, but retirement is considered final step in democratization (M)

headline: Company Says Halt in Trading Is Unjustified
abstract: Equisure Inc, whose shares have been suspended from trading amid investigation by American Stock Exchange, simultaneously outlines and denies what it says are exchange's suspicions; says 'exchange insinuated in its letter that company has virtually no money, no business and no offices except for one-man executive suite in Minnesota'; company statement rejects allegations as 'patently absurd' (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Microsoft Net Rises 89% But Barely Beats Forecasts  Microsoft's quarterly earnings rose 89 percent, to $1.05 billion, but that was only slightly above analysts' expectations, and the company's shares fell in after-hours trading.

headline: In Fair August, Work Is but a Midsummer Daydream
abstract: Article on growing number of Amerians who flee their jobs, if not their towns and even the country, for entire month of August; graph (L)

headline: PENNEY TO OFFER EARLY RETIREMENT TO MANAGERS
abstract: J C Penney Co will offer voluntary early retirement to 1,500, or about 5 percent, of its management employees and expects to take $200 million pretax charge against earnings later this year to pay for the program (S)

headline: CARR-GOTTSTEIN HAS LOSS AFTER CHARGE TO CLOSE UNITS
abstract: Carr-Gottstein Foods Company reports second-quarter 1997 loss of $5.1 million, after taking pre-tax loss of $8.9 million (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: HORIZON HEALTH CORP., Lewisville, Tex., a health care concern, acquired the closely held Specialty Healthcare Management Inc. of Englewood, Colo., a manager of mental health programs, for $32.6 million in stock.     SPARTAN MOTORS INC., Charlotte, Mich., a manufacturer of custom chassis, agreed to acquire three privately held fire truck apparatus manufacturers for $19.6 million in cash and stock.

headline: ALTERNATIVE LIVING SERVICES TO BUY STERLING HOUSE
abstract: Alternative Living Services agrees to buy Sterling House Corp for about $170 million in stock (S)

headline: MCI Profits Fell by 6.7% In 2d Quarter
abstract: MCI Communications Corp reports 6.7 percent decline in earnings during second quarter of 1997; net was $280 million, compared with $300 million in year-earlier period (S)

headline: Japan Trade Surplus Fell 21.6% in June
abstract: Japan's merchandise trade surplus decreased a seasonally adjusted 21.6 percent in June from May, to 865.46 billion yen, or $7.45 billion (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: STATE FARM INSURANCE CO., Bloomington, Ill., said it would pay $692.3 million as dividends to auto insurance policyholders in 30 states and the District of Columbia because claims had been lower than expected.     ALLIED SIGNAL INC., Morristown, N.J., said it would close an aerospace parts plant in Eatontown, N.J., and move the work to a plant in Tucson, Ariz. The New Jersey plant's 240 employees will be able to apply for the jobs in Tucson.     GREYHOUND LINES INC., Dallas, bought the ''running dog'' logo it has used for 80 years and a stake in five bus terminals from Viad Corp., Phoenix, for $10.2 million.

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: Debt  Bepensa S.A., Mexico, is selling $110 million of bonds due in 2004 through Santander Investment. The bonds carry an interest rate of 9.75 percent and are priced at par. The issue is rated BB- by Duff & Phelps.    Enterprise Oil P.L.C., London, is selling $350 million of Yankee notes due in 2007 through Lehman Brothers. The noncallable notes are priced at 99.717 to yield 6.7 percent. The issue is rated A3 by Moody's and A- by S.& P.

headline: A Continuous Role
abstract: United States aides hope American intelligence official official will play continuing role between Palestinian and Israeli intelligence officers to insure security cooperation continues beyond probe into Jerusalem bombing; say American intelligence officials, including Central Intelligence Agency head John Deutch, have played such role before (S)

headline: CUC TO ACQUIRE HEBDO MAG FOR $440 MILLION
abstract: CUC International Inc agrees to acquire Hebdo Mag International Inc for $440 million (S)

headline: Equitable About To Get New Chief
abstract: Equitable Companies names Edward D Miller to be its next president and chief executive; Joseph J Melone, who currently holds those jobs, will continue as chairman of Equitable Life and will become chairman of company's executive committee (S)

headline: DAVCO RESTAURANTS GETS $148 MILLION BUYOUT OFFER
abstract: Davco Restaurants Inc, largest franchisee of Wendy's restaurants, says it received cash buyout offer worth as much as $148 million from investor group that includes Ronald D Kirstien, Davco's president and chief executive, and Citicorp unit that is its principal shareholder (S)

headline: Albright Says She Found 'Tattered' Mideast Situation
abstract: US Sec of State Madeleine K Albright visits, Beirut, Lebanon, where she voices US support for Lebanon's sovereignty; says crisis of confidence between Israel and Palestinians is worse than she thought; says she will remain absorbed in issue but that there are other world problems to occupy her time if Middle East leaders are not prepared to make basic decisions about working together (M)

headline: Liberia Gets a Fair Vote, Courtesy of Unfree Neighbors
abstract: West African peacekeeping force, which is made up of soldiers from countries where leaders hold power by force, wins virtually universal praise for playing crucial role in recent free and fair elections in Liberia; with approximately third of vote counted, Charles G Taylor widens lead over opponent Ellen Johnson-Sirleaf, claiming approximately 66 percent of vote (M)

headline: Fidelity to Bar New Investors In Magellan
abstract: Fidelity Investments has decided to close Magellan fund to new investors; as of Sept 30, mutual fund, the nation's largest, will accept only new investments from current shareholders or from participants in retirement programs that include Magellan as an option (L)

headline: At F.C.C. Confirmation Hearings, Emphasis Will Be on Competition
abstract: Upcoming confirmation hearings of Pres Clinton's nomination of William E Kennard to be chairman of Federal Communications Commission is expected to focus less on Kennard's qualifications than on Senators' concerns about Telecommunications Act of 1996; there is still little competition among local telephone companies or cable television providers, 18 months after act was signed into law; Sen John McCain, critic of law, claims it gives FCC too much power over entry of companies into new lines of business, and that FCC impedes rather than embraces competition; Senate panel will also consider commission nominess Harold Furchtgott-Roth, Michael Powell and Gloria Tristani; photo; chart (M)

headline: Ivax, Drug Concern, Chooses President
abstract: Ivax Corp names David Bethune president-chief operating officer, following resignation of Robert Strauss (S)

headline: In Mexico's House, Speaker's Stature Signals a New Day
abstract: Porfirio Munoz Ledo, leader of Mexico's opposition, delivers response to Pres Ernesto Zedillo's state-of-the nation address, becoming first member of opposition ever to do so; photo (M)

headline: Switzerland, a Cult Magnet, Attracts Aliens and Cloning Offers
abstract: Nearly 1,000 members of Raelian movement gather in Switzerland to celebrate organization, which advocates cloning to promote human happiness, and believes that extraterrestrials are linked to people on Earth (M)

headline: U.S. MIDEAST ENVOY HITS SNAG IN TALKS ON SECURITY ISSUES
abstract: Special US Middle East envoy Dennis Ross begins meeting with Israeli Prime Min Benjamin Netanyahu and Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat in effort to restart Israeli-Palestinian peace talks but hits snag over security issues; both sides voice very different views about what Ross should be trying to tackle, and accuse each other anew of acting in bad faith; Ross says primary purpose will be to restore cooperation on security issues, which he says is basis of efffort to forge broader peace; photo (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: ENERGEN CORP., Birmingham, Ala., said its Taurus Exploration unit had agreed to buy Amoco Corp.'s Black Warrior coal-bed methane properties in Alabama for $72 million.

headline: Seoul to Prop Up Its Crumbling Banks
abstract: South Korean Government says it will pump 1.5 trillion won ($1.68 billion) into its crumbling banking system (S)

headline: Dell Computer Taking Aim at Consumers
abstract: Dell Computer Corp, world's largest mail-order seller of personal computers, has ambitious plans to expand beyond its corporate clientele and sell more to consumers; Dell plans to announce formation of new division aimed at consumers (M)

headline: Gambling Magazines: All That Glitters or Rolls
abstract: Article discusses growing success of magazines that deal with gambling; examples cited (M)

headline: Stride Rite Turns to Fashion to Walk Tall Again
abstract: Interview with Robert C Siegel, who is chief executive of Stride Rite, manufacturer of Keds and other shoes which has been under pressure from fashionable sports footwear of Nike and Reebok and who has watched stock price slip for years; photo; graphs (M)

headline: Japanese Official Backs Corporate Tax Cut
abstract: Japan's Vice Trade Minister Osamu Watanabe says Governemnt should cut Japan's corporate income taxes by 10 percent (S)

headline: Music Label Sale Planned
abstract: Alliance Entertainment Corp will sell back most of Red Ant Records to Wasserstein Perella & Co; deal will give Alliance, which is Chapter 13 bankruptcy proceedings, $625,000 in cash and 10 percent interest in record label (S)

headline: Canadian Insurer Sale
abstract: Confederation Life Insurance Company, failed Canadian insurer, puts its investment real estate portfolio up for sale (S)

headline: Serbia's Last Ally in the Yugoslav Breakup Is Restive
abstract: Montenegro, last state remaining with Serbia in Yugoslav federation, is becoming restless under autocratic thumb of Yugoslav Pres Slobodan Milosevic; Montenegrins are talking of regaining independence lost to Serbia in 1918 and turning nation into international tax haven and tourist mecca; Prime Min Milo Djukanovic has begun criticizing Milosevic and has turned against Pres Momir Bulatovic, Milosevic ally; map (M)

headline: Debt-Collection Scandal at Sears Curbs Profit
abstract: Sears Roebuck & Co reports second quarter net income fell to $117 million from $274 million a year earlier (M)

headline: Is Life Better In Bulgaria? It's a Matter Of Perspective
abstract: Appearance of another index ranking countries by their social conditions--study in which Bulgaria outranks US in quality of life--raises new questions about how and why these surveys are conducted; latest report is by Richard J Estes, scholar at University of Pennsylvania's School of Social Work (M)

headline: Three Restaurant Chains Prepare for Life After Pepsico
abstract: Pepsico Inc plans to spin off its fast-food restaurants, Taco Bell, Pizza Hut and KFC, as one company, leaving them to succeed or fail on their own; sales growth has slumped in recent years as restaurant chains failed to stand out in crowded industry; Andrall E Pearson, Pepsico's president from 1971 to 1984, is chairman of the spinoff called Tricon Global Restaurants Inc; graphs; photos (L)

headline: Stocks Lower in Japan
abstract: Japan's Nikkei stock index is down 46.80 points, or three-tenths of 1 percent, at 18,182.62 points at midday on Sept 1 (S)

headline: Big N.J. Property Owner in $1 Billion Deals
abstract: Cali Realty Corp of Cranford, NJ, is expected to announce agreement to acquire Mack Co, real estate developer and investor based in Rochelle Park, NJ; Cali is also expected to buy Patriot American Management and Leasing, office property company run by Paul Nussbaum (S)

headline: SAFECO TO PAY $140 MILLION FOR WASHINGTON MUTUAL UNIT
abstract: Safeco Corp agrees to acquire WM Life Insurance Co, insurance underwriting subsidiary of Washington Mutual Inc, for $140 million (S)

headline: World News Briefs; Allies of Peru's President Take Over a TV Station
abstract: Investors with close ties to Pres Alberto Fujimori seize control of Peruvian television station that has exposed Government wrongdoing; appeals court granted control of Frecuencia Latina TV to minority shareholders Samuel and Mendel Winter after majority owner, Baruch Ivcher, was stripped of his citizenship (S)

headline: White House Says Iran Pipeline Won't Violate Sanctions Act
abstract: Clinton Administration will not object to $1.6 billion project to build natural gas pipeline across Iran, despite new law aimed at discouraging investment in Iran's oil and gas industry; offficials say tacit approval does not reflect easing of longstanding efforts to isolate Iran economically and diplomatically and is based on fact that pipeline's primary beneficiaries are Turkmenistan and Turkey (M)

headline: E.D.S. Posts Decline in 2d-Quarter Earnings
abstract: Electronic Data Systems reports second-quarter 1997 net of $192 million, compared with $247 million in year-earlier period; loss attributed to tougher competition and shrinking margins in computer services industry (M)

headline: GOODYEAR UNIT AGREES TO BUY INDOMAX ASSETS
abstract: Goodyear Tire and Rubber Co's Engineered Products unit agrees to buy assets of Indomax CA, automotive hose maker in Venezuela, and three affiliates, as it continues its expansion in South America; terms undisclosed (S)

headline: Europe Offering Free Calls, But First, a Word From . . .
abstract: Number of European telephone companies are offering free calls to customers who agree to listen to commercials before they dial; Paolo Balestri's company has 12,000 subscribers in Viareggio and two other communities on west coast of Italy, and expects to spread to more than 100 cities; Gratistelefon of Sweden, which claims to have invented idea, has 30,000 subscribers who hear new phone ad every three minutes; subscribers say they do not mind listening because savings are considerable (M)

headline: BARRICK GOLD PLANS TO SET ASIDE $385 MILLION
abstract: Barrick Gold Corp, a Canadian gold producer, says it will set aside $385 million to cover third-quarter writedowns of mines in Chile and US (S)

headline: TIDEWATER SAYS IT MAY SELL COMPRESSION OPERATION
abstract: Tidewater Inc will consider ways to shed its natural gas compression unit to focus on its primary business of providing vessels for offshore energy industry (S)

headline: Proposal to Privatize Japanese State Insurer
abstract: Japanese Government panel led by Prime Min Ryutaro Hashimoto proposes that $814 million postal insurance system, known as Kampo, be turned into private company by year 2001; Kampo is world's largest life insurer (S)

headline: 7 Big-Name Companies Step Up to Invest In Start-Up Network
abstract: Seven big Internet and networking companies will invest $40 million in Juniper Networks Inc to help start-up company produce equipment that can speed flow of information over Internet; Juniper says 3Com Corp, UUNet Technologies unit of Worldcom Inc, Lucent Technologies Inc, Northern Telecom Ltd, Ericsson LM, and joint venture of Siemens AG and Newbridge Networks Corp will jointly acquire 24.2 percent stake (S)

headline: Financial Giants Woo Lower-Income Market : Tuning In To Small Investors
abstract: PARIS  If it is a banker's fate to follow his customers, there is one class of client that no bank in the world canafford to ignore any longer:the small investor.

headline: 2 Top Executives Leaving Valuevision
abstract: Valuevision International Inc says chief executive Robert Johander and chief operating officer Nicholas Jaksich will step down and that company will consider options include a merger (S)

headline: They Need Not Apply
abstract: Stories solicited for article on people who interview so poorly they will never be hired

headline: Swedish Truck Maker Has 19% Drop in Profit
abstract: Scania AB reports second-quarter net income fell 19 percent, to 581 million kronor ($72 million), down from 720 million kronor in 1996 period (S)

headline: JANUS CAPITAL IS 2D-BIGGEST VW SHAREHOLDER
abstract: Janus Capital Corp, a US mutual fund manager, has bought 5.09 perent of Volkswagen AG, making it car maker's second-largest shareholder behind state of Lower Saxony, with 20 percent (S)

headline: Executive Chages
abstract: HARLEY-DAVIDSON INC., Milwaukee, named Jeffrey Bleustein president and chief executive. He will retain the responsibilities of chief operating officer for the Harley-Davidson Motor Co. unit.

headline: North Korea May Let Japanese Go Back Home
abstract: North Korea weighs letting elderly Japanese wives of North Korean men visit their Japanese hometowns, apparently to win Japanese food aid; has long barred most family visits by or to such women, most of whom moved to Korea with husbands in 1959 and early 1960's; plan raises guarded hopes among family members in Japan; photo (M)

headline: In Post-Soviet Era, the Old Style Works
abstract: Former Soviet republic of Azerbaijan has been stable, if not prosperous, under Pres Heydar Aliyev, protege of Leonid I Brezhnev and former KGB officer who emerged after messy power struggle in 1993; even though he is praised by many Azerbaijanis, critics say his autocratic style has hindered development of democracy; map; photo (M)

headline: George Newi, 62, a Former ABC Executive
abstract: George H Newi, a former president of ABC Television Network, dies at 62 (S)

headline: Guerrillas Rain Rockets on Israel; Injuries Are Minor
abstract: Hezbollah guerrillas launch rocket attack into northern Israel from Lebanon to avenge attack by militiamen aligned with Israel; attack causes only minor damage and injuries but sends thousands of residents into underground shelters; Israel says it does not plan immediate retaliation; map; photo (M)

headline: Words Fly As Division Becomes Ever Wider
abstract: Verbal exchanges between Israeli and Palestinian leaders become more confrontational, even as Jordanian Crown Prince Hassan arrives in Jerusalem to appeal for renewed Israeli-Palestinian cooperation; Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat reportedly urges party cadres to stand their ground in coming battle; Hassan urges Israeli Prime Min Netanyahu to take softer line; Netanyahu stands by demand that Arafat crack down on militants, news conference (M)

headline: Relief Teams Say North Korea Faces Vast Drought Emergency
abstract: Relief officials say North Korea faces vast drought emergency and that millions may be on brink of starvation; two months of high temperatures and no rain comes after food stocks were already severly depleted by two years of floods and decades of economic ruin wrought by most bizarre of Communist systems, which is now struggling to feed itself without allies; chart; photo (M)

headline: ISRAELIS TIGHTEN CURBS ON ARABS, ARRESTING DOZENS
abstract: Israel makes new arrests in the July 30 suicide bombing in Jerusalem and bans most movement in West Bank; tense stalemate takes shape, with Israel holding off carrying out its threats to take drastic measures and the Palestinian leadership avoiding drastic new steps to clamp down on Islamic militants; new leaflet in name of Hamas, militant Islamic organization, again praises suicide attacks as best tactic to confront Israel; members of Yasir Arafat's cabinet resign, saying he needs fre edom to act; Pres Clinton says Dennis Ross, his Middle East negotiator, will return to region to try to rebuild tattered negotitations for peace; photos (M)

headline: Egypt's Big Deal With U.S. Reverses a Slump in Wheat
abstract: Wheat prices rise after Egypt buys grain from US, bolstering expectations that exports could pick up after slow start this year (M)

headline: USA WASTE SERVICES ADVANCES A $1.5 BILLION BID
abstract: USA Waste Services Inc reaches agreement with regulators that will allow it to complete its $1.5 billion acquisition of United Waste Systems Inc (S)

headline: Sad Tale of Motherhood, to Prod Church Fathers
abstract: Gustaw Herling, distinguished expatriate Polish author, has caused stir with impassioned short story criticizing Pope John Paul II's stand against abortion; Herling, visiting Poland, says he is surprised and pleased by strength of Polish reaction, interview; photo (M)

headline: Brunei Buys Frail Currencies And Cuts Asia Stock Losses
abstract: Government of Brunei intervenes in foreign-exchange market to support several floundering Asian currencies; purchases of Malaysian ringgit, Singapore dollars and Indonesian rupiah boost stocks (S)

headline: A Pension Gap for Women
abstract: Comment by Marie Rudie Barneby and Jennifer Kelly warns that women still lag behind men in traditional pension and Social Security benefits; urges Congress to approve bills that would encourage retirement savings during maternity leaves, faster vesting and more equitable division of pension assets in divorce (S)

headline: In Music Retailing, Different Drummers
abstract: Success of variety of acts contributed to gain of 5.4 percent in sales of compact disks and tapes in first half of 1997 from a year earlier; growth, which some analysts expect to continue through the year, has been refreshing news in industry with many problems; music industry still faces long-term problems, ranging from on-line competition to prices that are too high for primary group of customers, teen-agers; graph; photo (L)

headline: Tsingtao Brewery Plans Growth in Eastern China
abstract: Tsingtao Brewery Co, China's largest beer exporter, will sell peripheral businesses to its parent company to buy breweries in eastern China (S)

headline: Netanyahu Drops His Effort To Give Sharon New Post
