abstract: Prime Min Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel bows to pressure from Foreign Min David Levy and abandons effort to name a veteran hawk, Ariel Sharon, to Finance Ministry; appoints Yaaakov Neeman, a prominent corporate tax lawyer, to job; surprise announcement caught politicians and experts off guard; while Levy fought hard to prevent Sharon from receiving expanded powers, it had been assumed that Levy would agree to appointment as Finance Minister (M)

headline: Digital Equipment's Operating Earnings Rise in Quarter
abstract: Digital Equipment Corp reports net income of $124 million during its fiscal fourth quarter, compared with loss of $433 million a year earlier; total revenue was $3.5 million, compared with $3.7 million in 1996; for full fiscal year, Digital's revenues declined 11 percent, to $13 billion, from $14.6 billion in 1996, while net income was $141 million, after loss of $112 million a year earlier; table (L)

headline: In Phone Gear Consolidation, Comverse Will Acquire Boston
abstract: Comverse Technology Inc, leading maker of telephone voice mail systems, agrees to pay $843 million in stock to acquire one of its major rivals, Boston Technology; acquisition would continue consolidation of telecommunications-equipment industry, creating $390 million company that would be third largest in $3.5 billion voice mail arena, supplying message systems to 12 of world's 20 largest telephone carriers (L)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Raytheon in Deal to Sell Some Appliance Divisions  Raytheon has agreed to sell several businesses, including those that make Amana and Caloric appliances, for $550 million to Goodman Holding, a maker of furnaces and air-conditioners.

headline: Thousands Of Basques Hold Rally In Spain
abstract: Popular Unity party, political party linked to violent Basque separatists in Spain, rallies 18,000 supporters to march through streets of San Sebastian in biggest show of force since assassination of Miguel Angel Blanco, 29-year-old councilman, on July 13; warns millions of Spaniards who recently marched against terrorism that rebels fighting for independent Basque homeland will not be intimidated; map; photo (M)

headline: U.S. Examining Columbia's Use Of Subsidiaries' Cost Reports
abstract: Government officials are investigating whether maze of hundreds of corporate subsidiaries acquired by Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corp were used by some of its hospitals to fraudulently obtain Federal reimbursement that they did not deserve; Federal investigators obtain evidence that Columbia hospitals in at least four states may have improperly filed for Government reimbursement on expenses incurred in recruiting doctors; both areas of investigation signal further expansion of Federal inquiry into procedures Columbia hospitals used for reporting expenses to the Government (L)

headline: CGIP Lifts Holding In Cap Gemini
abstract: Compagnie d'Industrie et de Participations (CGIP), a French industrial holding company, buys Daimler-Benz AG's stake in Cap Gemini to become largest shareholder in France's biggest computer services company; CGIP pays Daimler $803.9 million for its 24 percent stake (S)

headline: Rights Group Blames Rwandans In Attacks on Civilians in Congo
abstract: Dr Jennifer Leaning, who led Physicians for Human Rights probe in region, tells House panel that Rwandan troops are responsible for most of atrocities in eastern Congo over last several months; says Rwanda Army soldiers, who are largely ethnic Tutsi, are committing murder, rape and robbery daily and have killed over 2,000 of Hutus who fled Rwanda in 1994 (S)

headline: An Electronic Sheriff to Battle Book Rustling
abstract: American Publishers Association plans global drive for newly developed digital system to tag electronic books and journals; prepares to use DOI system as part of more elaborate strategies for on-line purchases and creation of encrypted keys to protect digital material from unauthorized copying (M)

headline: Adding Power, Hitachi Becomes No. 2 to I.B.M. In Mainframes
abstract: Hitachi Data Systems has become second-largest mainframe computer maker due to success of its newest mainframe, Skyline; large companies have been snapping up machines as fast as Hitachi can make them, ever since their introduction 18 months ago; success of Skyline has given Hitachi entree into world's elite buyers of information technology; seeds of Hitachi's current success date back to 1993, when industry's leader, IBM, in budgetary move, stopped developing its line of giant, water-cooled mainframes built around chip technology known in trade as bipolar; IBM's new machines are one-tenth the cost to produce but are much slower; Hitachi's Skyline is hybrid machine that offers power of old-style mainframes with many cost savings of new silicon-chip-based designs; Hitachi Data Systems is joint venture of Hitachi Ltd and Electronic Data Systems (M)

headline: Soundscan Makes Business of Counting Hits
abstract: Soundscan Inc, company started in 1991, has drastically changed music charting system, and by extension, altered way recording industry does business; its system electronically tracks and tallies record sales every time album's bar code is read at participating store's cash register; count is crucial because of hit-driven nature of recording industry; as albums move up the charts, radio stations play songs more often, further driving sales of album; Soundscan boasts 85 percent to 90 percent participation rate by American music retailers; photo; chart (L)

headline: Colombia Cuts Domestic Coffee Price
abstract: Colombia, world's second-largest coffee exporter, is reducing its domestic coffee price 10 percent in keeping with variations in international prices; beginning on July 5, National Coffee Growers' Federation will pay coffee growers $308.18 for each 275-pound bag of coffee, or about $1.12 a pound (S)

headline: Japan's Economy Shrinks by 11.2% Annual Rate
abstract: Japanese Government reports economic output in second quarter fell at startling annual rate of 11.2 percent; size of drop in output is surprising and dashes hopes that early recovery from nation's long economic slump is in the works; graph (L)

headline: NATO and Russia Move Toward Arms Cutback
abstract: United States, Russia and 28 other nations meeting in Vienna agree on framework for treaty to cut number of tanks and other non-nuclear arms in Europe, especially in Central European countries of former Warsaw Pact; accord would expand and replace 1990 accord on conventional arms between NATO and then-members of Soviet bloc; idea is to remove most of conventional forces seen as threatening to Russia as NATO expands eastward (M)

headline: Australian Bank Buys Stake in E.D.S. Unit
abstract: Commonwealth Bank of Australia pays about $240 million (Australian), or $174 million (US), for 35 percent stake in EDS Australia; transaction is part of agreement under which Electronic Data Services Corp is taking over all of Commonwealth Bank's information technology functions (S)

headline: Southeast Asia Chokes on Indonesia's Forest Fires
abstract: Smoke from vast forest fires burning out of control in jungles of Indonesia, mostly on Sumatra and Borneo, is blanketing broad swath of Southeast Asia with choking haze; has forced cancellation of flights around region, disrupted busy Strait of Malacca shipping lanes and sickened millions of people; fires are mostly intentionally set by Indonesian and Malaysian agricultural companies as cheap and illegal means of land-clearing; smoke is combining in Malaysia and Indonesia with urban pollution and effects are being compounded by drought caused by return this year of El Nino, ocean current that upsets weather patterns; Malaysian state of Sarawak, in northwestern Borneo, is worst hit; map; table (M)

headline: Asians Are Cool to Albright on Cambodians and Burmese
abstract: Japan rebuffs US requests to use aid to pressure Cambodia into holding free and fair elections, while leaders of Association of Southeast Asian Nations listen noncommittally as Sec of State Madeleine K Albright bluntly admonishes them at meeting in Kuala Lumpur to work for democratic change in Myanmar; Albright gets some lecturing herself, particularly from Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad of Malaysia, who is known for his resentment of what he considers Western arrogance (M)

headline: People
abstract: * Mark Buckman, senior vice president and worldwide media director on the Coca-Cola account at McCann-Erickson Worldwide, New York, a unit of the Interpublic Group, was named to the added new responsibilities of worldwide media operations director. Muirne Laffan, vice president and international group media director, was named to the new post of senior vice president and media director. And Mark Stewart, executive vice president and media director at McCann New York, was named to the added responsibilities for McCann North America.    * Michael Breda, senior vice president and group account director at Ingalls Moranville Advertising, San Francisco, a subsidiary of Davis Elen Advertising, was named to head a new office in Seattle.

headline: Sale of Institutional Investor By Disney Is Expected Soon
abstract: Walt Disney Co is expected to reach agreement to sell Institutional Investor to Euromoney Publications PLC for between $120 million and $130 million (M)

headline: Valuing a Collectible
abstract: Rudy Franchi letter on July 27 article on collectible movie posters (S)e

headline: New Premier In Cambodia, Bringing Total To 3? 2? 1?
abstract: Cambodian Parliament obedient to Second Prime Min Hun Sen ignores constitutional and procedural roadblocks and elects Min Ung Huot to replace Prince Norodom Ranariddh as Co-Prime Minister; strips Prince Ranariddh of his parliamentary immunity, clearing way for trial; no move is taken to remove Prince from post as First Prime Minister; Prince is thought to be in France; Hun Sen holds votes prove he did not stage coup (M)

headline: PIZZA HUT PLANS TO SELL 148 RESTAURANTS TO PACPIZZA
abstract: PepsiCo Inc's Pizza Hut unit will sell 148 Pizza Hut restaurants in California, Oregon and Nevada to Pacpizza LLC for undisclosed sum (S)

headline: Struggling Informix Selects Chief Executive
abstract: Informix Corp names Robert Finocchio Jr president and chief executive; Finocchio succeeds Phillip E White, who will continue as chairman (S)

headline: Bayerische Vereinsbank Expands Share Offer
abstract: Bayerische Vereinsbank AG will sell 36 million new shares, raising estimated 3 billion marks ($1.7 billion) for its planned merger with Bayerische Hypotheken-und Wechsel-Bank AG; Vereinsbank's chief executive Albrecht Schmidt will head new bank; Hypo-Bank's chief executive Eberhard Martini will retire in late 1998 (S)

headline: After Pact With Netanyahu, Settlers Leave East Jerusalem House
abstract: Right-wing Jews who took over house in Arab neighborhood in East Jerusalem vacate premises after reaching agreement with Prime Min Benjamin Netanyahu, and are replaced by 10 Jewish religious students acting as guards and maintenance men; agreement follows negotiations with Dr Irving I Moskowitz, American owner who bought house and opened it to settlers; occupation posed difficult political challenge for Netanyahu; followed visit by US Secretary of State Madeleine Albright, who urged him to avoid taking actions provocative to Palestinians; eviction of settlers from house they legally owned would have set off fierce opposition from his religious and nationalist supporters (M)

headline: Two Financiers To Form No. 1 Investment Bank in Russia
abstract: Boris Jordan, American who founded Renaissance Capital, and Vladimir O Potanin, former head of Uneximbank, have joined forces to establish Russia's largest investment bank; new company will merge Renaissance Capital Group with International Company for Finance and Investment, which is now Russia's fifth-largest bank; announcement of merger is important sign for Russia's leaders that at least some Russian bankers believe there is real money to be made by investing at home (M)

headline: MIDCOM IN $75 MILLION STOCK DEAL FOR PHOENIX NETWORK
abstract: Midcom Communications Inc agrees to acquire Phoenix Network Inc for $75 million in stock (S)

headline: JOHN NUVEEN COMPANY TO ACQUIRE RITTENHOUSE FINANCIAL
abstract: John Nuveen Co agrees to buy Rittenhouse Financial Services Inc for $145 million (S)

headline: Mideast Hot Line For New Yorkers
abstract: Mayor Rudolph W Giuliani of New York sets up special phone number to help people trying to get information about Jerusalem bombing because international phone lines are jammed (S)

headline: Sul Hagar Journal; King Cotton Exacts a Tragic Toll From the Young
abstract: Recent death of 25 children from Sul Hagar, Egypt, and injury of others in crash of truck taking them to pick cotton racks town with sense of powerlessness; many residents, dependent on children's meager harvest wages, must send survivors back to fields; cotton growers, including Government, which owns some 10 percent of fields, routinely ignore minimum age rule and requirement that work not interfere with schooling; map; photo (M)

headline: Goldman, Sachs Fund Sets Office Venture
abstract: Goldman Sachs and Wellsford Real Properties form $400-million joint venture to buy and develop office properties in Northeast, highlighting booming market in region (S)

headline: High-Level Name-Calling Across the Racial Fence
abstract: Dispute between Prime Min Baseo Panday of Trinidad and communications magnate Kenneth Gordon has riveted and further divided ethnically and religiously diverse nation, raising issues of press freedom and race and class relations; Gordon sued Panday for calling him 'pseudo-racist'; Panday has long felt that predominantly black-owned press uses race as weapon to insult Indians; map; graphs; photo (M)

headline: China Telecom Offering Could Be Delayed
abstract: China Telecom (HK) Ltd may be forced to delay its $2 billion sale of shares, one of biggest in Hong Kong history, as regulators try to reassert their authority over a market whipsawed by rumor (S)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent                Previous   Year          Yesterday   Day   Ago               PRIME RATE   8.50   8.50   8.25        DISCOUNT RATE   5.00   5.00   5.00        FEDERAL FUNDS*   5.44   5.53   5.30        3-MO. TREAS. BILLS   4.91   4.93   5.13        6-MO. TREAS. BILLS   5.05   5.05   5.26        10-YR. TREAS. INFL.**   3.55   3.54   N.A.        10-YR. TREAS. NOTES   6.08   6.11   6.83        30-YR. TREAS. BONDS   6.37   6.39   7.04        TELEPHONE BONDS   7.49   7.49   8.06        MUNICIPAL BONDS***   5.42   5.43   5.95          *Estimated daily average, Dow Jones Markets  **Realized dollar amount rises with inflation  ***Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer  Sources: Salomon Brothers and Dow Jones Markets for Treasury's bellwether bonds, notes and bills

headline: Stocks Higher in Japan
abstract: Nikkei index of 225 Japanese stock issues rises 185.72 points, to 20,575.26 (Mon, 7/28) (S)

headline: New York Times Company Promotes Three Executives
abstract: Laura J Corwin, corporate secretary of The New York Times Co, has been promoted to additional position of vice president; company also says Ellen Taus has been promoted to treasurer from assitant treasurer and that R Anthony Benten has been elevated to assistant treasurer from director of treasury; photos (S)

headline: Demonizing the I.R.S.; Is an Overhaul Needed, Or Just Less Posturing
abstract: Senate committee hearings into Internal Revenue Service abuses are central element in drive by Republican leaders to exploit tax agency's unpopularity to strip IRS of much of its independence and power; bipartisan band of lawmakers wants to create new board of private-sector overseers and to impose other broad changes in way agency does business; group of Democratic lawmakers is pushing milder overhaul plan backed by Clinton Administration; Sen William V Roth Jr, who heads Senate panel, denies he has broader agenda then to make IRS more accountable for its actions, interview (M)

headline: German Effort On Digital TV Moves Ahead
abstract: Germany's troubled efforts to introduce digital television receives important boost, as nation's dominant cable provider and two biggest German entertainment companies agree to end years of feuding and support a common system; agreement calls for Deutsche Telekom to make its network available for digital television programming offered by Kirch Group and by Bertelsmann AG (L)

headline: Israelis and Palestinians Agree To U.S. Role in Attack Inquiry
abstract: Israeli and Palestinian authorities agree on three-way panel that includes United States Central Intelligence Agency station chief to regularly review findings about suicide bombing at Jerusalem market; refine plan at talks with US envoy Dennis Ross; plan will let US serve as referee and arbiter in dispute over whether Palestinians are doing enough to crack down on suspected Islamic militants; photo (M)

headline: Shoney's Averts A Proxy Fight With Settlement
abstract: Shoney's Inc and Raymond D Schoenbaum, dissident shareholder who had threatened proxy fight in effort to replace restaurant company's management, say they have settled their differences, at least for time being; Shoney says it has amended its bylaws to increase number of its directors to 11 from 7, and says that Schoenbaum and Michael J Bodner, one of his allies, have been named to board; Schoenbaum and his group agree that they will not begin any sort of proxy contest until May 1, 1998, at the earliest (L)

headline: Scripps and Knight-Ridder to Trade Papers
abstract: E W Scripps Co to trade two of its California newspapers, Monterey County Herald and San Luis Obispo Telegram-Tribune, for Knight-Ridder Inc's Boulder, Colo, Daily Camera (S)

headline: 85 Slain in New Attack Near Algiers, Setting Off Panic
abstract: At least 85 people are killed and 67 wounded in another brutal, unexplained attack on Algiers outskirts that spreads panic through capital; army seals off area; Government blames terrrorists; Islamic Salvation Front, banned in Algeria, issues statement in Paris scoring attack; photo (M)

headline: Down but Not Out, Clearly Down Under; Lean Times at an Australian Mainstay
abstract: Profile of Broken Hill Proprietary Co, Australia's giant producer of basic commodities; for Broken Hill, sprawling mining empire known for much of its 112 years as 'Big Australian,' it has been time of disappointment--and of equally broad reassessment; as an icon of an Australian economy in transition, not to mention country's biggest company, Broken Hill has come under intense fire from financial press, analysts and academics; Broken Hill has been slow to respond to increased competition of global economy; tables; charts; photos (L)

headline: CAPITAL BANCORP OF MIAMI SAYS IT IS IN ACQUISITION TALKS
abstract: Shares of Capital Bancorp jump 9 percent after bank says it is talking with several companies about possible acquisition (S)

headline: Third Management Shake-Up At McDonald's in Two Years
abstract: McDonald's Corp, with sales once again faltering in its domestic operations, announces that it will shift reponsibility for wide range of operations and marketing decisions from its corporate staff to five newly created regional divisions; management shake-up is third in two years; company announces retirement of Edward H Rensi, who has been president and chief executive of McDonald's USA since 1991; of three senior officers who had been reporting to Rensi, only one, Patrick Flynn is getting one of senior management jobs announced; executive vice presidents Thoams Glasgow Jr and Thomas Dentice are resigning; Robert Doran, who worked directly under Rensi, is not mentioned in announcement but is 'in the process of reassignment' (L)

headline: MCDERMOTT GETS $35.7 MILLION FROM SALE OF UNIFAB
abstract: McDermott International says its McDermott Inc unit received $35.7 million from sale of its stake in Unifab International Inc; McDermott sold its stake to Unifab (S)

headline: Barneys New York mixes commerce with romance.
abstract: Barneys New York's fall fashion catalogue called the Love Book is 47-page tale of New York City romance, told through one smitten fellow's prose written as captions with photographs of one fabulously dressed woman named Sara Lamm; book was produced in-house at cost of $350,000; photo (L)

headline: Some U.S. Cities Team Up to Attract Overseas Dollars
abstract: Many midsized US cities are increasingly looking for ways to appeal to 46.3 million international tourists who spend $84 billion in US last year; Cincinnati, Ohio, and Memphis, Tenn, for example, have formed alliances with different neighboring cities in an attempt to alter perception many travelers have of their cities; photo (L)

headline: Market Place; U.S. Healthcare a Harder Fit Than Aetna Thought
abstract: Aetna Inc., one of the nation's largest health insurers, is struggling to digest U.S. Healthcare, the health maintenance organization that it acquired more than a year ago for $8.8 billion.    In the course of integrating the two businesses, Aetna lost track of rising health-claim costs, the company acknowledged yesterday as it said that third-quarter earnings would be at least 16 percent lower than the consensus analyst estimate of $1.31 a share.

headline: METROCALL TO BUY PRONET FOR $73.8 MILLION PLUS DEBT
abstract: Metrocall Inc agrees to acquire another paging company, Pronet Inc, for $73.8 million in stock and assume about $170.3 million in Pronet's debt; combined company will have more than four million subscribers, making it nation's second-largest paging company (S)

headline: A pair of fledgling TV networks, UPN and the WB, tussle over affiliates and, maybe, survival.
abstract: Fledgling television networks WB and UPN are battling each other for affiliates and, possibly, survival; UPN is suing Sinclair Communications for switching batch of stations it manages to WB, even though Sinclair still controls five other UPN affiliates; WB chief executive Jamie Kellner outlines expansion plans; drawing (M)

headline: KROLL ASSOCIATES AGREES TO BE ACQUIRED FOR $89 MILLION
abstract: Kroll Associates, closely held international detective agency, agrees to be acquired for $89 million by O'Gara Company, publicly traded security services company (S)

headline: Manufacturing Growth Eased In August, Purchasers Report
abstract: National Association of Purchasing Management says its factory index fell to 56.8 in August from 58.6 in July, reflecting drop in orders and production (M)

headline: Dresdner Raising Money For Foreign Investment
abstract: Dresdner Bank of Germany plans to raise about 2 billion marks ($1.02 billion) to expand investment banking abroad; also reports that first-half operating profit rose 20 percent, to 1.7 billion marks, in line with expectations (S)

headline: Cash-Depleted Mexican Bank To Be Acquired by Citicorp
abstract: Citicorp plans to acquire Confia SA, cash-short Mexican bank, in transacation valued at as much as $245 million; Citicorp will pay $45 million in cash to Abaco Grupo Financiero SA, Confia's parent, and provide as much as $200 million in fresh capital to the bank; acquisition will mark biggest investment by US financial institution in a Mexican bank (M)

headline: Italian Insurer to Help Trace Policies Lost in War
abstract: Leading Italian insurance company that is seeking to expand its business in Israel offers to set up $12 million fund and investigate fate of policies that were issued by its Central European subsidiaries and confiscated by Nazi occupiers during World War II; company, Assicurazioni Generali, which is based in Trieste, is one of several big European insurance companies facing lawsuit in New York demanding compensation for confiscated policies (S)

headline: 700 Refugees Expelled From Congolese Town
abstract: Soldiers loyal to Congo's new leader, Laurent Kabila, forcibly expel almost 700 Rwandan and Burundi refugees from Kisangani; UN official condemns pre-dawn operation (S)

headline: Scott Adams Keeps the Home Office Humming
abstract: Interview with Scott Adams, creator of Dilbert cartoon character and chief executive of Dilbert Inc; photos (M)

headline: Former Bankers Trust Executive Charged in Securities Fraud Case
abstract: Alan Stricoff, former executive of Bankers Trust Co whose job it was to insure that the company complied with securities regulations, has been charged with conspiracy and securities fraud; Stricoff is arrested on charges he gave insider information to his brother, Jeffrey, and two other people that enabled them to generate $275,000 in profits from purchase of securities options of Caesars World Inc and four other Bankers Trust client companies, based on privileged information (L)

headline: Indonesia Considers Buying Radar Balloon to Patrol Gas Field
abstract: SINGAPORE  Indonesia is discussing the purchase of a long-range U.S. radar balloon to use with newly acquired reconnaissance aircraft to protect its giant Natuna gas field in the South China Sea.

headline: A Meeting That Transformed The U.S. Stance in the Mideast
abstract: Major shift in US Middle East strategy will involve speeding up timetable for talks between Israel and Palestinians to address nettlesome issues of final settlement and becoming more actively involved in negotiations between both sides; this caps months of growing unease and impatience with stalemate in region; follows June 19 meeting between Pres Clinton, Vice Pres Gore and senior foreign policy advisers at which decision was made that approach of holding back and helping Israelis and Palestinians work things out among themselves would not work; suicide bombings in Jerusalem market reportedly accelerated Clinton's decision to move, more quickly and more publicly (M)

headline: Higher Bid Seals Insurance Deal in Canada
abstract: Great-West Lifeco Inc, Canada's largest group life and health insurer, says it raised its offer to buy London Insurance Group and that companies signed agreement to prevent other bids; new agreement is valued at $2.1 billion (S)

headline: U.S. Envoy to Kenya Warns Both Sides to Restore Peace
abstract: Prudence Bushnell, US Ambassador to Kenya, strongly criticizes both Government and opposition leaders for heading down a path toward more confrontation and suggests that Kenya's foreign aid may hang in the balance if peace is not restored; says Pres Daniel arap Moi's Government must push through several political reforms if it expects world to judge elections to be held later this year as free and fair (M)

headline: A Sad Clinton Sends Message
abstract: Pres Clinton pays tribute; sends letters of condolence (S)

headline: CLEAR CHANNEL SCALES BACK DEAL WITH PAXSON
abstract: Clear Channel Communications Corp says it will not buy two professional sports teams from Paxson Communications Corp and will acquire only 348 billboards from Paxson as part of final purchase agreement between companies, valued at $600 million; Clear Channel will also buy two FM and two AM stations in West Palm Beach, Fla, that Paxson has agreed to buy from American Radio Systems Corp for $33 million (S)

headline: Scientists Press Campaign For Computer Data Security
abstract: Clinton Administration-backed proposal that would impose strict new controls on domestic use of data-scrambling equipment has drawn fresh opposition from some of nation's leading scientific, educational and engineering organizations; in letter in Congress, dozen groups including American Association for the Advancement of Science, Institute for Electronics and Electrical Engineering, American Mathematical Society and American Association of University Professors, have for first time criticized Government for its policy on control of encryption technology; proposed legislation would prohibit manufacture, sale, distribution, export or import of encryption systems that could hide communications from law-enforcement agencies after Jan 1, 1999 (L)

headline: Life Insurer, In Comeback, Is Set for Sale
abstract: Mutual Benefit Life Insurance Co, six years after it became largest American insurance company ever to collapse, has been revived, and is expected to announce that it is for sale; investment bankers estimate that company could bring as much as $1.5 billion (M)

headline: NATO TROOPS RAID SERB HARD-LINERS IN A BOSNIAN CITY
abstract: British soldiers seize six police sites in Banja Luka, Bosnia, effectively wiping out local power base of Radovan Karadzic, Bosnian Serb leader who is wanted on war-crimes charges; move by NATO-led force openly pits 31,000 peacekeepers against wartime leaders, who still command loyalty among thousands of police officers and wield near-total control of economy in Serbian-controlled portion of Bosnia; raid splits Bosnian Serb sector into areas controlled by Karadzic and his successor as sector's president, Biljana Plavsic; map (M)

headline: Kellstrom Aircraft Deal
abstract: Kellstrom Industries agrees to buy commercial aircraft and jet engines from Aerocar Aviation Corp for $20.3 million in cash (S)

headline: Campbell Soup Expected to Announce Spinoff
abstract: Campbell Soup Co plans to make major announcement in Manhattan on Sept 9, causing speculation among analysts that company plans to spin off several businesses; company reports net income rose 6 percent, to $191.9 million in its fiscal fourth quarter from $180.4 million in year-earlier quarter; sales grew 5 percent, to $1.725 billion from $1.640 billion (M)

headline: Japan Continuing To Keep Rates Low
abstract: Japan's cental bank will continue to hold interest rates at record lows to keep nation's economy on path of moderate recovery (S)

headline: SHARES OF TALBOTS FALL 20.5% ON NEWS OF EXPECTED LOSS
abstract: Shares of Talbots Inc fall 20.5 percent after retailer says it will lose money in second quarter (S)

headline: GRR HOLDINGS TO BUY GROUND ROUND AT $1.65 A SHARE
abstract: GRR Holdings LLC agrees to acquire shares of Ground Round Restaurants it does not already own for $18.7 million, or $1.65 a share, in cash (S)

headline: Millions of Dollars Pouring In To Diana's Favorite Charities
abstract: Contributions are pouring in to Princess of Wales Memorial Fund, charitable fund set up by Princess Diana's lawyers at request of mourners; some $240 million may have already been contributed, and donations could exceed $1 billion; singer Elton John donates proceeds of new recording of song Candle in the Wind, with new lyrics, he sang at funeral; Mohamed al-Fayed, father of Emad Mohamed al-Fayed, who died with her in crash, pledges at least $15 million to hospitals that were part of her charitable work and to construction of new children's hospital named for her; photo (M)

headline: NCR-Sun Marketing Deal
abstract: NCR Corp agrees to sell and support Sun Microsystems Inc's Sun Solaris software products, offering them with NCR Worldmark servers (S)

headline: Merck Shares Soar on Earnings
abstract: Merck & Co reports second quarter income rose to $1.15 billion from $972.1 million a year earlier (S)

headline: Chirac and Jospin Politely Share Bastille Day Festivities
abstract: French Pres Jacques Chirac and Socialist Prime Min Lionel Jospin politely celebrate annual Bastille Day garden party at Chirac's residence in Paris; Chirac says his political cohabitation with Socialist Prime Minister could continue well into next century; photo (M)

headline: Market Place; Signs of Life, and Wall St. Applause, for the Giant of Detroit
abstract: Market Place column on recent rise in price of General Motors Corp stock; says in last two months, GM's shares have risen about 20 percent after treading water over most of last three years; holds some analysts predict GM stock will continue its climb based largely on turnabout in company's market share; says analysts see value investors becoming interested because they believe auto stocks are cheap; graph (L)

headline: Hang Seng Bank Shares Rise on Takeover Talk
abstract: Shares of Hang Seng Bank Ltd of Hong Kong rise as much as 5.8 percent, to $108.50 (Hong Kong), or $14.10 (US), on speculation that bank might be sold to Chinese interests (S)

headline: Back-to-School Purchases Lift Retail Sales
abstract: Goldman, Sachs retail composite index rose 5.7 percent in August compared with the month a year earlier; it is second consecutive month, and third time this year, in which nation's merchants reported increases of more than 5 percent; graph; table (L)

headline: Malaysia's Conspiracy Theory Draws Criticism From Albright
abstract: Sec of State Madeleine K Albright and deputies, who are attending annual summit of Assn of Southeast Asian Nations in Kuala Lumpur, reject allegations by Prime Min Mahathir Mohamad of Malaysia that financier George Soros has sabotaged Southeast Asian currencies because member countries admitted Myanmar into organization; Soros, who monitors human rights in Myanmar, denies allegations (M)

headline: Warner Music Names a New Top Executive
abstract: Warner Music Group confirms it has signed exclusive multiyear agreement with David Foster, an award-winning arranger, composer, producer and musician, to become senior vice president of the group; financial terms undisclosed (S)

headline: At Tiananmen Square, Exuberance Is Reined In
abstract: Exuberance is reined in by Chinese authorities in Beijing, where select crowd of approximately 70,000 workers, students, police families and Communist Party members are bused to Tiananmen Square for celebration marking return of Hong Kong to Chinese rule; square is closed to general public for elaborate fireworks display and scripted entertainment extravaganza; photo (M)

headline: U.S. ASSAILS CHINA OVER SUPPRESSION OF RELIGIOUS LIFE
abstract: State Department issues first comprehensive review of persecution of Christian groups worldwide, and it sharply criticizes China for suppressing religious worship and urges Pres Boris Yeltsin to veto legislation restricting religious freedom in Russia; accuses China of regularly violating constitutional promise of religious freedom by restricting all actual religious practice to Government-authorized religious organizations and registered places of worship; expresses concern over new legislation pending in Russian Parliament restricting religious freedom in Russia for first time since fall of Soviet Union; crackdown by China on unregistered Catholic and Protestant movements, and suppression of Christians in Iran, Saudi Arabia and Singapore discussed (M)

headline: WHITMAN TO REVAMP AND TAKE $120 MILLION CHARGE
abstract: Whitman Corp will take about $120 million in charges against second-half earnings to restructure its Hussman, Midas International and Pepsi-Cola General Bottlers unit (S)

headline: People
abstract: * David Henke was named to the new position of executive vice president and creative director on the General Motors corporate account at N. W. Ayer & Partners, New York, a unit of MacManus Group. He had been executive vice president and executive creative services director at Temerlin McClain, Irving, Tex., a unit of Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt.

headline: STOCKS FALL 3.11%, THE MOST SINCE '91, AS ECONOMY GAINS
abstract: Stock market plummets, with Dow Jones industrial average suffering its worst one-day selloff in nearly six years; Dow plunges 247.37 points, or 3.1 percent, to 7,694.66; collapse leaves stock market wobbly and investors uncertain, capping nasty weeklong decline in prices that began just after Dow reached its most recent peak; even with recent decline, Dow is up 19.3 percent for year; many analysts insist that stocks were due for pause after rally that took Dow up 29 percent since spring; graph; photo (M)

headline: With the Old Hatreds, Ulster Faces New Marching Season
abstract: Northern Ireland braces for July and marching season, series of full-dress pageants commemorating battles of past 300 years between Catholics and Protestants who are still killing each other; as in past two years, people living in nearby Catholic areas of Portadown vow to block Protestants' parade passage through their neighborhood; Portadown was site of violent five-day standoff year ago; map (M)

headline: 'Euroskeptics' Offer Lesson in Playing Politics on the World Wide Web
abstract: 'Euroskeptic' groups, which oppose European Union and common currency, have emerged as one of most pugnacious political movements on Internet; groups have wildly different goals and styles, but their World Wide Web sites are now tightly linked; have created textbook example of how political groups ignored by media can use Web as political tool; table (M)

headline: Ulster Protestants Reject Disarmament Bid
abstract: Northern Ireland's main Protestant political parties vote to reject proposal by British and Irish Governments on methods and timing for disarming Irish Republican Army and Protestant paramilitary groups; British and Irish officials say setback will not kill peace talks (M)

headline: Utilities May Bear Brunt Of New Clean Air Rules
abstract: Much of American industry is overwhelmingly opposed to new clean air regulations announced last week by Clinton Administration; auto makers, truckers, petrochemical producers, utilities and other trade organizations are poised to campaign in Congress and courts to delay, limit or kill proposed new rules; it appears likely that utilities in Midwest and South will bear brunt of new regulations; utilities will have to invest in scrubbers and other pollution control equipment; some utilities in Northeast endorse new standards, which might help them compete with Southern and Midwestern utilities that have been operating with fewer environmental constraints (L)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: GENERAL ELECTRIC CO.,  Fairfield, Conn., said its GE Aircraft Engines unit had received a $600 million order from Continental Airlines for engines to power 35 new jets.    CHESAPEAKE CORP.,  Richmond, a paper company, said it would close two packaging plants and lay off most of its 200 workers, resulting in an unspecified second-quarter charge.    CLOROX CO.,  Oakland, Calif., the maker of Clorox bleach and Pine-Sol household cleaners, said its board had approved a 2-for-1 stock split and a 10 percent increase in its dividend.

headline: Sawyer Riley Wins 3 Creative Awards
abstract: Sawyer Riley Compton in Atlanta takes top honors, winning three awards at Creative Excellence in Business Advertising competition sponsored by American Business Press in New York (S)

headline: Profit Up 8% at Germany's Biggest Utility
abstract: RWE AG, Germany's largest diversified utility, says that profit and sales each rose 8 percent in latest fiscal year, slightly higher than expectations; profit in fiscal year, which ended on June 30, rose to 1.3 billion marks, or $741.9 million (S)

headline: North Korea to Accept Private U.S. Medical Aid
abstract: North Korea to let private relief organization Americares airlift about $23 million worth of donated medicines to nation for emergency use; Americares says some volunteer doctors and nurses will stay in North Korea to oversee distribution of medicines (S)

headline: MARKETS TIMING
abstract: MONDAY  The Agriculture Department reports on planting progress for seven crops.  The National Association of Realtors reports on home resales for July.    TUESDAY  The Commerce Department reports on July durable goods orders.  The Conference Board releases its consumer confidence index for August.  Mitsubishi Bank/Schroder Wertheim releases its weekly retail sales report.  LJR Redbook Research releases its weekly retail sales survey.    WEDNESDAY  The Mortgage Bankers Association of America releases its weekly report on mortgage applications.  The Energy Department releases its weekly report on petroleum stocks, production, imports and refinery utilization.    THURSDAY  The Commerce Department reports its second estimate of economic growth for the second quarter; it initially saw an annual rate of 2.2 percent.  The Labor Department reports initial weekly claims for unemployment insurance.     FRIDAY  The Commerce Department reports personal income and spending for July.  The Commerce Department reports on July new home sales.  The Purchasing Management Association of Chicago releases its manufacturing index for August.

headline: Defying U.S., French Firm To Explore for Gas in Iran
abstract: French oil company, Total SA, in direct challenge to US, teams up with Russia's Gazprom and Petronas of Malaysia in signing $2 billion contract to explore for gas in Iran; deal is signed despite Clinton Administration's warnings that US will issue trade sanctions against any company that violates 1996 law that mandates action against any foreign company that props up Iranian Government by investing more than $40 million there; move is likely to lead to additional trade frictions between US and European Union (M)

headline: Milken's Honorees, but Not His Proteges
abstract: Survey of educators who received money from Milken Family Foundation, which has recognized 1,170 exceptional young teachers since 1985, shows that most of winners paid bills or took vacations instead of investing money; financial results of some of teachers who did invest money discussed; photo (L)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: WASHINGTON MUTUAL INC., Seattle, completed its merger with Great Western Financial Corp., of Chatsworth, Calif., creating the nation's largest savings and loan.     BOISE CASCADE OFFICE PRODUCTS CORP., Itasca, Ill., a unit of Boise Cascade, will buy Jean-Paul Guisset S.A., France's third-largest direct marketer of office products, for an undisclosed amount.

headline: CREATIVE COMPUTERS OFFERS $43 MILLION FOR ELEK-TEK
abstract: Creative Computers Inc agrees to pay $43 million to acquire Elek-Tek Inc; Elek-Tek files for protection under Chapter 11 of US Bankruptcy Code, and Creative Computers signs deal in connection with Elek-Tek's bankruptcy filing (S)

headline: Fresenius Income Nearly Doubles
abstract: Fresenius AG indicates its second-quarter net income almost doubled; profit rose to 65 million marks ($35.9 million) in three months ended June 30, from 33 million marks a year earlier (S)

headline: Clinton Seeks to Make Trade Deals Congress Can't Amend
abstract: Pres Clinton, arguing that economic links now form core of relations between most nations, begins tough struggle with nation's labor unions and much of own party in Congress over his authority to negotiate new trade deals he says are critical to US world leadership; portrays stakes as far more than dispute about job losses or effect of trade on environment; says without ability to negotiate such accords, he will be crippled in conducting foreign policy (M)

headline: Asian Leaders Assail 'Rogue Speculators' : Tough Talk Fails to Aid Currencies
abstract: SUBANG JAYA, Malaysia  Southeast Asian political leaders angrily assailed a fresh wave of speculation against their currencies Thursday, urging united action against a "security threat" and "a well-planned effort to undermine" the region's economies.

headline: 9.5% Growth In China Stuns Experts Again
abstract: Chinese Government announces that gross domestic product grew 9.5 percent in first half of year, compared with first half of 1996; during same period, retail price index, China's benchmark for inflation, rose just 1.8 percent; exports grew 26 percent, to $80.8 billion; imports remained steady at $63 billion; sharp decline in inflation rate has surprised even most optimistic forecasters (L)

headline: SHONEY'S CALLS A SPECIAL SHAREHOLDER MEETING SEPT. 25
abstract: Shoney's Inc calls meeting for Sept 25 at which shareholders will be asked to vote on dissident shareholder group's proposal to replace company's board; dissident group is led by Raymond D Schoenbaum, whose father, Alex, founded the restaurant chain (S)

headline: Labor Showdowns: The Effect on Stocks
abstract: Outlook for contract negotiations and other strikes that could affect US economy discussed in light of Teamsters walkout at UPS (S)

headline: Diana: Shy Girl Who Became 'Queen of People's Hearts'
abstract: Obituary of Diana, Princess of Wales; she was born Lady Diana Spencer on July 1, 1961, in Sandringham, Norfolk, to Frances Shand Kydd and eighth Earl Spencer; parents were divorced in 1969; father died in 1992; photos (L)

headline: Case Against Columbia Includes Tapes of Executive's Discussions
abstract: Robert Whiteside, executive responsible for obtaining Federal reimbursement for Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corp, was secretly recorded by Government witness in April as part of criminal investigation into possible fraud involving company hospital in Florida; Whiteside was one of three Columbia officials indicted on criminal charges last month; draft transcript of tape was one of hundreds of pages of documents that the Government has offered to turn over to lawyers for three defendants; other documents include cost reports from 1987 through 1996 for Columbia's Fawcett Memorial Hospital in Port Charlotte, Fla; documents also include correspondence between Blue Cross and Blue Shield of Florida and Basic American Medical Inc, which owned Fawcett before company was acquired by Columbia; Florida Blue Cross served as what is known as agent of Federal Medicare program, conducting audits of Fawcett for Government (L)

headline: KATZ MEDIA TO BE ACQUIRED FOR $155 MILLION
abstract: Evergreen Media Corp and Chancellor Broadcasting Co, which plan to merge, say they have agreed to buy Katz Media Group Inc for about $155 million and assumption of $218 million in debt (S)

headline: India's Ex-Premier Is To Go to Trial
abstract: Indian court clears way for trial of former Prime Min P V Narasimha Rao and four of his Cabinet colleagues in four-year-old vote-buying scandal (S)

headline: DONALDSON, LUFKIN & JENRETTE TO ACQUIRE BRITISH FIRM
abstract: Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities Corp acquires London Global Securities Inc, a British stock lender, from Paloma Partners LLC of Greenwich, Conn; terms undisclosed (S)

headline: Current-Account Deficit Falls in South Korea
abstract: South Korea's current-account deficit fell 73 percent in June, to $360 million (S)

headline: Business Best Sellers
abstract: HARD COVER    THIS MONTH/LAST MONTH    +1/1 THE MILLIONAIRE NEXT DOOR by Thomas J. Stanley and William D. Danko (Longstreet Press, $22). How to become wealthy in America.     +2/3 THE DILBERT FUTURE by Scott Adams (Harper Business, $25). Satirical speculations, in words and cartoons, about the 21st century.     *+3/2 SUCCESS IS A CHOICE by Rick Pitino with Bill Reynolds (Broadway Books, $25). The basketball coach offers a 10-step program for achieving goals.     +4/4 STOCK MARKET MIRACLES by Wade B. Cook (Lighthouse Publishing Group, $24.95). An author advises sticking to one strategy and making many small deals in rapid succession.     *+5/5 WALL STREET MONEY MACHINE by Wade B. Cook (Lighthouse Publishing Group, $24.95). Strategies for enhancing cash flow and wealth.     6/-- THE QUICKENING by Art Bell (Paper Chase Press, $24.95). A discussion of accelerating trends toward global economics and government.    +7/6 BUSINESS BUY THE BIBLE  by Wade B. Cook (Lighthouse Publishing Group, $16.95). Applying God's principles to saving and investing.     8/8 SELLING THE INVISIBLE by Harry Beckwith (Warner, $15). A guide to service marketing.     +9/7 THE SEVEN SPIRITUAL LAWS OF SUCCESS by Deepak Chopra (Amber-Allen/New World Library, $14). How to generate all forms of wealth.     10/-- DANGEROUS COMPANY by James O'Shea and Charles Madigan (Times Business/Random House, $27.50). Management consulting firms can ruin businesses they were brought in to save.    PAPERBACK    THIS MONTH/LAST MONTH    +1/1 A CIVIL ACTION by Jonathan Harr (Vintage, $13). A lawsuit brought by homeowners against industrial polluters.     +2/2 THE SEVEN HABITS OF HIGHLY EFFECTIVE PEOPLE by Stephen R. Covey (Fireside/Simon & Schuster, $14). Principles for success.     +3/4 THE DILBERT PRINCIPLE by Scott Adams (HarperBusiness, $11.95). The foibles of the business world.     +4/5 THE MOTLEY FOOL INVEST-MENT GUIDE by David and Tom Gardner (Fireside/Simon & Schuster, $12). How inexperienced investors can prosper.     5/3 CASUAL DAY HAS GONE TOO FAR by Scott Adams (Andrews & McMeel, $9.95). More workplace satire from Dilbert and Dogbert.    *6/-- THE TRUTH ABOUT MONEY by Ric Edelman (Georgetown University Press, $19.95). A personal finance manual.    Rankings are based on August sales figures of almost 4,000 bookstores and of wholesalers serving 50,000 hardcover retailers and 60,000 paperback retailers (gift shops, department stores, newsstands, supermarkets). The numbers are statistically weighted to represent sales in all such outlets nationwide.     *Indicates that a book's sales are barely distinguishable from those of the book above.     +Some bookstores report receiving bulk orders of these titles.

headline: An industry women's group passes judgment with the Good, the Bad and the Ugly Awards.
abstract: Advertising Women of New York, organization founded in 1912, is officially passing judgment on myriad images of women in sales pitches for products; organization on Sept 24 will present initial honors and dishonors in what is intended to be annual event called the Good, the Bad and the Ugly Awards (L)

headline: AMERUS LIFE AGREES TO BUY DELTA LIFE FOR $163 MILLION
abstract: Amerus Life Holdings Inc agrees to buy Delta Life Corp for $163 million in cash (S)

headline: Misdirected
abstract: New York Times is looking for stories on embarrassing experience of sending computer message to wrong destination; drawing (S)

headline: CHRYSLER SAYS IT WILL CLOSE OFFICE IN BEIJING
abstract: Chrysler Corp plans to close its Beijing, China, office, saying China's sluggish automobile market offers few opportunities for new projects (S)

headline: U.S. Trade Gap Widened to $10.3 Billion
abstract: Commerce Department reports US trade gap widened sharply in July, to $10.34 billion, biggest since January, from $8.29 billion in June; lower exports and higher imports both contributed to surprisingly big rise; deficit with Japan was $5.2 billion; graph (L)

headline: A 'Socko' Albright Steals the Show
abstract: SUBANG JAYA, Malaysia  The Burmese foreign minister, Ohn Gyaw, best known to the outside world as the impassive face of the Burmese military regime, went on stage and performed a traditional Burmese dance with his wife and daughter, amid great hilarity from the audience as he giggled at his own clumsiness.

headline: Greenspan Silence on Stocks Speaks Volumes to Investors
abstract: Analysis of Federal Reserve Board chairman Alan Greenspan's testimony before Congress on state of economy focuses on Greenspan's silence on stocks; says Greenspan appeared to acknowledge that he was wrong in December when he coined the phrase 'irrational exuberance' to describe investor psychology; holds many economists believe that Greenspan's concerns have been assuaged by strong profits American businesses have enjoyed this year, making stock prices relative to earnings less inflated than they might have seemed (L)

headline: HNC SOFTWARE IN $190 MILLION DEAL TO BUY COMPREVIEW
abstract: Shares of HNC Software Inc rise 11 percent after company says it will acquire closely held Compreview Inc for about $190 million in stock; HNC stock closes at $42, up $4.125 a share (S)

headline: Lowest-Caste Hindu Takes Office as India's President
abstract: K R Narayanan, member of Hinduism's untouchable caste, is inaugurated President of India; post is ceremonial, but could give him key role in era of unstable coalition governments; photo (M)

headline: Swedish Bank to Pay Penalties in U.S.
abstract: Skandinaviska Enskilda Banken, Swedish bank, signs consent order to pay $5 million in penalties, divided equally between Federal Reserve Bank of New York and New York State Banking Department; banking regulators contended that bank's branch in New York City did not properly report some transactions between 1993 and 1996 (S)

headline: Ore-Ida Narrows Its Review to 4
abstract: Ore-Ida Foods specialty products division of H J Heinz Co narrows review on its account for frozen pasta, snack and wrap-sandwich brands to four finalists (S)

headline: G.M.'s Deals For Olympics Said to Cost $900 Million
abstract: General Motors Corp's decision to sponsor Olympics through 2008 is seen as wager that next six Winter and Summer Games will galvanize interest of fans, viewers and potential car buyers as they have in recent years; company reportedly will buy $500 million in media time on five NBC telecasts, and will invest $400 million in cash and vehicles to support training of 44 national teams (M)

headline: A Dying Village Is Fertile Soil for Bookworms
abstract: Montolieu, France, once dying farm village, has reinvented self as mecca for book lovers; now has 12 bookstores filled with rare and secondhand books and attracted almost 100,000 visitors last year; map; photo (M)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent                Previous   Year          Yesterday   Day   Ago               PRIME RATE   8.50   8.50   8.25        DISCOUNT RATE   5.00   5.00   5.00        FEDERAL FUNDS*   6.50   5.52   7.80        3-MO. TREAS. BILLS   5.12   4.99   5.12        6-MO. TREAS. BILLS   5.14   5.02   5.22        10-YR. TREAS. INFL.**   3.66   3.65   N.A.        10-YR. TREAS. NOTES   6.49   6.44   6.74        30-YR. TREAS. headline: In the Dignity Department, U.P.S. Wins
abstract: Prof Jeffrey A Sonnenfeld article scores Teamsters Brotherhood head Ron Carey for leading strike against United Parcel Service, which he lauds as progressive company (M)

headline: UROHEALTH RAISES ITS OFFER TO ACQUIRE IMAGYN MEDICAL
abstract: Urohealth Systems Inc raises its offer to acquire medical devises maker Imagyn Medical Inc to $55.3 million in stock (S)

abstract: In percent                Previous   Year          Yesterday   Day   Ago               PRIME RATE   8.50   8.50   8.25        DISCOUNT RATE   5.00   5.00   5.00        FEDERAL FUNDS*   5.63   5.57   5.28        3-MO. headline: NASA Aides and House Panel Debate Safety of Mir Station
abstract: NASA officials, in testimony before House Science Committee, say it is safe to send Americans to live aboard troubled Mir space station, but committee members say further stays aboard Russian craft pose unacceptable risks (S)

headline: Prosecution of Photographers Is Urged
abstract: Lawyer for Mohammed el-Fayed, whose son was killed in automobile crash in Paris with Princess Diana of Wales, urges prosecutors to bring charges of involuntary homicide against photographers who reportedly chased limousine at time of accident (S)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent                Previous   Year          Yesterday   Day   Ago               PRIME RATE   8.50   8.50   8.25        DISCOUNT RATE   5.00   5.00   5.00        FEDERAL FUNDS*   5.75   5.44   6.09        3-MO. headline: Besieged as Undemocratic, Islamist Turks Seek Democracies' Aid
abstract: Former Turkish Prime Necmettin Erkaban, who during year in power sought to move Turkey away from identification with Europe and West, is appealing to Western countries to help keep Islamist Welfare Party from being banned; prosecutors have asked country's Supreme Court to ban party on ground that its pro-Islamic policies are aimed at subverting secular order (M)

headline: A Tale of Murder and Sex Slaves to Stun Dostoyevsky
abstract: Aleksandr Komin is charged with killing two women and two men in Vyatskiye Polyany, Russia; Komin says he lured homeless women and kept them chained in bunker; says he starved, beat and had sex with his captives; two of three women who survived had word 'slave' crudely tatooed on their foreheads; map; photos (M)

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: Debt     * BellSouth Capital Funding, Atlanta, is selling $500 million of bonds due in 2097 through Morgan Stanley, Dean Witter, Discover & Co. The bonds are noncallable, carry an interest rate of 7.12 percent and are priced at par.

headline: A New President Is Named at Columbia/HCA Healthcare
abstract: Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corp names Jack O Bovender Jr president and chief operating officer; he replaces David Vandewater, who resigned under pressure (S)

headline: Accounts
abstract: * McCabe & Co., New York, was awarded two accounts for which billings have not been determined: Reliance Group Holdings, New York, as the insurance company's first agency, and Petrie Retail, Secaucus, N.J., for the reintroduction of its Marianne and Stuart's chains.

headline: Many Reported Unready To Face Year 2000 Bug
abstract: Study by Gartner Group shows that large proportion of businesses and government agencies around world are not properly preparing for effect that year 2000 will have on their computer systems, increasing possibility of potentially serious disruptions as end of century approaches (M)

headline: Product Delay Sends Microsoft Shares Lower
abstract: Shares of Microsoft Corp fall more than 5 percent in heavy trading after company confirms it will delay shipments of Windows 98, new version of its dominant operating system software; Microsoft says introduction of software will be pushed off into second quarter of 1998 instead of first quarter; share price falls $7.25, to $130.6875 (L)

headline: Suitor Drops $1.9 Billion Bid For Utility
abstract: Calenergy Co is dropping its $1.9 billion hostile takeover bid for New York State Electric and Gas Corp after failing in its first step, an offer for 9.9 percent stake in the utility; takeover would have given Calenergy, large power producer with headquarters in Omaha, a base in Northeast from which to sell its electricity as states in region open their utility markets to competition; last month, Calenergy offered $159 million in tender offer to acquire 9.9 percent of utility's stock (L)

headline: Playing for Profits
abstract: Descriptions of some popular on-line video games; photos (M)

headline: Informix Says It Is Restating Results Again
abstract: Informix Corp says continuing audit has shown that it must restate 1996 and 1995 financial results to greater degree than previously reported; company's shares plummet on disclosure; Informix says Nasdaq stock market initiated proceedings to delist Informix stock as result of company's delay in filing its second-quarter earings report (M)

headline: SEAGATE TECHNOLOGY TO ACQUIRE REST OF QUINTA
abstract: Seagate Technology Inc will buy remaining part of Quinta Corp that it does not own for as much as $325 million (S)

headline: Noranda Puts Mill on Sale
abstract: Noranda Forest Inc is looking for buyer for its only newsprint mill in Masson-Angers, Quebec (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: IMC Global to Acquire Freeport-McMoran Inc.  IMC Global, fortifying its position as the world's dominant producer of phosphate fertilizers, agreed to buy Freeport-McMoran Inc. for about $750 million.    The deal undoes a snarl or two in the still-tangled corporate realm of James R. Moffett, chairman of Freeport-McMoran Inc. and of the separate and larger Freeport-McMoran Copper and Gold, and would give investors in the battered shares of Freeport-McMoran Inc. a premium. $(Page D2.$)

headline: Pomp Pushes the Poorest From Mother Teresa's Last Rites
abstract: Mother Teresa is laid to rest in Calcutta, India, after funeral that is largely closed to poor she had devoted her life to helping; many foreign dignitaries attend funeral; Hillary Rodham Clinton represents US; photos (M)

headline: Mexico's Recovery Just Bypasses the Poor
abstract: Recent boasts by Mexican Government that economy has recovered from peso crisis in 1994 seem like cruel jokes, especially to residents of impoverished village of Macuila, where record-setting pace of Mexican stock market, shrinking interest rates and vigorous peso are meaningless; gap between rich and poor, which has been enormous, has widened since peso devaluation; just as large is gap in economic recovery, which seems to have taken hold at only highest income levels; map; photos (M)

headline: Ex-Snapple Chief Takes South Beach Posts
abstract: Michael B Schott, who headed Snapple juice and iced tea business during last 10 months of its ownership by Quaker Oats Co, becomes president and chief operating officer of South Beach Beverage Co (S)

headline: Fleet Taking Another Fork In Road to Bank Expansion
abstract: Fleet Financial Group Inc, with its $1.6 billion acquisition of Quick & Reilly Group Inc, is betting that buying discount brokerage firm with national reach is cheaper and safer way of building its securities business quickly around the country; some of its competitors have chosen to acquire brokerage firms with underwriting and capital markets expertise, particularly in high-technology companies and other fast-growing industries; with its purchase of Quick & Reilly, Fleet Financial will acquire holding company for financial services subsidiaries, US Clearing Corp, JJC Specialist Corp and Nash, Weiss & Co; graph (L)

headline: Treasury Prices Rally Again After Report on Wage Costs
abstract: Treasury prices extend their rally after reports show muted increase in labor costs; graph shows Treasury yield (M)

headline: As Nurses Take On Primary Care, Physicians Are Sounding Alarms
abstract: Highly trained nurses are assuming charge of patients without immediate supervision of doctors, practice endorsed by more and more private insurers as well as Medicare and Medicaid, but vehemently opposed by medical establishment and many doctors; nursing experts say nurse-practitioners can work in primary care as effectively as physicians and can add benefits of extra time and attention to whole person; private insurers and health care industry view innovation as additional tool to help cut costs; medical establishment says public has right to ask for real doctor, and must be protected from representation that nurse clinician is equivalent in training to physician; maps; photo (M)

headline: Muslims, With NATO Escort, Return to a Village in Bosnia
abstract: British troops escort group of displaced Muslims back to village of Donja Sibenica in Bosnia; this is second effort at resettlement this month by United Nations High Commissioner of Refugees and NATO-led peacekeepers; first small group of returnees were driven out of village by mob of ethnic Croats who threatened to kill them; those in latest group say they were led to understand they would be protected by British troops, but local company commander says troops will stay in village only few days before departing, then they will set up mobile patrols; resettlement effort appears to be latest example of new resolve on part of NATO commanders to make supreme push to make peace agreement work; map (M)

headline: I.B.M. to Introduce Faster Version Of Popular Minicomputer
abstract: International Business Machines Corp to offer new, much faster version of its AS/400 minicomputer (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: LITTON INDUSTRIES, Woodland Hills, Calif., a supplier of technology defense and information systems, said its PRC subsidiary had received a two-year, $693 million contract to provide computers and software for the Defense Department's military health service system.     ALLIANCE ENTERTAINMENT CORP., New York, said it had received a $2.2 million cash offer for its Red Ant Records from the music concern Bust-It Records, countering Wasserstein Perella & Co.'s offer to buy back most of the label it helped finance.

headline: GENICOM BUYS DIGITAL'S PRINTING SYSTEMS UNIT
abstract: Genicom Corp buys Digital Equipment Corp's printing systems business for undisclosed price, broadening its reach in helping companies set up and maintain computer printers (S)

headline: The Subaru is not a Porsche, but new ads try to close the gap.
abstract: Temerlin McCain's print and television ad campaign for Subaru of America Inc emphasizes all-wheel-drive feature of Subaru vehicles, comparing it with system used to improve traction on luxury cars (Advertising column); photo (S)

headline: Debt Ratings Affirmed On Nomura and Bank
abstract: Dai-Ichi Kangyo Bank and Nomura Securities, which were peanlized for making payoffs to racketeer, have debt ratings affirmed by Standard & Poor's (S)

headline: MONROC HIRES DILLON, READ TO RAISE ITS MARKET VALUE
abstract: Monroc Inc hires investment bankers Dillon, Read & Co to examine ways to raise its market value, including possible merger or sale (S)

headline: Sailing on a Rising Tide of Juice; The Almost Accidental Success of Nantucket Nectars
abstract: Profile of Nantucket Nectars, a $60 million 'new age' juice-drink empire begun in mid-1990's; Tom Scott and Tom First say they had no complex strategy when they started company from small boat in Nantucket, Mass; table; photos (L)

headline: U.S. May Cut Back on Aid Until Cambodian Election
abstract: United States aides say US plans to suspend all but basic humanitarian aid to Cambodia until new elections are held under international monitoring; see move as only way to prevent Hun Sen from outright power grab (M)

headline: Clinton to Rekindle Old Debate on Trade
abstract: This week President Clinton plans to leap into what promises to be a bruising battle over the expansion of Nafta and of his powers to negotiate other international trade accords.

headline: The greatest good for the greatest number? Try Lojack.
abstract: Economic Scene column on Lojack Co's auto-alarm system to prevent theft; drawing (L)

headline: House That Lou Built Reflects a New I.B.M.
abstract: IBM will open new Z-shaped headquarters in Armonk, NY, on Sept 18; building breaks mold of traditional button-down corporate office in favor of more open workplace; structure signifies postmodern, postdownsizing, employee-empowerment era that company now represents; photo (L)

headline: Child of Oil and Gas Merger Starts Growing Right Away
abstract: Pioneer Natural Resources agrees to buy Chauvco Resources, a Canadian oil and gas company, for $975 million in stock; deal, which will add Chauvco's Canadian and Argentine properties to Pioneer's primarily US operations, will make Pioneer second-largest independent petroleum producer in the nation (L)

headline: Currency Trading Schemes Leave Unwary Investors Holding the Bag
abstract: Fraudulent schemes involving currency trading are on rise, replacing precious metals as commodity of choice among investment frauds; attributed to growing awareness of currency market, as large companies increasingly try to minimize effects of changes in value of dollar against foreign currencies, and as major speculators generate headlines; law enforcement officials say schemes may have increased since US Supreme Court decision in February 1997, removing Commodity Futures Trading Commission from regulating certain parts of foreign currency market; fraudulent currency trading scheme involving AEL Fund Inc, which was operated by 35-year-old Russian immigrant, Alex Efrosman, described (M)

headline: Spain to Sell Part Of Utility Stake
abstract: Spanish Government says it will sell up to additional 35 percent of Empresa Nacional de Electricidad SA, state-controlled electricity producer known as Endesa; SEPI, state holding company that owns 67 percent of Endesa, says offer, scheduled for October, will be largest privatization ever carried out in Spain; SEPI expects sale to generate between $4.9 billion and $7.1 billion (S)

headline: U.N. Chief Promises to Overhaul Organization From the Top Down
abstract: Sec Gen Kofi Annan proposes sweeping reorganization of United Nations management system, General Assembly; rejects demands by UN critics for large staff and program cuts, holding goal is to make UN more efficient, not smaller, news conference; calls for naming of Deputy Secretary General, reinstatement of Disarmament Department, strengthened role for human rights office and creation of development fund with money saved in adminstrative reforms; Sen Jesse Helms's aide says proposal falls short of changes Annan pledged in earlier meetings with Helms; diagram; graphs (L)

headline: Looking Glass; Inspiration in Every Corner
abstract: Lisa de los Reyes explains how and where she found tchotchkes for every corner of set of new situation comedy, Union Square; photos (M)

headline: $1.9 Billion Hostile Bid For Utility
abstract: Calenergy, large independent power producer, announces it has begun hostile takeover attempt to buy New York State Electric and Gas Corp, a utility that serves 804,000 customers in upstate New York; bid is aimed in part at giving Calenergy a base in Northeast to sell its electricity as states in region move toward opening their utility markets to competition, allowing customers to choose their power supplies (L)

headline: INSIDE
abstract: INVESTING IT /Page 5/   Patience has paid off for investors in Cummins Engine. Its cost-cutting has helped it shine in a rebounding truck market. By Barnaby J. Feder.    MUTUAL FUNDS /Page 6/   Bridgeway is a little fund family with some big performance numbers, but it has had a few problems in operations. By Edward Wyatt.

headline: Korean Won Tumbles To a Record Low
abstract: South Korean won tumbles to record low as mounting bad loans and turmoil in Asian currency markets prompts banks and companies to buy dollars to insure they can repay foreign debt (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Investment Firm to Buy Corning Consumer Lines  Corning, whose name has for decades been synonymous with Pyrex, Corning Ware and other household brands, said that it would sell a controlling interest in its consumer products operations as it focuses instead on high-technology businesses.    The buyer is AEA Investors, an investment firm that is paying $975 million, considerably more than analysts had expected. $(Page D4.$)

headline: Jews Oust Arab Tenants From House In Jerusalem
abstract: Militant Jewish settlers move into house in Arab neighborhood of East Jerusalem after ousting tenants; action draws condemnation from Prime Min Benjamin Netanyahu, Jewish peace advocates and Palestinian officials, but strong support from Israeli right; is embarrassment and challenge for Netanyahu, coming immediately after visit by US Sec of State Madeleine K Albright, during which she urged Israel to cease actions that provoke Palestinians; comes day after Netanyahu reafirmed opposition to construction of apartments for Jews on adjacent site, in Arab neighborhood of Ras al-Amud; photo (M)

headline: Ford Offers Workers Bonus to Relocate
abstract: Ford Motor Co offers workers who are scheduled to be laid off in Lorain, Ohio, bonuses of up to $45,000 if they agree to move to truck plant in Louisville (S)

headline: Bankruptcy Commission Faces an Inquiry
abstract: National Bankruptcy Review Commission, charged with recommending ways to revamp nation's bankruptcy laws, is examining whether a conference call among five of its members, led by Federal Judge Edith H Jones, amounted to secret meeting that may have violated Federal rules; conference call, on July 24, focused on proposals by commission to change requirements by which individuals can seek protection from creditors, a hotly contested topic on panel's agenda; photo of Jones (M)

headline: New Build-to-Order Desktops at CompUSA
abstract: Computer retailer CompUSA Inc introduces new line of build-to-order desktop computers in challenge to Dell Computer Corp and Gateway 2000 Inc (S)

headline: MARKET TIMING
abstract: List of upcoming dates important to business and financial world

headline: Islamic Rule Weighs Heavily for Afghans
abstract: Kabul is place of deepening frustration and fear under harsh Islamic rule of Afghanistan's Taliban movement; young Taliban militants roam city seeking targets and extracting ransoms; Taliban says it will review controversial ban on women from work and girls from school when security situation improves; map; photo (M)

headline: U.S. Is Alone in Seeking Loophole in Ban on Mines
abstract: United States negotiators are nearly isolated at international conference, Oslo, as they try to amend draft treaty banning antipersonnel land mines; seek number of key changes they say are needed to protect American troops; want to allow mines along border between North and South Korea, allow clusters of mines that eventually self-detonate and let any nation wait nine years before complying with major elements of treaty; Eric Newsom, chief American delegate, comments, interview; United Nations Sec Gen Kofi Annan calls for total ban, speech (M)

headline: Chief of Hughes Again Emerges as a Top Candidate to Head AT&T
abstract: C Michael Armstrong, chief executive of Hughes Electronics, has emerged as top candidate to head AT&T Corp; Armstrong would succeed chairman Robert E Allen; Armstrong still faces strong competition from John D Zeglis, AT&T's vice chairman and popular internal cnadidate; photos (L)

headline: High Technology Could Add New Life to an Old Product
abstract: New process is enabling chemical companies to make basic plastics stronger, clearer and harder and offers prospect of less expensive goods; for the chemical companies it could mean huge new profits from lackluster old products; through chemcial process known as metallocene catalysis, basic plastics normally used to make things like coffee cups and trash bags, will soon be adapted to more profitable ones reserved for high-performance plastics like polycarbonate and nylon, which can sell for twice as much; chart; photos (L)

headline: Kodak Warns Of Weak Sales; Stock Drops
abstract: Eastman Kodak Co warns that third-quarter sales and earnings could be below expectations, and its stock tumbles in late trading; company also says it will 'eliminate chronic money losers and nonstrategic units' but does not give details; shares of Eastman Kodak fall 8.4 percent, or $5.50, to $60; graph (L)

headline: Stable Prices and Low Wage Pressures Seen
abstract: Latest regional economic survey by Federal Reserve finds economy is continuing to expand moderately with subdued wage pressures and stable prices over all; map (M)

headline: 8-Foot Barrier Closes Part of Thai Border : Malaysia Slams the Door On a Troubled Neighbor
abstract: PEDANG BESAR, Thailand  Bicha Ponboon, a sprightly man in his early 20s, lives on Wall Street, an address that has more in common with downtown Manhattan than just a name. Mr. Bicha's neighborhood is full of dealers and traders whose main business centers on commodities and a thriving service industry.

headline: Ericsson Says Net Income Rose 45% in Quarter
abstract: Ericsson AB says second-quarter net income rose 45 percent; profit rose to 2.788 billion kronor ($355 million), from 1.926 billion kronor in second quarter last year (S)

headline: Suspense Ads Focus On New Oldsmobile
abstract: Two ads for General Motors' Oldsmobile Intrigue sedan have been playing at 141 movie theaters nationwide as part of contest that urges viewers to guess who made car; ads have short mysterious plots reminiscent of spy thrillers (Advertising Column) (S)

headline: In Fight Over Privatization, Netanyahu Wins a Round
abstract: Israeli Prime Min Benjamin Netanyahu apparently wins first round of battle with powerful public-workers unions over plan to sell 12.5 percent stake in Bezek, Government-owned telephone monopoly, to Merrill Lynch; weathers several days of disrupted phone services and one-day general strike; battle is seen as preliminary skirmish over his plan to privatize Government-owned companies and eliminate state monopolies (M)

headline: BALKANS SOLUTION ELUDES U.S. ENVOY IN 4 DAYS OF TALKS
abstract: United States envoy Richard C Holbrooke ends talks with Yugoslav Pres Slobodan Milosevic and four days of talks in Croatia, Bosnia and Serbia without any major breakthrough on salvaging faltering Bosnia peace accords; expresses skepticism of pledge made during talks that former Bosnian Pres Radovan Karadzic would be stopped from wielding power; says he warned that NATO will continue heavy pressure on Karadzic, indicted war criminal (M)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent                Previous   Year          Yesterday   Day   Ago               PRIME RATE   8.50   8.50   8.25        DISCOUNT RATE   5.00   5.00   5.00        FEDERAL FUNDS*   5.50   5.54   5.19        3-MO. TREAS. BILLS   4.99   4.99   5.20        6-MO. TREAS. BILLS   5.16   5.15   5.36        10-YR. TREAS. INFL.**   3.56   3.57   N.A.        10-YR. TREAS. NOTES   6.32   6.32   6.98        30-YR. TREAS.
