headline: 81.99 Rebound in Blue Chips Recoups Part of Week's Loss
abstract: Stock market regains some of ground it lost in previous two trading sessions, as Dow Jones industrial average rises more than 1 percent; Dow soars 81.99 points, to 7,742.97 (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: GANNETT CO., Arlington, Va., the nationwide news and information company, approved a 2-for-1 stock split and a 5.6 percent increase in its quarterly dividend, to 38 cents.     AMERICAN EXPRESS CO., New York, said its Travel Related Services unit acquired a minority stake in Infobeat Inc., of Denver, a personalized E-mail publisher, for undisclosed terms.

headline: Irish Political Figure Admits Receiving $2 Million
abstract: Former Prime Min Charles J Haughey of Ireland admits accepting some $2 million in 1991 from Ben Dunne, who was then chief executive of Dunnes department store chain; special tribunal probes reports Dunnes gave members of Parliament $5 million, 1986-96; has uncovered large payments to both major parties; Prime Min Bertie Ahern scores Haughey, his former mentor (S)

headline: The Disklavier is a piano with optical sensors. What would Chopin have said?
abstract: Yamaha's Disklavier Gran Touch Digital Grand Piano combines traditional piano with futuristic innovations; it has traditional keyboard, but hammers do not strike strings stretched tautly over iron plate, but instead pass across optical sensors that are used to calculate nuanced piano-like sound; floppy disk read by computer can record pianist's own playing and play it back; it can also be programmed to add more than 700 synthesized sounds that emerge out of speakers hidden in its compressed body; Disklaviers range in price from $9,500 to $52,500; photo (M)

headline: TEXACO TO SPLIT ITS STOCK AND INCREASE DIVIDEND
abstract: Texaco Inc says that it will split its stock 2 for 1 and increase its quarterly dividend by 5.9 percent (S)

headline: Ex-East German Chief Gets 6 Years for Deaths at Wall
abstract: Egon Krenz, last hard-line Communist leader of East Germany, is sentenced by German court to six years in prison for being responsible for shooting deaths of people trying to cross Berlin Wall; conviction marks final and most ambitious attempt to hold East Germany's top political leaders responsible for hundreds of people killed during cold war while trying to escape to West; court also convicts two other members of former Politburo and sentences them to three years in prison each; photo (M)

headline: Under Pressure, Kenya Allows Rally for Reform
abstract: Thousands of people rally peacefully in Mombasa, Kenya, to press Government to open up repressive political system and change electoral rules that effectively preclude a challenger from unseating Pres Daniel arap Moi; Government decided to permit the rally following heavy international pressure (S)

headline: Arafat Says the U.S. Should Do More for Peace in the Mideast
abstract: Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat says US should do more to rescue quest for broader Middle East peace; calls on Clinton Administration to support creation of Palestinian state (M)

headline: COMFORCE AND UNIFORCE SERVICES IN $135 MILLION DEAL
abstract: Comforce Corp agrees to acquire Uniforce Services Inc for $135 million in cash, stock and debt assumption (S)

headline: Stocks End Mixed; Dow Rises 7.67 Points
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average rises 7.67 points to 8,121.11; table (M)

headline: U.S. Bull Nears Age When Japan's Stumbled
abstract: Market Place: Prolonged rise in stocks, which is seen as proof by corporate and government officials of superiority of nation's economic system, is similar to situation in Japan in late 1989; that stock market rose by almost exactly equal amount, over almost exactly the same period of time; that bull market ended badly, and is now almost universally seen as having been a bubble; it damaged Japan's economy because banks were left with huge quantities of bad loans that had been based on inflated asset valuations; graph (L)

headline: Budget Deal May Push More Elderly Into Managed Care
abstract: Analysis of aspects of Federal budget agreement that will likely speed flow of Medicare patients into managed care; budget calls for higher payments to HMO's in rural areas, which will likely draw in more of the elderly, without cutting generous payments that have allowed urban HMO's to offer broad coverage; patients retain right to return to traditional Medicare, but fee-for-service coverage is becoming every more costly; photos; graphs (M)

headline: FMC Plans Stock Buyback
abstract: FMC Corp will buy back up to $500 million of its stock (S)

headline: Italy Convicts Ex-SS Officers In '44 Killings
abstract: Italian military court sentences former German SS officers Erich Priebke to 15 years in prison, reduced to 5 years because of mitigating circumstances, and Karl Hass to 10 years, cut to eight months, for their roles in massacre of civilians outside Rome in 1944; Priebke, 83, who has only six months left to serve, will appeal; Hass, 84, will be set free immediately; relatives of 335 men and boys killed in reprisal for partisan attack and Italian Jewish leaders hail verdict; photo (M)

headline: Disney Sets Deal For Record Label
abstract: Walt Disney Co agrees to buy Mammoth Records, independent record label, in move to bolster its struggling presence in music industry; financial terms undisclosed (S)

headline: Innovation to Double Chip Power May Cut Life Span of Computers
abstract: Intel Corp is set to announce technology breakthrough that could cut cycle for doubling capacity of computer chips, and thus making older computers obsolete, in from 18 months to nine months or less; development, which alters basic physics of chip design, promises coming generation of chips with greater memory at falling costs; new chips can store not one but two bits of data on each transistor; Intel engineers believe it may be possible to store even more bits per transistor (M)

headline: Malaysia, in Crisis, Will Delay Projects
abstract: Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad says Malaysia will have to delay several big projects because of its currency problems (S)

headline: Europe and U.S. In Accord on Textiles
abstract: European Commission drops case with World Trade Organization over American import regulations on textiles, following US decision to amend rules designating origin of product based on source of raw materials used rather than place where raw materials were processed (S)

headline: Jury in CSX Case Sent Angry Message With a $3.4 Billion Stamp
abstract: Lawyer for CSX Corp blames runaway jury for $3.4 billion award to plaintiffs in 10-year-old case stemming from raging fire in leaky, unattended rail car owned by CSX in mostly black neighborhood of New Orleans; there was no proof of deaths or serious injury, but corporate carelessness in minds of jurors can be costly; at time of fire, railroad refused to take responsibility and initially declined mayor's frantic request for help; it did nothing to help those evacuated; about half the jurors suspected racism had put tank car in black neighborhood; some jurors say award will probably be reduced, but it was important to send message to corporate America; photo; map (M)

headline: CHOICEPOINT SAYS IT HAS CALLED OFF ACQUISITION OF KROLL
abstract: Choicepoint Inc calls off acquisition of Kroll Associates, citing inability of both companies to reach final agreement (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: European Panel Opposes Takeover by Boeing  The European Union's antitrust advisory committee has come out against the $14 billion takeover of McDonnell Douglas by Boeing. It said the planned takeover would strengthen Boeing's ''existing dominant position and therefore should be prohibited,'' people familiar with the decision said.

headline: U.S. Lifts the Ban on Travel to Lebanon
abstract: State Sec Madeleine K Albright lifts ban on travel by Americans to Lebanon, imposed in 1987 when pro-Iranian militants were taking Westerners hostage; says Lebanon remains very dangerous and urges Americans not to go there; Prime Min Rafik al-Hariri sought end to ban; photo (M)

headline: Joint Venture in Auto Lighting Systems
abstract: Valeo SA, world's biggest producer of car lighting systems, and Osram Sylvania, US unit of Siemens AG, have agreed to joint venture that would be biggest North American producer of auto lighting systems; each company will own 50 percent of the venture (S)

headline: Discovery Zone Gets Aid
abstract: Discovery Zone Inc, operator of indoor playgrounds, emerges from bankruptcy protection with new ownership group and $100 million in private financing (S)

headline: Pakistan's Bitter Roots, and Modest Hopes
abstract: Survey of Pakistan as it celebrates 50th anniversary of its birth on Aug 14, 1947, when it was carved out of British India as homeland for Indian Muslims; Pakistanis taking stock of their country have much to regret, but also much that makes them proud; country has large industrial base, skilled scientists who developed stockpile of nuclear weapons, armed forces that are among most modern and efficient in Asia and have acquitted themselves well as United Nations peacekeepers around world; country is in some respects more up-to-date than India, having never closed its economy to foreign trade and technology to extent India did; on negative side, Pakistan has endured military coups, assassinations, loss of half the country in civil war that created nation of Bangladesh, and string of civilian politicians who have been incompetent and corrupt; in addition, country is still heavily burdened by poverty; photos; chronology of events in last 50 years in Pakistan (L)

headline: People
abstract: * Michael Miller was named manager at the Design Mill, Salisbury, N.C., a new graphic and apparel design division of Jordan Group. He had been president at Miller Designs, Salisbury, which closed.

headline: Accounts
abstract: * Fox Photo Inc., St. Louis, a joint venture of Eastman Kodak Co. and CPI Corp., to Simmons Durham, St. Louis, to handle its integrated marketing account, which had been handled by various agencies, including Simmons Durham, on a project basis. Billings were estimated at $7 million to $8 million.

headline: Jet Leaser Places 126-Plane Order
abstract: International Lease Finance Corp has ordered total of 126 aircraft, valued at $8.5 billion, from Airbus Industrie and Boeing Co (S)

headline: Manila Journal; People Power 2: A Sleeping Giant Is Awakened
abstract: Philippines Pres Fidel Ramos arouses ire of Filipinos by allowing backers to try to change Constitution and keep him in office after single term expires in 1998; residents of Manila stage 'noise barrage,' or ritual of protest to register their opposition; photo (M)

headline: Thompson Hires BBDO Executive
abstract: J Walter Thompson Co names Larry Tolpin, top executive from BBDO Worldwide, as worldwide creative director (S)

headline: Agencies to Merge On Long Island
abstract: Advertising agencies Lowell/Harrison/Leifer in Rockville Centre, NY, and Phillips Miller Speyer & Frost in Amityville, NY, are merging to form Harrison Leifer Miller & Speyer; terms undisclosed (S)

headline: Executive Changes
abstract: ABC INC., New York, named Peter E. Murphy senior vice president and chief financial officer, succeeding Ronald J. Doerfler, who is resigning from the broadcasting company effective Oct. 31. Mr. Murphy was most recently senior vice president for strategic planning and development at Walt Disney Co., which acquired Capital Cities/ABC Inc. last year. Earlier this month, Mr. Doerfler said he was leaving to pursue other opportunities in corporate finance. He will remain at the company through January.    STARTER CORP., New Haven, the sports apparel maker, said John M. Tucker had resigned as president and chief operating officer. His responsibilities have been assumed by  David Beckerman, chief executive.

headline: The Fallen Commissars of 1918, Now Fallen Idols
abstract: Azerbaijanis seem to have largely forgotten 26 young Bolsheviks killed in 1918 in struggle to establish Communist rule; Baku memorial to 26, who were once widely revered, was smashed in 1989 as Soviet Union began to collapse; map; photo (M)

headline: New York Times Company Posts 81.5% Rise in Quarterly Profit
abstract: New York Times reports second quarter earnings rose 81.5 percent to $84.9 million from $46.8 million a year earlier (M)

headline: Chairman Is Replaced At Groupe Bull
abstract: Groupe Bull, France's largest manufacturer of computer equipment, says its chairman Jean-Marie Descarpentries has resigned; Bull's board names Guy de Panafieu, managing director of Suez Lyonnaise des Eaux, to replace Descarpentries (S)

headline: When TV Fantasy Becomes Reality
abstract: Tim Allen, actor-comedian who stars in ABC series Home Improvement, is longtime tool enthusiast who has entered hand-tools business and is actively seeking new ideas; photo (L)

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.    MONDAY   Federal Budget Aug.

headline: Gold Plunges as Central Bank In Australia Sells 167 Tons
abstract: Gold prices plunge to 11 1/2-year low on Comex division of New York Mercantile Exchange after Australia's central bank says it has sold 167 metric tons from its reserves; gold for August delivery falls $7.10, to $325.20 an ounce (M)

headline: Liquor Maker Given Respite in South Korea
abstract: Jinro Group, South Korea's biggest liquor maker, is given reprieve by creditors, who have agreed to extend bailout that has kept company afloat (S)

headline: Vicious Reminder of 70's Atrocities in Argentina
abstract: Adolfo Francisco Scilingo, former Argentine Navy captain who broke military code of silence two years ago when he admitted publicly to atrocities, says that four attackers slashed his face and warned him to stop speaking with journalists about crimes by repressive military Govt of 1970's; Scilingo shocks Argentina with his grisly account of pushing political prisoners to their death from planes; estimated 30,000 people were killed or disappeared without trace during military's violent crackdown on leftists; photo (L)

headline: Accounts
abstract: * Di Noto Lee, New York, was awarded two accounts with combined billings estimated at $5 million: Domaine Chandon, Napa, Calif., a unit of LVMH Moet Hennessy Louis Vuitton, to handle advertising for the maker of sparkling wine, previously handled in-house, and Boise Technology, Itasca, Ill., a division of Boise Cascade, as the first agency to handle advertising for the maker of high-tech office products.

headline: Federal Express Aided by Overseas Gains
abstract: Federal Express Corp says net income rose 15 percent in fiscal fourth quarter ended May 31; net income rose to $132.6 million from $115.4 million a year earlier; revenue for quarter rose 12 percent, to $3.07 billion from $2.74 billion; table (S)

headline: In Intel Inquiry, U.S. Regulators Send a Message
abstract: Antitrust experts and industry analysts say Federal Trade Commission, with its investigation of Intel Corp, is signaling that Government will continue to closely police leading high-technology companies that play increasing role in the economy; antitrust inquiry is second time trade commission has examined Intel; first investigation ended in 1993, after two years, without any charges of using unfair business methods to undermine competition; Microsoft Corp has been under investigation by Justice Department since 1993 (L)

headline: San Pablo de Cantesiaya Journal; Across Jungle Iron Curtain, Cousins Yearn to Meet
abstract: Members of semi-nomadic Secoya tribe, divided by war between Peru and Ecuador 56 years ago, are pressing Governments to let them visit relatives across heavily guarded border; say military in both nations view bid with suspicion; map; photos (M)

headline: NATIONAL TECHTEAM'S STOCK SKIDS ON EARNINGS FORECAST
abstract: Shares of National Techteam Inc fall 37 percent after company says its second-quarter earnings will fail to match Wall Street's expectations (S)

headline: France Telecom Issue Is Prepared
abstract: French Finance Ministry will sell about 37 billion French francs, or about $6.2 billion, worth of shares in France Telecom SA to institutional and individual investors at price at high end of anlayst expectations (S)

headline: Mexico Finds Body But Then Wonders: Is It Top Drug Boss?
abstract: Mexico tentatively identifies body of man who died in Mexico City hospital after facial surgery and liposuction as billionaire drug trafficker Amado Carrillo Fuentes; Mexican anti-drug agents, who once seemed sluggish in prosecuting Carrillo Fuentes, aggressively chased his presumed corpse, bringing it back to Mexico City for testing from funeral parlor in Sinaloa state; United States Drug Enforcement Administration director, Thomas A Constantine, says American agents have viewed body; Mexican and US aides say Carillo's apparent death could destabilize drug ties across continent; map; photos (M)

headline: Alien advertising has landed, earthlings, and it is taking over.
abstract: Article on growing number of advertising campaigns that are linked to space aliens and unidentified flying objects; some companies that are using such advertising include Eastman Kodak Co, Star Tribune newspaper in Minneapolis, Minn, and Hostess snack cakes sold by Interstate Bakeries Corp; photos (L)

headline: Offerings Expected This Week Of Equity and Convertible Debt
abstract: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:    Armor Holdings Inc., Jacksonville, Fla., 4 million shares. Dillon, Read & Co.

headline: McDonnell Douglas-Boeing Merger Wins F.T.C. Approval
abstract: Federal Trade Commission says it will not oppose proposed $14 billion acquisition of McDonnell Douglas Corp by Boeing Co (L)

headline: A new campaign by Leo Burnett will try to promote Prozac directly to consumers.
abstract: New advertising campaign for Prozac by Leo Burnett Co is aimed at consumers; until campaign begins running in August issues of more than 20 magazines, Eli Lilly & Co, which brought out Prozac a decade ago, had advertised the brand solely to health care professionals; photo (L)

headline: In Italy's Piracy Culture, Black Market Is Thriving
abstract: Enormous market for pirated goods of all kinds has sprung up in Italy, rivaling those in East Asian countries like Taiwan and Thailand; this underground bazaar offers up everything from fake Gucci bags and belts to illegal copies of American software, music recordings and books; experts estimate size of illegal commerce at $6 billion a year and growing; much of pressure to crack down on counterfeiting is coming from US; software companies, mainly American, lose estimated $350 million a year in Italy because of piracy; music industry, also heavily American, says it loses $100 million; charts; tables; photos (L)

headline: NATO at Crossroads in Bosnia: Serb Power Struggle Is Seen as 'Defining Moment'
abstract: Seizure of police station in Banja Luka, Bosnia, by NATO forces in move to isolate and neutralize Bosnian Serb leader Radovan Karadzic and protect successor, Biljana Plavsic, has moved troops closer to combat in Balkans than at any time since they were sent to Bosnia in 1995 as peacekeepers to enforce Dayton accords (M)

headline: Learning to Sacrifice
abstract: Letter by Nancy J Governali on July 13 article on raising a family on one income (S)

headline: Separating Work And Grief
abstract: Richard O Nemec article on returning to work after personal tragedy; holds succeeding at work and coping with mourning must be kept separate; drawing (M)

headline: Her Death Is Less a Morality Play Than a Modernized Greek Tragedy : The Royal Superstar
abstract: LONDON  From the single flower laid beside palace walls to the grand tributes from world leaders, the heartfelt reaction to the death of Diana, Princess of Wales, comes from society's emotional gut.

headline: ITT Rejects Takeover Bid by Hilton Hotels
abstract: ITT Corp rejects $11.5 billion hostile takeover offer from Hilton Hotels Corp as inadequate, second time in six months the company has spurned Hilton's overtures (S)

headline: Republic Selling Security Unit To Ameritech for $610 Million
abstract: Ameritech Corp says it will buy security business of Republic Industries for $610 million, giving Ameritech more residential customers and wider reach for its fast-growing theft-protection unit; purchase, subject to regulatory approval, would make Ameritech's Securitylink No 2 behind ADT, nation's largest security company; Republic, controlled by H Wayne Huizenga, tried and failed to buy ADT, which has been acquired by Tyco International; Republic is now focusing on auto sales; it says it won Federal District Court order dismissing challenge by Honda Motor Co to its acquisition of dealerships, paving way for Republic to continue buying franchises of Honda; Honda had accused Republic of violating laws against unfair competition and of interfering with agreements Honda makes with its dealers (M)

headline: Issue of Foreign Adoption Follows Shevardnadze to Washington
abstract: Georgian Amb Tedo Japaridze expresses concern that effort to halt foreign adoptions will become key issue of Pres Eduard Shevardnadze's United States visit; Shevardnandze, whose wife, Nanuli, leads crusade against foreign adoptions, is under heavy pressure from US, members of US Congress and many members of Georgian Parliament to let 16 American families complete adoptions put on hold in Dec (M)

headline: Russians Are Left With One Less Reason to Smile
abstract: Russians mourn death at age 75 of Yuri Nikulin, clown, actor and circus director who poked fun at system through decades of Soviet tyranny and raucous democracy that has followed; thousands pay their respects as he lays in state at Moscow Circus; photos (M)

headline: DEFECTING ENVOY FROM NORTH KOREA TO GET U.S. ASYLUM
abstract: United States to grant political asylum to Chang Sung Gil, North Korea's Ambassador to Egypt, highest-ranking North Korean to seek asylum in US, his brother, Chang Sung Ho, diplomat, and their families; has brought them to US; Clinton Administration says little publicly for fear of upsetting talks with North Korea; senior officials privately call defections intelligence bonanza; say Chang is familiar with missile and other arms sales to Egypt, Syria and Iran; photo (M)

headline: Can 2 Magazine Cultures Find Happiness Together?
abstract: Euromoney Publications PLC has ousted David Cudaback, editor and 21-year veteran of Institutional Investor, and put its own managers in charge of main units of magazine, which it recently acquired; Euromoney's $142 million acquisition is British takeover of Wall Street institution; Euromoney's challenge will be to find way to merge decidedly different cultures on opposite sides of Atlantic, without jarring Institutional Investor's editorial independence and established reputation for reporting and writing; photos; chart (M)

headline: De Klerk's Party Ends Suit Against South Africa's Truth Panel
abstract: Former South African Pres F W De Klerk and his National Party drop lawsuit against Truth and Reconciliation Commission investigating apartheid-era crimes after obtaining apologies from commission's leaders, who suggested he lied during testimony (M)

headline: Caffeinated Drinks Catering to Excitable Boys and Girls
abstract: Article on popular new brand of soft drinks called energy drinks or extreme beverages; says beverages are generally high in caffeine and sometimes laced with so-called exotic additives, like Brazilian guarana berries or ginseng; holds products, which are under fire from some health experts, are primarily marketed to teen-agers and Generation X'ers; says market for such drinks is so enticing that Coca-Cola Co and Pepsico have entered the fray by creating their own supercharged brands, which are now hitting national market; graph; photos (L)

headline: Lincoln National Set to Acquire Bulk of a Cigna Business
abstract: Lincoln National Corp to buy most of Cigna Corp's individual life insurance business for $1.4 billion; Lincoln chairman Ian M Rolland comments (M)

headline: Stocks Higher in Tokyo
abstract: Japan's Nikkei average is up 52.11 points, or three-tenths of 1 percent, at 18,685.97 at midday Sept 9 (S)

headline: A Good Forecaster Is Hard to Find; Local Stations Seek Those Who Understand Storms and People
abstract: Television stations in areas susceptable to hurricanes and other potentially dangerous weather patterns seek good, experienced meteorologists who can also relate to viewers; news directors say it is not enough to show complicated graphics and computer-enhanced images because viewers must like, and trust, person who brings that message; as result, meteorologists are often odd mix of scientist and celebrity; photo (M)

headline: In Rescuing a Relative, a Helping or a Heavy Hand?
abstract: Gerald Stern letter on Roy Furchgott's Aug 10 article on his effort to take control of finances of and provide care for aged great-uncle, Joseph Nathan Rosolio, who resisted his help (S)

headline: 525 Made in America continues to seek name recognition by using dogs to model its clothes.
abstract: Manhattan-based knitwear company 525 Made in America is repeating memorable ad campaign, with dogs as models, that it began one year ago; company is quadrupling the budget, to $2 million, and introducing ads to new markets; campaign is created by Leibler-Bronfman Lubalin; photo (L)

headline: Promus and Doubletree Hotel Companies Will Merge
abstract: Promus Hotel Corp and Doubletree Corp agree to merger that will create one of biggest hotel companies in the world, with combined revenue of $5 billion; merged company will control 1,136 hotels and 172,000 rooms and 40,000 employees in US; deal values Promus at about $2.1 billion and Doubletree at $1.8 billion; Promus shareholders will own about 55 percent of new company; chart (L)

headline: Hillary Clinton Will Go to Diana's Funeral
abstract: White House announces First Lady Hillary Rodham Clinton will attend funeral of Diana, Princess of Wales, in recognition of close personal association between both women (S)

headline: F. W. Zuckerman, Former Treasurer Of 3 Corporations
abstract: Frederick W Zuckerman, former treasurer of Chrysler Corp, RJR Nabisco and International Business Machines Corp, dies at age 63 (M)

headline: Delta Hires Its New Chief From Outside The Airlines
abstract: Delta Air Lines names Leo F Mullin its new president and chief executive, succeeding Ronald W Allen, who resigned on July 31 after board refused to renew his contract; Mullin is vice chairman of Unicom Corp and its subsidiary, Commonwealth Edison (L)

headline: Correction
abstract: Correction of July 27 article about tax credits for investments in low-income housingp

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Apple Chief Resigns, Casting Doubt on Recovery  Apple Computer's chairman and chief executive, Gilbert F. Amelio, resigned. The surprising move cast doubt on whether the company -- which pioneered personal computing but has seen its sales slide steadily -- could be revived.     The departure of Mr. Amelio, who had been touted as a turnaround specialist when he was recruited a year and a half ago, was the latest development in a corporate soap opera at Apple. $(Page A1.$)

headline: Chancellor Media Forms Radio Network
abstract: Chancellor Media Corp is forming national radio network and has hired president of ABC Radio Networks, David Kantor, to run the business; programming on network called AMFM Radio Networks, will run on Chancellor's 99 stations, which reach about 41 million listeners a week (S)

headline: Mate Boban, 57, Chief Builder Of Croatian Enclave in Bosnia
abstract: Mate Boban, hard-line leader of Bosnian Croats during war with Bosnian Muslims and close ally of Pres Franjo Tudjman, dies at age 57 after suffering stroke; was handpicked by Tudjman in 1992 to form independent enclave in Bosnia held by Croats; photo (M)

headline: As U.S. Mediator Arrives, Arafat Calls for Confrontation
abstract: Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat welcomes efforts of United States mediator Dennis Ross, but tells Palestinian legislature that Israelis seek to humiliate Palestinians and calls for confrontation; intensifies attacks on Israeli policies, television interview; Ross arrives, Jerusalem; photo (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Cigarette Companies In Big Florida Accord  Philip Morris, RJR Nabisco and other large cigarette makers have agreed to pay $11.3 billion to settle a smoking-related lawsuit brought by Florida officials. The companies will also tear down cigarette billboards near schools, finance anti-smoking campaigns, remove vending machines from places where children can get to them and stop advertising at sports events and on buses and trains.    By resolving the Florida case, tobacco companies no longer face a long trial and adverse publicity that could affect deliberations over a proposed $368.5 billion national settlement. But the settlement with Florida could also lead other states to seek added concessions. $(Page A1.$)

headline: Bills and Notes Being Offered By Treasury
abstract: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week has today's regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills, as well as auctions of two-year and five-year notes, tomorrow and Wednesday, respectively.    According to traders, at the close of the New York cash market on Friday the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 5.10 percent and the rate on the six-month issue, 5.12 percent. In when-issued trading the two-year note was offered at a price to yield 5.88 percent, and the five-year note at 6 percent.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: GOOD GUYS INC., Brisbane, Calif., disclosed a plan to renovate all 76 of its consumer electronics retail stores in an effort to increase sales.    ENSERCH EXPLORATION INC., Houston, an oil and natural gas concern that is a unit of the Enserch Corporation, agreed to sell its 40 percent interest in an oilfield in the Gulf of Mexico for about $20.5 million.

headline: Stock Issues Expected This Week
abstract: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:    Advantage Learning Systems Inc., Wisconsin Rapids, Wis., an initial public offering of 2.3 million shares. Piper Jaffray Inc.

headline: R.A. Jackson, the Cartoonist Jak, 70, Dies
abstract: Raymond Allen Jackson, British cartoonist known as Jak, dies at age 70; cartoon; photo (M)

headline: Bill Sales Set By Treasury For This Week
abstract: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week consists of today's regular weekly auction of three-  and six-month bills and the auction of a one-year bill on Thursday.    By the close of the New York cash market on Friday, traders said, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 5.01 percent and a six-month bill was 5.15 percent; the rate on a one-year bill was 5.27 percent.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: B. F. Goodrich to Buy Rohr For $789 Million in Stock  B. F. Goodrich agreed to acquire Rohr Inc., a maker of aircraft engine parts, in a stock swap valued at $789 million.     The deal, which values Rohr at $31.19 a share, was announced after the market's close. Rohr had disclosed that a deal was imminent, and trading in its shares was halted. Last week Rohr said an earlier deal worth $30.25 a share had fallen through. $(Page D2.$)

headline: Police Listened In on Bosnian Serb President
abstract: NATO soldiers and UN workers search police station in Banja Luka, Bosnia, for evidence of electronic eavesdropping on Bosnian Serb Pres Biljana Plavsic by political rivals; find extensive listening equipment, boxes of audio tapes and copies of faxes sent to and from her office, as well as military weapons and ammunition, beyond what police forces are allowed under NATO rules; say police were running espionage center; map (M)

headline: New-Media Executives Often Lose Their Way
abstract: Several prominent executives in old media businesses like television and publishing were lured away in recent years to take jobs in new interactive media ventures; but so far, profits have been elusive and most executives have returned, sadder but wiser, to their roots; article focuses on executives Stephen A Weiswasser, Walter Isaacson, Howard Stringer, Robert M Kavner and Paul Sagan; photos (L)

headline: INSIDE
abstract: INVESTING IT/Page 4/  Plaids and high heels? Meet the new, trendy Stride Rite and its snazzy new lineups of Keds shoes. By Sharon R. King.    MUTUAL FUNDS/Page 9/  Energy stocks have caught fire -- but the big question is whether the sharp rises will continue. A key is the future of oil prices.  By Anne Tergesen.

headline: MICROSOFT BUYS STAKE IN SPEECH TECHNOLOGY COMPANY
abstract: Microsoft Corp acquires minority stake in Lernout & Hauspie Speech Products NV of Belgium for $45 million; companies plan to develop products for Microsoft Windows programs that allow computers to recognize spoken words (S)

headline: 2 Killed by Spanish Police in Basque Region
abstract: Spanish Min Jaime Mayor Orega reports police killed two Basque rebels in shootout, Bilbao, and later arrested 12 other members of Basque commando unit, televised news conference; warns fight against terrorism continues (S)

headline: Sheik Abdullah al-Tariki, 80, First Saudi Arabian Oil Minister
abstract: Sheik Abdullah al-Tariki, Saudi Arabia's first oil minister and founder of Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, died on Sept 7 at age 80; photo (M)

headline: First-Half Profit Up For HSBC Holdings
abstract: HSBC Holdings PLC posts net income of 1.75 billion pounds ($2.85 billion) for six months ended June 30, up from 1.58 billion pounds a year ago (S)

headline: RUSSIANS SUGGEST AMERICAN TAKE ON MIR REPAIR TASK
abstract: Russian Space Agency head Yuri N Koptev suggests Michael Foale, American astronaut aboard Mir, make tricky space walk to repair damaged space station in place of Russian commander Vasily Tsibliyev, who suffers from fatigue and irregular heartbeats, interview; says crew has discussed move and Foale wants to make repairs; NASA officials are skeptical; photos (M)

headline: U.S. Petroleum Data
abstract: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization             Aug 29   Aug 22   Aug 30          1997   1997   1996       Gasoline production, daily   8.2   8.0   7.6       Distillate production, daily   3.5   3.4   3.4       Gasoline stocks   187.5   189.5   192.8       Distillate stocks   127.0   125.0   108.9       Crude imports, daily   8.5   8.0   6.7       Product imports, daily   1.8   2.0   1.8       Crude stocks   305.7   308.6   313.1       Crude production, daily   6.3   6.3   6.4       Refinery utilization (%)   99.7   99.4   94.4          Source: American Petroleum Institute

headline: As Bonn Fails at Tax Reform, German Businesses Study U.S.
abstract: German politicians acknowledge failure of efforts to streamline burdensome tax system, even as US lawmakers negotiate budget-balancing and tax accord; German business people are gloomy about becoming more competitive in world market; praise pragmatic common sense of Americans (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: AMERICAN ANNUITY GROUP INC., Cincinnati, which markets individual and group annuities, agreed to purchase General Accident Life Assurance Co. of Puerto Rico, a subsidiary of General Accident Fire and Life Assurance Corp. P.L.C., Perth, Scotland, for $50 million.     E-STAMP CORP., Palo Alto, Calif., a maker of software that lets consumers purchase and print stamps from the Internet, said Microsoft Corp. and AT&T Corp. had each acquired a 10 percent stake in the company.

headline: Michael Clinton Leaving Conde Nast
abstract: Michael A Clinton, executive vice president at Conde Nast Publications, has resigned; he will not be replaced (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Starts of Housing Decline As Inflation Stays in Check  Housing starts unexpectedly dropped 4.8 percent in August, to an annualized 1.363 million, as builders began projects at the slowest pace this year.    A report from the Federal Reserve showed that labor shortages have not translated into rising consumer or industrial prices. Both are further evidence of slower growth that will keep inflation in check and give the Fed little reason to raise interest rates. $(Page D3.$)

headline: INTEGRION FINANCIAL ACQUIRES VISA'S INTERACTIVE UNIT
abstract: Integrion Financial Network acquires assets and operations of Visa Interactive, remote banking subsidiary of Visa International; terms undisclosed (S)

headline: For Japan, A Quandary On Pleasing Two Giants
abstract: Tensions rise between China and Japan following comment by senior Japanese politician that Japan might support US if conflict arose over Taiwan between China and US; comments have fueled debate within dominant Liberal Democratic Party, underscoring growing discord within Japanese Government about security issues and relations with China; issue of Taiwan arose because Japan and US are revising guidelines on military cooperation (M)

headline: WARNER-LAMBERT SHARES RISE TO ALL-TIME HIGH OF $145
abstract: Shares of Warner-Lambert Co rise 7.2 percent on expectations that its cholesterol-lowering drug Lipitor will keep gaining market share; stock rises to all-time high of $145 (S)

headline: Lawyers Eclipse Agents in TV Deals
abstract: Entertainment lawyers are taking increasingly active roles in making deals for television performers and others that were once handled mainly by agents; critics say downside of this new way to do business in television industry is that shows often get on air based on how a deal was structured, not on somebody's original idea for concept of a show; new television industry playing field has emerged since elimination of Federal Communications Commission rules that once greatly restricted number of shows in which network could own an interest; new vertically integrated companies own both production studios and networks; this concentration of power has led many producers and stars to rely on entertainment lawyers, rather then just their agents, to find creative--often complicated--ways to make a deal; photo (M)

headline: Ripple Effect Likely From Citibank Move
abstract: Decision by Citibank to consolidate almost all advertising and direct marketing tasks at Young & Rubicam may affect agency's other accounts; possible ripple effects discussed (S)

headline: In Not-So-Serene Venice, Leaders Fear Rising Desire for Secession
abstract: Interview with Massimo Cacciari, Mayor of Venice, Italy, who voices concern that Rome is taking too long in facing up to secessionist fevers in Veneto region (M)

headline: Of White Lies and Yellow Pads
abstract: Survey of workers in all kinds of businesses finds wide variety of unethical practices, from lying about sick days to taking credit for another's work; table (S)

headline: Novell's $121 Million Loss Exceeds Analysts' Estimates
abstract: Novell Inc reports loss of $121.6 million for fiscal third quarter ended July 31, compared with earnings of $58.5 million in year-earlier quarter; loss exceeds analysts' estimates; revenue was $90.1 million, compared with $365.1 million reported in third quarter of fiscal 1996; chairman Eric Schmidt predicts rebound for rest of 1997; chart (L)

headline: HSN, WITH 50.1%, HAS CONTROLLING STAKE IN TICKETMASTER
abstract: HSN Inc, parent company of Home Shopping Network, increases its share to 50.1 percent and gains controlling stake in Ticketmaster Group Inc, computerized ticket company (S)

headline: Drugs' Effect on Driver Discounted
abstract: Alcoholism researchers say drugs found in blood of Henri Paul, driver of Princess Diana's limousine, were unlikely to have added substantially to profound effects of large quantity of alcohol he drank (S)

headline: G.E. TAKES A 20% EQUITY STAKE IN ADVANCED NMR SYSTEMS
abstract: General Electric Co pays $5.1 million to Advanced NMR Systems Inc for two magnetic-resonance imaging businesses and 20 percent stake in the company (S)

headline: Cuban Accusations of U.S. Insect Raid on Island to Be Studied
abstract: Signers of Biological Weapons Convention say Cuban accusations that US staged biological attack in 1996 by using crop-duster to spread insects over island will be examined further (M)

headline: An inventor sees garment bags becoming passe for the hard-pressed business traveler.
abstract: Don Chernoff patents plastic tube device to enable business travelers to keep suits they carry wrinkle-free; William A Fraser patents system for displaying advertising on supermarket cashier's conveyor belt; Irv Bush patents hand-held device that makes bell sound for use by in-line skaters and others to warn pedestrians they are approaching (M)

headline: Federal-Mogul Offers to Buy T & N for $2 Billion in Cash
abstract: Federal-Mogul Corp, ailing maker of auto parts now showing signs of recovery, says it has offered to pay about $2 billion in cash to buy British auto supplier T & N PLC; Federal-Mogul is part of broad consolidation trend in worldwide auto parts industry; Blackstone Capital Partners II Merchant Banking Fund, part of Blackstone Group, agrees to buy controlling stake in American Axle and Manufacturing Inc from Park Corp; deal is valued at about $650 million (L)a

headline: Gauging a New Drop In H.M.O.'s Stocks
abstract: Stock analysts discuss outlook for HMO companies, suggesting they remain potentially good investments despite recent price tumbles (S)

headline: COMPUTER PRODUCTS-ZYTEC IN $529 MILLION DEAL
abstract: Computer Products Inc, maker of power conversion equipment for computer industry, agrees to acquire rival maker of electronic components, Zytec Corp, in $529 million stock swap (S)

headline: Hamburg Results Stir Rivalries in German Left
abstract: FRANKFURT  - The rivalry within Germany's political left over who will challenge Chancellor Helmut Kohl next year stepped up on Monday following the Social Democratic Party's worst postwar showing in Hamburg's local elections over the weekend.

headline: Grand Met-Guinness Role to LVMH Head
abstract: LVMH Moet Hennessy-Louis Vuitton chairman Bernard Arnault has bought right to call special stockholders meeting of both Grand Metropolitan PLC and Guinness PLC and allow investors in the companies, which have agreed to merge, to vote on his alternative proposals (S)

headline: Stores Redo the Merchandise Mix And the Hispanic Dollars Flow
abstract: Sears, Roebuck & Co is tailoring inventory at some stores to fit profile of consumers in surrounding communities; at Sears in Los Angeles, sales rose to $50 million in 1996, double $25 million of 1992, and profits increased 30 percent between 1995 and end of last year after it brought in merchandise that caters to Americans of Hispanic origin; other stores that are redoing merchandise mix include J C Penney, Nordstrom Inc and Circuit City; graphs; tables; photos (L)

headline: McDonnell Posts Rise in Profits
abstract: McDonnell Douglas Corp reports second quarter income rose 3.7 percent to $195 million (S)

headline: Celestial Seasonings Changes Its Agency
abstract: Celestial Seasonings Inc names Campbell Mithun Esty to handle its advertising account, which had been at Dailey & Associates (S)

headline: At First Meeting, Ulster Unionist Leader Blasts Sinn Fein
abstract: Northern Ireland Protestant political leaders attend peace conference with Sinn Fein, political wing of Irish Republican Army, for first time, Belfast; Ulster Unionist Party head David Trimble scores Sinn Fein and British Prime Min Tony Blair's Government; he and other Protestants urge British and Irish Governments to expel Sinn Fein from talks, holding IRA has not renounced violence; Sinn Fein head Gerry Adams, at talks, denies Sinn Fein and IRA are same (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: After Big Swings, Dow Declines by 32.52  Stocks were generally lower after a day of wide gyrations. Prices initially rose sharply after economic reports by the Government contained few signs of inflation, but then receded into negative territory.   The Dow industrials, up as much as 80 points early on and later down by just as much, ended the day at 7,928.32, down 32.52. $(Page D6.$)

headline: A Stalinist Dowager in Her Bunker
abstract: Nexhmije Hoxha, wife of late Albanian Communist dictator, Enver Hoxha, who ruled Albania for more than 40 years; is unrepentant over harsh conditions of husband's tenure, especially poor treatment of political prisoners; served five-year prison term after fall of Communism in 1991; she is treated with contempt by Albanians, and is virtual pariah in own country; photo (M)

headline: Fox in Deal With New Regency Productions
abstract: Fox Filmed Entertainment signs production and distribution deal with Arnon Milchan's New Regency Productions; 15-year agreement marks end of seven-year association between New Regency and Warner Brothers; Fox does not release terms of deal (S)

headline: Emad al-Fayed, 41, a Friend, Dies in the Crash With Diana
abstract: Obituary of Emad al-Fayed, companion of Princess Diana of Wales who died with her in car crash in Paris; photo (S)

headline: Why will a pin pierce the Stones logo? And why are those Cover Girls spicing it up this fall?
abstract: Advertising column asks 20 questions about advertising, marketing and the media (L)

headline: British Auto Maker and Unions Sign Deal
abstract: Rover Group Ltd, British auto maker owned by BMW of Germany, says that it reached agreement on three-year pay package after almost week of talks with its joint trade unions (S)

headline: Pooling Shareholder Votes To Speak in Louder Voices
abstract: Several prominent financial advisers have recently begun voting their clients' shares in mutual fund elections, using proxies from clients who could otherwise vote themselves; by bundling their clients' votes into a single group, advisers believe they can speak with louder voice when a fund company asks shareholders to approve a change in a charter (L)d

headline: Laura Ashley Stock Drops After Resignation
abstract: Shares of Laura Ashley Holdings PLC drop to 78 cents, lowest level in more than six years, following resignation of design director, Basha Cohen; she is third executive to leave in two months (S)

headline: Russians Are Said to Block Plans for Bosnian Serb Elections
abstract: Russia thwarts proposal to have international organization supervise elections that Bosnia Serb Pres Biljana Plavsic has called in her power struggle with her predecessor, Radovan Karadzic; this is setback for Clinton Administration and major European Governments, which openly side with Plavsic; Russia has long been Serbs' major outside ally, and Moscow is reluctant to get caught in internal Serbian power struggle (M)

headline: OWENS CORNING TO BUY AMERIMARK BUILDING PRODUCTS
abstract: Owens Corning agrees to aquire Amerimark Building Products Inc for $310 million (S)

headline: J. P. Morgan Profit Falls 15%, But Its Stock Price Advances
abstract: J P Morgan & Co says earnings fell 15 percent in second quarter; income fell to $374 million from $440 million a year earlier; revenue rose 1.7 percent, to $1.79 billion from $1.76 billion; Morgan's stock gains $1.625, to $108 a share; First Union Corp says earnings rose 11 percent in second quarter; income rose to $485 million from $436 million in 1996 second quarter (L)

headline: James J. Houlahan, 90, Ex-Chief Of the William Esty Ad Agency
abstract: James J Houlahan, former advertising executive at William Esty Co, died on Sept 18 at age 90 (S)

headline: AT&T Long-Distance Rates Cut and MCI Joins in Move
abstract: AT&T Corp says it will reduce rates by 5 percent for day and evening calls and 15 percent for night and weekend calls; new rates go into effect immediately; MCI Communications Corp immediately matches AT&T's cuts, while Sprint Corp says it is still deliberating how to respond (M)

headline: Overhauling Kenya's Charter Sends Factions Near the Brink
abstract: Kenya's political crisis deepens as Government, civil rights leaders and opposition politicians fail to reach agreement on reforming Constitution or repealing repressive laws from the colonial era; factions throw sticks and chase each other outside parliament; photo; more violence feared, with further damage to tourism and currency (S)

headline: Bankers Trust to Buy Stake in Nippon
abstract: Bankers Trust New York Corp buys option that allows it to buy as much as $124 million of shares of Nippon Credit Bank Ltd of Japan in three years; two companies also say they will buy between $8 million to $16.5 million in each other's shares (S)

headline: Ins and Outs of French Law: Hotel Could Be Charged in Diana's Death
abstract: Lawsuits filed in France in death of Princess Diana highlights subtleties of French law, which is still based on Napoleonic Code, and how it is likely to influence progress of case; victims and representatives can become parties to investigation, while prosecuting authorities are especially powerful in determining outcome of case; Code gives investigating judges almost unlimited scope to follow facts wherever fault seems to lie, and gives other people who have suffered from accident same incentive to pushfor criminal prosecution; complicated system could eventually pit civil parties against each other (M)

headline: France Snips at the Old Ties That Bind It to Africa
abstract: France, which has for decades propped up or toppled governments in French-speaking Africa as if it were still colonial master, is now planning to cut back on troop contingents and take fresh look at how money is doled out to old cronies; map; new Prime Min Lionel Jospin, who believes paternalism has thwarted development of democracy, orders top-to-bottom policy review; other factors pushing shift are budget constraints, shift to all-volunteer army and recent turmoil in French-speaking African countries (M)

headline: Survey Ranks Nigeria as Most Corrupt Nation
abstract: Corruption Perception Index issued by Transparency International ranks Nigeria for second year in a row as world's most corrupt country; Denmark is listed as least corrupt; United States ranks 16th-cleanest (M)

headline: Agency Is Sought For Hotel Alliance
abstract: Hilton Hotels Corp and Hilton International Corp are seeking advertising agency to handle account of strategic alliance between two hoteliers (S)

headline: PATRICK INDUSTRIES SAYS IT RECEIVED A TAKEOVER OFFER
abstract: Patrick Industries receives takeover proposal from unidentified company that its board is considering (S)

headline: NATO General Vows to Curb Bosnian Mobs
abstract: Gen Wesley K Clark, new NATO commander, warns American and other Western peacekeeping troops in Bosnia will use 'lethal means' to protect selves against sort of mob violence used in recent days by Bosnian Serbs, news conference; sees pattern of violence aimed at dissuading NATO force from enforcing peace accord; American forces are clearly preparing for new round of confrontations with Bosnian Serb mobs backing ousted Pres Radovan Karadzic as they try to shore up forces loyal to Pres Biljana Plavsic (M

headline: HECHINGER ACCEPTS REDUCED OFFER FROM LEONARD GREEN
abstract: Hechinger Co will accept 21 percent lower acquisition offer of $2.375 a share, a total of $100.2 million, from Leonard Green & Partners LP because Hechinger's second-quarter loss was worse than expected (S)

headline: In cyberspace, neither nostalgia nor board games are what they used to be.
abstract: Edward Rothstein comment on playing computerized versions of classic board games against anonymous rivals via Internet; photo (M)

headline: Pennzoil Holders Accept Offer
abstract: Union Pacific Resources Group says holders of 61.5 percent of Pennzoil Co's stock agreed to accept its $84-a-share hostile takeover; but Union Pacific Resources says it will not purchase shares until Pennzoil or the courts eliminate anti-takeover defenses that its target had erected to make buyout prohibitively expensive (S)

headline: Credit-Data Web Site Suspended
abstract: World Wide Web site where consumers could look at their credit histories is shut down after some reports are sent to wrong people due to technical problem; before the problem, the site, run by Experian Inc, had raised fears among consumer advocates that there would be misuse of personal information available through the site (M)

headline: Pepsi Names Agencies In Soft-Drink Review
abstract: Pepsi-Cola International names three agencies to participate in creative review for Mirinda and 7Up soft-drink brands, with billings estimated at $20 million to $25 million (S)

headline: Robert J. Schwartz, 50, a Leader in Use Of Financial Hedges
abstract: Robert J Schwartz Jr, banker who was among first to promote derivatives as financial instrument to help companies hedge against fluctuating currencies or interest rates, dies at age 50 (M)

headline: Charles Takes Diana's Body Home From Paris : World Mourns the 'People's Princess'
abstract: LONDON  The body of Diana, Princess of Wales, was brought back to Britain on Sunday by Prince Charles, and Prime Minister Tony Blair expressed a nation's grief over the loss of "the people's princess" after her storybook life ended tragically when a car she was riding in crashed at very high speed in a Paris tunnel.

headline: Deal Spotlights New Shrewdness in Detective Business

headline: 2 Leading Suppliers of Oil Drilling Equipment Plan to Merge
abstract: Reading & Bates Corp and Falcon Drilling Co, two of world's largest suppliers of oil drilling equipment, are merging; merger would create a company with largest fleet of ships that drill for oil in deep water in the world; under terms of the deal, which companies call a merger of equals, new holding company is to be formed called R & B Falcon Corp (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: EXCEL REALTY TRUST, San Diego, a real estate investment trust, acquired nine shopping centers in California and Nevada for about $84.5 million.    COOPER INDUSTRIES, Houston, acquired Kearney Co., Tucker, Ga., a maker of switches and other electrical equipment, from the closely held Dyson-Kissner-Moran Corp. for an undisclosed price.    DU PONT MERCK PHARMACEUTICAL CO., Wilmington, Del., a joint venture of Du Pont Co. and Merck & Co., agreed to sell its generic drug business, Endo Pharmaceuticals L.L.C., to a management-led group. Terms were not disclosed.

headline: BANDAG TO PAY $158.5 MILLION FOR 5 RETREAD TIRE DEALERS
abstract: Bandag Inc agrees to acquire five franchised Bandag retread tire dealerships for $158.5 million (S)

headline: But U.S. Solar Cell Makers See Clouds Rolling In From Overseas
abstract: American solar power industry has never been so successful; with $850 million in sales last year, American manufacturers remain global leaders in systems that make electricity from sunlight; industry is worried about future because so far most of demand for solar power systems is overseas; foreign competitors, aroused by American industry's mounting success, have begun sniffing about; Federal Government is taking steps to keep American solar companies in technical vanguard; having poured some $1.5 billion of research money into solar industry over last 25 years, Government wants to help keep some of benefits in US; major part of effort involves easing American companies' reliance on exports by fostering demand and stimulating innovative uses in US; graph; photos (L)

headline: GROUP SEEKING TO BUY XPEDITE INCREASES ITS OFFER
abstract: Investment group seeking to buy Xpedite Systems raises its offer price 50 cents a share, to $23 (S)

headline: U.N. Renews Censure of New Israeli Housing in East Jerusalem
abstract: United Nations General Assembly, 131-3, condemns Israel for continuing to build housing in East Jerusalem; threatens boycott of products made in disputed areas and Israeli rights within UN; United States and Israel accuse General Assembly of reverting to cold-war era anti-Israeli crusades; Dore Gold, new Israeli UN representative, holds Palestinians tend to bring impasses to UN and international community, tactic doomed to fail, interview (M)

headline: Mumeo Oku, Japanese Pioneer In Women's Rights, Dies at 101
abstract: Mumeo Oku, pioneer in Japan's consumer movement and early campaigner for women's rights, dies at age 101; photo (M)

headline: Indonesia Reins In Property Developers
abstract: Bank Indonesia says that is its prohibiting new loans to property companies for land purchases and that existing land holdings cannot be used as collateral for new loans (S)
