abstract: Market Place column examines management crisis at AT&T following resignation of heir apparent John R Walter following escalating struggle with chief executive Robert E Allen; photo (M)

headline: 15 in Accord on Computer Disk Standard
abstract: Fifteen of world's biggest electronics manufacturers, including Fujitsu Ltd of Japan, LSI Logic Corp of United States and Philips Electronics NV of Netherlands, say they have agreed on standards for powerful new computer disk (S)

headline: The Evolution of the Calculator
abstract: Article on development of calculator on 30th anniversary of first hand-held electronic calculator, created by three engineers at Texas Instruments Inc; photos (M)

headline: ISRAELIS THREATEN MAJOR CRACKDOWN IN ARAB-RUN AREAS
abstract: Israeli Government reportedly threatens to send commandos into Palestinian areas and decrees severe punitive measures against Palestinian Authority in response to deadly bombing of Jerusalem market; measures include freeze on tax transfers, jamming of radio broadcasts and closing of Palestinian office in Jerusalem; suicide bombers killed 13 people and wounded more than 170 others; photos; map; Palestinian leaders bitterly denounce sanctions; bodies of two terrorists, apparently from Hamas, remain unidentified, although Israeli police raid Palestinian village near Hebron and seize relatives of two men missing for more than year; Prime Min Benjamin Netanyahu assails Yasir Arafat for condoning and encouraging terrorism, while Arafat says Netanyahu is trying to blame him for latest collapse of peace efforts (M)

headline: Brazil Hiccups. Funds Sneeze.
abstract: Mutual funds that invest in Latin America, while up sharply for year, were hurt by recent plunge in stock prices in Brazil and resulting drop in other Latin American stock prices; graphs (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Wage Gap Widens Again Between Men and Women  After nearly two decades in which the wage gap between men and women narrowed steadily, it is now widening again. According to the Bureau of Labor Statistics, the median weekly earnings of full-time working women are just under 75 percent of the men's median, down from 77 percent four years ago.

headline: Trade Deficit Is 17% Wider: Record Imports, Dip in Exports
abstract: US Commerce Department reports nation's trade deficit grew 17 percent in May as strong economy drew in record level of imports while exports fell slightly; gap between exports and imports grew to $10.23 billion, from $8.75 billion in April, bigger increase in deficit than analysts had expected; deficit with Japan narrowed for the month, but deficits with Canada, Mexico and China all expanded, graph (L)

headline: Philippine Peso, Cut Loose by Central Bank, Falls
abstract: Philippine central bank abandons its defense of peso, which drops over 11 percent (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Computer Makers vs. the Television Industry  The recent challenge Microsoft, Intel and Compaq issued to the television industry seems to be fading. The computer makers said they would set the standards for the new digital era. But even others in the personal computer business have failed to lend support, and the three-company front appears to be crumbling. $(Page D2.$)    Growth on Long Island  In the 1990's, Long Island is undergoing a nontraditional economic recovery. As military contracting has all but disappeared, the area has engineered a revival heavily reliant on smaller companies, computer technology, retailing and business services. $(A1.$)

headline: Treasury to Offer Bills and Notes
abstract: The Treasury's financings this week consist of today's regular weekly auction of three-  and six-month bills and the sale of an inflation-protection security on Wednesday.    The new issue, a five-year note, was offered in when-issued trading at a price to yield 3.53 percent.

headline: Harcourt General Sets $236 Million Charge
abstract: Harcourt General Inc to take charges of some $236 million after taxes, resulting in loss for third quarter, in part to dismiss 50 workers after June acquisition of National Education Corp (S)

headline: Comfort and Counsel in Times of Grief
abstract: Dozens of Internet sites offer advice on dealing with death, from virtual memorials to news groups; sites, as whole, form extensive support network for grieving family and friends; list; drawing (M)

headline: Old Ulster Enemies Face Each Other for First Time in Talks
abstract: Political leaders from both sides in Northern Ireland will hold face-to-face meetings for first time in 75 years of sporadic sectarian violence (S)

headline: Disk Maker's Shares Climb On Microsoft Connection
abstract: Shares in Nimbus CD International Inc rise 14 percent on heavy volume after company announces that it has signed contract to become authorized manufacturer of digital disks for Microsoft Corp; Nimbus, largest independent compact disk manufacturer in United States, also reports first-quarter earnings that, while down sharply from year earlier, slightly exceed Wall Street analysts' expectations (M)

headline: DIARY
abstract: WALL STREET  Travelers to Buy Salomon In $9 Billion Stock Deal  Travelers Group, a sprawling ensemble of financial services companies, agreed to acquire Salomon Inc., the Wall Street powerhouse that owns Salomon Brothers, for more than $9 billion in stock. The deal was a crowning achievement for Sanford I. Weill, Travelers' chairman. By combining Salomon, which is strong in bonds, with its Smith Barney brokerage, Travelers will rival Wall Street leaders like Merrill Lynch, American Express and Citicorp, as well as the biggest financial firms in Europe and Japan. Warren E. Buffett, who controls almost 20 percent of Salomon, will exchange his holding for a 3 percent stake in Travelers -- still significant for so large a company. The deal is likely to touch off another round of mergers among insurance concerns, brokerage firms and commercial banks.    THE ECONOMY  First Fear, Then Hope  Durable goods orders rose 2.7 percent last month, well above analysts' expectations, to a record of nearly $186.6 billion, the Commerce Department said. The increase, the third consecutive monthly advance, reflected booming demand for electronic products. That report, combined with a report from the Labor Department that jobless claims fell unexpectedly by 2,000 the previous week, to a seasonally adjusted 306,000, renewed fears that the Federal Reserve might push up interest rates to ward off inflation. But on Friday the Commerce Department reported that the economy grew a bit more slowly in the second quarter than previously estimated. Gross domestic product, the broadest measure of national economic activity, grew at a 3.3 percent annual rate in the quarter, down from the 3.6 percent rate reported a month ago. The new figure eased the fears of a rate increase.    MARKETS  Recovering From a Slide  The slower economic growth, in turn, reinvigorated financial markets. Bond prices were up, sending their yields lower. The 30-year Treasury bond ended the week at 100 5/32, to yield 6.36 percent, down 1 basis point. That helped stocks recover on Friday from a three-day slide. The Nasdaq index hit a record high of 1,689.18, before ending the week at 1,682.24, up 1.87 points. Propelled by a surge of 74.17 on Friday, the Dow Jones industrial average closed at 7,922.18, up 4.91 points for the week.     COMPUTING  I.B.M. Holds the Chips  I.B.M. plans to make chips early next year that are 40 percent more powerful than the most advanced chips now made commercially. The computer maker said it had solved a fundamental problem, enabling it to use microscopic copper wiring on silicon chips, instead of the aluminum now used. The new process will also cut chip-making costs by 20 to 30 percent. Separately, Intel, which supplies the chips that are the brains of 80 percent of the world's personal computers, said the F.T.C. was investigating whether it engaged in any practices that would deter computer makers from using competitors' chips. Intel is cooperating. But no matter who makes the chips, employers want to be sure they are used for their benefit. Many are cracking down on employees who use office PC's to play games or send personal E-mail.    PEOPLE  Family Values Win  Brenda Barnes resigned as president and chief executive of Pepsi-Cola North America, citing family reasons. ''Every time you would miss a child's birthday, or a school concert or a parent-teacher discussion, you'd feel the tug,'' said Ms. Barnes, who has three children, aged 10, 8 and 7. Pepsico, the parent company, named Philip A. Marineau, the former Quaker Oats executive who was praised for the success of Gatorade but held responsible for the decline of Snapple, to replace her. He is quitting as president of Dean Foods. . . . William H. Joyce, chief executive of Union Carbide, made a seemingly heroic gesture: If the company fails to earn $4 a share in 2000, he will return his base salary. But some compensation experts were not impressed. He'll be paid the salary, which amounts to only 20 percent of total compensation, and if the earnings fall short of the target, an amount equal to the salary will be deducted from other compensation . . . Ron Carey, the teamsters president, asserted that he was a victim, not a participant, in improper fund-raising. Three top aides have pleaded guilty; he accused them of betrayal.     CABLE TV  The Rates Keep Climbing  Cable television rates are spiraling upward, and two consumer groups, the Consumer Federation of America and Consumers Union, blamed the F.C.C., saying that it failed to keep a rein on an aggressive industry. Cable rates have risen at three times the inflation rate since the telecommunications law was passed in early 1996, the groups said. They asked the commission to freeze rates and to overhaul its formula for determining reasonable rates.     TOBACCO  Business Better Than Usual  Tobacco industry profits could soar under terms of a legal settlement proposed in June by 40 state attorneys general and cigarette makers, according to a new analysis by the F.T.C. It said the tobacco companies could reap as much as $123 billion in additional profits in the next 25 years if the settlement plan were adopted as drafted. It found that the real cost to industry would be about $207 billion, not the stated $368.5 billion value of the settlement. On the other hand, a Stanford University economist, Jeremy I. Bulow, calculated that the industry could easily live -- and conceivably thrive -- with President Clinton's alternative plan, which calls for raising cigarette prices as much as $1.50 a pack to discourage teen-age smoking.     HEALTH CARE  3 H.M.O.'s Back Regulation  Three big health maintenance organizations joined two consumer groups in calling for more regulation of managed health care, saying that all health plans should be subject to ''legally enforceable national standards.'' Until now, H.M.O.'s had generally sought voluntary, not governmental, standards. But three nonprofit H.M.O.'s with a total of more than 10 million members -- Kaiser Permanente, based in California; HIP Health Insurance Plans, based in New York, and the Group Health Cooperative of Puget Sound, based in Seattle -- said regulation was needed to restore the confidence of many patients.

headline: APPLE HIRES HEIDRICK & STRUGGLES FOR EXECUTIVE SEARCH
abstract: Apple Computer Inc hires Heidrick & Struggles Inc, an executive search firm, to help computer maker find a new chief executive (S)

headline: Stymied, SBC Seeks to Void Portion of Law
abstract: SBC Communications Inc sues Government, seeking to overturn critical provision of Telecommunications Act of 1996; SBC contends that act is unconstitutional because it prohibits SBC and five other regional Bell telephone companies from offering long-distance service until they have opened their local monopolies to competition; while SBC and other phone companies have sued Federal Communications Commission for how it is carrying out the act, this is first time a company has attacked the law itself (L)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Dow Sets Another Record, Rising by More Than 100  The Dow Jones industrial average hit its 32d record close of the year and its first above 7,900. It surged 103.82 points, or 1.32 percent, to 7,962.31, as investors remained optimistic about corporate profits and a stable economy. Broader market indexes also set records, with the Standard & Poor's 500 rising 6.55 points, to 918.75, and the Nasdaq composite index increasing 14.36 points, to 1,485.10.   The Dow was bolstered by heavy demand for cyclical issues, like International Paper -- which announced that it planned to cut its work force and sell assets -- as well as Caterpillar and Du Pont. $(Page D6.$)

headline: At Janus, Two Funds Lure the Most Cash
abstract: Assets under management at Janus Capital Corp, which manages Janus mutual funds and is 83 percent owned by Kansas City Southern Industries, have soared by 48 percent in 1997, to $68 billion; rise dwarfs gain at Berger Associates, also owned by Kansas City Southern, whose $4 billion in assets have grown by only about 10 percent; most of new money has gone into two Janus international portfolios managed by Helen Young Hayes, while flow of money into 10 domestic funds has been dropping steadily; graph (M)1

headline: J. B. HUNT SELLS FLATBED DIVISION FOR $40 MILLION
abstract: J B Hunt Transport Services Inc sells flatbed division for $40 million in net cash to division's management (S)

headline: Immunex Shares Jump on New Drug Data
abstract: Shares of Immunex Corp rise sharply after company releases positive clinical trials data on new drug, Enbrel, for rheumatoid arthritis; some analysts believe drug could be $1 billion product; stock of Scios Inc gains after company reports positive data on drug, Natrecor, for congestive heart failure (L)

headline: Seagram Sets Big Buyback Of Its Shares
abstract: Seagram Co says its board has given permission for company to purchase up to 10 percent of Seagram's 228.5 million publicly traded shares (S)

headline: Dow Sputters, but Small Stocks March On
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average finishes down 26.77 points at 7,970.06; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index gives up 3.50 points, closing at 951.93; Nasdaq composite index gains 7.91 points, closing at 1,697.36, while Russell 200 index gains 0.44 point, to close at record 449.42; chart (L)

headline: World Bank Report Sees Era of Emerging Economies
abstract: World Bank forecasts that growth in developing countries will accelerate over next decade, and that five biggest economies--China, India, Indonesia, Brazil and Russia--will become economic powerhouses in next quarter-century; bank forecasts that growth in developing nations will surge to average of 5.4 percent a year through 2006, up from 4.5 percent in 1996 and 2.3 percent from 1991 through 1995 (L)

headline: Faction Surrenders in Cambodia, But Renewed Fighting Is Predicted
abstract: Hun Sen, one of Cambodia's two Prime Ministers, declares victory after two days of heavy factional fighting; white flag is raised over residence of other Prime Minister, Prince Norodom Ranariddh, who is abroad; it is unclear whether fighting is over; Hun Sen calls rival traitor who should be put on trial, radio speech; calls on royalist party to name new First Prime Minister; break in governing coalition could drive royalists and Khmer Rouge together in opposition to Hun Sen; photo (M)

headline: GSD&M Is Named By Bank of America
abstract: Bank of America names GSD&M to handle broadcast media buying portion of its advertising account, with billings estimated at $20 million to $25 million; account was previously handled on interim basis by Deutsch Inc (S)

headline: Bond Prices Dip on Sale Of New Notes
abstract: US Treasury prices fall slightly after what traders call expensive auction of new five-year notes; benchmark 30-year bond falls 9/32, to 102 18/32; yield rises to 6.43 percent, from 6.41 percent on July 22; graph (L)

headline: TEL-SAVE AGREES TO BUY SHARED TECHNOLOGIES
abstract: Tel-Save Holdings Inc to buy Shared Technologies Fairchild Inc for about $511 million (S)

headline: Remarks Send Dollar Lower Against Yen
abstract: US dollar plunges against yen after remarks by Eisuke Sakakibara, Japan's vice finance minister of international affairs, that Group of Seven accord over the weekend supports a stronger yen (S)

headline: Eli Lilly Reports Net Loss, But It Had Operating Profit
abstract: Eli Lilly & Co reports net loss in second quarter, reflecting previously announced charge of $2.4 billion; profit from operations rose 21 percent; profit increased to $417 million from $345.7 million; total sales rose 17 percent, to $1.98 billion from $1.70 billion; Lilly says its drug Evista, for osteoporosis, will receive faster-than-usual review from regulators (M)

headline: Reily Foods Work To Martin/Williams
abstract: Reily Foods Co has named Martin/Williams in Minneapolis to handle creative and strategic services, formerly handled by Ryan Drossman & Partners in New York; billings estimated at $3 million to $5 million (S)

headline: UUNET TECHNOLOGIES ACQUIRES NLNET OF THE NETHERLANDS
abstract: Worldcom Inc's Uunet Technologies unit, Internet service provider, acquires Nlnet of the Netherlands for undisclosed amount of stock; acquisition of Nlnet, a Dutch Internet service provider, will allow Uunet to provide wider group of networking services to businesses in Europe (S)

headline: WebTV Introduces a System Linking Live TV and Internet
abstract: WebTV Networks, designers of set-up boxes that bring Internet services to television screens, introduces upgraded version that melds live television programming with related pages on World Wide Web; for last year, WebTV, subsidiary of Microsoft Corp, has been selling boxes that allow users to browse Web on their television sets, using connection to regular telephone line (S)

headline: Informix to Restate Financial Results
abstract: Informix Corp will restate 1996 financial results because of errors in recording of revenue; estimates about $70 million to $100 million of revenue will be adjusted; reported net income of $97.8 million for 1996, on revenues of $939.3 million (S)

headline: U.S. Petroleum Data
abstract: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization             Aug. 1   July 25   Aug. 2          1997   1997   1996       Gasoline production, daily   7.8   7.9   7.6       Distillate production, daily   3.4   3.4   3.2       Gasoline stocks   191.9   194.6   197.7       Distillate stocks   121.5   119.3   103.9       Crude imports, daily   7.8   8.1   8.0       Product imports, daily   1.8   1.7   2.1       Crude stocks   309.4   308.9   309.6       Crude production, daily   6.3   6.3   6.4       Refinery utilization (%)   97.1   96.1   94.0          Source: American Petroleum Institute

headline: Leo Burnett Plans Layoffs
abstract: Leo Burnett USA division of Leo Burnett Co in Chicago is laying off employees because of recent account losses; agency will dismiss 74 people, or 3.7 percent of its staff of 1,990 (S)

headline: MARKET TIMING
abstract: List of upcoming events affecting stock market

headline: MEXICO'S GOVERNING PARTY LOSES CONTROL OF CONGRESS, ENDING 7-DECADE MONOPOLY
abstract: Mexico's Governing Party Loses Control Of Congress, Ending 7-Decade Monopoly** Institutional Revolutionary Party, which controlled Mexican politics for more than 70 years, loses control of Congress in legislative elections, ending single-party rule and ushering in era of pluralistic-give-and take; gains only 38 percent of vote for lower house of legislature, failing to win majority for first time since founding in 1929; combined vote for two main opposition parties gives them approximately 52 percent; shows opposition nearly evenly divided between Party of the Democratic Revolution, which supports major role for government in economy and is skeptical of close relations with US, and conservative National Action Party, which has strong Catholic influence, opposes statist economic policies and is comfortable with strong political ties with US; photo; map; chart (M)

headline: Losses Expected From Pay-TV Start-Up
abstract: Bertelsmann AG of Germany expects start-up losses of two billion to three billion marks for its planned pay-TV service; company hopes to have six million subscribers within 10 years (S)

headline: Cashing In On Hoopla: A Colony Of Kitsch
abstract: Celebration marking transfer of rule in Hong Kong to China may be moment of patriotic pride, but is also business opportunity for merchants who can profit by selling mementos commemmorating event (M)

headline: Beyond the Ivory Tower, a Sabbatical Is a Valued Perk
abstract: Survey by Society for Human Resource Management finds 23 percent of members offer unpaid sabbaticals and 5 percent offer paid sabbaticals; sabbaticals can be carrot to recruit top talent or a reward to keep valued employees; photo (L)

headline: Chinese-Americans Rejoice, Dropping Politics for a Party
abstract: Chinese-Americans in New York celebrate return of Hong Kong to China; for many, event was chance to swell with pride and to identify with land from which they came (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Stocks Set Records, With the Dow Up 53  Stocks reached new highs, buoyed by economic reports that pointed toward low inflation and moderate growth. The Dow industrials surged 53.42 points, to 8,174.53.    Financial companies, American Express in particular, and companies that tend to prosper when the economy is doing well, like Caterpillar, were the catalysts. $(Page D8.$)

headline: Record Chicago Seat Sale
abstract: Chicago Board of Trade seat sells for record $130,000 (S)

headline: As Business Gets Lean, a Big King Dares Big Mac
abstract: Burger King will introduce version of signature Big Mac burger of McDonald's Corp; to be called the Big King, it will be available on Sept 1 at all 7,277 Burger King restaurants around the nation; McDonald's has laid groundwork to strike back at Burger King by test-marketing its own version of Burger King's flagship Whopper; called the Big and Tasty, it has yet to make its national debut; drawing (L)

headline: Corrections
abstract: Correction of table with Aug 17 article on junk-bond holdings of high-quality bond mutual fundst

headline: Thyssen Sells Its Stake In Mobile Phone Concern
abstract: Thyssen AG sells stake in E-Plus Mobilfunk, mobile phone operator, for $1.25 billion; purchaser is joint venture of Veba AG and RWE AG (S)

headline: AETNA NAMES PRESIDENT AND CHIEF EXECUTIVE
abstract: Aetna Inc names Richard L Huber as president and chief executive, ending weeks of uncertainty after resignation of Joseph T Sebastianelli (S)

headline: Executive of Top Pension Fund Leaving to Head New Travelers Unit
abstract: Travelers Group announces that Thomas W Jones, top executive at world's largest pension system, Teachers Insurance and Annuity Association-College Retirement Equities Fund (TIAA-CREF), will leave his posts there to join Travelers as vice chairman; Jones will oversee company's efforts to expand its fee-based asset management business (L)

headline: Stocks Drift Aimlessly as Dow Drops 28.34
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average closes off 28.34 points at 7,859.57; Nasdaq composite index rises 2.88 points, to 1,601.57; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index loses 3.39 points, to 920.16; table (L)

headline: Dow Surges 103.82 Points, to 7,962.31
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average surges 103.82 points, or 1.32 percent, to close at record 7,962.31; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rises 6.55 points, to record 918.75, and Nasdaq composite index increases 14.36 points, to record 1,485.10; Russell 2000 index also sets a record, gaining 2.02 points, to 398.28; table (L)

headline: For Stay-Home Workers, Speed Bumps on the Telecommute
abstract: Status of telecommuting assessed; Catherine Rossback discusses giving up working at home because she had no structure to working day and felt isolated, whereas Jenny Nelson, mother of three young children, says she enjoys flexibility of working for AT&T; from her Manhattan home; photos; 42 percent of companies have telecommuting arrangements, but only seven percent of their workers ever telecommute; analyst Christena Nippert-Eng says one in five arrangements fails, becuase employees have unrealistic expectations and employers are afraid of losing control; Dr Charles Grantham notes dearth of accurate data on number of people working at home in various ways; formal arrangements developed by Merrill Lynch and AT&T; explained (M)

headline: China, Pre-Marco Polo? Publisher Puts Off Book
abstract: Publisher, Little Brown & Co, postpones publication of The City of Light, book purporting to show that Jacob d'Ancona, 13th-century Italian-Jewish merchant, visited China four years before Marco Polo; move follows rumors among scholars that book may be hoax (M)

headline: A Key Ulster Protestant Agrees to Join Talks With Sinn Fein
abstract: David Trimble, head of largest Protestant political party in Northern Ireland, agrees to take part in formal, broad-based peace talks that include Sinn Fein, political wing of Irish Republican Army; is first Protestant unionist leader to agree to talks with Sinn Fein since Ireland was divided in 1922; says he will try to have Sinn Fein expelled from talks (M)

headline: Miscellany
abstract: * Publishers Information Bureau, New York, said magazine advertising pages in June increased 6.5 percent from June 1996, to 18,992. For the first six months of 1997, ad pages rose 5 percent from the corresponding period a year earlier, to 109,575.

headline: China's Leader Announces Sell-Off of State Enterprises
abstract: Pres Jiang Zemin opens China's 15th Communist Party Congress in Beijing by embracing program of bold economic reform for nation's ailing state-owned industries while deferring any significant change in nation's political system; more than 2,000 delegates attend congress to approve leaders and policy for coming five years, and Jiang presides there as unquestioned successor to late Deng Xiaoping (M)

headline: Questions Grow Over Haiti Peacekeepers' Role
abstract: Continued presence of United Nations peacekeepers in Haiti is focus of broad national debate as force's mandate is set to expire; UN Security Council is likely to extend mission through Nov 30; signs of fatigue are emerging, both among Haitians and nations backing mission; Enrique ter Horst, director of UN contingent, says Government, particularly fledgling national police, will continue to need technical aid after military leaves (M)

headline: Sihanouk, Back Home, Hopes to Be Mediator
abstract: King Norodom Sihanouk returns to Cambodia, voicing last, faint hope of peace and reconciliation; is greeted by nation's de facto leader, Hun Sen, and co-Prime Min Ung Huot; Hun Sen's army continues unsuccessfully to batter at band of several hundred holdout soldiers loyal to Prince Ranariddh; photo (M)

headline: Haitians in Brooklyn Turn To the Radio for Comfort
abstract: Haitian-Americans turn to Brooklyn radio station Radio Soleil d'Haiti for news about ferry that capsized off Haiti's coast and comfort as phone lines to Haiti remain busy throughout day (M)

headline: 2 Finalists Chosen In Midas Review
abstract: Midas International Corp narrows review on its advertising account to two agencies, DDB Needham and Foote, Cone & Belding; account had been handled by J Walter Thompson (S)

headline: Legal Uncertainty Clouds Status of Contracts on Internet
abstract: Business managers, corporate lawyers and legal scholars are uncertain about enforceability of electronic agreements, and this has had chilling effect, even at computer-astute companies; lawmakers are scrambling to fill gap between technology and the law; Profs Amelia H Boss and Raymond T Nimmer are helping revise Uniform Commercial Code to deal with electronic contracts; revised code, which individual state legislatures could adopt, adapt or ignore at their own choosing, is at least year away from completion; photos (M)

headline: CHINA RESUMES CONTROL OF HONG KONG, CONCLUDING 156 YEARS OF BRITISH RULE
abstract: China regains sovereignty over Hong Kong at stroke of midnight on July 1, 1997, ending 156 years of British colonial rule; British flag is lowered and Chinese flag raised in ceremonies of solemn precision presided over by Prince Charles of Great Britain and Chinese Pres Jiang Zemin; ceremonies in convention center described; Prince Charles lauds Britain for providing framework of opportunity within which Hong Kong has conspicuously succeeded; Jiang hails transfer as celebration for China and victory for universal cause of peace and justice; says Hong Kong has entered new era of development; gives oath of office to Tung Chee-Hwa, British-educated shipping magnate who is Beijing's choice to govern territory; elected Legislature is abolished, and Beijing-appointed body of lawmakers takes its place; 4,000 Chinese troops arrive, and range of civil liberties is rolled back; other immediate changes across Hong Kong described; Prince Charles and former colonial Governor, Chris Patten, leave aboard royal yacht Britannia; transfer of power ushers in time of uncertainty over whether China will honor pledge to maintain Hong Kong's way of life largely unaltered for next 50 years; photos (M)

headline: Technology Is Wagging the Market's Tail
abstract: Wall Street analysts note that in 11 of last 14 years technology stocks underperformed broader market in summer, but that in three of last four years, they outperformed broader market, as they have so far this summer; technology stocks on July 14 send Nasdaq composite index up 21.26 points, or 1.4 percent, to 1,523.88--its eighth consecutive record close; graph (M)

headline: INTELLIGENT ELECTRONICS SELLS COMPUTER BUSINESS TO G.E.
abstract: Intelligent Electronics Inc sells most of its direct computer sales business to General Elecctric Co for $136 million (S)

headline: Copper and Coffee Futures Take a Beating
abstract: Copper prices tumble on continuing signs that rising world production and slowing demand are increasing inventories; coffee prices slide (S)

headline: Government to Keep Control of Air France
abstract: French Government has decided to retain majority stake in Air France, move that will probably prompt its chairman Christian Blanc to resign (S)

headline: U.S. Petroleum Data
abstract: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization             Aug. 8   Aug. 1   Aug. 9          1997   1997   1996       Gasoline production, daily   7.9   7.8   7.7       Distillate production, daily   3.4   3.4   3.1       Gasoline stocks   191.1   191.9   198.7       Distillate stocks   120.7   121.5   104.3       Crude imports, daily   9.0   7.8   8.2       Product imports, daily   1.4   1.8   1.5       Crude stocks   312.2   309.4   308.1       Crude production, daily   6.3   6.3   6.4       Refinery utilization (%)   95.0   97.1   94.7          Source: American Petroleum Institute

headline: BASF UNIT TO PAY $98 MILLION TO SETTLE SYNTHROID SUIT
abstract: BASF AG, Germany, says its United States-based Knoll Pharmaceutical unit has agreed to pay $98 million to settle class action lawsuit by thyroid patients who said the company suppressed study saying its best-selling Synthroid drug was no beter than generic versions, suit, US District Court, San Francisco (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: COCA-COLA COMPANY, Atlanta, said that third-quarter case sales of its beverages would rise 9 percent to 10 percent worldwide, led by stronger-than-expected growth in Europe and Latin America.     OXFORD PROPERTIES GROUP INC., Toronto, a commercial real estate ownership and management company, agreed to buy two Canadian properties and increased its stake in another for a total of $132 million (Canadian), or $95.3 million (United States).     LUMISYS INC., San Jose, Calif., agreed to acquire Compurad Inc. of Tucson, Ariz., a health care software developer, for about $24.5 million in stock. Compurad shareholders will receive 0.928 of a Lumisys share for each share held.

headline: Kodak, in Retailing Push, to Open Up to 500 Co-Branded Stores
abstract: Eastman Kodak Co is poised to put its name on 300 to 500 photo specialty stores across the country within next 18 months; Kodak hopes to strengthen its brand image at retail (L)

headline: Ethnic Strife in Kenya Derails Talks on Reform
abstract: Recent series of ethnic attacks has deepened sense of political crisis in Kenya and derailed talks betwen Pres Daniel arap Moi and opposition leaders; at least 37 people have been killed in violent raids by armed gangs around Mombasa and Malindi; map; photos (M)

headline: Treasury Securities Drop in Price
abstract: Prices of Treasury securities fall on July 14; 30-year bond declines 10/32, to 101 to yield 6.55 percent (M)

headline: Dickson Concepts Makes Deal to Take Control of Barney's
abstract: Dickson Concepts (International) to buy 51 percent of bankrupt Barney's Inc for $78 million and provide some $127 million in new financing; deal includes $42 million note to be repaid by Isetan Co for use of chain's name in Asia; Barney's creditors, including Isetan, would divide $205 million and remaining 49% of chain; co-chief executives Bob and Gene Pressman would have role in reorganized company; Bob Pressman hails deal, phone interview (M)

headline: Panama's Move to Oust Editor Sets Off Storm
abstract: Gustavo Gorriti, Peruvian journalist and associate editor of La Prensa, Panama's leading newspaper, is battling expulsion from Panama; has angered ruling elite with articles detailing corruption and other questionable practices in campaign and administration of Pres Ernesto Perez Balladares and his party; Perez Ballardares has rejected requests by human rights groups and State Dpartment that he halt expulsion effort; Gorriti has taken refuge in newspaper office (M)

headline: Mahathir Halts Infrastructure Projects : Malaysia Threatens Economic 'Saboteurs'
abstract: SINGAPORE  Malaysia threatened Thursday to use its tough anti-subversion law to arrest those who "sabotage" its economy and announced that it had been forced to postpone key construction projects because of damage to its currency from financial market turmoil.

headline: Crude Oil Prices Rise on Hurricane Threat
abstract: Crude oil prices rise on New York Mercantile Exchange on concerns that hurricane in Caribbean would disrupt operations at refineries in area; on other markets, corn and soybeans fall (M)

headline: Evidence in Crash on Guam Is Reported to Indicate Pilot Error
abstract: Newly gathered evidence rules out mechanical failure and points to pilot error as cause of crash of Korean Air Lines Boeing 747 during landing approach to airport on Guam; crash killed 225 of 254 people aboard (M)

headline: Relatives File Civil Suits
abstract: French criminal investigation into death of Princess Diana in car accident gathers momentum with filing of civil suits by her mother and sisters that will allow them to seek damages if there is trial (S)

headline: Corrections
abstract: Correction of Aug 17 article on Hartford Capital Appreciation mutual fund

headline: Socking It Away for College, With Uncle Sam's Help
abstract: Article on new Federal tax bill focuses on new class of educational savings accounts modeled on Individual Retirement Accounts; says law allows contributions of $500 a child; adds contributions are not tax-deductible, but earnings in account accumulate tax free, and withdrawals are tax free when used for undergraduate or graduate-level tuition, room, board or books; graph (L)

headline: Saving Those Senior Discounts
abstract: Marcia Magill letter on Ted M Levine's July 27 article questioning need to offer elderly senior discounts; drawing (S)

headline: REXALL SUNDOWN IN $779 MILLION BID FOR TWINLAB
abstract: Rexall Sundown Inc is in discussions to acquire Twinlab Corp for about $779 million (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Makers of Oil-Drilling Gear Agree to a Combination  Reading & Bates and Falcon Drilling, two of the world's largest suppliers of oil drilling rigs and other equipment, said that they were merging in a stock deal.

headline: Race for 2004 Olympics Comes Down to the Wire
abstract: LAUSANNE, Switzerland  The outcome of many Olympic races last summer in Atlanta was easier to predict than the election that will take place Friday to name a host city for the 2004 Summer Olympics.

headline: Chicago Seat Record Price
abstract: Chicago Board of Trade says that seat giving the owner right to trade financial contracts sold for record $140,000 (S)

headline: VSI HOLDINGS IN DEAL FOR PROVIDER OF TECHNICAL SERVICES
abstract: VSI Holdings Inc agrees to acquire Visual Services Inc for $77.7 million in stock (S)

headline: In a Healthy Economy, Bond Funds Load Up on Junk
abstract: Low interest rates and strong economy are leading high-quality corporate bond funds to invest in junk bonds, and lower-quality funds to acquire more debt from emerging markets (S)

headline: Pair Hope to Help Farmers, Too : Putting a New Spin On Philippine Silk
abstract: MANILA  When Jean Goulbourn designed the barong shirts for the 18 leaders of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum who gathered in Manila late last year, she embroidered each front side with a column of intricate reproductions of Filipino windows from Spanish ancestral homes, churches and peasant bamboo huts.

headline: Dividend Meetings
abstract: A partial list for this week.    MONDAY   Dames & Moore  Jefferson-Pilot  Minn Mng & Mfg  OM Group  Pillowtex  Total Sys Svcs

headline: Yeltsin's Old Confidant Spills All in a Book
abstract: Aleksandr Korzhakov, uniquely powerful and widely feared until he was dismissed as Russian Pres Boris N Yeltsin's security chief last year, holds news conference, Moscow, on his book attacking Yeltsin, Boris Yeltsin: From Dawn to Dusk; complains security services he once controlled put pressure on printing houses not to publish book; portrayal of Yeltsin as man who drinks heavily, hides his health problems and is frequently out of touch is unlikely to shock Russians; excerpts are published in London Sunday Times and several Russian newspapers; photo (M)

headline: Brother (or Sister), Can You Spare a Dime for a Boom-Era Economist?
abstract: Economists at National Association for Business Economics annual meeting say sustained prosperity, corporate downsizing that has made research expendable and backlash against economic fraternity's inlfated forecasting claims have all combined to make life of business economist tougher than ever; they say for many economists, job insecurity is not abstract principle but a day-to-day reality (L)

headline: Correction: Leading Accounting Firms
abstract: Chart in Business Day on Sept 19 ranking Big Six accounting firms on several measures, included some incorrect figures for Ernst & Young and thus ranked firms incorrectly in several categories (S)

headline: IMMUNEX SHARES SOAR ON NEWS OF DEAL TO SELL NEW DRUG
abstract: Shares of Immunex Corp rise 10.7 percent after American Home Products Corp agrees to pay Immunex as much as $100 million for right to sell its rheumatoid arthritis drug, Enbrel (S)

headline: 20-Inch Screen, or 20% Return?
abstract: Funds Watch column notes survey finding that many Americans are far more confident about their ability to select television set than to choose mutual fund (S)

headline: Executive Changes
abstract: THE LIMITED INC., Columbus, Ohio, named Robert Bernard president and chief executive of Limited Stores, a chain of women's clothing stores.    LIZ CLAIBORNE INC., New York, named Gaetano Sallorenzo president of Liz Claiborne Europe.

headline: Dividend Meetings
abstract: A partial list for this week.    MONDAY  AK Stl Hldg Corp  Frontier Corp  Kimco Rlty Corp  Roc Communities    TUESDAY  Culp Inc  Essex Ppty TR Inc  Fisher Scientific Intl  Malan Rlty Invs Inc  Pioneer Hi Bred Intl  Pulitzer Pubg Co  Southwest Gas Corp

headline: Money Manager for Colleges Is Told to Return $2.6 Million
abstract: Securities and Exchange Commission and Commodity Futures Trading Commission order First Capital Stategists and its four partners to return $2.6 million to colleges and universities that lost more than $137 million on unauthorized investments by former First Capital trader Kent A Ahrens; without admitting or denying agencies' findings, First Capital and partners John J McCollum, Paul J Gangemi, Robert E Frith Jr and Keith H Cunningham agree to pay $2.6 million to educational institutions that lost money by investing through Common Fund (L)

headline: INTEL AND COMPAQ PLAN JOINT NETWORKING PRODUCTS
abstract: Intel Corp and Compaq Computer Corp are forming alliance to develop products aimed at reducing bottlenecks in computer networks (S)

headline: A 14-Brand Monopoly Takes 98% of Sales
abstract: South African Breweries Ltd controls 98 percent of beer sales, under 14 different labels, in that country; what makes South African Breweries noteworthy is how it defies stereotype that monopolies are sluggish and inefficient; it is considered one of best-managed South African companies and one of toughest competitors; company's beer production costs are world's lowest; and it keeps price increases below inflation rate, so real cost of a beer, before excise taxes, has been halved in 20 years; graphs; photos (L)

headline: Diana and the Paparazzi: A Morality Tale
abstract: Princess Diana and photographers who pursued her were bound together in dance of attraction and repulsion throughout summer that reached deadly limit of contradictions on last day of her life, special report, Collision Course; chronology of events leading up to fatal nighttime accident in Paris highway tunnel; photos; diagram; map (L)

headline: Here's One Way You Can Beat the Bursar
abstract: More and more states are encouraging people to save for college education; one of main types of state college savings programs is prepaid tuition plan, which allows families to put up money before a child is ready for college, and to lock in tuition in effect when they invest their money; tables; map shows states with college savings plans currently in effect, those with pending plans that will come into effect by January 2000 and those states with no current or near-term plans (L)

headline: Peso Crisis Bites Into Mexico's Long-Ruling Party
abstract: Millions of Mexicans are preparing to vote against governing Institutional Revolutionary Party (PRI) in upcoming elections, perhaps more than at any time since party was founded in 1929; biggest reason is that they continue to nurse wounds from economic crisis that the Government insists has long passed; voters in Cuernavaca have grown ornery, giving opposition politicians chance to wrest Congressional seat from PRI for first time in modern times; photos; map (M)

headline: Bond Prices Rise a Bit After Last Week's Selloff
abstract: US Treasury securities are higher, with selling on advances limiting session's gains; 30-year bond rises 11/32, to price of 97; yield falls to 6.61 percent, from 6.64 percent on Sept 5 (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Stocks Gain Over All, Though Dow Ends Lower  Stock prices were generally higher, despite a drop in the Dow industrials, closing a spectacular July run that took the main indexes to record highs.

headline: After record levels in the first half of 1997, account activity gets off to a strong start.
abstract: Advertising account activity is getting off to strong start in second half of 1997 after record levels in first half; activity of some major accounts detailed (L)

headline: WATKINS-JOHNSON TO SELL MILITARY-RELATED DIVISIONS
abstract: Watkins-Johnson Inc agrees to sell its military electronics and microwave components and subsystems business to TSMD Acquisition Corp for $103 million (S)

headline: U.S. Securities Markets Fall, Paring Early Gains by Dollar
abstract: US dollar rises modestly, erasing some early gains as US financial markets fall and offsetting positive effects of decision by Germany's Bundesbank to leave key money-market rate unchanged (M)

headline: 7 Wireless Allies to Create Nationwide Mobile Network
abstract: Seven regional wireless telephone companies from United States and Canada plan alliance that will eventually let customers use same mobile phone nationwide; companies share same GSM digital wireless technology, which is dominant worldwide, but not in United States, where major carriers have adopted rival standards; seven are Omnipoint Corp, Aerial Communications, BellSouth Mobility, Microcell Telecom, Pacific Bell-Mobile Services, Powertel Inc and Western Wireless (M)

headline: Asian Stock Damage Has Wider Effects
abstract: Southeast Asian stock markets continue to tumble, with declines of five percent or more in Hong Kong and Indonesia; significant effect is not expected in US, European or Latin American markets, although many American investors are taking millions of dollars out of mutual funds that invest in Asia (S)

headline: GOLDEN STATE BANCORP BUYING CENFED FINANCIAL
abstract: Golden State Bancorp says its Glendale Federal Bank unit will acquire Cenfed Financial Corp for about $210 million in stock (S)

headline: Lockheed Will Acquire Northrop for $11 Billion
abstract: NEW YORK  One of the final consolidations of the post-Cold War U.S. defense industry was announced Thursday when Lockheed Martin Corp. said it would acquire Northrop Grumman Corp. for $11.18 billion in stock and assumed debt.

headline: Pas de 2.0
abstract: Dance professionals are experimenting with rhythm and movement in virtual space before asking dancers to turn choreography into dance; best-known digital inroad is Lifeforms, software package from Credo Interactive that can be used to create a dance work on virtual three-dimensional stage; photo; diagrams (M)

headline: Smithfield Stock Split
abstract: Smithfield Foods Inc will split its stock 2 for 1 (S)

headline: TUPPERWARE STOCK FALLS ON FORECAST OF WEAK EARNINGS
abstract: Stock of Tupperware Corp falls 19 percent after company forecasts weak third-quarter earnings and flat sales and substantial decline in net income for full year (S)

headline: Slayer Tells Inquiry of Mandela Ally's Killing
abstract: After spending April 10, 1993, buying and testing bullets and silencers, Janusz Walus drove by Chris Hani's house, as he had done at least three times before, just for ''reconnaissance'' purposes. Although he intended eventually to kill Mr. Hani, one of this country's most popular black leaders, he still lacked a special ammunition to be used with the silencer.    But when Mr. Walus saw Mr. Hani leave his house alone and head for a shopping center, the assassin decided to follow his intended victim  and forget about using the silencer.  Mr. Walus watched Mr. Hani, who had given his bodyguards the day off, buy a newspaper. Then, using a shortcut, he beat Mr. Hani back to his house and waited, his gun behind his back.

headline: Japan Calls Mercury-Poisoned Bay Safe Now
abstract: Japanese regional government declares fish in Minamata Bay safe to eat; thousands of people suffered brain damage, other injuries after eating fish contaminated with mercury dumped into bay by Chisso Corp in 1950's and 60's; map (M)

headline: Apple Picks TBWA To Handle Europe
abstract: European unit of Apple Computer Inc selects TBWA International in Amsterdam to handle its creative account, with billings estimated at $20 million (S)

headline: Strike Closes Parts Factory In Job Dispute
abstract: Strike by UAW workers at General Motors Corp parts factory in Flint, Mich, shuts down plant; union members say they are determined to stay on strike until company gives in to their demands for increased staffing; if strike lasts more than a few days, it could shut down most of the company (M)

headline: TRW Seeking License for Satellite System
abstract: TRW Inc plans to build $3.4 billion global satellite system capable of transmitting and receiving digital data 100,000 times faster than today's PC modems; TRW plans to provide fixed satellite services in portions of extremely high frequencies spectrum, where only satellite system currently operating is military system built by TRW; TRW expects telephone companies and large corporations to be its biggest customers (M)

headline: G.I.'s Slaying in '92 Entangled in Panama's Politics
abstract: Pedro Miguel Gonzalez, son of powerful anti-American politician who is president of party that governs Panama, has still not been tried for slaying of US soldier, Sgt Zak A Hernandez, near Panama Canal in 1992; he remains imprisoned in air-conditioned jail cell equipped with television, cell phone, computer and fax; police official who led investigation that resulted in his arrest has been forced to resign, his life has been threatened and he faces prison on charges he and human rights groups say are fabrications; father, Gerardo Gonzalez, says son is innocent, and that there is no evidence against him (M)

headline: Small Stocks Gain, but Dow Loses 27.40
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average closes at 7,867.24, down 27.40 points; Standard & Poor's index of 500 companies rises 3.01 points, to 930.87; Nasdaq composite index gains 6.39 points, to close at 1,624.63; chart (L)

headline: More Leeway for Hedging
abstract: Roundup of mutual fund news; new tax law ended longstanding rule that discouraged short-term trading by mutual funds, giving fund managers more freedom and possibly increasing risks for shareholders; rule required funds to derive less than 30 percent of gross income from sales of securities held less than three months or lose their special tax status (M)

headline: Dow, Hit by Program Sales, Slides 119.88
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average closes down 119.88 points, or 1.51 percent, to 7,842.43; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index loses 11.21 points, or 1.22 percent, to close at 907.54; Nasdaq rises 1.53 points, to 1,486.63; table (L)

headline: Nikko Plans Venture With Smith Barney
abstract: Nikko Securities Co to form joint venture with Smith Barney to market wrap accounts in Japan (S)

headline: Without Surprise, Dell Posts Results That Beat Forecasts
abstract: Dell Computer Corp says second-quarter earnings ended Aug 3 were $214 million, more than twice $103 million reported in year-earlier quarter; sales rose 66.5 percent, to $2.81 billion, from $1.69 billion in quarter a year earlier; chart (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Dow Average Rises 49.54, Aided by Economic Reports  Bolstered by new evidence that economic growth is moderating and that inflation is under control, the stock market generally rose.    The Dow Jones industrial average climbed 49.54 points and closed at 7,722.33, about 70 points below its all-time high. Drug and financial stocks paced the advance, and the Standard & Poor's financials index rose sharply. But technology issues were weak, and the Nasdaq composite index fell 3.82, to 1,438.25. $(Page D6.$)

headline: U.S. Job Machine Absorbing Fresh Workers
abstract: United States labor force, composed of everyone working or actively seeking work, has been growing rapidly for 18 months and continues to grow faster than working-age population; four million more workers have joined growing economy since start of 1996, many of them Hispanics, younger women and men over 55; most are entering at relatively low pay, drawn into labor force by employers offering more than minimum wage; companies are recruiting among those ignored in past; graphs; map; photos (L)

headline: Cambodian Ruler Demands Ouster of U.N. Rights Team
abstract: Cambodian leader Hun Sen asks United Nations to replace its human rights team in Phnom Penh; demands apology from UN for reporting that his forces had executed at least 40 supporters of Prince Norodom Ranariddh; criticizes US for calling ouster of Ranariddh undemocratic (M)

headline: Spain Turns on Rebels With Outrage
abstract: Public outrage in Spain over assassination of town Councilman Miguel Angel Blanco by Basque separatists brought almost million people into streets of Barcelona and similar number in Madrid and offers vivid picture of Spain today: European democracy with large, confident middle class that yearns for stability; photo (M)

headline: Hilton Hotels Increases Its Offer For ITT to $70 a Share From $55
abstract: Hilton Hotels Corp renews attempted hostile takeover of ITT Corp, increasing offer to $70 per share from $55; sweetened bid is identical to price ITT said it would pay to repurchase about 25 percent of its own stock through cash tender offer, as part of strategy to fend off Hilton; analysts say new offer is realistic, and that Hilton may have backed ITT into corner from which it appears to have fewer options; graph (M)

headline: Lawyer Says 3d Test Confirms Diana's Driver Was Drunk
abstract: Third blood test confirms earlier findings that Henri Paul, driver in Paris crash that killed Diana, Princess of Wales, had level of alcohol produced by drinking eight or nine glasses of wine, more than three times legal limit in France; latest test reportedly shows 0.18 percent alcohol level and traces of anti-depressant drugs that could have compounded effect; lawyer for Mohamed al-Fayed, Ritz Hotel owner whose son also died in crash, says photo taken by one of pursuing paparazzi moments before crash shows Paul dazzled by camera flash from motorcycle (S)

headline: Welsh Back Home Rule, but It's Close
abstract: LONDON  Prime Minister Tony Blair vowed Friday to press ahead with plans to give Wales its first assembly in nearly 600 years, but a razor-thin margin in the Welsh referendum cast serious doubt on the government's program of decentralizing political power across Britain.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Market Volatility Continues With 127-Point Fall in Dow   The Dow industrials again moved by 100 points, but for the first time this week, the direction was downward.

headline: New Evidence Is Said to Link Mad Cow Disease to Humans
abstract: Scottish scientists report finding first 'compelling evidence' that mad cow disease, which killed thousands of cattle in Britain, was transmitted to people after they ate beef or were exposed to cattle; 14 people have died from brain disease and seven remain seriously ill and are expected to die from it (M)

headline: Stocks Rally Late in Day Of Big Swings
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average rises 108.70 points, to 7,803.36, a 1.4 percent increase; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rises 1.3 percent, or 11.68 points, to 912.49; Nasdaq composite index finishes 7.49 points higher at 1,569.52; table (L)

headline: BTG TO ACQUIRE MICROS-TO-MAINFRAMES FOR $25 MILLION
abstract: BTG Inc plans to acquire Micros-to-Mainframes Inc for $25 million in cash and stock (S)

headline: SUN HEALTHCARE CUTS OFFER FOR ACQUISITION
abstract: Sun Healthcare Group Inc reduces number of shares it will pay in its acquisition of Retirement Care Associates Inc, after Retirement Care says it will restate its financial results for 1997 fiscal year; Sun agreed in May to buy Retirement Care for $367 million; change reduces value of transaction by about $7.22 million (S)

headline: Mexican Anti-Torture Claim Is Challenged by Rights Groups
abstract: Independent Mexican human rights coalition issues report rebutting Government's claims of cracking down on torture and other human rights abuses; accuses Government's National Human Rights Commission of manipulating investigations and statistics; says systematic brutality has not diminished (M)

headline: AMOCO AND YPF FORM JOINT U.S. GAS VENTURE
abstract: Amoco Corp and YPF SA, Argentina's biggest oil company, form joint venture to own and operate 1 trillion cubic feet of natural gas reserves in Texas panhandle and western Oklahoma; new company is known as Crescendo Resources LP (S)

headline: Despite Consolidations, There's Room for Many Funds
abstract: Consolidation continues in mutual fund industry, but has not gained speed and seems to be leaving room for survival of small funds; prices being paid for mutual fund firms are only marginally higher than in 1996 (M)

headline: Coke's Net Up by 24.8% In 2d Quarter
abstract: Coca-Cola Co reports earnings for second quarter rose 24.8 percent to $1.31 billion (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: AT&T Earnings Fall But Top Expectations  AT&T reported a 38 percent plunge in second-quarter income from continuing operations, to $959 million, which it described as its ''low water mark of the year.'' Still, its earnings were a penny above analysts' forecasts and some saw a hint of a turnabout.    AT&T's woes have been compounded by management turmoil. Last week, its president, John R. Walter, resigned under pressure, and his lawyer met with AT&T lawyers on Friday. Mr. Walter was said to have presented a list of demands in addition to the more than $26 million he is to receive. $(Page D4.$)

headline: Opposition Is Set Back In Germany
abstract: Germany's opposition Social Democrats suffer embarrassing setback in a bellwether local election in Hamburg (S)

headline: CRESCENT REAL ESTATE ADDING DESERT MOUNTAIN
abstract: Crescent Real Estate Equities Co says that it had bought Arizona's Desert Mountain residential development for $229 million from Mobil Corp and investor Lyle Anderson, marking end of oil company's foray into real estate business (S)

headline: Dow Advances 16.73 in Fidgety Trading
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average gains 16.73 points, to close at 7,851.91; Standard & Poor's index gains 2.42 points, to 933.62; Nasdaq composite index gains 10.87, to 1,656.22; table (L)

headline: TELE-COMMUNICATIONS IN ASSET SALE TO CSG SYSTEMS
abstract: CSG Systems International Inc agrees to buy certain assets of cable giant Tele-Communications Inc's TCI Communications Inc unit for $106 million in cash, plus as much as $26 million if specific business goals are achieved (S)

headline: STAAR SURGICAL GETS F.D.A. APPROVAL FOR LENS TESTS
abstract: Staar Surgical Co receives Food and Drug Administration approval to begin second phase of clinical trials of implantable contact lenses to correct nearsightedness (S)

headline: Strongest Rebel in Tajikistan Is Reported Missing After Attack
abstract: Tajikistan's strongest rebel leader, Makhmud Khudoyberdiev, suffers surprising rout; his loss may strengthen recent accord meant to end five-year civil war; or his collapse may have unintended side effect, by strengthening hand of competing warlords who could provoke new violence in Tajikistan (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: On Main St., Few Alarms About Drop in Stocks  Many individual investors appear to be unfazed by the stock market's plunge on Friday, having come to see that steep short-term drops, followed by further big gains, have been a hallmark of the bull market.

headline: Philips Trims Stake In Semiconductor Maker
abstract: Philips Electronics NV says it has raised $526 million from sale of 100 million of its shares in Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co, reducing its stake to 31.1 percent (S)

headline: CISCO TO CUT PRICES ON KEY NETWORKING PRODUCT
abstract: Cisco Systems Inc shares fall after Cisco reports plan to cut prices on remote-access concentrators, devices used to link hundreds of phone callers to Internet (S)

headline: World Gets Plea to Act On Cambodia
abstract: Cambodia's United Nations representative, Prince Sisowath Sirirath, urges governments not to recognize what he calls Hun Sen's military junta; says Foreign Minister, who is loyal to Prince Norodom Ranariddh, will ask emergency Southeast Asian Nations Association meeting to reject Cambodia's bid for membership until elected Government is restored; urges renewed international intervention in Cambodia, where UN spent over $2 billion to set up democratic government; says armed royalist plan to set up resistance center, Battambang (M)

headline: CGI TO BUY TELEGLOBE'S INSURANCE SERVICES UNIT
abstract: Montreal-based CGI Group Inc agrees to buy insurance systems unit of Teleglobe Inc for $140 million (Canadian), or $100 million (US), in cash and preferred shares (S)

headline: OMNICARE PLANS ACQUISITION OF AMERICAN MEDSERVE
abstract: Omnicare Inc says it plans to acquire American Meserve Corp for $222.6 million, or $18 a share, in merger of two pharmacy-services providers (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Dow Loses 101 Points On Worries About Rates  Stocks fell sharply as concern persisted that the strength of the economy may cause the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates.    The Dow industrials plummeted 101.27 points, or 1.26 percent, to 7,960.84. The Dow has now fallen 3.6 percent from the closing high of 8,259.31 it reached last Wednesday -- the sharpest decline in the Dow since it fell 9.8 percent from March 11 to April 11. $(Page D8.$)    The Treasury market suffered its fifth straight loss, with the yield on the 30-year bond rising to 6.67 percent from 6.64. $(D15.$)    The dollar rose modestly, but slipped from its early level, as the losses in the stock and bond markets offset the positive effects of a German central bank decision to leave a key interest rate unchanged. $(D6.$)    A.M.A. to Endorse Sunbeam Goods  The American Medical Association has for the first time agreed to allow its name to be used in endorsing a line of products, in return for potentially millions of dollars. The products, made by Sunbeam, will include blood-pressure monitors, heating pads, thermometers, humidifiers and vaporizers. Advertising. $(A1.$)    Intel Accuses Digital on Patents  In response to a patent suit by Digital Equipment, Intel filed a counterclaim, accusing Digital of violating Intel patents that appear to affect nearly every aspect of Digital's business. Still, Digital's stock rose. $(D4.$)    Tougher Stances in U.P.S. Strike  Both sides ratcheted up the stakes in the United Parcel Service strike. The A.F.L.-C.I.O. said that other unions would lend the striking teamsters $10 million a week to help them weather the walkout, and U.P.S. officials warned that business losses could force the company to lay off 15,000 workers. $(A1.$)    Fund Executive Out, in Surprise  Thomas F. Marsico, the portfolio manager of two top-performing mutual funds of the Janus Funds, left abruptly as ''a result of philosophical differences'' with the company, a spokeswoman said. Mr. Marsico was the manager of the $5.3 billion Janus Twenty fund and the $1.5 billion Janus Growth and Income fund. $(D15.$)    Wal-Mart and Penney Post Results  Wal-Mart, the nation's largest retailer, said that net income rose nearly 13 percent in the most recent quarter as each of its divisions recorded a sales increase and a profit. And J. C. Penney said operating earnings grew almost 24 percent as the company cut costs and pared inventories, though net income fell 3 percent because of special charges. $(D2.$)    Over-the-Counter Crackdown  The N.A.S.D. plans to toughen the rules for small companies and brokers that trade on the over-the-counter bulletin board, which has been plagued by fraud, an official said. $(D2.$)    Housing Market Back in Order  For the first time in a decade, prices are rising nearly everywhere in the United States, with 80 percent of the nation's metropolitan areas showing a rise in home prices that exceeds the inflation rate. The strength in housing, particularly at the high end of the market, is even causing some bidding wars reminiscent of the 1980's. $(A1.$)    Clinton to Add Drug Regulation  President Clinton will order changes in the testing of prescription drugs to insure that manufacturers specifically examine their effects on children if the medications are to be used by a significant number of young patients, White House officials said. $(A17.$)

headline: Travelers Seeks Agency For Brand Image Work
abstract: Travelers Group is searching for agency to handle brand image advertising and campaigns for two insurance subsidiaries, Travelers Life and Annuity and Travelers Property Casualty; duties have been handled by MacNamara, Stewart and Saperstein (S)

headline: Hefty Penalties Against a Broker In Initial Issues
abstract: D H Blair & Co, brokerage arm of D H Blair Investment Banking, agrees to pay $2 million fine and to reimburse customers $2.4 million for overcharging them first few days of trading in new stock issues; charges by National Assn of Securities Dealers, which Blair settles without admitting or denying accusations, say firm had charged excessive markups in selling securities to its clients in the days after 16 initial public offerings underwritten by D H Blair Investment Banking from 1993 to 1995; D H Blair is accused of pushing up prices of 1994 offerings in Skyline Multimedia and Video Update (Market Place column) (L)

headline: Albright at Shrine to Victims of Nazis
abstract: US Sec of State Madeleine K Albright visits Yad Vashem memorial to Holocaust victims in Jerusalem; photo (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: QUICK & REILLY GROUP INC., Palm Beach, Fla., a discount brokerage firm, acquired Financial Systemware Inc., Jersey City, a maker of stock-trading software, for undisclosed terms.     FREEPORT-MCMORAN COPPER AND GOLD INC., New Orleans, a mining concern, said it would repurchase up to 20 million shares, or about 10 percent, of its common stock.     MVSI INC., Vienna, Va., a technology products and services company, agreed to acquire the privately owned Technet Computer Services Inc., a software development company, for 400,000 common shares.

headline: NASA's Face Red As Report of Fault On Mir Is Clarified
abstract: NASA aides say Russian astronauts had already fixed problem in Mir space station's oxygen-generating system by time NASA issued alarming report of breakdown; say NASA team did not know of repair because it left Russian Mission Control Center before last communication of day with Mir, confident that crew was in no danger (M)

headline: INVACARE PLANS TO TAKE A $39 MILLION AFTER-TAX CHARGE
abstract: Invacare Corp will take third-quarter pretax charge of about $61 million as it accelerates its plan to lower operating costs (S)

headline: Sometimes, Companies Grow by Baby Steps
abstract: Some companies grow by swallowing up many smaller operations, rather than through big dramatic mergers; list of companies preferring 'roll-up' acquisitions, as recommended by analysts (M)

headline: OFFICIALS SEE RISK IN NEW NATO PUSH FOR BOSNIA PEACE
abstract: Foreign and local officials express concern over risks as NATO peacekeepers press campaign in Bosnian Serb enclave of Banja Luka to implement faltering Bosnia peace agreement by seizing police stations and weapons and feverishly working with Bosnian Serb opposition leaders to build alternative power base; operation includes promoting Pres Biljana Plavsic in her effort to topple Radovan Karadzic, predecessor who continues to hold de facto power from stronghold in Pale; there is widespread recognition that 1995 agreement, which called for united Bosnia and return of refugees to homes, has not worked, and that war will likely resume after NATO forces withdraw, as scheduled, in June 1998; NATO commanders say their efforts in Banja Luka is Bosnia's last chance for peace; photo; map (M)

headline: TED TURNER PLANS A $1 BILLION GIFT FOR U.N. AGENCIES
abstract: Cable News Network founder Ted Turner tells United Nations Association that he will donate $1 billion to benefit UN agencies; says gift, largest charitable donation ever, will be used to establish not-for-profit foundation to benefit UN programs aiding refugees and children and clearing mines and fighting disease; says he will give UN $100 million a year for next 10 years; urges US to pay $1.5 billion it owes UN in back dues and calls on other wealthy people to follow his example; Turner receives association's Global Leadership Award (M)

headline: Shell in $2 Billion Deal With Essar in India
abstract: Shell International Gas Ltd, unit of Royal Dutch/Shell Group of Companies, plans to invest $2 billion in India for development of intergrated power plant and liquefied natural gas terminal at Hazira in Indian state of Gujarat (S)

headline: New Israeli Barriers Fail to Stop Street Clashes in Hebron
abstract: Rock-throwing Palestinian youths duel with Israeli soldiers in Hebron, despite placement of new Israeli concrete barriers along battle-scarred Shalala Street, which is boundary between Israeli-controlled security zone and Palestinian-controlled area; after weeks of daily clashes, Israel seems determined to toughen stance; photo; map (M)

headline: The King of Posh
abstract: Profile of Bernard Arnault, French deal maker who haeds LVMH Moet Hennessy Louis Vuitton SA, largest luxury products company in the world; $6-million company's famous brands range from Christian Dior and Louis Vuitton to Moet & Chandon and Veuve Clicquot; breakdown by segement; photos; chart; graphs; 48-year-old Arnault has built business largely by mastering both worlds of products and hardball financial negotiations; interview; his current attempt to block merger of Grand Metropolitan PLC and Guinness, drink companies in which Arnault has holdings, reviewed (M)

headline: American Topics
abstract: Dennis Saban's car-rental customers know where to find his business number: in the Yellow Pages, near the top of the list. Mr. Saban owns A-Aaable Rentals, a name he chose 27 years ago to keep his business in Phoenix, Arizona, high in the phone-book listings. But the regional phone company, US West, recently said that so many A's created dishonest competition. So Mr. Saban filed suit and won an injunction ordering the inclusion of A-Aaable Rentals in the next edition of the Yellow Pages. Said Mr. Saban: "Their regional manager comes to my office and says, 'What are you going to do, sue the phone company?' So that's what I did."

headline: 3-Day Slide In Treasury Prices Ended
abstract: Treasury bond prices rose on securities markets on August 6; benchmark 30-year bond closed up 6/32, to 101 31/32, to yield 6.47 percent; graph (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: MCKESSON CORP., San Francisco, the wholesale distributor of drugs and other health care products, signed a five-year agreement valued around $1.25 billion to be the primary pharmaceutical supplier to Phar-Mor Inc., Youngstown, Ohio.    ENTERPRISE FEDERAL BANCORP, West Chester, Ohio, a bank holding company, agreed to acquire North Cincinnati Savings Bank in a deal valued about $7.3 million.

headline: Skandia to Sell Its Reinsurance Unit
abstract: Hannover Re, world's fifth-largest reinsurer, will buy main part of Skandia Insurance AB's international reinsurance business for about $138 million (S)

headline: Growth in Germany Spurts on Export Surge
abstract: Bundesbank reports German gross domestic product grew 1 percent in second quarter from first quarter and 2.2 percent from 1996 second quarter, as weak mark fueled export surge (S)

headline: 3Com-Siemens Alliance Formed
abstract: Threecom (3Com) Corp and Siemens AG announce broad alliance aimed at developing products to integrate data and voice networks (S)

headline: Weiss, Whitten Wins Domecq Account
abstract: Domecq Importers, unit of Allied Domecq PLC, further expands its relationship with Weiss, Whitten, Stagliano by naming advertising agency to handle responsibilities for its Courvoisier Cognac brand (S)

headline: After 50 Stormy Years, Rays of Light Now Fall on Study of the Dead Sea Scrolls
abstract: International conference held, Jerusalem, celebrating 50th anniversary of the discovery of the Dead Sea Scrolls and end to battle over control of the documents; Stephen J Pfann, director of Center for the Study of Early Christianity, presents findings gleaned from deciphering documents from about 30 BC pertaining to ascetic Jewish sect known as the Essenses; photo (M)

headline: 26% Gain for B Sky B Surpasses Expectations
abstract: British Sky Broadcasting Group PLC says fourth-quarter earnings rose better-than-expected 26 percent; profit for quarter ended June 30 rose to $135 million from $106 million a year earlier; full-year results rose 23 percent, to $456 million from $371 million (S)

headline: Consumer Confidence Falls, but Remains High
abstract: Conference Board survey finds that Americans' confidence in the economy fell unexpectedly in July but remains close enough to 28-year high to suggest that consumer spending might accelerate; reports that its index of consumer confidence declined to 126.5 in July from revised 129.9 in June (S)

headline: MARRIOTT AND SODEXHO CONFIRM ALLIANCE TALKS
abstract: Marriott International Inc and Sodexho Alliance SA say they are in talks to combine their food service and facilities-management operations in North America (S)

headline: Women Earn High Marks on a Web Test
abstract: Results of World Wide Web navigating test, released by MCI Communications Corp and Educational Testing Service, indicate that older women can find their way around the Web better than young men can; Internet aptitude test, in which 16,500 Internet users participated, also reports that girls, who have often been said to be less computer-savvy than boys their age, scored higher than their male counterparts (S)

headline: U.S., Bending a Bit, Will Offer Wider Role for 3d World at U.N.
abstract: Pres Clinton plans to recommend that United Nations Security Council give three permanent seats to developing nations; Amb Bill Richardson outlines plan for Council restructuring; United States wants to double number of permanent members to 10 and add no more than one non-permament seat (M)c
