headline: Dow at High Again, With 8,116.93 Close
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average rises 28.57, to record 8,116.93; Standard & Poor's 500 index rises 3.74, to record 940.30, and Nasdaq composite index gains 1.48, to 1,569.13, about 11 points shy of its record; table (L)

headline: Early Returns In Liberia Put Rebel Leader Far Ahead
abstract: Early election returns suggest Charles G Taylor, Liberian warlord who started civil war that destroyed much of country, has won strong popular mandate to restore nation, or at least to rule it with some legitimacy; he has 62.4 percent of vote; photo (M)

headline: Airbus Wins 2 Big Orders For 4-Engine Rival to 747
abstract: Airbus wins two big airplane contracts: Virgin Atlantic orders 18 A340 Airbuses worth total of about $2.5 billion; Air Canada orders eight Airbus A330 and A340 planes, with total price of $1.4 billion (S)

headline: Japanese Stocks Lower
abstract: Japan's Nikkei index is down 214.82 points, or 1.12 percent, at 18,884.29 on Aug 13 (S)

headline: Lowe & Partners To Lose Executive
abstract: Bruce Kelley, executive of Lowe & Partners/SMS, says he will resign, effective July 31; no replacement has been named (S)

headline: News of Deal With Toyota Sends Republic Shares Higher
abstract: Shares of Republic Industries surge 7.5 percent, following announcement that the company, nation's largest car dealership owner, reached agreement with Toyota Motor Co that would allow Republic to buy more Toyota dealerships (M)

headline: STANDARD MOTOR AND COOPER TO SWAP SOME BUSINESSES
abstract: Standard Motor Products Inc agrees to swap its brake business for Cooper Industries' temperature control business (S)

headline: Dividend Meetings
abstract: A partial list for this week.    MONDAY  Eastern Utls Assoc  Goodrich B F Co  Moore Ltd  Southern Co  United Dominion Inds Ltd  Vesta Ins Grp Inc

headline: G.M. Is Likely To Make Huge Olympic Pacts
abstract: General Motors Corp, reinforcing Olympics' marketing cachet, plans sponsorship deals worth several hundred million dollars with NBC and United States Olympic Committee that would run into next decade; deals, in total, are likely to be largest sports sponsorship ever (M)

headline: Coffee Prices Drop Sharply On Strong Inventory Report
abstract: Coffee prices tumble after report by Green Coffee Association says stockpiles in US rose 11 percent in August, signaling unusually weak demand for roasters (M)

headline: SULLIVAN BROADCASTING TO BUY TV STATION FOR $60 MILLION
abstract: Sinclair Broadcast Group Inc will sell KOKH-TV in Oklahoma City to Sullivan Broadcasting for $60 million in cash, eliminating obstacle to its planned $630 million acquisition of Heritage Media Corp's television and radio stations (S)

headline: In Bosnia, Defiance
abstract: The Bosnian Serb leader charged with war crimes continues to exercise his power, obstructing the Bosnian peace agreement, as NATO leaders gathered in Madrid discuss how to resolve the issue.    Article, page A4.

headline: Albright Asks Arab States To Attend Summit Talks
abstract: Pres Hosni Mubarak of Egypt says he is hopeful situation in Middle East will improve enough for US-sponsored regional economic summit talks to go on as planned in Qatar in mid-Nov; Sec of State Madeleine K Albright, noting that some Arab countries are planning to boycott meeting, says that meeting 'is important in itself' and should not be made conditional on status of peace talks with Israel (M)

headline: Muslims Are Driven Out of Bosnia Homes a Second Time
abstract: Bosnian Muslims who returned to homes they fled during war have reportedly been driven out again; hundreds have been ousted by groups of Croatian thugs from homes in Kruscica; map (M)

headline: A Familiar Agony: Carnage in a Market Lane
abstract: Survivors describe terrorist bombing at Jerusalem market that is stronghold of Jewish religious nationalism; map; photos (M)

headline: Stocks Higher in Tokyo
abstract: Japan's Nikkei stock average is up 181.62 points, or about 1 percent, at 18,155.92 at midday on Sept 2 (S)

headline: A Promoter of Democracy Angers the Authoritarians
abstract: Financier George Soros has spent more than a billion dollars promoting a free press and political pluralism around the world; now, Soros and his philanthropic empire are coming under attack from authorities in Belarus and elsewhere; photo (M)

headline: Two Executives On the Move
abstract: Neil Kraft resigns as Carlson & Partners senior vice president and creative director; Pat Burnham joins Publicis/Bloom's Dallas office as executive creative director and executive vice principal (S)

headline: Executive Changes
abstract: ELCOR CORP., Dallas, named Harold Work chairman, president and chief executive, succeeding Roy E. Campbell, who died last Friday.    SMITH BARNEY INC., New York, a unit of the Travelers Group, named Joel Maryles to head its technology banking group. He continues as head of Smith Barney's Israel investment banking group, a position he has held since joining the company last year.

headline: Office Depot And Staples Merger Halted
abstract: Executives of office supply giants Staples Inc and Office Depot Inc say that their proposed merger is almost certainly dead after Federal Judge Thomas F Hogan issues order temporarily blocking $4 billion combination; Hogan rules that proposed merger would drastically reduce competition in office products business (L)

headline: Ronald Rosenfeld, 65, Part of Advertising's 1960's-70's Revolution
abstract: Ronald M Rosenfeld, important figure in 'creative revolution' that swept advertising industries in 1960's and 1970's, dies at 65; his work in advertising reviewed (S)

headline: Apple Foresees Weak Fourth Quarter
abstract: Apple Computer Inc, in filing with Securities and Exchange Commission, says it does not expect to be profitable in fiscal fourth quarter, which ends in September (S)

headline: Pawnshop Chains Grow As They Remake Image
abstract: Pawnshop chains are replacing mom-and-pop stores, which have reputation for being dingy and cramped; new suburban outlets like Cash America International, emphasize friendly service and large, clean store; pawnshops offer people a way to raise money quickly by using valuable items they own as collateral on loans; how transaction at pawnshop works described; diagram; photos (L)

headline: With Rates Down, Will Investors Sell?
abstract: Floyd Norris (Market Watch) column on complexity of new tax bill, especially in terms of capital gains revisions; says for investors, most important question is to what extent new rules will stimulate selling; graph on S&P 500, 1995-97 (M)

headline: Chicago Board's Seat Sale
abstract: Seat on Chicago Board Options Exchange is sold for record $715,000 (S)

headline: Renault Bounces Back, Reporting a Profit
abstract: Renault SA reports operating income of 364 million French francs ($59.6 million) in first half of year compared with operating loss of 255 million francs a year earlier (S)

headline: ACCESS BEYOND AND HAYES SET 'REVERSE ACQUISITION'
abstract: Access Beyond will issue $267 million in stock for closely held Hayes Microcomputer Products Inc in 'reverse acquisition' that would give Hayes shareholders 79 percent of merged company (S)

headline: Fujitsu to Pay $850 Million To Acquire Rest of Amdahl
abstract: Fujitsu Ltd of Japan will pay about $850 million to acquire 58 percent of shares of Amdahl Corp it does not already own; will pay $12 per share (M)

headline: Cheered by Wall Street, Some Asia Stock Markets Revive
abstract: Share prices jump 7.1 percent in Hong Kong, with benchmark index recording its biggest one-day gain ever in terms of points; Hang Seng index gains 978.66 points, or 7.1 percent, to 14,713.99; in Indonesia, Jakarta Stock Market Composite Index rises 33.57 points, or 7 percent, to 512.59; in Malaysia, benchmark Kuala Lumpur Composite index falls 44.97 points, or 5.7 percent, to 750.76 (L)

headline: Taiwan to Increase Insider Trading Penalty
abstract: Panel at Taiwan Ministry of Finance has decided to increase penalties for insider trading to maximum of seven years in prison from two years; major shareholders will be defined as those holding ownership of 5 percent or more in a company (S)

headline: A new campaign for BMW of America by Fallon McElligott plays up the performance of its cars.
abstract: BMW of North America is getting back to basics with campaign that parks recent pitches focused on attributes like safety and value in favor of taking performance aspects of 'the ultimate driving machine' for another spin; $30 million campaign was developed by Fallon McElligott; photo (L)

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.    MONDAY   None     TUESDAY   Consumer Borrowing May

headline: In Japan, a Textbook Case of Truth and History
abstract: TOKYO  For three decades, Saburo Ienaga and Nobukatsu Fujioka have stood on opposite sides of the barricades in a battle over how much schoolchildren here should learn about Japanese atrocities during World War II, including the slaughter of up to 300,000 Chinese in the Rape of Nanking.

headline: London Buildings Bought
abstract: Burford Holdings PLC agrees to pay 210 million pounds, or $348 million, to acquire two London theater district buildings: the Trocadero and London Pavilion; Burford will pay Trocadero PLC 160 million pounds upon completion of purchase; rest will be paid over 24 months (S)

headline: Japanese Stocks Flat
abstract: Japan's Nikkei index closes up 8.7 points at 17.974.50 on Sept 16 (S)

headline: 2 Office Complexes Sold
abstract: Brandywine Realty Trust acquires two Pennsylvania office complexes, Green Hills Corporate Center in Reading and Berwyn Park in Berwyn (S)

headline: Young & Rubicam Hired by Cruise Line
abstract: Norwegian Cruise Line names Young & Rubicam Advertising to handle its national and strategic planning account; account had been handled by Goodby, Silverstein & Partners (S)

headline: Export Limits On Computers Are Rejected
abstract: Senate, after heavy lobbying by computer industry and Clinton Administration, rejects, 72 to 17, proposal to tighten control of sale of American supercomputers to China and Russia and instead votes for further study on issue (M)

headline: 2 Executions In Chechnya Anger Russia
abstract: Chechen firing squad publicly executes two men, defying Russian demands that capital punishment be halted; Chechen officials say executions were in accordance with Islamic law; men were accused of murders of mother and two children (S)

headline: Westinghouse, in a Surprise, Says It Earned a Slight Profit
abstract: Westinghouse Electric Corp reports earning $1 million in second quarter before gains or charges, compared with year-earlier operating earnings of $25 million; table (M)

headline: Computer Breakdown on the Mir Sends It Spinning Out of Control
abstract: Main computer aboard Russian Mir space station fails, sending spacecraft spinning out of control during docking with cargo ship; forces new crew to shut down all major power systems after docking and to temporarily abandon Mir for Soyuz space capsule, using its engines to push wobbling station back toward orbit; Russian space officials voice dismay; are unable to explain cause of accident, latest in longest string of serious mishaps in space history; say crew is in no immediate danger; accident will postpone repairs on station's Spektr module, which was damaged during docking with supply ship on June 15; recent computer failure, following accidental disconnection of power cable by crew, recalled; photo (M)

headline: All Hail The Great Greenspan Bull Market
abstract: Market Watch column on latest surge in stock market; credits Federal Reserve chairman Alan Greenspan's remark that he is not worried about 'irrational exuberance' he had previously discussed (S)

headline: Tensions Threaten Angola's 3-Year Peace
abstract: Angolan Government officials and rebel leaders trade threats and accusations, imperiling fragile three-year peace process; military buildups reported by both sides; UN responds by postponing plans to remove peackeeping troops (S)

headline: Sunbeam Sues the A.M.A. On Voided Marketing Deal
abstract: Sunbeam Corp chairman Albert J Dunlap files suit on behalf of his company in effort to force American Medical Association to honor its endorsement deal with appliance manufacturer (M)

headline: Offerings of Equity Set for This Week
abstract: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:    Banc One Capital Holdings Corp., Dallas, 2 million convertible debt securities linked to stock. The securities, which are due in 2000, are convertible into shares of Firstplus Financial Group. Bear, Stearns.

headline: CYRIX EXPECTS A SIGNIFICANT LOSS FOR SECOND QUARTER
abstract: Cyrix Corp, maker of computer chips, says it will report second-quarter loss on revenue 'significantly' below $75.6 million of first quarter (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: MITCHELL ENERGY AND DEVELOPMENT CORP., Woodlands, Tex., a natural gas and oil producer, said it would use some of the proceeds from the sale of its Woodlands Corp. real estate unit to buy back about $180 million in long-term debt and about $100 million in common stock.     DESIGNS INC., Needham, Mass., a clothing retailer, plans to liquidate its Boston Traders brand and close 33 stores, or 21 percent of its chain, to focus on selling Levi's and Dockers casual wear.     WOOLWORTH CORP., New York, agreed to buy 27 sporting-goods stores from closely held Koenig Sporting Goods Inc. for about $10 million in cash.     GUIDANT CORP., Indianapolis, said its board had approved a 2-for-1 stock split.

headline: Aetna Stock Plunges 12% On Cost News
abstract: Shares of Aetna Life and Casualty decline more than 12 percent after company, one of the nation's largest managed health care concerns, says costs are rising faster than premiums, especially in its Medicare health maintenance organizations; rising costs and company's lowered projections for growth this year reflect intensifying competition among HMO's as Aetna has reconfigured itself into managed health care company; Moody's Investors Service analyst says outlook for rising medical costs and more intense competition on prices threatens to squeeze Aetna's profit margins; HMO companies in many cities have been competing for Government dollars by offering generous benefits to elderly persons, seeking market share at expense of profits (M)

headline: Inflation Outlook Lifts Bond Prices
abstract: US Treasury prices rise; price of 30-year Treasury bond gains 7/32, to 100 27/32; yield falls to 6.56 percent, from 6.58 percent on July 8 (L)

headline: Panic in Stocks Infects Hong Kong
abstract: HONG KONG  Foreign investors stampeded out of Hong Kong on Friday in the territory's busiest trading day ever, their confidence in Asia shaken by rising interest rates to ward off currency speculators and aggravated by Malaysian rules that make it harder to sell stocks.

headline: Saving Those Senior Discounts
abstract: David Gilston letter on Ted M Levine's July 27 article questioning need to offer elderly senior discounts; drawing (S)

headline: My Shining Moment At the Top of the Heap
abstract: Harvey J Lieberman essay on looking through his papers as he prepares to retire from job as deputy director of state psychiatric institution (S)

headline: Motorola Sees Low Earnings; Stock Tumbles
abstract: Motorola Inc says its earnings in third quarter will be significantly below expectations, hurt by weak sales of pagers and one-time costs; also says it will stop producing clones of Apple Computer Inc's Macintosh, resulting in $95 million charge; announcement, after close of market, sends Motorola stock down $8.375, to $66, in after-hours trading (L)

headline: Pension Insurer to End Shortfall Listing
abstract: Annual list of 50 large pension funds with biggest shortfalls will be scrapped by Pension Benefit Guaranty Corp, a Government-sponsored company that insures retirement benefits; list has long been attacked by companies whose seriously underfinanced pension plans put them on it (S)

headline: Courts Beginning to Make Order on Frontiers of Cyberspace
abstract: California appellate court recently found that state courts could hold jurisdiction over parties whose transactions in California were largely done via E-mail and telephone; case touches on larger issue of jurisdiction and cyberspace, where many unresolved questions are not as clear-cut as those surrounding E-mail; among these are questions about how courts will view other parts of Internet, including sites on World Wide Web and File Transfer Protocol and Telnet sites; ultimately, answers will dictate not just where courts have jurisdiction, but what governments have right to tax and regulate Internet businesses (M)

headline: Israel Steps Up Its Security In Fear of New Bombings
abstract: Israel steps up security nationwide amid signs that Islamic militants may be planning more attacks following recent suicide bombings in Jerusalem; deploys thousands of army troops, police officers and paramilitsry forces, nearly doubling number on streets of Jerusalem alone; move adds to sense of unease and leaves buses mostly empty and shopping centers nearly deserted; map; photo (M)

headline: PHONETEL CANCELS DEAL FOR COMMUNICATIONS CENTRAL
abstract: Communications Central Inc says Phonetel Technologies Inc has canceled its agreement to buy it for about $85 million in cash and assumption of debt (S)

headline: North Korean Leader Set to Take Over Top Posts
abstract: Provincial conference of North Korea's governing Workers Party recommends that Kim Jong Il, country's long-time 'Dear Leader,' be appointed General Secretary of party; this would be Kim's first public step toward assuming formal control over the country (S)

headline: Consumer Prices Rise 0.2% As Growth Stays Controlled
abstract: Labor Department reports consumer prices climbed two-tenths of 1 percent in July; Federal Reserve says industrial output expanded by only two-tenths of 1 percent last month; graphs (L)

headline: Nationsbank to Settle Suit Over Securities
abstract: Nationsbank Corp will pay $29 million to settle class-action lawsuit by customers alleging deceptive sales practices by Nations Securities unit (S)

headline: NATIONAL CITY TO CLOSE OR REORGANIZE 200 BRANCHES
abstract: National City Corp of Cleveland plans to close or reorganize 200 of its 750 full-service branches in next three years as it weeds out its least profitable offices; bank expects to close or sell 30 offices (S)

headline: German Unemployment Up by 11,000 in June
abstract: Number of unemployed in Germany rose by 11,000 in June, to 4,374 million; unemployment fell by 1,000 in western Germany; in eastern Germany, jobless rolls swelled by 12,000; unadjusted all-German unemployment rate fell to 11 percent from 11.1 percent (S)

headline: In 'New' Britain, Politicians Take Stock at Party Conferences
abstract: Britain's politicians hold their annual party meetings, in landscape dramatically altered from past seasons by electoral upheaval; Liberal Democrats, third party, celebrate their best showing in more than 60 years in national election in May, and plan ways of allying themselves with governing Labor Party in common liberal cause; Labor Party session is expected to focus on ways to broaden its base to guarantee long hold on majority; party has never won successive elections; Conservatives will meet to discuss how to regain power; party is battered and depleted by electorate, and riven by continuing bickering in their ranks (M)

headline: The Company Helped Pay for My Summer Vacation
abstract: Advice for employees on linking business and vacation travel so that company will pick up much of tab; photo (M)

headline: Slowly, U.S. Is Returning Some Envoys To the Sudan
abstract: Clinton Administration is returning few diplomats to Sudan to pressure Islamic Government to stop harboring Arab terrorists; revises strategy of treating regime as pariah state; up to eight American officials, although not Amb Timothy M Carney, will return to investigate human rights abuses, monitor and encourage peace talks with rebel forces in south and push Khartoum to fulfill recent promises to oppose terrorism; new embassy staff will also be able to gather intelligence on terrorist groups operating out of Sudan, including Hezbollah, Hamas and Palestinian Islamic Jihad (M)

headline: In U.S. Deportation Policy, a Pandora's Box
abstract: First of two articles, Deadly Exports, examining effects of stepped-up US efforts to deport growing numbers of immigrants who have become criminals; under effort mandated by Congress decade ago and strengthened with new financing in past four years, US is shipping back to countries of origin legal and illegal immigrants who have been convicted of broad range of crimes; however, program intended to lower American crime rate, free up prison space and save American taxpayers money, is having far more noticeable and unintended side effects; has resulted in exportation of American gang habits in such countries as El Salvador and around Caribbean, and trapped and marked for deportation small but significant number of people who under other circumstances would be considered good candidates to become law-abiding and productive; has also had boomerang effect, in which many who were deported have returned quickly after forging new connections to crime rings in own lands and compounding their ability to commit new crimes in US; effects of deportations in El Salvador, where American-bred gang violence is on rise discussed; Immigration and Naturalization Service has deported approximately 37,000 criminals in past fiscal year, up from 27,000 in three prior years, and more than 23,000 during first half of 1997, for annual rate of more than 45,000; map; photos (M)

headline: Market Place ; A Rare Sure Thing Goes Unnoticed
abstract: Market Place column on how market makers and institutional investors missed opportunity for potential profit when Real Goods Trading Corp offered to sell shares at price lower than its shares were selling on open market (M)

headline: Bond Prices Mixed Ahead Of Auctions
abstract: Prices of Treasury securities are mixed, in trading that is slightly above average for a Monday; session's gains fade at close as Government sets up its note auctions for this week, beginning with sale of $15.5 billion in new two-year notes on Sept 23 and $11.5 billion in five-year notes on Sept 24; 30-year bond rises 10/32, to price of 100 10/32; yield slips to 6.35 percent, from 6.37 percent on Sept 19; graph (L)

headline: Swiss Fund to Disburse Millions to Nazi Victims
abstract: Rolf Bloch, president of Switzerland's fund to compensate victims of Nazi atrocities, says $11.7 million will be distributed to Holocaust survivors, most of them living in Eastern Europe (S)

headline: Saving, on One Income
abstract: Dr Amy Malzberg Weintraub letter on Cynthia Tavlin's July 13 article on family living on one income (S)

headline: Hercules Is Too Weak to Lift Disney Stock
abstract: Market Place column on prospects for Walt Disney Co's stock in light of weak performance of its animated film Hercules and turmoil at its ABC television network; drawing (L)

headline: Heavy Supply Keeps Bonds On Defensive
abstract: Treasury securities prices remain depressed; 30-year bond drops 12/32, to 96 13/32, to yield 6.65 percent; graph (M)

headline: INVESTOR GROUP OFFERS $1.4 BILLION FOR FISHER
abstract: Investor group led by Thomas H Lee Companies will acquire Fisher Scientific International for $1.4 billion, thwarting $1 billion unsolicited offer by Bass Group (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: LESLIE FAY CO., New York, said Dickstein Partners had agreed to raise its stake in the women's clothing maker to 40 percent and named two of its officers to its board.

headline: Riot Flares in Belfast, but Cease-Fire Still Holds
abstract: Rioting erupts at police station in Roman Catholic part of West Belfast, Northern Ireland, as about 100 people throw gasoline bombs at police, who respond by firing plastic bullets; no injuries reported; reason for violence remains unclear; officials say violence did not violate cease-fire, called on July 20 by Irish Republican Army (M)

headline: Executive Changes
abstract: MILLER INDUSTRIES, Atlanta, a maker of towing and recovery equipment, named its chairman, William G. Miller, and its president, Jeffrey I. Badgley, co-chief executives.

headline: Getting the Goods on Missing Goods
abstract: Financial Q&A column; on locating family bank accounts (S)

headline: Fraud Case Focuses On Internet
abstract: Federal prosecutors and regulators say Theodore R Melcher, who late last year published Internet investing newsletter called SGA Goldstar Whisper Stocks, secretly received stock in companies he was praising in newsletter--stock that he sold while urging investors to buy; most notorious of Melcher's stock selections was Systems of Exellence, known as SEXI because of its stock symbol (M)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent                Previous   Year          Yesterday   Day   Ago               PRIME RATE   8.50   8.50   8.25        DISCOUNT RATE   5.00   5.00   5.00        FEDERAL FUNDS*   5.50   5.44   5.29        3-MO. TREAS. BILLS   5.04   5.07   5.15        6-MO. TREAS. BILLS   5.11   5.13   5.28        10-YR. TREAS. INFL.**   3.67   3.68   N.A.        10-YR. TREAS. NOTES   6.14   6.12   6.86        30-YR. TREAS. headline: Mellon Bank Agrees to Buy Pacific, a Discount Broker
abstract: Mellon Bank Corp will buy Pacific Brokerage Services Inc, a discount brokerage with strong presence on the Internet, for undisclosed amount in cash; addition of Pacific will give Mellon a network to sell stocks, bonds and other investments (M)

headline: Columbia's Ties to Doctors To Be Severed
abstract: Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corp chairman-chief executive Thomas Frist says Columbia/HCA will end its partnerships between doctors and hospitals at cost of $200 million to $300 million over one or two years; partnerships, which give doctors economic interest in Columbia's hospitals, have come under scrutiny amid wide-ranging Government investigation of business practices at Columbia/HCA (M)

headline: Diana, Princess of Wales, 36, Dies in a Crash in Paris
abstract: The death at 36 of Diana, Princess of Wales, in a car crash in Paris brought to a tragic close the life of a woman who had gone from being a shy young society girl to one of the world's most glamorous women.

headline: Funds That Staggered as the Market Danced
abstract: Quarterly report on mutual fund performance; few funds have managed to lose money in last year or so, no mean feat in raging bull market, in which stock mutual funds have averaged annual returns of almost 17 percent; tables showing recent performances by fund categories (M)

headline: A Terror to Journalists, He Sniffs Out Terrorists
abstract: Erol Canozkan, Turkish Government prosecutor assigned to enforce press laws, defends prosecutions of journalists as subversives for writing frankly about social and political problems, interview; points to 13-year-long conflict with separatist Kurdish guerrillas, and says he is defending nation's unity; publishers association estimates that more than 100 journalists are now in prison, although new Government has pledged to take steps toward greater press freedom; photo of Ayse Nur Zarakolu, who operates publishing house out of Istanbul basement and has served four prison terms for subversive acts since 1982 (Istanbul Journal) (M)

headline: How to Save on Taxes When Taking Those Stock-Market Gains
abstract: Article on how to save on taxes when taking stock-market gains; focuses on investing gains in housing developments that qualify for tax credits; holds through this program, Congress has authorized tax credits of $3.3 billion a year, enough to build or rehabiliate roughly 100,000 units annually (L)

headline: Clinton Embarking on a New Nafta Quest
abstract: Pres Clinton is set to open what is likely to be bruising battle to expand North American Free Trade Agreement within Latin America and his powers to negotiate other trade accords; issue bitterly divides Democrats and angers labor unions; Administration is arguing that United States has fewer trade barriers than most nations and therefore stand to gain from sweeping barriers away; warns Canada and Mexico are already striking deals with Latin American nations that exclude US (M)

headline: Right Message, Wrong Place
abstract: Oops. With the stroke of a computer key, a sensitive memo (about your love life, your finances or your boss) has gone astray. Welcome to the wonderful world of computers, where really embarrassing things can happen in a big hurry. Have you ever sent a message to the wrong destination? Send your best stories to On the Job, Money and Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Or send them by E-mail to onthejob@nytimes.com. Include your telephone number. All submissions become the property of The Times and may be republished in any medium.

headline: Dunkin' Donuts Is Retiring Fred
abstract: Fred, diligent Dunkin' Donuts baker who has dutifully driven himself with mantra 'Time to make the doughnuts,' is retiring after 15 years; Fred has been portrayed by Michael Vale; Dunkin' Donuts refuses comment on its next advertising campaign (S)

headline: Burlington In $2.5 Billion Deal to Create Big Oil Concern
abstract: Burlington Resources Inc agrees to buy Louisiana Land and Exploration Co for about $2.5 billion in stock transaction that would create huge independent natural gas and oil company (M)

headline: A.M.A. TO ENDORSE LINE OF PRODUCTS
abstract: American Medical Association, in first such move, will endorse line of Sunbeam Corp health-related products in return for royalties; says it will use funds for health, educational and research programs, not for day-to-day expenses; critics warn deal could erode confidence in doctors' group (M)

headline: German Court Sentences Serb To Life for Genocide in Bosnia
abstract: German court convicts Nikola Jorgic, a Bosnian Serb, of killing Muslims during war in Bosnia and sentences him to life in prison; charges against him include participation in June 1992 massacre of 22 Muslims in Grapska, where he is said to have fired an automatic weapon into a group of unarmed Muslims (M)

headline: Broadcasters Get Extra Time for TV Changeover
abstract: House and Senate budget conferees, in move that may slow transition to digital television, have agreed to make it easier for broadcasters to retain analog channels beyond eight-year transition period; have agreed to let company already operating broadcast station in given market to win second station serving same market and let owners of newspaper acquire broadcast station serving newspaper's market (M)

headline: How Less May Be More
abstract: Roundup of mutual fund news; Marketing Matrix survey of mutual fund group executives on industry outlook finds they expect much lower costs for investors, fewer fund groups and more money invested(M)

headline: MONTGOMERY WARD TO CLOSE SPECIALTY STORES
abstract: Montgomery Ward Holding Corp says it will close 44 Lechmere, Home Image and Electric Avenue and More stores and cut 3,900 jobs in first significant step of its plan to emerge from bankruptcy (S)

headline: Spanish Power Company To Buy Chilean Utilities
abstract: Empresa Nacional de Electricidad will pay $1.5 illion to take control of Enersis SA of Chile (S)

headline: Another Madison Avenue independent finds a buyer: Bozell, Jacobs plans to join True North.
abstract: True North Communications Inc, world's 7th-largest agency holding company, will buy 14th-largest, Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt Inc, in stock deal valued at $440 million; deal will make True North 6th-largest advertising company, with more than $11.5 billion in billings and more than 11,000 employees in 297 offices around world; deal has been approved by both boards and is expected to be completed by end of year; True North says it expects to save $10 million in consolidating administrative expences for combined companies; it is unclear if any jobs would be eliminated (M)

headline: Test for British: Tuition
abstract: Britain plans to impose tuition fees on college students, abandoning a long commitment to free higher education. The move is a further sign that Prime Minister Tony Blair is intent on dismantling many of the vestiges of Britain's welfare state.    Article, page A7.

headline: Albright's Trip: No 'Big Steps'
abstract: News analysis of US Sec of State Madeleine's first official visit to Middle East; Albright broke sense of deterioration and stalemate, and helped restore sense of American engagement and sway (M)

headline: Mannesmann Reports 54% Rise in Earnings
abstract: Mannesmann AG says first-half net income rose 54 percent; net income rose to 278 million marks, or $151 million, from 180 million marks (S)

headline: Jeanne Calment, World's Elder, Dies at 122
abstract: Jeanne Calment dies in nursing home in Arles, France, at age 122; she was oldest person whose age had been verified by official documents; photo (M)

headline: BAA of Britain Will Buy Duty Free International
abstract: BAA PLC will buy Duty Free International for $674 million (S)

headline: Russia and De Beers In Accord on Diamonds
abstract: Russia's diamond-marketing agency, RAO Almazi Rossii-Sakha, reaches two-year accord with De Beers/Centenary AG to sell $550 million a year of uncut diamonds, about half of its annual production, through De Beers's Central Selling Organization; deal will let Central Selling Organization re-establish virtual monopoly of wholesale trade (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: GUY F. ATKINSON CO.,  San Bruno, Calif., a provider of construction services, said it had filed for protection from creditors under Chapter 11 of the Federal bankruptcy law.    SERVICE INTERNATIONAL CORP., Houston, a funeral and cemetery company, agreed to buy the 28 percent of Arbor Memorial Services Inc., Toronto, owned by Loewen Group Inc. of British Columbia, for $69 million.

headline: Chain E-Mail: Heart-Rending Pleas Are Sometimes Counterfeit
abstract: Article discusses problem of counterfeit electronic mail messages on Internet; examples cited; America Online spokeswoman Tricia Primrose discusses problem and how AOL is dealing with it (M)

headline: Stock Seesaw Tips Down As Dow Posts Loss of 58.70
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average closes down 58.70 points at 7,848.01; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index drops 6.57 points, to 937.91, and Nasdaq composite loses 8.52 points, to 1,678.89; chart (L)

headline: Account Review For America West
abstract: America West Airlines places its advertising account in review; account has been handled by Team One Advertising (S)

headline: United Cuts Travel Agency Commissions
abstract: United Airlines has cut travel agency commissions to 8 percent from 10 percent for all tickets sold in US, saying it did so to save $80 million to $100 million annually so that it can 'survive and succeed' in global marketplace; members of American Society of Travel Agents denounces cuts (M)

headline: CRACKEN HARKEY IS BUYING EL CHICO RESTAURANTS
abstract: El Chico Restaurants agrees to be acquired for about $65 million by Cracken Harkey & Co, investment concern, and restaurateurs E Gene Street and Clyde E Culp 3d (S)

headline: Plan for Apartment House in East Jerusalem Angers Arabs
abstract: Palestinians respond angrily to Jerusalem city government's decision to let Dr Irving I Moskowitz, American Jewish supporter of far-right causes, build apartment house for Jews on land he owns in Arab neighborhood; Prime Min Benjamin Netanyahu, surprised by announcement, informs Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat he will block plan; map (M)

headline: Shape-Shifter
abstract: Andrew Sprung poem on how money, once gold and then paper, is becoming electronic; drawing

headline: Miller Adds Lucero/Bentz to Roster
abstract: Miller Brewing Co adds agency to its roster by naming Lucero/Bentz, a new shop in Dallas, to create advertising aimed at Spanish-speaking consumers for Miller Lite beer; billings undisclosed (S)

headline: World Bank, at U.S. Urging, Postpones Vote on Loan to Croatia
abstract: World Bank, under pressure from US, postpones indefinitely vote on $30 million loan to Croatia that country hoped to use to shore up its banking system and stimulate private investment (M)

headline: Positive News On Inflation Lifts Bonds
abstract: Positive economic news lifts US Treasury bond prices; 30-year bond surges 31/32, to price of 97 25/32, pushing yield down to 6.55 percent from 6.62 percent on Aug 13; graph (L)

headline: Returning to Its Roots, and Prospering
abstract: Stephen J McGruder, who has managed Lord Abbett Developing Growth fund for two years, has been architect of its turnaround; McGruder was hired by Lord Abbett in May 1995 from Wafra Investment Advisory Group, a US company owned by agency of Kuwaiti Government; McGruder comments; table; photo (L)

headline: Nynex Is Gone, But Its Name Has Yet to Go
abstract: Bell Atlantic on Sept 8 is rolling out three-step advertising campaign to inform Nynex Corp's 13.4 million customers that their phone company is now called Bell Atlantic; Bell Atlantic acquired Nynex on Aug 15 (S)

headline: Executive Named Chase Vice Chairman
abstract: Chase Manhattan Corp says Marc Shapiro, chairman and chief executive of its Texas Commerce Bank NA subsidiary, is named vice chairman for finance and risk management of Chase Manhattan Bank; John L Adams will succeed Shapiro as chairman and chief executive of Texas Commerce Bank NA (S)

headline: CROWN CORK AND SEAL TO REVAMP ITS CONSTAR UNIT
abstract: Crown Cork and Seal Co will close six US plastic beverage container plants and lay off 430 workers in restructuring of its Constar unit (S)

headline: Molson Seeking Partners' Shares in Brewery
abstract: Molson Companies wants to acquire 60 percent of Molson Breweries it does not own from its partners, Foster's Brewing Group Ltd and Miller Brewing Co, which could cost it as much as $1.1 billion (S)

TREAS. BILLS   5.04   5.05   5.11        6-MO. TREAS. BILLS   5.08   5.09   5.26        10-YR. TREAS. INFL.**   3.65   3.67   N.A.        10-YR. TREAS. NOTES   6.18   6.25   6.83        30-YR. TREAS. headline: ARCH COAL PLANS CHARGES AGAINST EARNINGS
abstract: Arch Coal Inc says it will take unspecified charges against third-quarter earnings for severance expenses and cost of writing down duplicate assets from its recently completed merger; Arch Coal was formed from July 1 stock swap combination of Ashland Coal Inc and Arch Mineral Corp (S)

headline: Rescuing A Relative Who Won't Accept Help
abstract: Article by Roy Furchgott on his efforts to rescue his 95-year-old great-uncle, Joseph N Rosolio, who is in reasonably good health, but is unable to care for himself; Furchgott's efforts to take control of Rosolio's finances and see that he was provided with caretakers, which resulted in unsuccessful court battle spurred by Rosolio, detailed; map; photos (L)a

headline: For those headed to China's Hong Kong, things are operating pretty much as usual.
abstract: Travel to Hong Kong is operating as usual; there is no visa requirement--same as usual--if visit is less than 30 days; visa is still needed if going on from Hong Kong to China; for annual fees ranging from $150 to $200, airlines pamper business travelers by providing members-only clubs full of comforts and conveniences; Trans World Airlines is breaking ranks with its competitors by letting certain nonmembers in the door on their day of travel; US Passport Agency in Rockefeller Center now requires an appointment; AMR's American Airlines has installed plug-in ports for laptop computers on its trans-Atlantic Airbuses flying out of Kennedy International Airport in New York and Logan International Airport in Boston; carrier will begin putting them in its 767 international fleets and its Super 80's that fly domestic routes (L)

headline: CIBC takes a big step toward a global securities business.
abstract: Market Place column on Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce's acquisition of Oppenheimer Holdings Inc; says Canadian Imperial, with acquisition, has taken big step toward its goal of building worldwide securities business to cater to needs of its North American and overseas company and individual clients (L)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent                Previous   Year          Yesterday   Day   Ago               PRIME RATE   8.50   8.50   8.25        DISCOUNT RATE   5.00   5.00   5.00        FEDERAL FUNDS*   5.50   5.65   5.13        3-MO. TREAS. BILLS   5.10   5.12   5.03        6-MO. TREAS. BILLS   5.14   5.14   5.12        10-YR. TREAS. INFL.**   3.58   3.56   N.A.        10-YR. TREAS. NOTES   6.36   6.38   6.77        30-YR. TREAS. BONDS   6.64   6.66   6.97        TELEPHONE BONDS   7.70   7.72   7.98        MUNICIPAL BONDS***   5.56   5.57   5.94          *Estimated daily average, Dow Jones Markets  **Realized dollar amount rises with inflation  ***Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer  Sources: Salomon Brothers and Dow Jones Markets for Treasury's bellwether bonds, notes and bills

headline: South African Currency and Growth Rate Are at Risk
abstract: Decline in gold prices over last few months--and plunge last week to 12-year low--have alarmed many in South Africa, where gold remains keystone of business and the economy; with commodity price of gold in $320-an-ounce range, index of gold-mining shares on Johannesburg Stock Exchange is down roughly 38 percent so far this year; plunge in gold could shake confidence in South Africa's currency, the rand, which has held steady at 4.55 to the dollar; layoffs could undermine confidence in Pres Nelson Mandela's Government, which has promised its constituents jobs, housing, and larger share of national wealth; tables; photo (L)

headline: Official in India Sets Up A Dynasty of His Own
abstract: Laloo Prasad Yadav, leader of India's impoverished Bihar state, stirs new wave of indignation by responding to warrant for his arrest as part of $280 million corruption scandal by resigning top post, naming wife as successor and vowing to continue ruling from jail cell; is head of country's poorest state, and his style has won him adulation among millions of lower-caste followers and approbrium from traditionalists, who have accused him of demagogy, incompetence and looting public funds on unprecedented scale; photo; map (M)

headline: Novartis Sales Meet Analysts' Expectations
abstract: Novartis AG says second-quarter sales rose 16.3 percent from year earlier, bringing first-half rise to 19.2 percent, which is lower than analysts' expectations; second-quarter sales rose to 8.386 billion Swiss francs ($5.6 billion), bringing first-half total to 16.562 from pro forma 13.891 billion francs (S)

headline: 7Up to Change Its Formula
abstract: Dr Pepper/Seven-Up beverage unit of Cadbury Schweppes PLC will change recipe for its 7Up soft drink in bid to gain on Sprite, a brand of Coca-Cola Co (S)

headline: Daewoo Denies Talk Of Italian Investment
abstract: Daewoo Corp chairman Kim Woo Choong says it is in talks with Ansaldo Trasporti SpA about acquiring power-generation equipment, not about buying a stake in state-owned Italian company (S)

headline: Jack Avrett, 68, Co-Chairman Of Avrett, Free Advertising Firm
abstract: Jack Avrett, co-chairman and founder of Avrett, Free & Ginzberg advertising agency, dies at age 68 (S)

headline: Accounts
abstract: * News Bar Inc., New York, to Blum/Herbstreith, New York, as the first agency to handle advertising for the new chain of coffee bars. Billings were not disclosed.    * Marvin Gold Management Co., Brooklyn, to Porte Advertising, New York, to handle its account, which was previously handled in-house. Billings were not disclosed.

headline: Rifts Develop Among Those Pursuing the Assets of Holocaust Victims
abstract: One day after Swiss banks release list of dormant accounts from Nazi era, an array of divisions develops among potential claimants and investigators over how to keep pressing search for assets belonging to Holocaust victims; first open rift is touched off by Paul A Volcker, head of independent investigative commission set up by major Jewish organizations; Volcker, in nine-page letter filed with Federal court in Brooklyn, objects to efforts of lawyers who are pursuing class-action suit in New York on behalf of many Jews who maintain that looted and other assets belonging to Holocaust victims are still languishing in Swiss bank vaults; Volcker contends that he is afraid that Swiss bankers and confidential sources might stop cooperating with his commission's inquiry into dormant accounts if lawsuit results in American legal orders to disclose documents and sources (M)

headline: Accounts
abstract: * Whistler Corp., Chelmsford, Mass., to Pagano Schenck & Kay, Boston, as the first agency to handle advertising and marketing for the consumer electronics company. Billings were estimated at more than $1 million.    * The Sports Center at Chelsea Piers, New York, owned by Chelsea Piers L.P., to Earthquake Advertising, New York, to handle its account, previously at Moo Advertising, New York. Billings were not disclosed.

headline: Union Pacific Resources has strong reasons to seek Pennzoil.
abstract: Market Place column on Pennzoil Co's fierce resistance to $4.2 billion hostile bid by Union Pacific Resources Group; says many analysts believe Pennzoil chairman-president-chief executive James L Pate, who took over as head of Pennzoil in 1990 when it was troubled, has put much of its house in order and that many of the steps he has taken are on the verge of paying off (L)

headline: Network Solutions Faces an Inquiry on Internet Addresses
abstract: Justice Dept begins investigation into practice of assigning Internet addresses to determine if control that Network Solutions Inc exercises over process amounts to violation of antitrust laws; Network Solutions has been target of growing chorus of complaints and two dozen lawsuits as Internet expands and competition for addresses has grown more intense (M)

headline: TRIQUINT STOCK DROPS 20% ON EARNINGS OUTLOOK
abstract: Shares of Triquint Semiconductor Inc stock tumbles 20 percent amid concern that its earnings would not increase as quickly as expected for rest of year (S)

headline: Profit Rises 23% At No. 3 German Bank
abstract: Westdeutsche Landesbank Girozentrale, Germany's third-largest bank, says first-half operating profit rose 23 percent; operating profit rose to 749.6 million marks ($408 million); trading profit rose to 274 million marks, almost 50 percent higher than 184 million marks in first half of 1996 (S)

headline: REYNOLDS TO BUY 26% STAKE IN BRITISH COMPUTER SUPPLIER
abstract: Reynolds & Reynolds Co agrees to acquire 26 percent interest in Kalamazoo Computer Group PLC of Britain for $35 million (S)

headline: Independent Films Draw a Financier: Icahn Sees Prospects in Distribution
abstract: Independent film distribution companies are cropping up; aim is to find small gem of a movie at a festival, pick it up cheaply, release it in movie theaters, then make bundle by selling company to major Hollywood studio; Miramax, former so-called indie now owned by Walt Disney Co, dominated Acadamy Awards last spring; that example, and strong stock market, made combination of small films and big finance inevitable; latest example is Stratospere Entertainment, set up by financier Carl C Icahn; Icahn says he knows little about films, but he has named longtime distributor Paul E Cohen to head venture and he is confident his eye for value will turn Stratosphere into money maker; photos (M)

headline: An Insider Trading Charge at J. P. Morgan
abstract: Federal authorities arrest 25-year-old junior analyst at J P Morgan & Co and charge him with insider trading; Govt says he had made illegal profits of more than $350,000 over two-month period this summer; Morgan employee, Roy Handojo, is an Indonesian who was working in J P Morgan's bank group in Manhattan; Federal prosecutors say in criminal complaint that Handojo had traded in securities of three companies--Signet Banking Corp, ACC Consumer Finance Corp and Barnett Banks Corp--that were involved in confidential merger negotiations at the time (M)

headline: U.S. Auctions Will Include One-Year Bills
abstract: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week consists of today's regular weekly auction of three-  and six-month bills and the sale on Thursday of a one-year bill. By the close of the New York cash market on Friday, traders said, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 4.98 percent and a six-month bill was 5.09 percent; the rate on a one-year bill was 5.21 percent.    The following issues are scheduled for pricing this week:    TAXABLE    ONE DAY DURING THE WEEK

headline: Honors
abstract: * Goodby, Silverstein & Partners, San Francisco, a unit of Omnicom Group, took top honors, winning first prize, in the fourth annual Out of the Box contest for ''creative thinking'' sponsored by the Medill School of Journalism at Northwestern University, Evanston, Ill. Goodby, Silverstein won for the ''Got milk?'' campaign for the California Fluid Milk Processor Advisory Board. Arnold Communications, Boston, won second place for the ''Drivers wanted'' campaign for Volkswagen of America.

headline: Bosnian Serb Farmers Bitterly Recall NATO Presence
abstract: Bosnian Serbs in Gornja Omarska bitterly resent presence of NATO peacekeeping troops, recalling NATO's 1995 bombing campaign that crippled Bosnian Serb military and laid foundation for Dayton peace agreement; map (S)

headline: WASHINGTON NATIONAL AND PENNCORP END MERGER PACT
abstract: Washington National Corp and Penncorp Financial Group mutually terminate their merger agreement (S)

headline: F.T.C. Asks Data On British Utility
abstract: Pacificorp and Energy Group PLC say they were ordered to provide Federal Trade Commission with more information before it rules on Pacificorp's $5.8 billion bid for Energy Group, a British-based power company (S)

headline: Lower Capital Gains Rates, but the Devil Is in the Detail
abstract: Article on new Federal tax law focuses on specific of cuts in capital gains tax on stocks and other investments; graph (L)

headline: A Nazi's Trail Leads to a Gold Cache in Brazil
abstract: Special Brazilian committee probing Nazi war criminals who fled there from Germany with looted Jewish property, as well as those who helped them flee, is investigating case of Albert Blume who fled to Brazil in 1938 and died outcast 14 years ago, leaving $4 million fortune in gold for which relatives have been battling in court; many suspect Blume, who was member of Nazi Party, never owned fortune, but was conduit for stolen gold that lies in bank vault in his name; suspect Blume may have been part of Operation Odessa, underground railroad for Nazi officials who were fleeing Germany and expected arrest; bizarre details and contradictions of his life are kindling interest among Brazilians in chapter of their past that once seemed remote, irrelevant or taboo; photo (M)

headline: Lonely Israeli Fights Israel's Treatment of Arabs
abstract: Interview with Yuval Lotem, lieutenant in Israeli Army reserve who was jailed for 26 days in military stockade for refusing to serve at Israeli prison where Palestinians are held without trial; photo (M)

headline: The New Mikey Is Named Marli
abstract: Marli Brianna Hughes, 4, is named as new child to replace 'Mikey' in Quaker Oats Co's advertising and promotion for its Life cereal brand; she succeeds John Gilchrist, now an account executive at WCBS-AM radio in New York (S)

headline: After the Vote, Brighter Mexican Prospects
abstract: Many investors are encouraged about Mexico's economic prospects in wake of elections that ended seven decades of one-party rule; hope more open economy will be matched by more open political system; vote has enhanced credibility of Pres Ernesto Zedillo, improving outlook for his moderate economic policy despite victory of some populist candidates; graph; photo (M)

headline: Executives Leave Paging Network
abstract: Chairman of Paging Network Inc, George Perrin, and chief executive, Glenn Marschel, resign; company names Jack Frazee, former Sprint Corporation executive, to their posts; Paging Network spokeswoman says executives resigned after board consolidated chairman and chief executive posts (S)

headline: AMERICA WEST SIGNS A $1.4 BILLION DEAL WITH AIRBUS
abstract: America West Holdings Corp's America West Airlines Inc unit signs contract with Airbus Industrie valued at $1.4 billion, before undisclosed price discounts, to buy 22 Airbus A319-100 aircraft and 12 Airbus A320-200 aircraft (S)

headline: Clinton Keeps Door Open to Extended U.S. Role in Bosnia
abstract: Pres Clinton says Bosnia peace is in danger, and that he has not ruled out United States military role in Bosnia next year after current deployment of American and other NATO peacekeeping troops ends; makes statement day after Senate vote urging him to make good on his earlier pledge to remove ground troops by June 30, 1998; Clinton's latest statement is clearest signal to date that Administration may be considering role for American troops after June 30 (M)

headline: The Corporate Wooing and Winning of Mammoth Records
abstract: Efforts of major music companies to court Jay Faires, which led to acquisition of his Mammoth Records by Walt Disney Co for nearly $25 million, discussed; shows hot property still can fetch surprisingly high price in depressed music industry; photo (M)

headline: BTR to Sell Several Divisions
abstract: British industrial conglomerate BTR PLC plans to sell several divisions by end of year; company reports first-half pretax profits of 608 million pounds, or $964.6 million, down from 626 milion pounds a year earlier (S)

headline: A company says it has built a better magnetic compass, one connected to a microchip.
abstract: Directional Robotics says it has figured out how to computerize magnetic field without electronic gear disabling the compass; company president Harold J Gallagher says his company has been able to do it by using optics rather than electricity; W Stan Lewis is scientist whose patents are foundation of the company, comments (M)

headline: David Anderson, 60, Ex-Envoy to Belgrade
abstract: David Anderson, US Ambassador to Yugoslavia in 1980's, dies at age 64 (S)

headline: HALTER AND BOLLINGER TO PURSUE CONTRACTS TOGETHER
abstract: Halter Marine Group Inc and privately owned Bollinger Shipyards Inc say they will form joint venture to pursue contracts potentially worth $10 billion to upgrade Coast Guard ships and aircraft; Avondale Industries Inc, Litton Industries Inc and Newport News Shipbuilding Inc are also looking to pursue Coast Guard contracts (S)

headline: North Korean Defector's 'Spy List' Proves a Hot Topic in Seoul
abstract: Defection of high-level North Korean official, Hwang Jang Yop, to South Korea stirs much speculation that he has brought list of North Korean spies who frequent South Korea; Hwang says did not directly supervise intelligence-gathering, but has passed along some information to South Korean counter-intelligence officials (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: BAY APARTMENT COMMUNITIES INC.,  San Jose, Calif., a real estate investment trust, bought Regent Apartments, a 195-apartment property in Daly City, Calif., for $13.9 million.    IDEXX LABORATORIES INC.,  Westbrook, Me., purchased Professionals' Software Inc., a part of Colgate-Palmolive Co.'s Hill's pet food division, for undisclosed terms.    LASON INC.,  Troy, Mich., a provider of document management services, acquired the privately held Image Conversion Systems Inc. of Arlington Heights, Ill., a document conversion company, for an undisclosed amount.

headline: S.E.C. Loses Fight Against Bond Trader
abstract: An administrative law judge for the Securities and Exchange Commission has dismissed the agency's charges that Warren Trepp, the former head of high-yield bond trading at Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., participated in an illegal plan to help a Drexel client ''park'' at least $300 million of high-yield bonds during the second and third quarters of 1986.    The commission had sought to  ban Mr. Trepp from the securities industry and bar him from further violations of Federal securities laws. Mr. Trepp, citing a recent court ruling in an unrelated case, contended that the commission waited too long to file charges.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: Japanese Economy Follows A Zigzag; Exporters Thrive as Other Sectors Sink
abstract: Japanese companies that are household names around the world are muscling their way once again to forefront of global market; forced to battle with American and European companies in open markets and volatile exchange rates and fickle consumer tastes, these companies have been bruised and battered, but remain perhaps toughest competitors in the world; at the same time, pillars of domestic Japanese economy--retail shops, distributors, utilities, brokerage firms and banks--are limping along or falling through the cracks; Government's efforts to revitalize domestic economy discussed; graphs; photos (L)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: U.P.S. Strike Is Disruptive, But Vital Goods Arrive  A strike by 185,000 members of the teamsters' union idled most of the trucks of the United Parcel Service, slowing the movement of millions of packages and inconveniencing businesses and their customers.    The most essential goods -- food for grocery stores, medicine and medical supplies for hospitals -- appeared to be getting to their destinations. But the walkout came at a bad time for the book publishing industry, because this is the week that most trade publishers start shipping major titles for fall. $(Page A14.$)

headline: Unicef Tells How Half the World Lacks Even Basic Sanitation
abstract: Unicef estimates that nearly three billion people, over half of world's population, lack access to even minimally sanitary toilet; says lack of basic hygiene contributes to spread of disease and and deaths from diarrhea or related illnesses of 2.2 million children a year; says sanitation statistics are worsening worldwide; International Women's Health Coalition aide Adrienne Germain says third-world governments often pay too little attention to sanitation problems, interview (M)

headline: Peru Leader Tries to Defuse Crisis, Denying Military Control
abstract: Pres Alberto K Fujimori delivers state of the union speech to Peruvian Parliament, which leaves unanswered several crucial questions about how firmly he is in control of country; emphatically denies widespread speculation that military is controlling Government; announces lower taxes, higher public salaries and new effort to create jobs; photo (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: BANK OF NEW YORK CO.,  New York, agreed to buy the corporate and municipal bond administration business of One Valley Bank of Charleston, W. Va., for undisclosed terms.    PIPER CAPITAL MANAGEMENT INC.,  the investment management subsidiary of Piper Jaffray Cos., reached an agreement to purchase certain assets of Washington Square Advisers from Reliastar Financial Corp. of Minneapolis. Terms were not disclosed.    O'SULLIVAN CORP.,  Winchester, Va., agreed to sell its Melnor unit, which makes lawn and garden watering products, to Gardena Holding A.G. Terms were not disclosed.    BURLINGTON NORTHERN SANTA FE CORP.,  Fort Worth, will repurchase as many as 10 million shares of its common stock. The company has about 155 million shares outstanding.

headline: As Currency Crisis Roils Asia, Thais Ask I.M.F.'s Help
abstract: Currency crisis, centered in Thailand, is shaking fast-growing nations of South and Southeast Asia; Thailand, underscoring severity of troubles and its inability to contain them, asks International Monetary Fund aid; Philippines has sought IMF aid and Malaysian and Indonesian currencies have fallen in three weeks since Thailand effectively devalued baht, making life more expensive and creating welter of economic and political problems for governments; concern is spreading over whether supercharged growth of past is ending; Bank of Thailand governor, Rerngchai Marakanond, who has been orchestrating defense of baht, resigns; graphs (M)

headline: Microsoft Freelancers Win Stock-Plan Appeal
abstract: Microsoft Corp loses Federal appeals court decision in case brought by freelance workers who want to take part in company's stock-purchase plans; US Appeals Court rules that Microsoft cannot exclude freelance workers it hired before 1990; under program, employees can use part of their pay to buy stock in Microsoft at 15 percent discount (M)

headline: Small-Stock Funds Handily Beat Their Big Index Brothers
abstract: Mutual funds that invest in stocks of smaller, faster-growing companies have been setting pace in last five months, while index funds are far behind; third quarter is expected to end with roughly four of every five mutual funds that invest in American stocks having beaten Standard & Poor's 500 index, most in any quarter since 1978; for first time in more than decade, domestic stock funds are likely to show double-digit returns in back-to-back quarters; shift in investor sentiment attributed to two factors: fund managers are less wary of sharp drop in overall stock market, so they are picking companies they believe can outperform over longer term rather than making safe bets on largest securities, and, strengthening dollar has dampened Wall Street's expectations for profits at many large, multinational companies that dominate S&P 500 index (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: ENTERPRISE OIL P.L.C., London, said it would an pay an initial $65 million in exploration drilling costs in exchange for 50 percent of Enserch Exploration's deepwater portfolio in the Gulf of Mexico. The company will pay an additional $35 million if drilling is successful and commercial development is possible.

headline: Kidnappers in Mexico Seize Son of a Former Governor
abstract: The son of a controversial Mexican politician has been kidnapped, according to Mexican press reports, in the latest in a series of unresolved abductions of public figures in the weeks before national elections on Sunday.    Ruben Figueroa Smutny, 26, was seized in Mexico City on Wednesday morning by a group of armed kidnappers reportedly wearing ski masks, relatives told Mexican journalists.

headline: U.S. and Europe in Battle Over Digital TV
abstract: United States and European Union have their own technical standards for digital broadcasts, and they are in fierce competition to provide technology for more than 12 nations that are preparing to begin transition to digital television; broadcasters and government officials from US and EU are on trade missions around world, trying to sell their systems; latest stop is Beijing, where American and European delegations are staging high-definition television demonstrations; so far, neither side has won decisive advantage, in China or anyplace else; at stake are both prestige and huge profits (M)

headline: CRESCENT TO BUY 3 TEXAS PROPERTIES FOR $489 MILLION
abstract: Crescent Real Estate Equities Co plans to buy three office properties in Texas for $489 million; one of properties will be bought from JMB Realty Corp (S)

headline: Cabletron's Chief Executive Plans to Step Down Sept. 1
abstract: Cabletron Systems Inc says president, chief executive and co-founder, S Robert Levine, will resign on September 1, and will be succeeded by Donald B Reed (M)

headline: MARKET TIMING
abstract: MONDAY  Janet L. Yellen, chairwoman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, speaks at the National Association of Business Economists in New Orleans.  President Clinton addresses the Service Employees International Union legislative conference.    TUESDAY  The Labor Department reports on the Consumer Price Index for August.  The Commerce Department reports on July business inventories and sales.  The Federal Reserve Board reports on industrial production and capacity utilization for August.  Mitsubishi Bank/Schroder Wertheim releases its weekly retail sales report.  LJR Redbook Research releases its weekly retail sales survey.

headline: Foley to Be Nominated Ambassador to Japan
abstract: Pres Clinton to name former House Speaker Thomas S Foley Ambassador to Japan and Nicholas Burns Ambassador to Greece (S)

headline: Euro Disney Will Build a Business Park
abstract: Euro Disney SCA of France says it will start work in next 'month or so' on long-planned commercial center next to Disneyland Paris theme park; new commercial and residential project will have housing for about 1,500 people, a shopping area with 150 stores, an office center and a golf course (S)

headline: Tunnels Aim to Lower Natural Trade Barriers
abstract: Proposals have been made to build four railroad tunnels through Alps to integrate economies of Europe; railway executives and financial planners in Germany, Austria and Italy are studying possibility of drilling railway tunnel under Brenner Pass, on Austria's Alpine frontier with Italy; Switzerland, though not European Union member, has approved digging of two railway tunnels under Alps; France plans to build tunnel that would link southeastern France and northwestern Italy; map; photos (M)

headline: Du Pont Sells Unit to Genstar Capital
abstract: Genstar Capital LLC purchases NEN Life Sciences unit of E I du Pont de Nemours & Co for as much as $118 million; names John Zabriskie, former head of Pharmacia & Upjohn, to lead it (S)

headline: Neuberger & Berman Genesis Fund
abstract: Investment strategy of Judith Vale, manager of Neuberger & Berman Genesis Fund, which has had 3-year annualized return of 20.3 percent, discussed; many of 125 stocks in $855 million protfolio are companies that basically make parts for other companies' products; some of fund's holdings noted; Vale photo (L)

headline: Panama Leader Accused of Cronyism Over Appointees to Run the Canal
abstract: Panamanian Pres Ernesto Perrez Ballardes is accused of violating his campaign promises by appointing various relatives and cronies to board of directors that will run Panama Canal after US hands over control in 1999; photo; map; diplomats, shippers and canal employees are concerned about efficient operation of vital waterway; other questions about Perez and nepotism also noted (M)

headline: WHIRLPOOL CONSIDERS ALLIANCES FOR FINANCIAL UNIT
abstract: Whirlpool Corp says it is exploring 'strategic business options' for its Whirlpool Financial Corp unit, including possible alliances or partnerships; Whirlpool expects to continue relationship with its financial unit regardless of study's outcome (S)

headline: Market Reform Irreversible, Chinese Leader Tells U.S.
abstract: Pres Jiang Zemin tells Treasury Sec Robert E Rubin that he is irreversible committed to the wide-ranging economic reforms already under way in China but that China will make major moves to open its markets only as economic conditions improve and only at a pace that it feels it can handle; is described as 'slightly ebullient' at success of 15th Communist Party Congress, which endorsed many market-oriented reforms and eased out several of Jiang's competitors in ranks of country's leadership (M)

headline: BUSINESS BEST SELLERS: AUGUST 3
abstract: New York Times list of business best sellers

headline: Plato Malozemoff, 88, Retired Executive
abstract: Plato Malozemoff, former chairman and chief executive of the Newmont Mining Corporation, dies at age 88 (S)

headline: Tug of Home Is Stronger Than the Pull of the Office
abstract: Brenda Barnes, who resigned as chief executive of Pepsico's $7.7 billion North American beverage business for family reasons, says she was not fired and that family is really the reason for resigning (S)

headline: Tausche Martin Gets A Daewoo Account
abstract: Southeast region of Daewoo Motor America in Atlanta has named Tausche Martin Lonsdorf as first agency to handle its advertising account; billings estimated at more than $10 million (S)

headline: In Movieland, Not All Big Deals Are for Big Pictures
abstract: Latest collectible to fetch big-time hype--and prices--is rare movie poster; recent boom in original movie posters is part of rising interest in all movie memorabilia; photo (L)

headline: Three Shops Resign Accounts
abstract: American unit of Club Mediterranee SA and its agency Messner Vetere Berger McNamee Schmetterer Euro RSCG agree to part ways; Club Med has not determined what to do with account; Team One Advertising decides against taking part in review on its America West Airlines account; TBWA Chiat/Day declines to compete in review for domestic account of KPMG Peat Marwick accounting firm (M)

headline: U.S., IN SHIFT, SAYS IT MAY SIGN TREATY TO BAN LAND MINES
abstract: Clinton Administration, in major policy shift, tells allies it could sign treaty banning anti-personnel land mines under compromise that would allow it additional nine years before it begins to remove mines on Korean peninsula; US warns it will insist on right to deploy anti-personnel mines in times of conflict, and on inclusion of clause allowing countries to withdraw if they are victims of aggression, after six-month waiting period (M)

headline: Corn and Soybeans Higher On Poor Iowa Crop Outlook
abstract: Corn prices surge their daily limit on Chicago Board of Trade after reports from Iowa suggest corn crop might be smaller than expected; soybeans also rise in response to reports (M)

headline: Digging for Treasure in Their Own Backyards
abstract: Debate is growing over value of regional mutual funds, which invest in companies in their own areas; critics hold regional focus is just marketing gimmick; performance of funds has been mixed; graph; map (M)

headline: Fed Leaves Interest Rates Unchanged
abstract: Federal Reserve decides to leave interest rates unchanged, betting that the economy can continue to enjoy low unemployment without inflation; Commerce Department reports orders placed with factories declined somewhat more than expected in May, latest sign that growth is moderating to more sustainable pace; orders fell by seven-tenths of 1 percent, to seasonally adjusted level of $323.2 billion, after rising 1.4 percent in April; April figure is revised upward from 1.2 percent; graph (L)

headline: Five Large Drug Concerns Post Strong Quarterly Gains
abstract: Drug makers SmithKline Beecham PLC, Warner-Lambert Co, Schering-Plough Corp, Bristol-Myers Squibb Co and American Home Products Corp report strong second-quarter earnings; Bristol-Myers Squibb says profit rose 12.7 percent; net income rose to $738 million from $655 million; sales rose 10 percent, to $4.06 billion from $3.69 billion; Warner-Lambert's profit rose 8.5 percent; net income climbed to $231.4 million from $213.3 million a year earlier; American Home's earnings rose 17 percent; reports net income of $459.1 million, up from $391.2 million in year-earlier quarter; Schering-Plough says profit rose 18 percent; net income rose to $373.1 million; Smithkline Beecham says profit in quarter fell to $179 million from $181 million in quarter a year earlier; at constant exchange rates, however, profit in quarter rose 14 percent; Smithkline Beecham PLC says it is ready to enter lucrative but crowded market for cholesterol-lowering drugs; it will be co-marketer of Bayer AG's new drug Baycol beginning next year; chart (L)

headline: North Korea Agrees to Join 4-Party Talks
abstract: North Korea, 44-years after Korean War ended with bitter, tenuous cease-fire, agrees to hold talks with South Korea, US and China in effort to negotiate lasting peace; agreement represents breakthrough in effforts to forge peace on Korean Peninsula (M)

headline: Greenspan Opposes Accounting Change on Derivatives
abstract: Federal Reserve chairman Alan Greenspan opposes proposed new accounting rules that would change way companies account for derivatives and possibly discourage some from using them; letter to Financial Accounting Standards Board argues that current accounting should basically be retained, possibly supplemented by some additional disclosures that would not affect financial statements; move could lend crucial support to opposition by many major banks and some corporations that oppose it and to effort to get Congress to block rule (M)

headline: Seven executives at the Deutsch agency find that suddenly they're working for themselves.
abstract: Seven executives at Deutsch Inc are becoming part owners of ageny as part of significant management changes; Cheryl Greene and Linda Sawyer are named managing partners; executives being named partners are Kathy Delaney, Valerie DiFebo, Peter Drakoulias, John Mittnacht and Steve Soldano (M)

headline: Albright to Visit Syria on Mideast Trip to Meet With Assad
abstract: Sec of State Madeleine K Albright is planning to go to Syria for talks with Pres Hafez al-Assad during her first official trip to Middle East in Sept; Albright's primary goal is to get Palestinians and Israelis talking seriously to each other again about peace (M)

headline: Japanese Stocks Lower
abstract: Nikkei average of 225 Japanese stocks is down 346.23 points, or 1.85 percent, at 18,358.54 at midday (Thur, 9/11) (S)

headline: Honors of a Homecoming Adorn Albright's Success
abstract: US Sec of State Madeleine K Albright spends cheerier day in Czech Republic, land of her birth, after emotionally taxing visit to memorial for Czech victims of Nazi Holocaust, where names of her grandparents are inscribed; is presented with Order of the White Lion, Czech Republic's highest honor, by Pres Vaclav Havel (M)

headline: Perkin to Acquire Perseptive in Stock Swap
abstract: Perkin-Elmer Corp agrees to acquire Perseptive Biosystems Inc in stock swap valued at $360 million (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: With Growth and Prices In Control, Bonds Gain  Growth is solid, inflation is subdued and Federal Reserve policy makers will probably stand pat for now on interest rates -- at least, that was what analysts drew from the latest economic reports by the Government.

headline: Prices Surge As Yield Hits 7-Month Low
abstract: US Treasury prices surge; price of 30-year bond rises 27/32, to 101 31/32; yield falls to 6.47 percent, from 6.54 percent on July 15; graph (L)

headline: An 'Unknown' Co-Founder Leaves After 20 Years of Glory and Turmoil
abstract: Interview with Armas Clifford (Mike) Markkula Jr, third and perhaps least understood co-founder of Apple Computer Inc; Markkula offers his version of company's rise and near-fall; graph; photo (L)

headline: Despite Freeing of a Militant, No Letup in Algerian Strife
abstract: Algeria's decision to release Abassi Madani, a leader of banned Islamic Salvation Front, has failed to create the hoped-for momentum toward settlement, and the bloodshed continues; a French researcher notes that other Islamic leaders, including the charismatic Ali Belhadj, are still in prison and much of Government remains committed to repression rather than negotiations; photo (M)

headline: Kohl Believes Something Will Turn Up: His Ratings
abstract: Germany is set to beginf yearlong season of elections, starting with vote in Hamburg's city-state, that essentially turns on political survival of Chancellor Helmut Kohl; Kohl, meeting with 200 journalists, displays certainty that reports of his political demise are exaggerated (M)

headline: Columbia Inquiries Said to Look at Olsten Dealings
abstract: Series of 1994 transactions between Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corp and manager of home health agencies in Florida have grown into important part of unfolding criminal investigations of giant hospital company; Federal prosecutors are investigating whether transactions between Columbia and manager, now known as Olsten Corp, were structured to improperly increase amount of expenses that are partly reimbursable by Government; investigators are said to have obtained evidence that some Columbia hospitals had improperly told Government that money spent on deals for their doctors were actually expenses related to patient care; in such a circumstance, hospital could then improperly receive reimbursement for part of that expense; spokesman for Columbia/HCA says that the company has no knowledge of these areas of investigation (L)

headline: 4 Energy Companies Post Strong Earnings
abstract: Mobil Corp, Chevron Co, Shell Oil Co and Conoco Inc report strong earnings for second quarter; Mobil says it earned $850 million, up 8.6 percent from $783 million in year-earlier quarter; revenue fell 14.4 percent, to $16.7 billion; Chevron earned $823 million, down 5.6 perent from $872 million in quarter a year ago; revenue fell 6.6 percent, to $10.27 billion; Shell Oil Co earned $531 million, up 15.2 percent, from $461 million in year-earlier quarter; revenue declined 1.4 percent, to $7.09 billion; Conoco earned $246 million, up 39 percent from $177 million in quarter a year ago; revenue fell 2 percent, to $4.86 billion; table (L)

headline: U.S. Increases Its Lead in World Market for Weapons
abstract: Congressional Research Service's annual arms survey finds United States pulled further ahead as world's biggest weapons merchant in 1996; survey shows American share of weapons market was up by 23 percent, to $11.3 billion in orders, at time when global market was growing at only 5 percent; United States received 35.5 percent of orders, Britain received 15.1 percent and Russia got 14.5 percent; together, US, Britain and Russia are responsible for nearly two-thirds of world's arms sales; graph (M)

headline: MET LIFE TO ACQUIRE ANNUITY UNIT FROM LONDON INSURANCE
abstract: Metropolitan Life Insurance Co agrees to acquire Security First Group, unit of Canada's London Insurance Group, for $377 million (S)

headline: DOMINION TEXTILE IS PLANNING CUTBACKS
abstract: Dominion Textile Inc will close fabric plant in Ireland and cut production at plant in Italy to increase competitiveness of its Klopman International unit in Europe, eliminating 265 jobs, or 29 percent of Klopman's work force (S)

headline: Chinese Party Conclave Will Put Old Faces in New Posts
abstract: Chinese Communist Party announces that it has set Sept 12 for its next Congress, grand event held every five years, when 2,000 delegates assemble at Great Hall of People and formally approve slate of leaders and sweeping plan for political and economic policy (M)

headline: STOCK OF TINSLEY LABS SOARS ON NEWS OF ACQUISITION
abstract: Tinsley Laboratories Inc stock almost doubles on news company will be acquired by Silicon Valley Group Inc for $42 million in stock (S)

headline: South Korean Banks Get New Flexibility
abstract: Bank of Korea says banks will be allowed to set their own interest rates on savings deposits of less than three months starting on July 7, as part of fourth stage of interest rate liberalization (S)

headline: 24 Top Mafia Figures Get Life Sentences in Sicily
abstract: Court in Sicily convicts and sentences Salvatore Riina, chieftain of Sicilian Mafia, and 23 top lieutenants to life sentences for their role in killing of Giovanni Falcone, prosecutor whose work and dramatic death in 1992 made him the hero and martyr of Italy's war against organized crime; all but 2 of the 24 are currently in prison, many, like Riina, serving multiple sentences; photo (M)

headline: Vietnam Said to Bar Journalist From Taking a U.N. Fellowship
