abstract: Nguyen Manh Hung, first Vietnamese journalist awarded international fellowship to report on UN, has reportedly been barred from traveling to US by Vietnamese Government because award had not been presented through Government channels (S)

headline: Senate Scolds Canada Over the Salmon Fracas
abstract: Senate approves Sen Frank H Murkowski resolution accusing Canada of failing to take responsibility for fishermen's blockade of Alaskan ferry boat in dispute over salmon fishing rights; urges Pres Clinton to take 'appropriate action' (S)

headline: Copter Crash In Bosnia Kills Envoy And 11 Aides
abstract: United Nations helicopter carrying officials trying to help Bosnia carry out elections crashes, near Bugojno, killing all 12 passengers; four Ukrainian Air Force crew members contracted to UN, including pilot, survive; dead include five Americans; map (M)

headline: America the Beautiful? (A Rare Rave)
abstract: Interview with Qian Ning, son of China's Foreign Min Qian Qichen, whose book, Studying in America, expresses admiration for US; book chronicles lives of Chinese students who have become significant presence on almost every university campus across America; photo (M)

headline: INTERACTIVE GROUP STOCK SOARS ON ACQUISITION DEAL
abstract: Interactive Group stock soars 33 percent after company agrees to be acquired by Dataworks Corp for $57 million in stock (S)

headline: An Ethical Role for Recruiters
abstract: Ouster of John R Walter as president just seven months after he joined AT&T Corp raises questions about ethical responsibilities of executive recruiters; compensation system gives recruiters, who now play bigger role in corporate America, incentive to plump up candidate's credentials; recruiters are reluctant to resign assignment when they know client's search process is flawed (M)

headline: London Journal; How to Review 'The Royals' Without Viewing It
abstract: Britain's tough libel laws, which place burden of proof on defendants, have prevented British media from publishing parts of, or discussing in any meaningful way, Kitty Kelly book, The Royals, which describes un-regal behavior in upper reaches of British royal family; photo (M)

headline: Directory Venture Is Set
abstract: Atlantic Information Services Group of Bell Atlantic Corp and R R Donnelley & Son say they will form joint venture to publish Yellow Pages shopping directories outside US; new venture will be called Global Directory Services Co (S)

headline: DIGITAL LOWERS THE PRICES OF ITS PERSONAL COMPUTERS
abstract: Digital Equipment Corp says that it has lowered prices of its personal computers by up to 21 percent (S)

headline: Clinging to Its Past, Europe Is Warily Awaiting the Euro
abstract: First of two articles in series Changing Money, on planned introduction of single European currency by 1999; several governments, at huge political risk, are preparing to impose euro on restive, sometimes openly hostile, citizens, who see union as cause of stagnation and sacrifice; seek to forge greater European unity to halt continent's relative decline in American-dominated world; skeptics worry about imposing single economic policy on diverse countries; map; table; photo (L)

headline: Conglomerates Learn to Pick Their Spots
abstract: Many companies have stubbornly and successfully stuck with their conglomerate structures; most diversified companies, following General Electric Co model, stress only businesses where they can be top players, selling off other units; try to keep balance sheets clean, avoid purchases that dilute earnings and buy back stock with excess cash when they lack attractive acquisition targets; tables; photos (L)

headline: Miscellany
abstract: * Nautica division, Nautica Enterprises, New York, signed the basketball star Glen Rice of the Charlotte Hornets as the first professional athlete to endorse its Nautica Competition line of sportswear and basketball shoes. A campaign by Anne Taylor Davis Communications, New York, begins next month.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent                Previous   Year          Yesterday   Day   Ago               PRIME RATE   8.50   8.50   8.25        DISCOUNT RATE   5.00   5.00   5.00        FEDERAL FUNDS*   6.00   5.52   6.01        3-MO. TREAS. BILLS   5.07   5.07   5.19        6-MO. TREAS. BILLS   5.19   5.16   5.38        10-YR. TREAS. INFL.**   3.58   3.59   N.A.        10-YR. TREAS. NOTES   6.27   6.33   6.88        30-YR. TREAS. BONDS   6.55   6.60   7.05        TELEPHONE BONDS   7.63   7.65   8.10        MUNICIPAL BONDS***   5.53   5.55   6.03          *Estimated daily average, Dow Jones Markets  **Realized dollar amount rises with inflation  ***Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer  Sources: Salomon Brothers and Dow Jones Markets for Treasury's bellwether bonds, notes and bills

headline: Asian Economies, Once a Miracle, Now Muddled
abstract: Economic outlook for Southeast Asia's once-barreling economies is bleakest in years as region enters new era of currency volatility that has shaken even strongest institutions; markets have fallen sharply as currencies have been devalued, raising fears that region's economies will decline further; while many experts wonder whether boom has fizzled, most corporate executives and economists are unruffled; say economic troubles are natural consequence of dizzying growth rates, and may be brief respite before next assault; graphs (M)

headline: Building Better Boards
abstract: Amy Beth Kressel letter comments on Albert J Dunlap's August 10 article on corporate reform (S)

headline: Bosnian Serb Leader Is Said to Fear for Life
abstract: Officials close to Biljana Plavsic, president of the Bosnian Serb Republic, said tonight that she feared for her life and was considering fleeing if she loses her power struggle with Radovan Karadzic, her predecessor, who is charged with war crimes.    ''This is a battle we will probably lose, but it is a battle to save the Serb Republic,'' a senior Bosnian Serb official who is an ally of Ms. Plavsic said as the leadership crisis deepened.

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: Debt     * City of St. Louis is selling $198.6 million of tax-exempt airport revenue bonds through Bear, Stearns & Co. The bonds are priced to yield a maximum of 5.58 percent for an issue in 2027 and 5.55 percent for an issue in 2022. For short-maturity serial bonds, the yields range from 4.45 percent in 2001 to 5.52 percent in 2017. The bonds are rated triple-A by both Moody's and S.& P.

headline: A Swiss Effort to Spotlight Anti-Semitism
abstract: Swiss anti-Semitism is being put on center stage at time when country's actions during World War II are being re-examined; troupe of actors is traveling around country, reading dozens of recent letters to newspapers from Swiss readers, commenting about Jews (M)

headline: Sounding an Alarm From the Newsstand
abstract: Personal-finance magazines are warning that stocks are overvalued and offering strategies to prepare for sharp correction; photo (M)

headline: Coming of Age in Consumer Land
abstract: Article examines findings of J Walker Smith/Ann Clurman book, Rocking the Ages: The Yankelovich Report on Generational Marketing (M)

headline: Unlike Other Fashion Houses, Versace Should Survive Its Founder
abstract: Article on future of Gianni Versace Group in light of murder of its founder Gianni Versace; says Versace took steps to insure his business would survive him; his sister, Donatella, will likely take over design side, while his brother, Santo, oversees finances; photos (L)

headline: REPUBLIC INDUSTRIES IN $40 MILLION DEAL FOR ANDERSON
abstract: Republic Industries, which is building nationwide chain of used-car dealerships, agrees to acquire Anderson Dealership Group for about $40 million in stock (S)

headline: Kmart in Link To Pizza Chain
abstract: Kmart Corp reaches agreement with Little Caesar Enterprises to have pizza chain supply all its in-store restaurants, allowing retailer to cut costs; pizza chain's Blue Line division will serve as national distributor to supply Kmart's new Kcafe restaurants, replacing about 25 agreements with local and regional distributors; terms of agreement undisclosed; sales at 1,850 restaurants in Kmart stores run more than $350 million a year (S)

headline: Rebates by Brokers Under S.E.C. Review
abstract: Market Place column on practice of 'soft dollars' at brokerage firms that is meant to improve quality of service that investors receive from mutual fund and other money managers; says it also can be a way for brokerage companies to reward those managers for steering stock trades their way; holds critics charge system is open to abuse because many services provide no direct benefit to investors who pay commissions that finance them; practice is under review by Securities and Exchange Commission; diagram (L)

headline: KPMG Venture With Microsoft
abstract: KPMG Peat Marwick LLP will announce formation of 500-member consulting group dedicated to Microsoft Windows NT operating system and business-oriented applications, and creation of joint venture with Microsoft and Cisco Systems to apply Microsoft and Cisco products to electronic commerce, on-line call centers and sales automation (S)

headline: Pet Food Business To Hurt Dalgety Profit
abstract: Dalgety PLC, British food concern, more than triples its estimate of charge for its 1997 fiscal year and says pretax profit will not meet expectations; Dalgety now expects charges of $229 million (S)

headline: Private Investors to Be Offered 20% of Stock : A Slice of France Telecom
abstract: PARIS  The government said Monday it would sell 20 percent of France Telecom to private investors, making it clear that control of the state-owned company, Europe's largest remaining phone monopoly, would remain firmly in state hands.

headline: Order for 12 Boeing Jets
abstract: Boeing Co receives order for 12 jetliners from Easyjet Airline Co valued at $492 million before discounts (S)

headline: BRIGHTPOINT TO BUY DISTRIBUTOR OF WIRELESS EQUIPMENT
abstract: Brightpoint Inc agrees to acquire Legend International Ltd, distributor of wireless communication equipment based in Hong Kong; terms undisclosed (S)

headline: Short Sales Outstanding Increase Slightly on Nasdaq
abstract: Open positions of short sales on Nasdaq stock market rose slightly in most recent month; short interest increased nearly five-tenths of 1 percent, to 1.509 billion shares from 1.503 billion; tables (M)

headline: Biotechnology Company Says It Has Cloned a Cancer Gene
abstract: Geron Corp and University of Colorado researchers report cloning gene for human telomerase catalytic protein, which is believed to play key role in cancer and age-related diseases, raising hopes about possible new treatments, article in journal Science; Geron's stock price soars; experts say cloning of gene is still many years removed from potential drug (M)

headline: Palestinian, 16, Killed In Clash With Israelis
abstract: Israeli troops kill Palestinian youth and wound six others in Gaza Strip after Arab youths stone Jewish settlers bulldozing land claimed by Palestinians; Palestinians in Hebron throw stones and firebombs at Israeli soldiers, who respond with live ammunition, wounding at least two dozen youths; clashes accompany general strike called to protest anti-Muslim posters spread by Israeli woman, who has been arrested by Israelis (S)

headline: Kia Executives Put Rescue Plan in Jeopardy
abstract: Executives of Kia Group refuse to submit resignation letters to creditor banks in exchange for emergency loans, jeopardizing rescue plan for South Korea's eighth-biggest conglomerate; stalemate could push company into bankruptcy because it has $10 billion of debt (S)

headline: H & R Block Shares Up on Report of Compuserve Sale Talks
abstract: Shares of H & R Block and Compuserve rise following report that investment firm Welsh, Carson, Anderson & Stowe is in talks to buy majority stake in Compuserve, Block's faltering on-line service; Block shares rise 68.75 cents, to $40.75, while Compuserve gains 25 cents, to $12.875 (L)

headline: AVANT TO BUY TECHNOLOGY MODELING FOR $150 MILLION
abstract: Avant Corp agrees to buy Technology Modeling Associates Inc for about $150 million, increasing its capabilities in computer-aided chip design and heating up its rivalry with Cadence Design Systems in electronic design automation business (S)

headline: Accounts
abstract: * Screenvision Cinema Network, New York, to the Levinson/GFS Group, New York, as the first agency to handle advertising for Screenvision, the in-theater advertising network. Billings were estimated at $1 million.

headline: Inflation Fear Drops Prices Of Treasuries
abstract: Prices of US Treasury securities tumble to nearly two-month low; 30-year Treasury bond drops 1 3/32, to price of 99 24/32; yield rises to 6.39 percent from 6.31 percent on Sept 24; graph (L)

headline: Broadcast Giants Vie for Control of Regional Sports Markets
abstract: Rapid deployment of Fox Sports Detroit underscores rush to control regional sports by Fox Sports Net, a joint venture of Fox Inc, unit of Rupert Murdoch's News Corp, and Liberty Media, programming arm of Tele-Communications Inc; Fox Sports Net plans to use growing network of local sports programming to compete with ESPN for national advertising and possibly for national rights to pro sports (L)

headline: Stocks Roar Back; Dow Climbs 257.36
abstract: After suffering through a steep August selloff, the stock market roared back to life yesterday, posting some of the biggest gains of the decade.

headline: Time Warner Is Said to Plan A Cable Sale
abstract: Time Warner is expected to offer for sale cable systems reaching over 150,000 subscribers in bid to cut debt (S)

headline: For a new generation of Asian tigers, a harsh currency lesson.
abstract: Economic Scene column on devaluation of currencies of Thailand, Malaysia, the Philippines and Indonesia; says to some conservative analysts, lesson in Asian nations is that these emerging markets erred by abandoning fixed exchange rates and will now suffer the consequences; holds what currency shock has done is remind Asia's fast-growing economies that the old rules--high savings rates, strong work ethic and welcome mat to foreign investors--are not quite sufficient to insure prosperity indefinitely (L)

headline: MARKET TIMING
abstract: MONDAY  The Agriculture Department releases its weekly report on crop conditions.  The Commerce Department reports on construction spending for June.    TUESDAY  The Conference Board reports leading indicators for June.  The Commerce Department reports June housing completions.  Mitsubishi Bank/Schroder Wertheim reports on weekly retail sales.  LJR Redbook Research releases its weekly retail sales index.

headline: Art museums stretch scarce marketing dollars with carefully targeted publicity campaigns.
abstract: Article on how major art museums are stretching marketing dollars with carefully targeted publicity campaigns (L)

headline: FROM THE DESK OF; The Answer, My Friend, Is Snapping In the Wind
abstract: Article by Alan Robbins looking for broken rubber band on electronic equipment before sending equipment to repair shop; drawing (L)

headline: Volvo Profits Rise 48%, Aided by Asset Sales
abstract: Volvo AB says second-quarter profit rose 48 percent; profit rose to 1.96 billion kronor ($252 million), from 1.325 billion a year earlier (S)

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: Debt     * Fannie Mae is selling $100 million of notes due in 2002 through J. P. Morgan Securities. The notes carry an interest rate of 6.3 percent and are priced at par.    * Fannie Mae is selling $100 million of notes due in 2007 through Goldman, Sachs & Co. and Paribas. The notes carry an interest rate of 7 percent and are priced at par.

headline: New President Is Selected for Barney's
abstract: Barney's Inc says it has named Thomas C Shull as its president and chief operating officer to replace John Brincko, who resigned; Shull appointment is subject to approval of bankruptcy court (S)

headline: Times Mirror's Chief Replaces Top Publisher
abstract: Mark H Willes, chmn, chief exec and president of Times Mirror Co, nails another title to his office door with announcement that he will replace Richard T Schlosberg 3d as publisher of company's flagship newspaper, Los Angeles Times (M)

headline: The Cosmopolitan Touch
abstract: Carole Gould (Funds Watch) column discusses recent survey by Gallup Organization for Scudder, Stevens & Clark, which shows mutual fund investors in United States are moving more money abroad; says number of American households that invest overseas through funds has risen almost 18 percent since 1994, to 6.7 million; graph on international funds (M)

headline: Saving Those Senior Discounts
abstract: Felicia Ackerman letter on Ted M Levine's July 27 article questioning need to offer elderly senior discounts; drawing (S)

headline: For Relatives Of Victims, Anger Adds To Anguish
abstract: Hundreds of friends and relatives of people on Korean Air flight that crashed on Guam gather at airline center, Seoul; South Korea's four major television networks suspend normal programming for blanket coverage of crash (M)

headline: De Klerk Quits As Party Chief In South Africa
abstract: Former South African Pres F W de Klerk, who negotiated end to apartheid, resigns as head of opposition National Party and retires from politics; departure is major blow to largely white-backed party, which resisted his efforts to make it into multiracial party; photos (M)/

headline: Privately held MacManus competes against publicly traded rivals for acquisitions.
abstract: MacManus Group, world's ninth-largest agency company, finds that being privately held, which was once a strength, now makes its more difficult to counter growth efforts by publicly held rivals like Omnicom Group and Interpublic Group of Companies; most advertising stocks have surged in price, so public companies can easily use their shares instead of cash to purchase agencies; Craig D Brown, vice chairman and chief operating officer at MacManus, says company is resolved to remain private unless and until it cannot get money it needs from operating profit and lenders to be an acquirer in age of consolidation (M)

headline: Telecommunications Concerns Top Estimates
abstract: Bell Atlantic Corp, Nynex Corp and Northern Telecom all beat analysts' estimates as they announce double-digit growth in earnings in second quarter; Bell Atlantic's earnings of $499 million were modest 7.6 percent higher than last year's second-quarter profits of $463.7 million; revenue increased by 6.7 percent, to $3.4 billion from $3.2 billion; Nynex reports profits of $380.5 million, up from $358 million in year-earlier quarter; overall sales increased by 2 percent, to $3.5 billion from $3.4 billion; Northern Telecom reports earnings of $165 million; revenues increased 26 percent, to $3.8 billion from $3 billion; tables (L)

headline: Malaysian Market Rises 12.4%, Regaining Losses
abstract: Malaysia's benchmark stock index jumps 12.4 percent, ending 10-day losing streak, after Malaysia ends share-trading restrictions and delays some public works projects (S)

headline: Bonds Rise As Investors Await Reports
abstract: Prices of US Treasury securities rise slightly; 30-year bond gains 6/32, to 97 15.32, to yield 6.57 percent, down from 6.58 percent at close on Sept 12; graph (M)

headline: Asset Sales and Cost Cuts Double Pechiney Profits
abstract: Pechiney SA says company earned 1.03 billion French francs in first half of year, up from 426 million francs a year earlier (S)

headline: APOLLO GROUP TO BUY COLLEGE FOR FINANCIAL PLANNING
abstract: Apollo Group Inc agrees to buy College for Financial Planning for about $35 million from National Endowment for Financial Education (S)

headline: New Toothpaste From Colgate Set
abstract: Colgate-Palmolive Co says it has cleared last regulatory hurdle for selling Colgate Total toothpaste, first toothpaste approved for marketing as effective in simultaneously fighting gingivitis, plaque and cavities (S)

headline: Could That Murderous Child Be One of Mine?
abstract: Unidentified 14-year-old boy is accused of strangling and beheading 11-year-old Jun Hase in Kobe, Japan; grisly killing has set off national discussion about whether Japanese society is in some way partly to blame, and even Cabinet has taken up case; photos (M)

headline: TESORO TO BUY UNOCAL'S ALASKA OIL PRODUCTION
abstract: Tesoro Petroleum Corp will buy all of Unocal Corp's crude oil production from Alaska's Cook Inlet field, allowing Tesoro to increase profitability of its refining unit by $2.5 million to $4 million a year; terms undisclosed (S)

headline: Soybeans and Coffee Plunge; Gasoline Up as Supply Shrinks
abstract: Soybean futures prices plunge after two of world's largest grain traders, Cargill Inc and Continental Grain Co, unexpectedly deliver new supplies against expiring contract on Chicago Board of Trade; gasoline rises after big drop in inventories and coffee prices plunge (M)

headline: U.S. Petroleum Data
abstract: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization             Sept. 5   Aug. 29   Sept. 6          1997   1997   1996       Gasoline production, daily   8.1   8.2   7.4       Distillate production, daily   3.5   3.6   3.4       Gasoline stocks   188.3   187.5   191.4       Distillate stocks   132.5   127.0   111.8       Crude imports, daily   7.6   8.5   7.4       Product imports, daily   1.7   1.8   1.9       Crude stocks   297.8   305.7   309.8       Crude production, daily   6.3   6.3   6.4       Refinery utilization (%)   99.1   99.7   94.7          Source: American Petroleum Institute

headline: Barney's Draws Four Offers, But Saks Cools On Earlier Bid
abstract: At least four bidders come forward to meet deadline for bids for Barney's Inc, luxury retailer in bankruptcy; Saks Holdings Inc says it will decline to improve upon $290 million it offered in April that had been leading offer; Dickson Concepts (International) Inc of Hong Kong has previously offered $240 million; others presenting plans to Blackstone Group, investment bank advising Barney's, are Ong Beng Seng, a retail executive from Singapore, Texas Pacific Group and at least one other nonretail suitor (L)

headline: Israeli Melee as Women Pray With Men at the Western Wall
abstract: Group of Conservative and Reform Jewish men and women are forcibly evicted by police, amid jeers by strictly Orthodox Jews, from Jerusalem's Western Wall while praying together, contrary to Orthodox custom; incident is latest confrontation between Orthodox Jews and members of other branches of Judaism who have been locked in divisive debate over authority of Orthodox rabbinic establishment in Israel (M)

headline: Coffee Prices Decline as Rain Aids Crops in 2 Key Regions
abstract: Coffee futures decline as rainfall in Colombia and Indonesia, two of world's top producers, raises prospects for world supplies (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: WESTFIELD AMERICA INC., Los Angeles, a real estate investment trust, will purchase the 50 percent of Meriden Square mall in Meriden, Conn., it did not already own from the closely held GGP/Homart Inc. for $54.5 million.     BORG-WARNER AUTOMOTIVE INC., Chicago, a maker of components and systems for automotive drivetrains, will buy a 63 percent stake in the German engine maker Kuhnle, Kopp & Kausch from Penske Corp., Detroit, for undisclosed terms.

headline: SEAGULL ENERGY SAYS IT WILL SELL A UNIT TO RIO ALTO
abstract: Seagull Energy Corp plans to sell its Canadian exploration and production unit to Rio Alto Exploration Ltd for $182 million of stock (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: No Change in Rates, For Now, Fed Decides  The Federal Reserve voted to leave interest rates unchanged, continuing a remarkable economic experiment in which the central bank has kept rates low despite shrinking unemployment and unusually strong economic growth.    Still, the Fed's action was no surprise, as a variety of recent economic measurements show that inflation remains at barely noticeable levels, indicating no need to apply the monetary brakes. $(Page A1.$)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: Hershey Foods Corp purchases 9.9 million shares of its common stock for about $500 million, or $50.50 each, from Hershey Trust Co (S)

headline: No Deal for Purchase by HFS Of Ward's Direct-Market Unit
abstract: Montgomery Ward Holding Corp rejects revised offer from HFS Inc to buy its Signature Group direct-marketing unit because it is too low and sets too many conditions; HFS says it has terminated discussions about acquisition of Signature (M)

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: OFFICE DEPOT INC., Miami, named John C. Macatee president and chief operating officer.    PAGING NETWORK INC., New York, said Keith Sanders, its senior vice president and chief financial officer, had resigned.

headline: Fighting Erupts Between Cambodia's Two Rival Leaders
abstract: Troops loyal to Prime Min Hun Sen attack stongholds of forces loyal to his co-Prime Minister, Prince Norodom Ranariddh, jolting Phnom Penh, Cambodia, and signaling collapse of coalition Government; ambassadors from dozen nations meet with Hun Sen's aides and plead for end to fighting; map; photo (M)

headline: Dow Soars 100.43 Points On Jobs Data
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average surges 100.43 points, or 1.29 percent, to close at record 7.895.81; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index also sets closing high, gaining 12.89 points, or 1.43 percent, to 916.92; Nasdaq composite index gains 12 points, to record 1,467.61; table (L)

headline: A City of Sleepwalkers? No, They Just Like PJ's
abstract: Growing number of Shanghai residents are wearing pajamas on street this summer, apparently favoring comfort over style; pajamas, once unaffordable luxury, are also fashion statement; photo (M)

headline: Timothy Joyce, 63, a Pioneer in Market Research
abstract: Timothy Joyce, pioneer in field of magazine readership research, dies at age of 63; photo (M)

headline: Mutual Fund Manager Abruptly Leaves Janus
abstract: Thomas F Marsico, portfolio manager of Janus Funds' Twenty fund and Growth and Income fund, leaves company abruptly; Janus names Scott Schoelzel to replace Marsico as porfolio manager of Janus Twenty fund and David Corkins to take over as manager of Growth and Income fund; Claire Young will assume Schoelzel's place as manager of Olympus fund (L)

headline: ZELL PAYS $300 MILLION FOR 38 HOME PARKS
abstract: Manufactured Home Communities Inc, which is headed by billionaire financier Sam Zell, agrees to buy 38 manufactured home communities for $300 million; purchase is being made through tender offer for units of closely held partnerships managed by Gerald Ellenburg (S)

headline: EQUITY OFFICE TO BUY 13 BUILDINGS AND A PARKING GARAGE
abstract: Equity Office Properties Trust to buy 13 office buildings, including headquarters of Texaco Inc.'s production operations, and parking garage for $284.7 million in cash, securities and assumed debt (S)

headline: G.M. June Sales Off 13.3% Amid Industrywide Decline
abstract: General Motors Corp says sales fell 13.3 percent in June; Mazda Motor of America says its sales rose 28.2 percent; BMW of North America Inc says sales rose one-tenth of 1 percent; Mercedes-Benz unit of Daimler-Benz Ag reports 14.6 percent increase in sales; Chrysler Corp says sales fell 4 percent, Toyota Motor Co says sales dropped 2.3 percent, Honda Motor Co says sales rose 8.9 percent and Nissan Motor Co says sales rose 2.4 percent (L)

headline: Stock and Bond Issues Picked Up Speed as Quarter Progressed
abstract: Heavy flow of business in June more than made up for what had been a different start to second quarter for stock and bond underwriters; Securities Data Co says in second quarter, volume of stock and bond underwriting rose 15.6 percent from comparable period a year ago, to $285.08 billion; for first six months of the year, total stock and bond underwritings reached record $571.9 billion; table (L)s

headline: Yahoo Plans $21 Million Charge To Exit Joint Venture With Visa
abstract: Yahoo Inc will take $21.2 million charge against its second-quarter earnings, reflecting its decision to buy its way out of joint venture with Visa International; will restate its results for quarter to show net loss of $20.5 million rather than earnings of $610,000 (S)

headline: Robust Profits Continue, and Smaller Companies Join In
abstract: Corporate America is once again showing robust earnings, three-fourths of way through second-quarter reporting season; winners are not just big players; even smaller companies are showing surprisingly strong earnings gains, creating first signs of earnings parity since first quarter of 1996; chart (M)

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.    MONDAY   Consumer Borrowing July

headline: Saw Maung Is Dead at 68; Led a Brutal Burmese Coup
abstract: Gen Saw Maung, who organized bloody military coup in Burma in 1988 and served as titular ruler of Myanmar until 1992, dies at age 68; photo (M)

headline: Greenspan Voices Doubt On Statistics
abstract: Alan Greenspan, chairman of Federal Reserve, speaking at Center for Economic Policy Research at Stanford University, casts doubt on reliability of key economic statistics, but says he is unsure why economy has remained inflation-free despite strong growth and low unemployment; his speech breaks little new ground, but it continues process in which Greenspan is essentially thinking out loud about some of most vexing and sensitive issues facing central bank in effort to dispel criticism about being too secretive about Fed's deliberations (M)

headline: Bond Prices Rally After Purchasing Report
abstract: Bond prices rally; price of 30-year Treasury bond ends up 20/32, to 97 21/32; yield falls to 6.55 percent, from 6.60 percent on Aug 29; graph (L)

headline: Card Holders' Credit Improved in June
abstract: Moody's Investors Service reports credit quality of US credit card holders improved in June as banks wrote off less debt and consumers paid more of their bills (S)

headline: Trump Plans Indiana Hotel
abstract: Trump Organization's Trump Hotels and Casino Resorts Inc has announced plans to build 300-room hotel at Trump Indiana riverboat casino at Buffington Harbor, Ind (S)

headline: In Financial Arena, Merger Is the Game
abstract: As securities, banking, insurance and money management industries continue their rapid consolidation, some of biggest names in finance are on prowl for acquisitions on Wall Street--or have recently made the plunge; main decision they all face is which firm will give them the biggest lift as they seek to build a global financial business; some major players noted (M)

headline: Admirers Pay Respects With Tears And Flowers
abstract: New Yorkers mourn death of Princess of Wales in car accident in Paris (M)

headline: You've Heard of Soundscan, Now Read About Bookscan
abstract: Soundscan, company whose computerized sales tracking system brought order to nation's pop music charts, is preparing a version for books that some publishers hope could bring precision and efficiency to an industry struggling with declining sales and bloated print runs; new tracking system, called Bookscan, will calculate sales of each book by scanning purchases at cash register by bar code or identification number; most major publishers and sponsors of best-seller lists--such as The New York Times and Publishers Weekly, publishing industry's trade magazine--have been approached about subscribing to Bookscan and subsidizing its creation; New York Times confirms that company has talked to representatives of Bookscan project (L)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Table shows key interest rates

headline: A Quandary For Fidelity
abstract: Planned merger of Price Waterhouse and Coopers & Lybrand accounting firms creates quandary for Fidelity Investments, mutual fund giant that uses both firms to audit its books; Fidelity has not decided whether to hire third auditor (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: MILLS CORP., Arlington, Va., and Simon DeBartolo Group Inc., of Indianapolis, said they had bought 165 acres of land near Charlotte, N.C., on which they plan to develop a $180 million, 1.4-million-square-foot factory-outlet- style shopping mall.    NEW PLAN REALTY TRUST, New York, a real estate investment trust, agreed to buy three community shopping centers in Illinois and Georgia for $61.8 million

headline: ITT May Shrink, but Chief's Pay Stays the Same
abstract: ITT Corp chairman and chief executive Rand V Araskog's salary is escaping unscathed and his total compensation should remain quite ample as he seeks to shrink company again, this time in apparent response to Hilton Hotels Corp's hostile takeover bid; he plans to head ITT Destinations, which would keep ITT's hotel and casino operations; seeks to split ITT into three units without shareholders vote; graph; photo (M)

headline: Staying Too Close to Home
abstract: Funds Watch column on funds that invest in emerging markets (M)

headline: Ford to Rejuvenate Dying Mercury Cougar
abstract: Ford Motor Co plans to rejuvenate its tired Mercury division by reviving Mercury's oldest nameplate: Mercury Cougar; Cougar was introduced as flashy sports coupe 30 years ago but has over that time put on love handles of gentle-riding large car; Ford planned to halt Cougar's assembly line this summer because of slow sales, but now it says Cougar will come back to life in 1998 as small, sporty, wedge-shaped coupe; chart (M)

headline: Republic Reaches a Preliminary Pact With Toyota on Dealerships
abstract: Republic Industries, which has been feuding in courts with US arm of Toyota Motor Co and with American Honda Motor Co, reaches preliminary agreement with Toyota that would allow Republic to buy more Toyota dealerships and would end litigation between the two sides (L)

headline: Series of Shifts At McCann Units
abstract: McCann-Erickson Worldwide unit of Interpublic Group makes series of changes at units devoted to new media and public relations; some changes noted (S)

headline: Motrin Account To Cordiant Unit
abstract: McNeil Consumer Products unit of Johnson & Johnson names Saatchi & Saatchi Health Care Connection in New York to handle its recently acquired Motrin brand of pain reliever; billings expected to total $25 million to $30 million (S)

headline: 2d-Quarter Net at Pepsico Matches Street Expectations
abstract: Pepsico Inc says earnings rose 13 percent in second quarter, to $656 million from $583 million in year-earlier quarter; sales were flat, rising to $7.707 billion from $7.691 billion; chart (L)

headline: From an Icon to a Consumer Brand
abstract: J P Morgan & Co, which once catered to account that exceeded $5 million, is reaching out to smaller investors who want to buy its mutual funds and stock of companies it is underwriting and maybe get its financial advice over the Internet (M)

headline: F.C.C. Accord Said to Be Near On Debts of Wireless Companies
abstract: Federal Communications Commission, under escalating pressure from Congressional members, is close to resolving standoff over how to refinance debts of group of troubled companies that are seeking to offer new type of cellular service; FCC chairman Reed E Hundt now seems likely to support plan that would include several proposals backed by commission's three other members: Susan Ness, Rachelle B Chong and James H Quello (M)

headline: A Senior Discount? I Don't Deserve It
abstract: Article by Ted M Levine, founder and chairman of Development Counsellors International, discusses concept of providing senior citizens with discounts (M)

headline: Inquiry Takes Up Killing of Mandela Aide
abstract: South Africa's Truth and Reconciliation Commission begins deliberating fate of Janus Walusz and Clive Derby-Lewis, convicted of assassinating Chris Hani, who headed armed wing of African National Congress; both have applied for amnesty, but Hani family is bitterly opposed to their liberation; photos (M)

headline: Man in the News: Marian Krzaklewski; Architect of Solidarity's Victory
abstract: Profile of Marian Krzaklewski, leader of Poland's anti-communist Solidarity Party which routed Communists in recent parliamentary elections (M)

headline: Bosnia Jitters: West Fearful of Having to Use Force
abstract: News analysis; despite recent setbacks for Serbian hard-liners in Bosnia, there is rising concern among NATO commanders and senior Western diplomats that more force will be needed to make Dayton peace plan work; many are persuaded that only way to make accord effective is to arrest hardliner Radovan Karadzic, who has been indicted for war crimes; photo (M)

headline: Stock Rally Fades a Lot By Day's End
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average gains 36.28 points, to 7,922.72; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rises 4.29 points, to 947.72 Nasdaq composite index rises 3.55 points, to record 1,670.02; Russell 2000 index also sets record, gaining 0.35 point, to 446.50 (M)

headline: Institutional Investor Editor Dismissed
abstract: Euromoney Publications PLC has ousted David Cudaback, editor of Institutional Investor magazine, just weeks after it agreed to acquire publications from Walt Disney Co for $142 million (S)

headline: Rossignol Shares Jump On Adidas-Salomon Deal
abstract: Shares of Skis Rossignol SA rise on speculation that company, French maker of winter-sports goods, might be takeover target after acquisition of its rival, Salomon SA, by Adidas AG (S)

headline: Report of Decline in Inventory Pushes Gasoline Prices Higher
abstract: Prices for gasoline contracts surge on New York Mercantile Exchange after report by American Petroleum Institute shows that inventories declined more than expected last week, as vacationing motorists had their busiest week of the year (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: Jitney-Jungle Stores of America Inc, Jackson, Miss, supermarket chain company, receives United States antitrust approval to buy its rival Delchamps Inc by promising to sell 10 grocery stores in Mississippi and Florida (S)

headline: $2.2 Billion Bailout For South Korean Banks
abstract: Bank of Korea will inject two trillion won ($2.2 billion) into ailing Korea First Bank and other banks to help increase liquidity (S)

headline: Possible Travel to Cuba
abstract: The Clinton Administration is leaning toward an easing of restrictions on travel by Americans to Cuba during the Pope's five-day visit there in January, allowing hundreds and perhaps thousands of people to go to Cuba for the visit.    Article, page A4.

headline: Digital-Age Wiretapping Plan By F.B.I. Draws Opposition
abstract: Privacy advocates will challenge Federal Bureau of Investigation's proposal for high-technology wiretapping, contending that agency is seeking powers never intended by Congress when it enacted 1994 law to bring wiretapping into digital age; phone companies have also challenged law, contending that Government is forcing them to open their new generation of communications networks in way that exceeds legal and constitutional limits; law in question calls for spending $500 million to modify nation's phone network to allow continued wiretapping by law enforcement groups and specifies standard-setting process to redesign equipment; law was passed after FBI contended that new communication technologies were outstripping their ability to identify and monitor suspected criminals who were using cellular and other communication gear to avoid surveillance (M)

headline: In Rescuing a Relative, a Helping or a Heavy Hand?
abstract: Teri Koff letter on Roy Furchgott's Aug 10 article on his effort to take control of finances of and provide care for aged great-uncle, Joseph Nathan Rosolio, who resisted his help (S)

headline: Andersen Partners Name Acting Chief
abstract: Andersen Worldwide says its partners unanimously elected W Robert Grafton as acting chief executive (S)

headline: TRANSWORLD HEALTHCARE UNIT TO ABSORB ALLIED MEDICARE
abstract: Transworld Healthcare Inc's British unit agrees to acquire Allied Medicare Ltd for $60.1 million (S)

headline: Dollar Ends Little Changed After Early Gains Evaporate
abstract: Dollar loses early gains on currency on July 30 against mark and yen; settles at 118.57 against yen and 1.8370 against mark (S)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent                Previous   Year          Yesterday   Day   Ago               PRIME RATE   8.50   8.50   8.25        DISCOUNT RATE   5.00   5.00   5.00        FEDERAL FUNDS*   5.56   6.23   5.35        3-MO. TREAS. BILLS   4.99   5.07   5.17        6-MO. TREAS. BILLS   5.15   5.19   5.35        10-YR. TREAS. INFL.**   3.57   3.58   N.A.        10-YR. TREAS. NOTES   6.32   6.27   6.92        30-YR. TREAS. BONDS   6.60   6.55   7.10        TELEPHONE BONDS   7.65   7.63   8.14        MUNICIPAL BONDS***   5.52   5.53   6.05          *Estimated daily average, Dow Jones Markets  **Realized dollar amount rises with inflation  ***Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer  Sources: Salomon Brothers and Dow Jones Markets for Treasury's bellwether bonds, notes and bills

headline: Mexican Party Balks at Vote, So Zedillo Chooses Its Chief
abstract: Mexican Government party, PRI, names Mariano Palacios Alconer as its new leader, after Pres Ernesto Zedillo steps in to end two days of wrangling; Pres Ernesto Zedillo had urged party to organize democratic election for post, but in the end selects Palacios, antagonizing both old guard and reformers (S)

headline: Europe Agency Takes On The Fight for Democracy
abstract: Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe is being pressed into service increasingly in Europe to settle ethnic conflicts and to help formerly Communist countries become democratic ones (M)

headline: Sara Lee Announces a Big Revamping, and Stock Climbs
abstract: Sara Lee Corp announces major revamping that will include sale of several manufacturing assets and $3 billion repurchase of company's common stock, largest such repurchase in company's history; company will sell its textile and yarn businesses for investment group led by Jack Ward, former executive vice president of Sara Lee and consultant to the company; Sara Lee stock rises $6, to $48.5625; graphs (L)

headline: Another Top Nynex Executive Is Reported Quitting
abstract: Days before it is expected to win Federal approval of its merger with Bell Atlantic, Nynex Corporation is losing another top manager, according to executives at the companies; Donald B Reed, president and group executive for external affairs at Nynex reportedly plans to announce he is resigning to become chief executive of telecommunications-related company; Reed's departure raises new questions about balance of power between Nynex and Bell Atlantic (M)

headline: Treasury Prices Fall a Bit Pending Economic Reports
abstract: US Treasury prices decline; 30-year bond falls 7/32, to 96 9/32, with yield rising to 6.66 percent from 6.65 percent; graph (L)

headline: Guides for Making the College Try
abstract: Roundup of guidebooks designed to help students choose college; photo (M)2

headline: HARCOURT TO BUY 18% OF STECK-VAUGHN FOR $42.8 MILLION
abstract: Harcourt General Inc acquires 18 percent of Steck-Vaughn Publishing Corp it does not already own for $42.8 million in cash (S)

headline: Amid a Slump for Stocks, Some Sectors Shine
abstract: Biotechnology stocks and gambling issued have done well over past month, during which Dow Jones Industrial Average declined more than 5 percent; charts (M)

headline: Shipping Concern Alters Bid for Swedish Rival
abstract: Frontline Ltd changes its offer for ICB Shipping AB to all-cash bid of 3.237 billion Swedish kronor ($426 million) from stock-and-cash bid; ICB urges shareholders to reject bid (S)

headline: Fresh Air or Windfall?
abstract: Comment by Richard J Mahoney on praise given by Pres Clinton and both parties in Congress on new Federal budget, while deferring problem areas like coming explosion of entitlement spending in Social Security and health care (L)

headline: People
abstract: * Paul Caine, advertising sales manager for the New York division at People magazine, New York, owned by Time Warner Inc., was named associate publisher of a new magazine, Teen People. In addition, Gina Giambalvo, national sales development manager at People, was named marketing director of Teen People.    * Stephen Shepherd was named to the new position of associate publisher of Travel Holiday magazine, New York, which is published by the Hachette Filipacchi Magazines division of Lagardere Group. He had been travel advertising director at Modern Bride, New York, a K-III Communications Corp. magazine.

headline: Mexico's Voters Have Spoken. Its Investors Agree.
abstract: American investors are bidding up shares of Mexico Fund, closed-end fund that invest in Mexico, despite opposition victories in recent election; graph (S)>

headline: 3 Executives Leave Lally McFarland
abstract: Maureen Regan, president of Lally McFarland & Pantello/Euro RSCG, executive vice president Richard Campbell and chief creative officer Brendan Ward have unexpectedly left agency to form shop specializing in health care advertising under aegis of McCann-Erickson World Group; executives will open agency named Regan Campbell Ward as part of Torre Lazur McCann Health Care Worldwide unit of McCann-Erickson (S)

headline: China's Growth Slowed in July
abstract: China's benchmark measure of industrial output grew 8.4 percent in July, slowest rate in more than three years; value-added industrial output for month total $19.5 billion (S)

headline: Get Along Little Dogie #384-591E
abstract: Technology is transforming cattle and dairy industries, as farmers and ranchers respond to competitive pressures, high feed costs and demand for prime, specialty beef; cowboy gear may now include electronic scanners that collect identifying data from electronic ear tags that, when downloaded into laptop computers, automatically call up each cow's family and medical history; photo; drawings (M)

headline: Earnings Drop In 2d Quarter For Salomon
abstract: Salomon Inc reports second quarter earnings fell 26 percent to $220 million (S)

headline: Bert Phillips, 78, Clark Equipment Officer
abstract: Bert Phillips, former chairman and chief executive of Clark Equipment Co, dies at age 78 (S)

headline: Incyte and SmithKline Form Venture in Genetics Field
abstract: Incyte Pharmaceuticals Inc and SmithKline Beecham form joint-venture company, Diadexus, to develop and produce gene-based diagnostic products; companies have invested $25 million in Diadexus; creation of joint venture underscores drug industry's interest in emerging field called pharmacogenomics, which is use of patients' genetic data to fine-tune diagnosis and treatment, and ultimately drug development as well (M)

headline: VIAD ACQUIRING GAME FINANCIAL IN $50 MILLION STOCK SWAP
abstract: Viad Corp agrees to acquire Game Financial Corp for about $50 million in stock (S)

headline: CIRCON SHUNS A FOURTH OFFER BY U.S. SURGICAL
abstract: Circon Corp rejects fourth bid by US Surgical Corp, calling offer of $16.50 a share, or $235 million, too low (S)

headline: Drummond Matthews Dies At 66; Studied Earth's Crust
abstract: Drummond Matthews, geophysicist whose work provided critical underpinning for theory that earth's crust consists of large rigid plates, dies at age 66; photo (M)

headline: Corruption Panel Urges Arafat to Dismiss His Cabinet
abstract: Panel of Palestinian legislators that probed Palestinian government corruption urges Yasir Arafat to dismiss his entire Cabinet and take legal action against several of most powerful ministers; stops well short of accusing Arafat; report reflects popular anger with ostentatious and loose life styles of Palestinian Liberation Organization veterans who returned with Arafat from Tunisia, many of whom work for Palestinian Authority; ministers cited include Nabil Shaath, peace negotiator most popular with Israel and United States (M)

headline: Magazine Account For Gotham Inc.
abstract: Ladies' Home Journal magazine names Gotham Inc to handle its advertising account, which had been in-house (S)

headline: Treasuries Extend Losses A Third Day
abstract: US Treasury securities lose ground for third consecutive day; 30-year bond falls 13/32, to price of 96; yield rises to 6.69 percent, from 6.65 percent on Sept 10; graph (L)

headline: Seeking Flora and Fauna In the Wilds of the Web
abstract: Environmental consultant Richard Stafursky is compiling on his World Species List World Wide Web site what seems to be world's first comprehensive index of flora, fauna and microbes; seeks to tie conservation to holistic vision of all species; table; drawing (M)

headline: Some in Latin America Fear End of U.S. Ban Will Stir Arms Race
abstract: Many Latin American officials and military analysts express concern that Clinton Administration decision to permit the sale of advanced weapons could set off regional arms race (M)

headline: A Virtual Cleanup of Chernobyl
abstract: Tecnomatix Technologies Ltd, Israeli computer software company, is aggressively marketing its robotics process-planning and three-dimensional graphic-simulation software, known as Robcad, which is being used to clean up Chernobyl's atomic reactor number 4; nuclear accident spewed out at least 50 tons of volatile radioactive particles in April 1986; photo (L)

headline: Daewoo Heavy Industries Has Small Gain in Net
abstract: Daewoo Heavy Industries Co says net profit for first half of year rose estimated 3.3 percent; reports interim net profit was about 38 billion won ($42.69 million), compared with 36.78 billion won a year earlier; operating profit dropped 10 percent, to 47 billion won; sales totaled 2.84 trillion won ($31.9 billion), up 12 percent from year earlier (S)

headline: Arafat Aides Say Israel Prevents Security Ties
abstract: Palestinian security officers are following line of non-cooperation with Israel that was laid down by Yasir Arafat, since Israel announced series of punitive measures after suicide bombing in Jerusalem; Palestinian police refuse to arrest suspected militants, key action Israel is demanding before any resumption of stalled peace talks; fear is that making arrests would further inflame ordinary Palestinians, who are already suspicious that Arafat has made too many concessions and that Israel has provided too few rewards; photo; map (M)

headline: Once Prized, Japan's Elderly Feel Abandoned and Fearful
abstract: Article in series Main Street, Japan, on life in the little town of Omiya, reports that there as elsewhere in Japan a considerable share of the elderly are growing old apart from children for the first time in Japanese history and that resulting loneliness, guilt and resentments are casting long shadow on family life; slightly more than half of Japanese over 65 live with children, compared with 80 percent as recently as 1970; social reorganization that followed has led to casting off of many traditions, especially that of filial devotion, such that many young Japanese currently feel even less of debt to parents than young Americans do toward theirs; map; photo (M)

headline: Harte-Hanks Sees Future, and It's Marketing
abstract: Harte-Hanks Communications Inc, which once owned 70 newspapers, is selling all its newspapers and television stations and moving to business of target marketing; this includes making telemarketing calls to consumer, sending junk mail, and mailing out free, advertising-packed papers known as shoppers; Harte-Hanks now publishes more copies of shoppers than any other company in United States and has become international presence in direct marketing; photo; charts (M)

headline: MUTUAL FUNDS; Investing With: Ronald E. Elijah
abstract: Profile of Ronald E Elijah, who runs Robertston, Stephens & Co's Value + Growth and Information Age stock funds; graph; photo (L)

headline: GPU PLANS TO TAKE THIRD-QUARTER CHARGE OF $110 MILLION
abstract: GPU Inc reports it plans to take third-quarter charge of $110 million; company reports net income for second quarter was $70.3 million, compared to $73.6 million a year earlier (S)

headline: Gasoline Prices Dip on Report That a Refinery Is Restarting
abstract: Gasoline futures prices fall on market expectations that Tosco Corp's refinery in Linden, NJ, largest on East Coast, will restore full production early, after almost three weeks of maintenance (M)

headline: For Now, Survivor Is Unable To Speak With Investigators
abstract: Parents of Trevor Rees-Jones, bodyguard critically hurt in car crash that killed Diana, Princess of Wales, say he is recovering from surgery but will be unable to talk to French investigators for some time; photo (M)

headline: 'The Full Monty' is by far the biggest film success at Fox Searchlight Pictures.
abstract: Marketing and distribution of The Full Monty, a low-budget British film, by Fox Searchlight Pictures offers lesson in way behind-the-scenes decisions are made in Hollywood; film is likely to become one of the most succ essful smaller movies in years, but rival distribution executives say film was released far too slowly around the nation, reducing its potential box office; Fox Searchlight disputes this view; photo (M)

headline: Easy Money From Your House (If It's Paid Back)
abstract: Home equity loans and lines of credit explained, particularly with regard to interest costs and repayment pitfalls (S)

headline: Spain Chooses Arbed As Steelmaker Partner
abstract: Spain chooses Arbed of Luxembourg over Usinor Sacilor of France to become major shareholder and partner of Corporacion Siderurgica SA, known as CSI (S)

headline: I.B.M. Dropping Plans for a Simplified PC
abstract: IBM is abandoning plans to make simplified personal computer called a NetPC, though it will offer the enhanced flexibility of the machines across its personal computer line; executives of Sun Microsystems Inc and Oracle Corp, proponents of simpler personal computer based on different concept, say they are not surprised by decision; but they say interest in alternative concept, network computer, remains strong (L)

headline: Market Place; Petrofina of Belgium tiptoes into Big Board trading.
abstract: Market Place column on Petrofina SA, Belgium-based oil and petrochemical company that made its debut on New York Stock Exchange in early September; says stock has risen about 45 percent in last 52 weeks; holds until Sept 3, when Petrofina's American depository receipts began trading on Big Board, company attracted little attention from American investors (L)

headline: The Right Way to Dump the Boss
abstract: Article by Don Hunt and Brian Edwards laments decision by most corporations to use phrase 'resigned to pursue other interests' instead of saying 'fired' when referring to departure of top executives, who almost everyone knows were asked to leave; notes professional sports teams have no difficulty in saying a coach or manager was fired for good of the team; urges corporate America to be as equally forthcoming (M)

headline: He Was Here a Minute Ago
abstract: On the Job, Money and Business column invites readers to send in their best stories about co-workers or bosses who, after reporting to work, are then not seen for most of day

headline: Planning Your Estate Around the New Exemptions
abstract: Article on new Federal tax bill focuses on provisions that lower estate taxes (L).

headline: CBS Executive Is Promoted To Television Unit President
abstract: CBS names Leslie Moonves, president of entertainment subsidiary, president of CBS Television; he has been widely credited with building network's programming base; photo (M)

headline: Keeping the Shop Talk Out of the Pillow Talk
abstract: Couples comment on handling ethical or economic conflicts of interest that arise from their work for competing firms or from careers that overlap in key areas; photos; cartoon (L)

headline: New Rule Will Be Issued On Derivatives Accounting
abstract: Financial Accounting Standards Board, turning aside pressure from banks and brokerage firms, says it will issue new rule on accounting for derivatives this fall; rule will become effective on Jan 1, 1998; changes generally give companies greater freedom to treat derivative contracts as hedges to other things, and therefore to keep profit or loss from derivative from showing up in reported profits until hedged item is also reported; board's officials say they kept to principle that derivatives should be reflected on companies' balance sheets, at their fair value, rather than hidden off balance sheet, as is often case now (M)

headline: Write-Down Causes Loss For Viacom
abstract: Viacom Inc reports second-quarter loss of $195 million, in part result of $323 million charge at company's Blockbuster unit; says loss compares with profit of $41.1 million in same quarter yuear earlier (M)

headline: Getting Advice, or Getting the Ax
abstract: Deborah Stead reviews nonfiction book Dangerous Company, by James O'Shea and Charles Madigan, and novel The Ax, by Donald Westlake (S)

headline: Small Daily Tries to Teach College Paper a Lesson
abstract: Legal drive by Daily Tribune of Ames, Iowa, to curb competition for advertising and readers from campus newspaper could cause repercussions at dozens of public colleges whose student papers have come to act more and more like commercial papers; Michael G Gartner of Daily Tribune charges Iowa State Daily unfairly uses tax-free status, subsidized circulation and increasingly professionalized, nonstudent business staff to expand circulation off campus and solicit advertising from noncampus businesses; Gartner and partner, Gary G Gerlach, teach journalism classes sfor sudent reporters and editors who work on school paper and hire many of students after graduation; photos (M)

headline: 2 BDDP Units Changing Names
abstract: Wells Rich Greene BDDP will become Wells BDDP, and Wells Rich Greene BDDP Communications, holding company, will be renamed BDDP North America (S)

headline: ZALE TO SELL FINE JEWELRY OPERATIONS FOR $65 MILLION
abstract: Zale Corp agrees to sell most of its Diamond Park Fine Jewelers unit to Finlay Enterprises Inc for about $65 million (S)

headline: Tokyo Stocks Tumble
abstract: Stocks fall sharply in Tokyo on Aug 1; Nikkei index of 225 issues closes down 527.05 points, at 19,804.38 (S)

headline: A G.E. Apartment Venture
abstract: GE Capital Services agrees to invest $470 million in venture with JPI Realty to build and acquire apartments (S)

headline: Attention Disorder Is Found In Growing Number of Adults
abstract: Attention Deficit Disorder, once diagnosed primarily in school-age children, is being diagnosed in record number of adults; several recent studies estimate between 6 million and 9.5 million Americans suffer from disorder, making it as common as severe clinical depression or drug abuse; after spotting it in generations of children, psychiatrists have only recently accepted that illness carries over into adulthood; at current pace, adults will receive 729,000 prescriptions in 1997 for Ritalin, mild stimulant used to treat disorder, compared with 217,000 in 1992; critics say illness is being overdiagnosed, and many question whether it really exists; of particular concern is growing use of Ritalin as recreational stimulant by college students and fast-track professionals; photos; graphs (M)

headline: Accounts
abstract: * Frank's Nursery and Crafts, Detroit, owned by the General Host Corp., to Media That Works, Cincinnati, for media planning and buying on its account, with billings estimated at $10 million. Those duties had been handled by TBS Media Management, New York.    * Marshall Field's, Chicago, a unit of the Dayton Hudson Corp., to the Leo Burnett Co., Chicago, to handle a new brand advertising account for the Field's store on State Street in Chicago. Billings were not disclosed.

headline: Swiss Freeze the Assets of Four Argentines Accused in Spain
abstract: Switzerland agrees to freeze bank accounts and other assets of four Argentine military officers who have been charged in Spain with responsibility for secret kidnapping and killing of Spanish nationals during repression of leftist insurgents in Argentina in 1970's; move is in response to request from Spain, where High Court judge is conducting criminal investigation into torture, disappearance and killing of 320 Spanish citizens (M)

headline: Get Rich in Chechnya: Kidnap Your Neighbors
abstract: Gangs of kidnappers from Chechnya have abducted hundreds of people throughout southern Russia, including several Westerners, and held them for ransom in year since secessionist republic forced out Russian army; members of Tlupov family describe ordeal; photo; map; four French and two British aid workers are still captive and $2-million ransom was paid for release of Moscow television reporter and her crew in August; Western officials blame desperate economic conditions, but incidents have revived Russian impressions of Chechnya as zone of banditry and peril; well-kept Russian city of Nalchik is main site of abductions (Nalchik Journal) (M)

headline: MARKET WATCH ; Default: The Risk Bondholders Forgot
abstract: Floyd Norris Market Watch column on continued new lending to third world by foreign investors, with little fear of default, despite collape of Thai baht and economic problems in many Asian nations; graph (L)

headline: Blind Turk Is Going to Jail To Find Freedom, He Says
abstract: Esber Yagmurdereli, blind lawyer, is latest Turkish intellectual willing to sacrifice his freedom to draw attention to what they consider their country's lack of full democracy; he has been sentenced to 23 years in jail after making speech deemed favorable to Kurdish separatism; his imprisonment is likely to focus further attention on human rights problems that have kept Turkey out of European Union; court decision upholding Yagmurdereli's sentence came at same time court set free accused gunmen charged with membership in state-sponsored death squads, and policemen charged with beating journalist to death; photo (M)

headline: U.N. Picks Judge to Lead Inquiry in Congo Killings
abstract: United Nations Secretary General, Kofi Annan, names Atsu-Koffi Amega, former president of Supreme Court of Togo, to lead team to investigate allegations that Hutu refugees from Rwanda were killed in eastern part of Zaire, now Congo, over the past year (S)

headline: U.S. JOBLESS RATE INCREASES TO 5%
abstract: Nation's unemployment rate rises two-tenths of percentage point in June, to 5 percent, easing tightest labor market in quarter century; Government figures show moderate 217,000 jobs were added to payrolls; chief dark spot in job picture is fact that ranks of unemployed grew by 302,000, more than offsetting May's improvement; analysts feel that despite rise in unemployment rate, job market remains in healthy shape; White House and Wall Street hail figures, which suggest economy is still growing solidly but no longer at breakneck pace of earlier in year that threatened to fan fears of inflation; graph (M)

headline: Tyson to Pay $681 Million For Hudson
abstract: Hudson Foods Inc, after tainted-beef crisis last month that led to largest recall of meat in nation's history, agrees to be bought by Tyson Foods Inc in cash-and-stock deal valued at $681 million (M)

headline: In the Murdoch-Levin dispute, money talked.
abstract: Time Warner Inc's surprise decision to give News Corp's Fox News Channel access to its New York City cable television systems and many of its other cable systems around nation comes despite series of legal victories by Time Warner; has spurred number of theories, but results mainly from News Corp head Rupert Murdoch's willingness to pay high price for access; drawing (M)

headline: History Channel To Moss/Dragoti
abstract: A & E Television Network's History Channel names Moss/Dragoti to handle its advertising account, previously handled on project basis (S)

headline: Look Who's Writing the New Book n Wall St.
abstract: Wade B Cook and his Profit Financial Corp, who earn big royalties from his books, tapes and seminars on investing, disclose he is under investigation by Securities and Exchange Commission for securities fraud and battles Arizona securities regulators; graph (M)

headline: Pigeon Forge, Tenn., Attracts Tourists And Money, as Well as Traffic Jams
abstract: Many small towns across country, such as Pigeon Forge, Tenn, home of Dollywood, Dolly Parton's flower-laden theme park, have used local attractions to turn themselves into major tourist destinations; Pigeon Forge has developed tourism department that has contributed to town's success in taking in $545 million last year; nearby Gatlinburg pulled in nearly $307 million, also a record; there is transient quality to life in Pigeon Forge; many of thousands of new jobs are low paying and hard to fill; town officials acknowledge town's social problems; other small towns that have become major tourist destinations include Bar Harbor, Me, Branson, Mo, Eureka Springs, Ark, Jackson, Wyo, Sedona, Ariz, and Solvang, Calif; chart; map; photos (L)

headline: Creating No. 1 Drug Wholesaler, Cardinal to Buy Bergen Brunswig
abstract: Cardinal Health Inc agrees to buy Bergen Brunswig Corp for $2.41 billion in stock and will assume $386 million of debt; purchase will create nation's biggest drug wholesaler, with 31 percent of annual $64 billion market; graph (L)

headline: Matsushita Profit Jumps 42%, Aided by High-Technology Sales
abstract: Matsushita Electric Industrial Co says net income rose 42 percent in fiscal first quarter ended June 30, compared with year-earlier income; income climbed to 26.3 billion yen ($222.6 million) from 18.5 billion yen a year earlier; sales rose 10 percent, to record 1.893 trillion yen from 1.720 trillion yen (M)

headline: N.A.S.D. Bars 20 Brokers for Exam Fraud
abstract: Regulatory arm of National Association of Securities Dealers says it has fined, censured and barred 20 registered representatives suspected of paying imposters to take an exam for them; NASD says it has assessed the 20 more than $1.2 million in forfeited commissions and $650,000 in fines (S)

headline: Bosnia's Latest Power Struggle Puts Serb Against Serb
abstract: Bosnian Serb Parliament, dissolved recently by Pres Biljana Plavsic, meets in Pale, where power still lies in hands of ousted Pres Radovan Karadzic, declaring her authority illegitimate; reverses her plan for local elections in Sept, to be overseen by Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe; international officials say parliament acted illegally; Plavsic calls military leaders together to discuss her power struggle with Karadzic, meeting boycotted by four of eight top generals; remains dependent on foreign support and has nothing to counter Karadzic's vast patronage machine; Western powers plan to concentrate aid in Banja Luka, which is under he control; map; photo (M)

headline: Key Officials Quit in Peru As Fujimori Faces Protests
abstract: Government of Peruvian Pres Alberto K Fujimori falls deeper into turmoil with resignations of Defense Min Tomas Castillo Meza and Justice Min Carlos Hermoza over scandal involving wiretapping and respression of press freedoms (M)

headline: Corrections
abstract: Correction of Aug 10 article by Roy Furchgott about Furchgott's efforts to put financial affairs of his great-uncle, Joseph N Rosolio, in order

headline: Wiley to Sell Legal Unit to Dutch Publisher
abstract: John Wiley & Sons agrees to sell its Wiley Law Publications division to Wolters Kluwer NV for undisclosed amount (S)

headline: Mr. Rubin's Long March to China
abstract: Day-by-day account of Treasury Sec Robert E Rubin's 10 day-trip to Asia; he wrestled with Southeast Asia's currency crisis at meetings of Group of Seven finance ministers and at annual meeting of International Monetary Fund and World Bank, Hong Kong; he then traveled to China's interior to assess nation's confusing, often contrary brew of economic changes; map; photos (L)

headline: Russia to Join Paris Club of Creditors
abstract: French Finance Ministry says Russia will formally join Paris Club of creditor nations; Paris Club is informal group of representatives from creditor countries who meet regularly in Paris to examine requests for debt relief from cash-short countries (S)

headline: EQUITY RESIDENTIAL TO PAY $625 MILLION FOR RIVAL
abstract: Equity Residential Properties Trust, a Chicago real estate investment trust controlled by financier Sam Zell, plans to pay about $625 million in securities to buy rival apartment company, Evans Withycombe Residential Inc, based in Scottsdale, Ariz (S)

headline: Stocks End Week Up, but the Day Down
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average drops 5.45 points, to 7,917.27; Nasdaq composite index rises 10.34 points, to record 1,680.36; Russell 2000 index of smaller company stocks rises 0.67 points, to 447.17, new record; table (M)

headline: Accounts
abstract: * Vivus Inc., Menlo Park, Calif., to Hoffman/Lewis, San Francisco, to handle the first direct-to-consumer national advertising for MUSE, an impotency treatment. Billings were estimated at more than $5 million.    * Favorite Brands International, Lincolnshire, Ill., to Grant/Jacoby Inc., Chicago, as the first agency to handle American advertising for the company's Jet-Puffed Marshmallows brand. The account had been inactive for the last two years, when the brand was owned by the Kraft Foods division of the Philip Morris Cos. Billings were not disclosed.

headline: New Terms Are Expected In MCI Deal
abstract: MCI Communications Corp and British Telecommunications PLC are expected to announce new, reduced terms by which British company will acquire MCI; MCI is expected to reduce its $23.4 billion price tag by between 15 percent to 20 percent--roughly in line with predictions of most analysts (L)

headline: Stocks Close On High Side In Seesaw Day
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average gains 44.33 points, to close at 7,886.76; Russell 2000 index gains 1.75, to close at record 399.15; Nasdaq composite index gains 4.30 points, to record 1,490.93; table (M)

headline: Retail Sales and Producer Prices Up, but Modestly
abstract: Retail sales rise in August and producer prices increase for first time this year; but reports are generally in line with expectations and do little alter perceptions that economy continues to advance with prices in check; consumers spent $213.7 billion at retail counters and in showrooms last month, 0.4 percent more than in July; Labor Dept's Producer Price Index, though posting its first gain of 1997, is driven mainly by surge in energy prices that analysts dismiss as normal gyration; with energy and food disregarded, index edges up just 0.1 percent; chart (M)

headline: Patents; Targeting cancerous tissue without poisoning the body.
abstract: Two researchers at Burnham Institute are granted patent for technique that might lead to method to target cancerous tissue without poisoning the rest; they are Erkki Ruoslahti and Renata Pasqualini (S)

headline: Laggards Become Leaders As Small Stocks Revive
abstract: Stocks of smaller companies and cyclical stocks, which failed to keep pace earlier in year with gains posted by big multinational and consumer products stocks, are new market leaders; gains come in face of recent market slump and last week's wild volatility; experts say changes have been driven by concerns about corporate earnings that underpin bull market; turnabout has lifted some depressed diversified domestic mutual funds, particularly funds that invest in smallest stocks; graph; table; drawing (M)

headline: Doubts Shelve Book On Marco Polo Era
abstract: Little, Brown & Company announced that it was postponing publication of a book purporting to be a 13th-century Italian-Jewish merchant's account of visiting China four years before Marco Polo.

headline: Old Kent Shares Rise 7%
abstract: Shares of Old Kent Financial Corp, bank holding company in Grand Rapids, Mich, climb more than 7 percent ahead of stock's move to S&P Mid Cap 400 index after close of trading (S)

headline: Admire Her Art? (Her Camera Adored Swastikas)
abstract: Article on controversial German filmmaker Leni Riefenstahl, whose films in 1930's celebrated Nazi pageantry; notes that she will be 95 on Aug 22; photo (M)

headline: Rehabilitated Partner for Columbia/HCA
abstract: Executives at Tenet Healthcare, in courting acquisition candidates, have taken advantage of what they call the 'ABC phenomenon'--anything but Columbia; for hospitals rattled by Columbia/HCA's aggressive tactics, Tenet portrays itself as a rescuer and a companion, even letting acquired hospitals keep their own names; Tenet could be friendliest available partner for Columbia/HCA; Columbia, more than twice the size of Tenet, is facing Federal investigations of its most basic practices (L)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: List of rates for key government bonds

headline: Defiant Israelis Crowd Jerusalem Mall Where Suicide Bomb Attack Killed 4
abstract: Defiant Israelis crowd Jerusalem mall, where suicide bombs exploded killing four people, in spontaneous demonstration of national refusal to be cowed by terrorists; photo (M)

headline: UNC SELLS EQUIPMENT MAINTENANCE UNITS TO CARLYLE
abstract: Carlyle Group acquires military aircraft and vehicle divisions of UNC Inc for undisclosed sum; Carlyle will rename operations Lear Siegler Services Inc (S)

headline: As the stigma fades, Madison Ave. steps up its fight against AIDS.
abstract: Many major advertising agencies are becoming involved again--or for first time--in efforts to fight AIDS; on Sept 25, more than dozen New York agencies will cosponsor fund-raiser for AIDS charities; participants include shops owned by Cordiant PLC, Interpublic Group of Companies, Omnicom Group and WPP Group as well as large independents like Grey Advertising and Young & Rubicam; big agencies like Ammirati Puris Lintas and McCann-Erickson New York have been working on pro bono projects for organizations like Gay Men's Health Crisis and Names Project Foundation, which oversees the AIDS quilt; drawing (L)

headline: Interpublic Buying Marketing Services
abstract: Interpublic Group of Companies agrees to buy four marketing service businesses and name of Marketing Corp of America; terms undisclosed (S)

headline: CUC REDUCES PRICES FOR BOOKS MEMBERS BUY ON LINE
abstract: CUC International Inc's on-line book unit discloses price cuts aimed at stealing market share from Amazon.com Inc and Barnes & Nobles Inc in fledgling industry of electronic book selling; CUC's Book Stacks Unlimited says it will increase its discounts to 40 percent off suggested retail price for hardcover books and 30 percent off for paperbacks (S)

headline: Asset Growth of Mutual Funds Doesn't Reduce Fees, a Study Says
abstract: Study by Lipper Analytical Services says mutual fund industry, whose assets have doubled in last four years and quadrupled in last seven, does not enjoy economies of scale that would allow fund companies to lower fees charged to investors as assets grow; study also concludes that fund fees in general are at a reasonable level, given returns investors have received and compared with fees charged for alternative investments (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: United Parcel Strike Could Be Long, Union Says  Company and teamsters' union officials met for a second day of intense talks aimed at ending the five-day-old United Parcel Service walkout. But with no significant progress reported on a new contract, union officials warned locals nationwide to be prepared for a long strike.   $(Page 9.$)    A mechanic in Iowa cannot get parts for car repairs. Pet fish are stranded at a Florida distributor. The United Parcel strike has straitjacketed many smaller businesses around the country. If problems for small businesses grow, they could mean serious problems for the nation's economy.   $(1.$)

headline: HARNISCHFEGER TO BUY BACK 10 MILLION SHARES
abstract: Harnischfeger Industries, which three months ago failed in hostile bid for Giddings & Lewis Inc, says that it will buy back as much as 21 percent of its shares and might sell a heavy machinery unit (S)

headline: Aborigine Enters History Books, 100 Years Late
abstract: Aborigine known as Jandamarra, who resisted white takeover of Australia in 19th century, has long been hero to Aborigines and either ignored or depicted as outlaw by white Australia; now he is being written up in books, pamphlets and newspapers and taught in schools, and film about him is under negotiation; new interest in Jandamarra is among signs of change in Australian thinking about Aborigines; drawing; map (M)

headline: In an Industry Built on Turmoil, Novell Must Struggle to Rebound
abstract: Article on Novell Inc focuses on corporate strategy of new chief Eric Schmidt, who must aim struggling company in new directions while fending off Microsoft Corp's attacks on its core network software business; efforts by previous company heads Robert Frankenberg, John Young and Raymond Noorda discussed; graph; drawing; photos (L)

headline: Mobutu Sese Seko, Zairian Ruler, Is Dead in Exile in Morocco at 66
abstract: Mobutu Sese Seko, Zaire's longtime dictator, dies in exile in Morocco after long battle with prostate cancer; was 66 years old; his rise to power and humiliating defeat in May 1997 after seven-month rebellion by life-long opponent, Laurent Desire Kabila, reviewed; photos (L)

headline: Lawsuit Against TLC Beatrice Is Settled
abstract: TLC Beatrice International Holdings Inc says Carlton Investments, company's largest shareholder, agreed as part of overall settlement to withdraw lawsuit it filed against company in 1994; lawsuit contested $22.1 million compensation package paid to TLC Beatrice's chairman and chief executive Reginald F Lewis, before his death in 1993 (S)

headline: Lawyers wrangle over the move by Ritz-Carlton to strip its imprimatur from four U.S. hotels.
abstract: Business Travel column says controversy over loss of use Ritz-Carlton name by hotels in New York, Washington, Houston and Aspen, Colo, appears to be unresolved as lawyers are still wrangling over it; notes owners of four hotels have filed $250 million lawsuit in New York State Supreme Court against Marriott International and Ritz-Carlton, charging fraudulent conveyance in connection with Mariott's 49 percent acquisiton of hotel chain's assets in 1995; in separate news, column notes National Business Travel Assn finds that while business travelers are not happy about taxes and fees imposed on air fares, neither are they outraged; says American Express finds air fares for business travelers have risen substantially this year, with typical business air fare for more than 215 point-to-point routes from 40 major US cities up 24 percent from Jan to June; says most airlines are offering fares over Labor Day holiday as low as $158 round trip between Newark and Los Angeles but that seats and travel times are limited (M)

headline: Leo Gruliow Is Dead at 84; A Self-Taught Soviet Scholar
abstract: Leo Gruliow, self-taught scholar who lectured widely on Soviet affairs and translated Soviet periodicals into English, dies at age 84; photo (M)

headline: Sitting in the 70's; With Outdated Styles, Furniture Sellers Are Struggling
