abstract: Furniture retailers are struggling because sellers are not giving consumers products they want; furniture has remained firmly entrenched in 1970's, when many suburban middle-class homes had same basic easy chairs and dinette sets; many mainstream retailers have been far more focused on pushing easy credit terms rather than updating style of their offerings; decision by Levitz Furniture Corp, one of country's largest furniture chains, to file for bankruptcy protection discussed; graphs; photos (L)

headline: LVMH Juggles Stakes In 2 British Companies
abstract: LVMH sells some of its stake in Guinness PLC to buy more shares of Grand Metropolitan PLC in bid to exert more influence over British companies' planned merger (S)

headline: Nomura Profit Declines, but Beats Predictions
abstract: Nomura Securities Co reports income for first quarter declined 4 percent to $301 million (S)

headline: A new Belgian carrier is modeling itself after Southwest Airlines, apparently with success.
abstract: City Bird, new Belgian airline owned by City Hotels, is offering unrestricted one-way coach tickets between Newark, NJ, and Brussels, Belgium, for $148, good until mid-December, when fare will increase to $189; Smith Travel Research says hotel occupancy declined slightly in first half of 1997 for first time in five years; in top business markets like New York, where average daily room rate has increased to $160 from $142 a year ago, room demand continues firm; New York Passport Agency opens for business at its new, roomier offices in West Village; Russian Government plans to lop three 000's off its ruble notes in early January; 5,000 denomination note is now worth about $1; after the change, 10 rubles, roughly equivalent of $2, will be lowest paper denomination available; silver or gold members of British Airways' Executive Club program can use 210,000 miles to play golf in Scotland at sport's fountainhead, the Royal and Ancient Golf Club at St Andrews (Business Travel column) (L)

headline: OPPOSITION LEADER DECLARES VICTORY IN MEXICO ELECTION
abstract: Opposition leader Cuauhtemoc Cardenas Solorzano declares victory in Mexico City mayoral race, as ruling Institutional Revolutionary Party suffers unprecedented setbacks in key national elections; Pres Ernesto Zedillo congratulates Cardenas and pledges to work with him to improve life in city; another opposition party claims victory in gubernatorial race in key state of Nuevo Leon; election is first managed by autonomous federal election council; photo (M)

headline: A Ceremony in North Korea Breaks More Than Ground
abstract: International delegation breaks ground near Kumho, North Korea, for project in which Western nations will give North Korea two modern nuclear reactors in exchange for North Korea's accord to give up older reactors that could be used to make nuclear arms; rite is milestone in opening up diplomatically isolated North Korea to outside world; project will involve work in North Korea by thousands of South Korean laborers even though two nations are still technically at war; map (M)

headline: Finding an Initial Public Offering in the Temperate Zone
abstract: Study by Laurie Krigman, Wayne H Shaw and Kent L Womack finds initial public stock offerings that are good, but not spectacular, performers on first day, rising more than 10 percent and less than 60 percent, tend to continue winning streak into next year; Womack cites tendency of underwriters to price offerings some 15 percent to 30 percent below what they think stock is worth; graph (M)

headline: Humans' Earliest Footprints Discovered
abstract: Scientists report finding earliest fossilized footprints of anatomically modern human being in 117,000-year-old sandstone on shore of South African lagoon, about 60 miles from Cape Town; new discovery is particularly welcome in study of human origins because fossil record--on bones or footprints--is woefully incomplete for period when archaic Homo sapiens evolved into modern species; it is thought this fateful transition occurred between 100,000 and 200,000 years ago, when 'African Eve,' one common ancestor of all living humans, is thought to have lived; until now, only 30 ancestral human fossils from period have been found anywhere in world; photo; map (M)

headline: Stock Buyback Begun At British Gas Company
abstract: BG PLC, Britain's biggest natural gas distributor, begins stock buyback worth $2.1 billion (S)

headline: Derivatives in the Darkness: The Birth of a Thriller
abstract: Comment by Stephen Rhodes, stock trader, on how he came to write thriller about derivatives; The Velocity of Money will be published in October (S)

headline: Tax Negotiators to Seek a Win-Win-Win Deal
abstract: Status of tax plan negotiations between White House and Congress reviewed; table (S)

headline: Hong Kong Stocks Extend Plunge, Falling 6.5% More
abstract: Hong Kong's benchmark Hang Seng fell 709.60 points on Sept 1 and by noon in Hong Kong on Sept 2, dropped further 195.93 points to stand at 13,229.72 (L)

headline: 2 Japanese Bank Officials Are Indicted
abstract: Tokyo prosecutors say they have indicted former vice pres of Dai-Ichi Kangyo Bank Ltd, Ichiro Fujita, and former managing director, Tateo Fukushima, in connection with illegal loans that bank purportedly made to corporate racketeer; separately, NHK television reports that prosecutors arrested Tadashi Okuda, bank's former chmn; case reviewed (S)

headline: STERLING ELECTRONICS STOCK RISES 13% ON MERGER TALKS
abstract: Shares of Sterling Electronics Corp rise as much as 13 percent after semiconductor distributor says it is in talks with unidentified company over possible 'strategic combination' (S)

headline: Book Chains' New Role: Soothsayers for Publishers
abstract: Publishing executives, unsettled by flagging sales and heavy book returns, are turning to dominant book chains, such as Barnes & Noble and Borders for guidance on broad range of issues that could determine manuscript's destiny; are nurturing ties with techniques straight from books on relationships that are stacked on self-help shelves, sharing listening and communicating; increasing reliance on advice of few big retailers is far cry from pre-superstore era, when sales representatives for publishers sampled tastes of reading public by traveling to hundreds of bookstores to meet buyers; new coziness is raising alarm among critics, wary that few large national chains could ultimately dictate production and packaging in literary marketplace; photos (M)

headline: Diana Killed in a Car Accident in Paris
abstract: Diana, 36-year-old Princess of Wales, dies in high-speed car crash in Paris with companion, 41-year-old Emad Mohammed al-Fayed, and limousine driver; bodyguard is critically injured; she succumbs to massive injuries at Pitie-Salpetriere Hospital in southeast Paris; nighttime accident, in highway tunnel on right bank of Seine under Place d'Alma, demolishes Mercedes limousine; reportedly occurs while car was being pursued by photographers on motorcycles after leaving Ritz Hotel; police detain several motorcyclists for questioning; photos (M)

headline: Svenska Cellulosa Bids For Shares of PWA
abstract: Svenska Cellulosa AB says it will bid 550 million German marks ($300 million) to acquire 20 percent of German paper maker PWA Papierwerke Waldhof-Aschaffensburg AG it does not already own; PWA says its first-half net income rose 29 percent, to 107 million marks ($58.47 million), from 83 million marks in year-earlier period; sales remained at last year's level of 2.5 billion marks (S)

headline: Corn Prices Rise as Dryness Cuts Crops in U.S. and China
abstract: Corn prices surge on Chicago Board of Trade after Agriculture Department reports that dry weather this summer hurt US and Chinese crops far more than forecasters had expected (M)

headline: Sam Chase, 80, Retired Broadcasting Executive
abstract: Sam Chase, broadcasting and publishing executive who won awards for programming dealing with civil rights, died on Aug 11 at age 80; photo (M)

headline: Campbell Soup Adds to List of Businesses That It May Sell
abstract: Campbell Soup Co is thinking of selling or spinning off operations with total of $1.4 billion in revenues as it concentrates on its soup, sauces, baked-goods and food-service operations, which it considers its key businesses (M)

headline: Mexican Tale: Drugs, Crime, Torture and the U.S.
abstract: Special report, Witness to Evil, on abduction by Mexican military of Alejandro Enrique Hodoyan, minor member of drug organization who was detained illegally for 80 days and tortured into becoming Government witness against major drug cartel; American officials, who say they knew of Hodoyan's captivity shortly after he was imprisoned, admit to turning a blind eye to methods used by military to secure Hodoyan's cooperation; case highlights perils for US in working with secretive Mexican military, which has been given central role in drug war despite its lengthening record of corruption and brutality; photos (M)

headline: I.B.M. Reports Mixed Results For Quarter
abstract: IBM reports second-quarter earnings higher than expected by analysts; earnings rose 7.4 percent, to $1.4 billion from $1.3 billion in year-earlier quarter; revenue was $18.8 billion, slightly less than 4 percent above last year's $18.2 billion; table (L)

headline: In Apartheid Inquiry, Agony Is Relived but Not Put to Rest
abstract: Many victims of apartheid-era brutality who told their stories to South Africa's Truth and Reconciliation Commission are experiencing psychological symptoms and growing anger that process reopened old wounds but gave them no follow-up support; some expected concrete help like pensions and job training, but no such aid has materialized; are upset that commission has freed dozens of those responsible for murder and torture; photos (L)

headline: On-Line Guide To Music Offered By MTV and Yahoo
abstract: MTV Networks and Yahoo Inc introduce World Wide Web music guide, Unfurled; site will offer comprehensive directory linking users to music-related Web sites and have daily music news, event listings and industry gossip (S)

headline: A New Bloom in a Garden of Advice
abstract: Crowded field of personal finance magazines noted, along with some recommendations in current articles; cover photos (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Du Pont in $3 Billion Deal For Imperial Chemical Units  Du Pont agreed to buy industrial chemical businesses from Imperial Chemical of Britain for $3 billion, in a deal that will strengthen Du Pont's position as a leading manufacturer of the basic building blocks for paint as well as for polyester clothes and plastic bottles.

headline: Morgan Stanley Wins in Bias Case
abstract: Morgan Stanley Group Inc wins dismissal of discrimination charges in lawsuit filed by black workers Yolanda Owens and Edward Hutton who contended that racist jokes circulated on company's E-mail created hostile workplace; Federal District Court Judge Denise Cote rules that dissemination of single electronic message containing racist jokes is not enough to constitute racist workplace at the firm (S)

headline: Second Thoughts on Free Trade
abstract: Kenneth Lewis article on his shift away from ardent support of free trade; cites efforts of trading partners to manage trade to maintain certain industrial independence (M)

headline: TBWA Chiat/Day Gets Apple Account
abstract: Apple Computer Inc names TBWA Chiat/Day to handle its domestic account, with billings estimated at $60 million to $80 million (S)

headline: British Troops Detain Four Men in Blasts at Base in Bosnia
abstract: British soldiers detain four men they suspect of having set off three small explosive charges at British base in Banja Luka, Bosnia; there are no injuries and charges appear to have done no damage at base; map (M)

headline: IRON MOUNTAIN PLANS TO BUY 2 COMPANIES FOR $60 MILLION
abstract: Iron Mountain Inc, business records storage concern, agrees to buy Records Retention/File Safe and Data Securities International Inc for $60 million; Iron Mountain will pay $42 million in cash and assumption of liabilities valued at $3 million for Records Retention; it will buy Data Securities for $18 million in stock and assumption of debt (S)

headline: People
abstract: * Gary I. Singer was named to the new position of managing director and chief operating officer at D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles, St. Louis, a unit of MacManus Group. He will work with Charles E. Claggett Jr., who continues as managing director and chief creative officer. Mr. Singer had been at the Leo Burnett Co., Chicago, as senior vice president and worldwide head of the account of the Kraft Foods unit of the Philip Morris Cos.

headline: World News Briefs; Official Who Took Bribes May Quit Japan Cabinet
abstract: Koko Sato, Japanese politician once convicted in bribery scandal but recently appointed to Cabinet, suggests he will resign, defusing political crisis for Prime Min Ryutaro Hashimoto (S)

headline: A BLUNT ALBRIGHT CHALLENGES ISRAEL AND PALESTINIANS
abstract: State Sec Madeleine K Albright acknowledges that she made little progress in restarting peace talks between Israel and Palestinians and says she has no intention of returning to Mideast unless leaders on both sides make 'the hard decisions' required to restore mutual confidence; is disappointed that she could only announce a new set of talks about talks; senior advisers to Prime Min Benjamin Netanyahu and to Yasir Arafat are to go to Washington week of Sept 21, and about a week later Albright is to host meeting at United Nations between Foreign Min David Levy and Arafat's No. 2, Mahmoud Abbas; photo (M)

headline: New Cliffhanger at Marvel In Battle Over Its Debts
abstract: Marvel Entertainment Group Inc's efforts to emerge from bankruptcy have so far been unsuccessful, in large part because players are unable to fashion a deal that everyone can live with; Marvel says it has failed to reach deal with creditors; with company's latest financing package set to expire next week, that has raised questions about how it will pay its bills (M)

headline: F.B.I. CONDUCTS RAID ON J.B. OXFORD SECURITIES FIRM
abstract: FBI raids headquarters of J B Oxford Holdings Inc securities firm in Beverly Hills, Calif; agents decline to say why they raided Oxford (S)

headline: Big Board Reports a Drop In Uncovered Short Sales
abstract: New York Stock Exchange reports open positions on short sales fell to 3.35 billion shares in month ended Sept 10, down 0.5 percent; American Stock Exchange reports short interest rose to record 182.28 million shares in period, up 3.3 percent; tables (S)2

headline: 3 Big Utilities Join to Supply Large Users Nationwide
abstract: Cinergy Corp, New Century Energies and Florida Progress Corp, three big utilities, are forming alliance to sell electricity, natural gas and energy management services to large national chain stores, restaurants and hotels; instead of going merger route, three utilities will set up jointly owned marketing company called Cadence, which will be based in Cincinnati; industry trade groups have estimated that Cadence's potential customers may buy about $60 billion of energy a year (M)

headline: ECOLAB GETS 14.9% OF GIBSON CHEMICAL OF AUSTRALIA
abstract: Ecolab Inc buys 14.9 percent stake in Gibson Chemical Industries Ltd of Australia for about $18.7 million and says it is considering buying more (S)9

headline: Veliko Trgovisce Journal; Boyhoods Enshrined: Keeping Up With Tito
abstract: Croatian village of Veliko Trgovisce is renovating birthplace of Pres Franjo Tudjman, in hopes of cashing in on his prominence; photo; map; project reminds some townspeople of Tito's home in another village, which became museum but fell into neglect after death of longtime Communist leader; Tudjman's office says president is embarrassed by fuss (Veliko Trgovisce Journal) (S)

headline: S.G.B. Sells Stake In Union Miniere
abstract: Societe Generale de Belgique SA sells 24 percent stake in Union Miniere SA to group of banks for $560 million in cash (S)

headline: JOHNSON & JOHNSON TO BUY GYNECARE FOR $79 MILLION
abstract: Johnson & Johnson to buy Gynecare Inc for stock valued at about $79 million (S)

headline: Supermarkets Get a Brand New Bag
abstract: Fierce competition among supermarket chains in Atlanta and other cities across US discussed; profit margins are so slim that big stores have taken to installing other services, from dry cleaning to gyms, to lure customers; photos; graphs; push to create larger regional chains is reshaping competition, although Northeast, particularly New York area, lags because of scarce vacant land, high real estate and labors costs and zoning barriers (L)

headline: Credit Lyonnais to Sell Stake in Italian Bank
abstract: Credit Lyonnais to sell its 56.8 percent stake in Credito Bergamasco to Banca Popolare di Verona for 1.24 trillion lire ($694 million); under Italian law, Banca Popolare will now have to offer to buy remaining Credito Bergamasco shares (S)

headline: Motorola Wins Phone Contract in India
abstract: Motorola Inc wins $50 million order from Bharti Telenet Ltd, an Indian telecommunications company, to provide some of equipment to build phone network in India (S)

headline: Gone, Again
abstract: Readers are invited to submit anecdotes on co-workers who frequently disappear for much of work day7

headline: People
abstract: * Liz Dolan, vice president and marketing director at Nike Inc., Beaverton, Ore., is leaving to form her own sports and marketing company, working on projects for Nike and others. Ms. Dolan was scheduled to return next week from a three-month sabbatical; many of her duties had been assumed by other Nike executives.

headline: Renault Has Sales Rise Of 9.5% in Quarter
abstract: Renault SA says sales increased 9.5 percent in second quarter; sales rose to 52.84 billion francs ($8.41 billion) in quarter, from 48.27 billion francs in year-earlier quarter (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: I.R.S. Official Apologizes For Agency Mistreatment  The acting commissioner of the Internal Revenue Service issued an extraordinary public apology to all Americans for the mistreatment some of them have endured from agency officials.

headline: Bunzl of Britain To Buy Filtrona
abstract: Bunzl PLC to buy American Filtrona Corp for $178 million (S)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: List of rates on key Government bonds

headline: U.S. Finds Hard Feelings in an Allied Gulf Sheikdom
abstract: Western diplomats say ties between United States and United Arab Emirates have frayed, mostly due to running dispute over who should have legal jurisdiction over American military personnel serving, or on leave in emirates; issue is so sensitive that diplomats think it might deprive American military contractors of large contracts from area, including $6 billion military aircraft package; American officials argue that right of US to maintain jurisdiction over its military personnel was part of Defense Cooperation Agreement between US and emirates that was reached in 1994; officials of emirates have been demanding that issue be reopened since 1995, when rape of schoolgirl by American servicemen in Okinawa received wide attention; only 300 US servicemen are stationed in emirates, but tens of thousands of them are granted shore leave there each year; photo; map (M)

headline: Debt
abstract: * City of Austin, Tex., is selling $226.9 million of tax-exempt combined utility systems revenue refunding bonds through Smith Barney. The bonds are priced to yield a maximum of 5.43 percent for an issue due in 2020. For short-maturity serial bonds, the yield ranges from 4.10 percent in 1999 to 5.40 percent in 2017. The bonds are rated triple-A by Moody's Investors Service and Standard & Poor's.    * New York City Municipal Water Finance Authority is selling $288.7 million of tax-exempt water and sewer system revenue bonds through Paine Webber. The bonds are priced to yield a maximum of 5.35 percent for an issue due in 2022 and 5.42 percent for an issue due in 2017. For short-maturity serial bonds, the yield range from 4.85 percent in 2008 to 5.375 percent in 2015. The bonds are rated A2 by Moody's and A- by S.& P.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: Sparetech Corp will acquire Preferred Plastic Sheet unit of Echlin Inc for undisclosed sum (S)

headline: INVESTMENT FIRM TO BUY CONTROL DATA FOR $288 MILLION
abstract: Control Data Systems Inc agrees to be acquired by investment firm Welsh, Carson, Anderson & Stowe for $288 million in cash (S)

headline: PEPSICO GAINS $830 MILLION IN SALE OF FOOD SYSTEMS UNIT
abstract: Pepsico Inc says it received about $830 million from sale of its Pepsico Food Systems restaurant-supply unit to Ameriserve Food Distribution Inc (S)

headline: Ted Turner's Really Big Pledge Problem
abstract: Ted Turner seeks strategy to give United Nations agencies up to $1 billion over 10 years while retaining for as long as possible his 10 percent stake in Time Warner (M)

headline: Finding Opportunity Where Disorder Recently Ruled
abstract: Interview with J Mark Mobius, manager of eight Franklin/Templeton emerging-market funds; photo; graphs (M)

abstract: In percent                Previous   Year          Yesterday   Day   Ago               PRIME RATE   8.50   8.50   8.25        DISCOUNT RATE   5.00   5.00   5.00        FEDERAL FUNDS*   5.44   5.51   5.28        3-MO. headline: Bozell, Jacobs Buys Niche Agencies
abstract: Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt has acquired Charles Barker PLC, leading European public relations agency; Bozell, Jacobs also acquired Skunkworks Marketing Lab and Hammond & Thackeray in Sydney, Australia (S)

headline: Workers in Germany Fear the Miracle Is Over
abstract: German workers fear competitive global economy poses threat to nation's economic miracle, which produced ever-shrinking work hours and ever-expanding income; suspect that employers demanding longer working hours at less convivial times will win battles with unions seeking more leisure time; employers argue that people will have to work longer and reduce leisure time if Germany is to revive the competitiveness on which its export-driven economy depends; graph (M)

headline: Leap Partnership To Handle Michelob
abstract: Anheuser-Busch Companies names Leap Partnership to handle advertising for its Michelob beer brands, which had been handled by Glennon Co (S)

headline: IMPERIAL OIL TO SELL 3 CANADIAN FIELDS
abstract: Imperial Oil Ltd says it will sell three of largest and prolific oilfields in Canada to Pengrowth Gas Corp for $595 million ($426.9 million American) (S)

headline: 2 Banks Sell Stake In Big German Retailer
abstract: Deutsche Bank AG and Commerzbank AG sell their 20.3 percent stake in Karstadt AG, Germany's second-largest retailer, to Schickedanz Holding Stiftung, a German mail-order retailer; sale price undisclosed (S)

headline: Apple Getting Reactions On the Web
abstract: Article discusses Web sites dedicated to news about Apple Computer Inc; reaction to resignation last week of chief executive Gilbert Amelio discussed (M)

headline: Liquor Advertiser In Magazine Pact
abstract: Notorious, magazine planning to publish its first issue in October, signs unusual agreement with International Distillers and Vintners North America for that company to become its exclusive liquor advertiser (S)

headline: Can Museums Put Art On Virtual Walls?
abstract: Museums are in quandary as they assess opportunities and threats presented by Internet; at issue is whether they should publish images of art in cyberspace; there is uncertainty about legality of posting images that often do not belong to them, even though artworks themselves do, and there is fear that Web's raw power as copying machine will hurt quality of art and commercial rights of artists and their heirs; it is unclear to museum directors how to balance their twin missions of making art available to public and protecting value and integrity of art; photo (M)

headline: P.& G. Will Acquire Concern in Mexico
abstract: Procter & Gamble Co agrees to buy tissue-products unit from Mexican holding company, Grupo Carso, for $170 million (S)

headline: DEADLY EPIDEMIC EMERGES IN SUDAN
abstract: Dr Michaleen Richer and aid workers from CARE International are trying to determine extent of outbreak of sleeping sickness that is spreading through villages in southwestern part of Sudan along border of Central African Republic; preliminary results are frightening; as civil war in Sudan grinds into its 15th year, sleeping sickness, parasitic malady that is fatal but curable, is once again raging through Western Equatorial province, infecting at least one in five people in Tambura County; doctors say outbreak is among worst documented this century; map; photo (M)

headline: A Durable Operation On Too Solid Ground
abstract: Barnett Bank, which is being acquired by Nationsbank, has biggest share of Florida's market, with 660 branches across state and assets of $42 billion (S)

headline: Patent Fights Aplenty for M.R.I. Pioneer
abstract: Dr Raymond V Damadian, who holds basic patents for magnetic resonance imaging, wins patent infringement cases against all major manufacturers, including $128.7 million judgment against General Electric; comments on plans to expand his Fonar Corp and on legal victories as vindication of patent system; graphs; photos (M)

headline: AAMES FINANCIAL IS SAID TO BE CONSIDERING SALE
abstract: Aames Financial Corp is reportedly considering putting itself up for sale (S)4

headline: Turkish Ex-Premier's Comeback Hits a Snag
abstract: Former Foreign Min Tansu Ciller faces possibility that Turkish Parliament may lift her immunity from prosecution and send corruption charges against her to Supreme Court for investigation (M)

headline: Japan Says Trade Surplus Is Up Sharply
abstract: Japan's Finance Ministry says merchandise trade surplus rose seasonally adjusted 51.1 percent in August from July, to 1.099 trillion yen ($9.12 billion); from August 1996, surplus grew 113.6 percent, to 742.06 billion yen; exports rose 3.3 percent from previous month; imports declined 6.7 percent (S)

headline: Treasury Sales Set for This Week
abstract: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week is confined to today's regular weekly auction of three-  and six-month bills.    By the close of the New York cash market on Friday, traders said, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 5.08 percent, and a six-month bill was 5.13 percent.

headline: POST PROPERTIES-COLUMBUS IN $600 MILLION DEAL
abstract: Post Properties Inc to acquire Columbus Realty Trust for about $600 million, including debt (S)

headline: Apple's executive MacMath: The greater the loss, the greater the salary.
abstract: Technology Column discusses how many disgruntled employees of Apple Computer Inc are lamenting style of leadership practiced by company's board and three different chief executives in less than four years that has allowed its revolving door management leave with increasingly large sums of cash even as company's losses mount and its share price falters (M)

headline: Accounts
abstract: Sargento Foods Inc., Plymouth, Wis., to DDB Needham Chicago, a unit of Omnicom Group, to handle the account of the maker of snacks, which had been handled by Laughlin/Constable Inc., Milwaukee. Billings were estimated at $5 million.

headline: MAIDENFORM AND NCC INDUSTRIES FILE FOR BANKRUPTCY
abstract: Maidenform Worldwide Inc and NCC Industries are filing for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection as companies restructure their operations (S)

headline: Asian Central Banks Seek Ways to Block Speculators
abstract: Asian central bankers, reeling from speculative attacks in foreign-exchange market, agree to study ways to increase value of their countries' currencies but stop short of promising to intervene in market to support currencies (S)

headline: Platinum Price Soars as Strike Hits Refinery in South Africa
abstract: Platinum futures prices soar in response to strike at Gencor Ltd's Impala refinery in South Africa; platinum for Oct delivery rises $16.70, to $455.20 an ounce (S)

headline: Jittery on Thailand, Asia Currencies Dip
abstract: South Asian currencies are lower, on concern that amid problems at Thai banks they might become targets of new speculative attack (S)

headline: Siebel Marketing Acquired by Grey
abstract: Grey Advertising acquires Siebel Marketing Group; terms not disclosed; Siebel will operate as independent unit (S)

headline: Dispute Over Emmy Flares Up Again
abstract: National Academy of Television Arts and Sciences in New York, which fought decision by Academy of Television Arts and Sciences in California to introduce Emmy Award for television commercials, seeks new arbitration of jurisdictional dispute; holds winning advertisement, for HBO television network, first appeared during daytime broadcast and was outside prime-time jurisdiction of California academy (S)

headline: British Telecom's Chairman Makes Fateful Trans-Atlantic Pledge to MCI
abstract: Tortuous merger negotiations between MCI Communications and British Telecommunications were moved forward when British Telecom's chairman, Sr Iain Vallance, promised to resign if his shareholders did not ratify deal; his pledge is said to have given MCI's board confidence to accept revised deal, in which MCI agreed to accept 22 percent reduction in value of deal; prolonged dispute over terms laid bare stark differences between two companies and two sets of shareholders; photos; chronology of events since merger plans were announced on Nov 3, 1996 (L)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: UNITED GRAIN GROWERS LTD., Winnipeg, Manitoba, sold 4.8 million shares of common stock to Archer-Daniels-Midland Co., of Decatur, Ill., for $55.4 million. Archer now has a 45 percent stake in United Grain.    WEYERHAEUSER CO., Tacoma, Wash., the forest products giant, agreed to buy a box plant from Union Camp Corp., Wayne, N.J., for an undisclosed price.

headline: Slave Trade In Africa Highlighted By Arrests
abstract: Three recent arrests of traders transporting large groups of children in Benin and Nigeria calls attention to what authorities say is growing slave trade in children in region; child welfare groups believe well-organized criminal rings are involved; map (M)

headline: Targeted Advertising On Times Web Site
abstract: New York Times Electronic Media Co to introduce new marketing technology to its World Wide Web site aimed at helping on-line advertisers reach specific audiences (S)

headline: A study indicates there may be more to travel illness than jet lag and infectious diseases.
abstract: Recently published study of World Bank employees strongly suggests that travel to foreign lands on business may be hazardous to one's health; study finds that business travelers file medical claims at greater rate than stay-at-homes; Ministry of Tourism of the Bahamas is sponsoring a Weather Conference for July 17-20 in Nassau with intention of bringing more candor to issue of impact of hurricanes on the Bahama Islands; Zagat will publish its biennial survey of US hotels, resorts and spas; winner of best hotel is Mansion on Turtle Creek in Dallas, Tex; British Airways will operate eight nonstop flights to Britain from Kennedy International Airport; but because of three-day strike scheduled to start at 1 AM on July 9, it has canceled four flights--two from Kennedy to London's Heathrow, one from Kennedy to Gatwick and one from Newark to Heathrow (L)

headline: In India, an Ancient Christian Tradition
abstract: Mother Teresa's death has thrown spotlight on India's Christian minority, which has played long and significant role in country's spiritual and intellectual history (M)

headline: The Roller Coaster Known as Micro Cap
abstract: Recent gains for micro-cap funds, which invest in companies with market capitalizations of less than $250 million, reviewed; table; such funds are particularly risky because of speculative nature of many of small companies in which they invest, and are considered poor choice for investors unable to wait at least five years for returns (S)

headline: U.S. Bond Prices Drop, but Brighter Days Are Expected
abstract: US bond prices drop; price of 30-year bond falls 21/32, to 98; its yield rises to 6.78 percent from 6.74 percent on June 27 (L)

headline: Sex and the Afghan Woman: Islam's Straitjacket
abstract: Interview with Alhaj Maulavi Qalamuddin, Muslim cleric who heads Taliban movement's religious police in Afghanistan; he sees police role as insuring conformity with Sharia, ancient Islamic social and penal code; this includes enforcement of dress codes for women, and floggings for women who allow faces or ankles to show beneath head-to-toe shrouds; Qalamuddin confirms that women are at risk of flogging if anything about their feet or legs, including way they walk, arouses suspicion among his men; many Afghans complain that Taliban militants are making up taboos as they go along; Qalammuddin claims Taliban has brought measure of 'peace and security' to country, and brought great honor and dignity to Afghan women, who are banned from working, denied education and restricted to domestic seclusion; photo (M)

headline: Mideast Alarm Button
abstract: Analysis of confrontational stances adopted by Israel and Palestinians, more than three weeks after suicide bombing shattered Jerusalem market; Israeli Prime Min Benjamin Netanyahu had American backing when he argued that Yasir Arafat should begin to combat terrorism in earnest, for Palestinians' and Israelis' sakes; but public way in which Israel pressed its demands, and its imposition of economic sanctions against Palestinians, led Arafat to conclude that any victory for Israel would be loss for him; Arafat appears to have calculated that he cannot comply with Israeli demands without undermining his own standing, which is shaky; so he is seeking to build support among broad spectrum of Palestinians, including public embrace of Hamas leader that was guaranteed to infurate most Israelis; photo (M)

headline: Chip Production To Slow in Korea
abstract: South Korean semiconductor manufacturers Samsung Electronics, LG Semicon Co and Hyundai Electronics will cut production of mainstay computer chips by one-third in next few weeks in effort to bolster prices (S)

headline: Tenet Healthcare Tries to Settle Some Old Accounts
abstract: As managed care companies move into area of mental health, many psychiatrists fear patients are being overlooked by organizations eager to scrimp on insurance costs; doctors say seriously ill patients are often discharged from mental health units after just few days, trapping them in cycle of hospitalization, relapse and hospitalization; managed care companies defend practice as reigning in undisciplined and wasteful spending on mental health care, where it is often hard to measure extent of patient's progress; payment by Tenet Healthcare Corp, which changed its named from Medical Enterprises, of $100 million to settle 700 claims of mistreatment by former psychiatric patients in Texas discussed; mental health care professionals say company came to symbolize excesses of era when corporate thirst for insurance dollars overrode patients' needs; photos (M)

headline: Accounts
abstract: * Omnipoint Communications Services, Cedar Knolls, N.J., to Hill, Holliday/Altschiller, New York, part of Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos, to handle its account, which had been handled by Grace & Rothschild, New York, until that agency resigned in late April. Billings were estimated at $6 million to $10 million.

headline: U.S. to Let 1,000 Sail From Miami to Cuba for Pope's Visit
abstract: Clinton Administration will allow Archdiocese of Miami to sail a cruise ship to Cuba with more than 1,000 American Catholics during Pope John Paul II's visit in January; other Catholic groups, including archdioceses of Newark and New York, are expected to win similar exemptions (M)

headline: The challenge of selling a Korean-language musical to America with a $150,000 ad budget.
abstract: Producers of South Korean musical The Last Empress, to be performed at Lincoln Center in Aug, are mounting complex, highly focused, extremely thrifty advertising campaign on relatively small budget; seek to attract East Coast's large and rapidly growing Korean population to show, performed in Korean with projected English subtitles; photo (M)

headline: HarperCollins Selling Basic Books Unit to Venture Capital Firm
abstract: HarperCollins announces sale of its Basic Books division to Perseus Capital, a venture capital firm that is rapidly establishing foothold in publishing industry with new companies emphasizing quality fiction and non-fiction; financial terms undisclosed (M)

headline: For a Projector Maker, Multiplexes Are a Ticket to Growth
abstract: Movie theater boom across US is good news for companies that make projection booths for multiplexes; graph showing rise in stock of Ballantyne of Omaha Inc (S)

headline: One Income. One Purpose. Yes, a Family Can Stay Afloat.
abstract: Cynthia Tavlin article on living frugally on single salary to allow family to have stay-at-home parent (M)+

headline: I.R.A. Offers Support (of a Sort) for Nonviolence
abstract: IRA says it approves of pledge by its political wing, Sinn Fein, to adhere to principles of nonviolence during formal peace talks; rare statement also says IRA 'would have problems' with some of pledges to which Sinn Fein subscribed at preliminary talks (S)

headline: A Fatal Quake Shatters Fresco In Assisi Shrine
abstract: Two earthquakes hit central Italy, killing at least 10 people and sending parts of vaulted inner roof of Basilica of St Francis of Assisi crashinging to ground, damaging 13th-century frescoes on its walls and ceiling; two Franciscan friars and two surveyors from Culture Ministry are killed by second quake as they inspect damage from the first; damage is also reported in Rufino, Foligno and Orvieto; photo; map (M)

headline: In a Reversal, Apple Decides It Will Keep Its Newton Unit
abstract: Apple Computer Inc decides not to spin off its Newton division and will instead develop general purpose version of company's Emate portable, which is now sold only to schools; Apple had been planning to spin off Newton division and sell Emate 300 under licensing agreement with newly independent Newton; that idea was reportedly rejected by Steven P Jobs, Apple's co-founder, who has taken over as unofficial chief executive; Jobs also reportedly rejected plan to build hand-held computers, which were part of vision of Apple's former chief executive, John Sculley(M)

headline: A Microsoft Browser Tied Tighter to Windows 95
abstract: Microsoft Corp on July 15 will introduce test version of its Internet software that is more closely linked to company's Windows 95 operating system (M)

headline: Petroleum Chief Resigns At Broken Hill
abstract: Broken Hill Proprietary Co says that chief exec of its its petroleum unit, John O'Connor, resigned after board of directors blocked his attempt to split off division (S)

headline: State Agencies Turn Data Base Records Into Cash Cows
abstract: News organizations are beginning to find that even as millions of public records are becoming available in data bases for increasingly sophisticated searches and analyses, many state and local governments see a new source of revenue, and are imposing stiff access fees for information that, in paper form, has traditionally been free; photo (M)

headline: Tel Aviv Journal; 'Out of Lebanon!': Mothers' Cry Rouses Israelis
abstract: Support for withdrawal of forces from southern Lebanon increases among Israelis as casualties there rise; battles in occupied zone with Hezbollah guerrillas have taken increasing death toll on army in recent months, sometimes setting off rocket attacks on northern Israeli communities; total of 34 Israeli soldiers have been killed in Lebanon since start of 1997, and 20 Israelis have died in suicide bomb attacks in recent weeks in Jerusalem; losses have left many Israelis grieving and confused about what path Government should take to stop bloodshed; photo (M)

headline: 98 Die in One of Algerian Civil War's Worst Massacres
abstract: Hooded attackers slay at least 98 residents of Rais, highest death toll in Algeria's civil war; authorities blame Islamic guerrillas; photo (M)

headline: Rejection Guaranteed
abstract: Readers are invited to submit anecdotes about job applicants who behave badly at job interviews; drawing8

headline: Nobody Beats the Wiz Set to Close 5 Stores
abstract: Consumer electronics retailer Nobody Beats the Wiz will close five stores in Connecticut and Massachusetts and will concentrate on its remaining 58 stores in New York area and upstate; fewer than 300 full-time and part-time jobs, or about 7 percent of company's work force, will be eliminated (S)

headline: SUIZA FOODS TO ACQUIRE COUNTRY FRESH FOR $135 MILLION
abstract: Suiza Foods Corp to buy Country Fresh Inc for stock worth about $97 million and assumption of some $38 million in debt and preferred stock (S)

headline: Some Changes At WPP Group
abstract: WPP Group agrees to purchase Cockpick Holdings Ltd in London and Cockpit's wholly owned financial public relations services subsidiary, Buchanan Communications Ltd, for estimated $24.1 million; two worldwide WPP advertising agencies--Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide and J Walter Thompson Co--have begun merging media services operations to form unit named Mind Share, which will handle media accounts with billings estimated at more than $14 billion; Dominic Procter becomes chief operating officer of Mind Share (S)

headline: Death-Row Rule Sours Caribbean on Britain
abstract: Popular support for capital punishment among Caribbean populations frightened by rising crime fuels move in Barbados to discard Queen Elizabeth II as head of state; at issue is 1993 ruling by her Privy Council, British high court retained as supreme tribunal after independence by most former British colonies in region, that death-row inmates not executed within five years should have sentences commuted; number of death-row prisoners and number of sentences commuted has been rising since ruling, leading some nations to speed up appeals procedures; map (M)

headline: Bertelsmann Mum on Compuserve Rumor
abstract: Bertelsmann AG declines to comment on report that it is joining with American Online Inc to acquire Compuserve Inc, its nearest rival in on-line computer services (S)

headline: Clinton Makes Also-Ran Feel Like Winner
abstract: Pres Clinton visits Romania to console a nation he blocked from joining NATO in its first round of expansion; Clinton is given boisterous welcome by tens of thousands in Bucharest as first US President to visit a free Romania; photo (M)

headline: Rand McNally To Sell Control
abstract: Rand McNally, world's largest commercial map maker, agrees to sell controlling interest to AEA Investors for undisclosed amount (S)

headline: No Pact in 'Open Skies' Talks With South Korea
abstract: South Korea and US end two days of talks of aviation discussions without reaching 'open skies' agreement that would end Government restrictions on air links (S)

headline: 'Fodder Scam' Could Bring Down a Shaky Indian Government
abstract: Indian Prime Min I K Gujral is struggling to hold his ruling coalition together in face of corruption scandal that could send one of his most powerful political allies, Laloo Prasad Yadav, to jail (M)

headline: U.S. SURGICAL ACQUIRES PROGRESSIVE ANGIOPLASTY
abstract: US Surgical Corp acquires Progressive Angioplasty Systems Inc for $78 million in stock (S)

headline: Harry A. McQuillen, 51, Executive in Charge of 63 Magazines
abstract: Harry A McQuillen, chief operating officer of K-III Communications Corp, dies at age 51 of self-inflicted gunshot wound; photo (M)

headline: ASEAN Opts For Continued Mediation In Cambodia
abstract: SINGAPORE  The Association of South East Asian Nations decided Monday to continue its efforts to mediate an end to Cambodia's political conflict, saying it was ready to arrange talks between the warring parties to help restore stability.

headline: Owning a Fraction of a Jet
abstract: Market for partial ownership of small jets has taken off, helped by strong economy, increased competition and growing interest among wealthy individuals; Net Jets, fractional-ownership program started in 1986 by Richard Santulli, chairman of Executive Jet, discussed; photo (L)0

headline: Death Plot Reported Against a High-Ranking Russian Official
abstract: Russian officials report unearthing plot to assassinate Anatoly B Chubais, main architect of Russia's economic reforms and one of country's most senior officials; security precautions are strengthened (M)

headline: Tandem Chief Gets A Post at Compaq
abstract: Compaq Computer Corp names Roel Pieper, former Tandem Computers Inc chief executive, senior vice president and general manager of global sales and marketing (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Economic Reports Strong, But Market Effect Is Muted  The index of leading economic indicators rose at the fastest rate in five months during July, and construction spending advanced.    But inflation-wary investors, who had already seen evidence of strength in other data, did not seem overly troubled. $(Page D8.$)

headline: INSIDE
abstract: List of major stories in Business section

headline: BROWNING-FERRIS APPROVES $1 BILLION STOCK BUYBACK
abstract: Browning-Ferris Industries says its board approved $1 billion stock buyback and raised quarterly cash dividend by 12 percent (S)

headline: Stocks Lower in Japan
abstract: Nikkei index of 225 Japanese stock issues is down 134.21 points at midday, falling to 19,670.17 (Mon, 8/4) (S)

headline: WHX AGREES TO SUPPORT MERGER OF CTS AND DYNAMICS
abstract: WHX Corp agrees to support merger of CTS Corp and Dynamics Corp of America after CTS amends its offer; CTS's offer would give Dynamics's shareholders option of receiving either 0.889 CTS share of $58 cash for each Dynamics share held; WHX owns 13.5 percent interest in Dynamics (S)

headline: Lucent Introduces Strategy To Aid Data Networking
abstract: Lucent Technologies Inc announces long-awaited data networking strategy; says it intends to focus on supplying equipment to telecommunications carriers and big organizations, rather than trying to compete in retail markets; Lucent has spent last few months negotiating deal to acquire ODS Networks Inc (M)

headline: People
abstract: * Julie Rieger was named to the new post of media director at Sicola Martin, Austin, Tex. She had been a media account director at the technology group of Foote, Cone & Belding, San Francisco, a unit of True North Communications.    * Lois Geller was named president at Mason & Geller, New York, a direct marketing agency formed in partnership with Mason & Madison Advertising and Public Relations, New Haven. Ms. Geller had headed the Lois Geller Co., New York.

headline: CSX and Others Ordered to Pay Billions in '87 Rail Chemical Fire
abstract: CSX Transportation says jury has ordered it to pay $2.5 billion in punitive damages stemming from railroad-car chemical fire in New Orleans, La, on Sept 9, 1987; CSX says it will appeal; case detailed (L)

headline: Israel Hits Power Lines to Warn Lebanon
abstract: Israeli warplanes strike back at targets in southern Lebanon, including power lines feeding Sidon, region's largest city; Israeli military statement says raids are meant to warn Lebanese officials to do more to rein in Shiite Muslim militants who lobbed dozens of rockets into northern Israel on Aug 19; map (M)

headline: Euro RSCG Forms Unified Italy Group
abstract: Euro RSCG Worldwide reorganizes its operations in Italy by forming a group, Euro RSCG Italia, that will oversee agencies specializing in services like advertising, media buying, health care marketing and new media (S)

headline: Spanish Police Free 2 Kidnapped by the Basques
abstract: Spanish police rescue prison guard Jose Antonio Ortega Lara from Basque rebels who kidnapped him 17 months ago; police say Cosme Delclaux, businessman who was abducted seven months ago, has also been freed (M)

headline: Retail Customers To Get Intel's New Chips First
abstract: Intel Corp will offer its newest generation of microprocessor chips to retail customers instead of to corporations; new chip, latest in Pentium line, contains smallest transistors Intel has ever made for commercial sale (L)

headline: STARWOOD LODGING BUYS CROWNE PLAZA IN NEW ORLEANS
abstract: Starwood Lodging Trust acquires Crowne Plaza Hotel in New Orleans, La, for $58.5 million from joint venture run by affiliates of Holiday Inns Inc, unit of Bass PLC, and Joseph C Canizaro Interests; Starwood sells three Best Western hotels--in El Paso, Las Cruces, NM, and Savannah, Ga--to Columbus Hotel Properties LLC, a Canizaro affiliate, for $12 million (S)

headline: MINDING YOUR BUSINESS ; Where to Go to Make Some Really Cold Cash
abstract: Laura Pedersen-Pietersen responds to Elliott Prag's letter on becoming a cook at South Pole; photo (L)

headline: U.S. Increasing Its Dependence On Oil Imports
abstract: American drivers are consuming record quantities of gasoline in 1997, with about half refined from imported oil, and dependence is also setting records as domestic production slowly declines; industry experts say prospect is for trend to continue robustly, at least as long as economy remains strong; imports, which account for about 50 percent of consumption, fill far more of Americans' petroleum needs than during beginning of first oil crisis in 1973, when they accounted for 36 percent of supply; US production is declining because it is easier to obtain oil from other countries than from dwindling reserves in US; graphs (M)

headline: MELLON SAID TO SEEK FOUNDERS ASSET MANAGEMENT
abstract: Mellon Bank Corp is rumored to be leading contender to buy Founders Asset Management Co for as much as $300 million (S)

headline: INMC MORTGAGE TO BECOME REAL ESTATE INVESTMENT TRUST
abstract: CWM Mortgage Holdings Inc agrees to acquire Countrywide Asset Management Corp for $80 million in CWM stock, or 3.4 million newly issued shares; under the agreement, CWM, which has changed its name to INMC Mortgage Holdings Inc, will become self-managed real estate investment trust; Countrywide Credit, unit of Countrywide Credit Industries, will become its largest shareholder, with 8 percent (S)

headline: EXIDE ELECTRONICS' BOARD REJECTS DANAHER BUYOUT OFFER
abstract: Board of Exide Electronics Group Inc rejects offer of $20 a share, or about $200 million, from Danaher Corp and considers alternative transaction with undisclosed third party (S)

headline: Executive Changes
abstract: Continental Express, subsidiary of Continental Airlines, names Fred Cromer vice president and chief financial officer (S)

headline: Interpublic Unit Adds Demographics Concern
abstract: International Poster Management, Interpublic Group of Companies unit, acquires majority stake in Business Geographics Ltd (S)

headline: US Airways Order Hinging On Pilot Talks
abstract: US Airways and its pilots negotiate feverishly in hope of reaching new contract in time for airline to meet deadline to confirm order for as many as 400 jets from Airbus Industrie; management says that without contract it will scrap order and cut back airline; officials of Air Line Pilots Assn say substantial progress was made in last few days, but that several key issues remain; two other unions, International Assn of Machinists and Assn of Flight Attendants, are also negotiating with US Airways; both are expected to quickly reach deal with airline once pilots' agreement is signed (M)

headline: Arafat Orders The Arrest Of Policemen
abstract: Yasir Arafat orders arrest and investigation of several Palestinian Authority police officers following Israeli accusations that they were involved in planning attack on Jewish settlers on West Bank; detentions come after Israeli arrests of three officers near Jewish settlement outside Nablus, who had guns and grenades and were allegedly preparing attack against Jewish motorists (M)

headline: For Japan's Women, More Jobs And Longer and Odder Hours
abstract: Restrictions on late-night and overtime work for women are being lifted in Japan as part of push for equal opportunity; but after years of complaining about their second-class status, some women now fear the price of equality will be schedules as arduous as those of Japan's notoriously overworked men; lifting of restrictions on women's working hours, which was approved by Parliament in June and will take effect in two years, could open more opportunities for women, not only in factories, but also in some white-collar jobs, where working until midnight is often required; graphs; photos (L)

headline: German Judge Dismisses Criminal Charge Over Internet Link
abstract: Local judge in Berlin, Germany, dismisses criminal charges against 25-year-old student Angela Marquardt who had provided electronic link on her Internet home page to leftist magazine Radikal that published articles such as one about how to derail trains; decision, first court ruling of its kind in Germany, is setback for attempts by German prosecutors to block what they consider dangerous material on the Internet (L)

headline: BERRY PLASTICS BUYS VENTURE PACKAGING FOR $50 MILLION
abstract: Berry Plastics Corp acquires Venture Packaging for $50 million in cash or assumption of of indebtedness and $5 million of preferred stock (S)

headline: Israelis Turn Military Skills Into Software Export Boom
abstract: Computer software industry is booming in Israel, fueled by skills of army-trained computer engineers; veterans bring combination of discipline, obsession and anarchic inventiveness to business that thrives in that kind of environment; software is Israel's fastest growing export industry, engine of expanding high-technology sector; photos; graph (M)

headline: Autobiography of Disney Chief Is Delayed
abstract: Random House has taken unusual step of announcing postponement of Walt Disney Co chairman Michael Eisner's autobiography, which had been scheduled for release this fall; there has been speculation that decision was prompted by bitter battle between Eisner and Jeffrey Katzenberg, former president of Walt Disney Productions; Katzenberg has sued company, contending that he is entitled to percentage of profits from string of movie hits released during his decadelong tenure at Disney; lawyers for Katzenberg last month sought to obtain transcripts and other materials for planned book; judge has granted request and is drafting order that will determine what is required to be produced from those documents (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: WEXFORD MANAGEMENT L.L.C., Greenwich, Conn., a unit of Wexford Capital, acquired a drilling rig for $110 million from Smedvig A.S.A., Stavanger, Norway, an integrated offshore drilling and oil services company.     SGL CARBON A.G., Wiesbaden, Germany, a unit of Hoechst A.G., acquired Hitco Technologies, a maker of carbon products for the aerospace industry, from Veritas Capital of New York. Terms were not disclosed.     TOWER AUTOMOTIVE INC., Minneapolis, said it would buy as much as 40 percent of Metalsa, Mexico's largest maker of automotive frames and structures, for an undisclosed amount.

headline: Digerati are unlikely celebrants of a primitivist conflagration in the Nevada desert.
abstract: Annual Burning Man festival will be held in Nevada's Black Rock Desert on Labor Day weekend; festival is paean to state of being that can be found in precincts of cyberspace, which libertarian celebrants hail for its invented identities in multi-user domains (MUD's) and chat rooms, its sexual license and lack of restrictions, its virtual communities and fantasy games; Larry Harvey, Burning Man impresario, claims Burning Man and Internet make it possible to regather tribe of mankind; photo (M)

headline: Trying to bring an air-conditioning system that kills microorganisms to a hospital near you.
abstract: Patents column; James Coellner and Henry Mark are granted patent for air conditioning system that kills microorganisms; Michael Marinangeli and Min Lim receive patent for intravenous needle that changes color once it has been used; Michael Robinson and Robert Greco receive patent for device that connects telephone to computer (M)

headline: Lawrence Chait, 80, Pioneer in Mail Order
abstract: Lawrence G Chait, pioneer in direct marketing industry, dies at age 80 (S)

headline: 2 Agencies to Share Diesel Jeans Account
abstract: Review for Diesel jeans worldwide account, which began with Diesel prepared to change agencies, has ended with account being divided between incumbent, Paradiset DDB in Stockholm, and finalist in review, Lowe Howard-Spink in London; billings estimated at $30 million (S)

headline: Brother Defends Tadic
abstract: Ljubo Tadic proclaims innocence of brother, Dusan Tadic, Bosnian Serb sentenced to 20-year prison term by UN war crimes tribunal in The Hague for ethnic cleansing campaign against Muslim civilians during Bosnian war in 1992 (S)

headline: ABC Campaign Said To Get Bad Reaction
abstract: TV Guide reports ABC proceeded with irreverent brand image campaign for television network despite overwhelmingly negative reaction to advertising among focus group of consumers; ABC aide Alan Cohen disputes report, holding research found generally positive reaction to ads (S)

headline: Saul Poliak, 92, a Trade Show Innovator
abstract: Saul Poliak, innovator in industry trade shows and a major donor to his alma mater, Columbia University, dies at 92; photo (S)

headline: People
abstract: Deborah Millman, senior vice president at Sterling Group, New York, was named to the new position of president of its Sterling Design division.    Colleen O'Kane was named to the new position of senior principal and media director at Publicis/Bloom, Dallas, a unit of Publicis S.A., succeeding Pat Dermody, who left to join DDB Needham Chicago, a unit of Omnicom Group, as media director. Ms. O'Kane had been president of O'Kane Media Group, Kansas City, Mo., which will close.

headline: Israel Identifies Four Suicide Bombers as West Bank Palestinians
abstract: Prime Min Benjamin Netanyahu reports Israel has identified four of five suicide bombers who struck in Jerusalem this summer; says they were West Bank Palestinians and had not come from abroad, as suggested by Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat, had escaped from Palestinian prison and were on list of 88 Palestinians Israel had asked Arafat to arrest; charges Palestinian Authority is not doing enough for Israel's security; all four were from Asira al-Shamaliya, town under Israeli control (M)

headline: Doctors in Mexican City Strike Over the Killings of 4 Colleagues
abstract: Thousands of physicians and nurses stage two-hour strike in Ciudad Juarez, Mexico, to protest slayings of four doctors whose bodies were dumped along road hours after they were called to treat wounded man, apparently drug trafficker; walkout underlines growing anger over Government's failure to solve proliferating criminal and drug violence (M)

headline: Trade Deficit Fell in June, but Not With Asians
abstract: Commerce Department reports US trade deficit narrowed markedly in June as exports rebounded to new record and imports subsided for first time this year; deficit declined to $8.2 billion from $9.54 billion in May; while deficit narrowed with Canada and Mexico, two of country's biggest trade partners, China and Japan increased significantly, prompting fresh expressions of displeasure by Clinton Administration; graph (L)

headline: CD Pioneers Decide to Form 2d Standard For Next Disks
abstract: Sony Corp, Philip Electronics NV and Hewlett-Packard Co have decided not to support industry's proposed technical standard for type of disk called DVD-RAM; such disks would be re-usable, allowing consumers to copy digital computer disks or record television programming digitally; current digital versatile disk systems and disks do not record, so industry battle has no immediate effect on consumers and will not delay rollout of nonrecording mass-market products like DVD's for video players or DVD-ROM's with computer software (L)

headline: High Alcohol Level Is Reported in Diana's Driver
abstract: French prosecutor reports body of driver in car crash that killed Priness Diana of Wales and companion Emad Mohammed el-Fayed had blood alcohol level well above legal driving limit; investigators say Henry Paul, who also died in crash on Paris expressway, had blood alcohol level of 1.75 grams per liter, or more than 0.1 percent legal limit in most states in US; police estimate car was traveling at 90 miles an hour at time of impact, or well above legal limit of 30 miles per hour; photographers chasing car at time of accident remain in police custody; face possible criminal charges for taking photographs of wreckage and victims immediately following crash, instead of providing aid as required under French law; investigators remain unable to question Trevor Rees-Jones, Princess Diana's surviving bodyguard, who remains in serious condition in intensive care; photos (M)

headline: New York May Drop Pension Manager
abstract: Spokesman for New York City Comptroller Alan G Hevesi says city has frozen funds managed by W R Lazard & Co for city employees and is seriously considering recommending the pension fund withdraw their money; says move results from problems that 'seem to be continuing' at the firm (S)

headline: In $5 Billion Deal, Grace Will Sell Packaging Business
abstract: W R Grace Co will divest itself of its packaging business in complex, two-step transaction that culminates strategy of focuing on company's other main business, specialty chemicals; deal essentially involves purchase of Grace's Cryovac packaging business by Seal Air Corp, in deal valued at $5 billion; Sealed Air says merger will increase its annual revenue to $2.5 billion from $800 million, making it the world leader in flexible packaging; Grace name will be retained by specialty chemicals, which will be spun off to shareholders and has $1.5 billion in revenue; current Grace shareholders will own 63 percent of new packaging company, while Sealed Air shareholders will own the other 37 percent; current Grace shareholders will continue to hold 100 percent of stand-alone specialty chemicals company; chart (L)

headline: Roche Delaying Its Obesity Drug
abstract: Roche Holdings AG will temporarily withdraw its application with Food and Drug Administration for weight loss drug Xenical (S)

headline: Ruling on Stock Trade Sought in Australia
abstract: Brierley Investments Ltd may be forced to sell some of its stake in John Fairfax Holdings Ltd if Australian regulatory panel upholds securities commission opinion that Brierley engaged in unacceptable conduct to buy the shares; securities commission applies to Corporations and Securities Panel for ruling on trading between Brierley and Merrill Lynch & Co's Australian futures arm (S)

headline: SUN COMMUNITIES IN $93 MILLION DEAL WITH PARK REALTY
abstract: Sun Communities Inc agrees to buy nine manufactured housing communities from partnerships managed by Park Realty Inc for about $93 million; properties are in Southwest, Indiana and Florida (S)

headline: Soybean and Corn Prices Slip On Rain Forecasts for Midwest
abstract: Soybean and corn futures drop on forecasts that rain will fall in Midwest this weekend, easing heat wave that has been threatening crops in the region (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: F.C.C. Moves to Cut Costs Of Phone Calls Overseas  The F.C.C. issued tough new rules to reduce the payments that American telephone companies make to foreign carriers to complete their calls.

headline: Suit vs. Caremark Settled by Coram
abstract: Coram Healthcare Corp settles two-year-old fraud and breach-of-contract lawsuit against Medpartners Inc's Caremark International Inc and Caremark Inc subsidiaries; Coram filed suit in state court in San Francisco against Caremark in 1995, seeking more than $200 million in damages relating to Coram's acquisition of Caremark's home-infusion business (S)

headline: Beyond Medicare: New Choices in Health Insurance
abstract: Article on new Federal budge law focuses on new health insurance options for older Americans; says new law creates parallel 'Medicare+Choice' program, with several alternatives; graph (L)

headline: Russians May Delay Repair of Spacecraft
abstract: Russian space officials said they would probably wait for a new crew to arrive at the damaged Mir space station before undertaking a space walk to repair it.    The crew has already endured a fire, a collision and an emergency power shortage, misfortunes that have been emotionally draining for the three men and for the ground controllers at the Russian space center near Moscow, and Russian space officials say Mir's crew may be too tired to conduct the complex mission.

headline: Small Claims, Big Price In Homeowner Insurance
abstract: Consumer groups report increasing number of homeowners are being dropped by insurance companies after filing even minor claims; companies, which point to huge losses from Hurricane Andrew in 1992, often refuse to renew policies after several claims have been made, based on studies showing that people who file repeat claims are more likely to do so in future (S)

headline: Photographers Invoke Their Right to Privacy
abstract: Several of six photographers and motorcyclist under suspicion of contributing to crash that killed Diana, Princess of Wales invoke France's strict privacy laws and refuse to be photographed or interviewed; those who speak to media choose own interviewers and insist they did not cause crash; many of their colleagues refuse to take pictures of Paris court scene to protest what they see as unfair attempt to blame photographers for crash; photographer Romuald Rat says he did not arrive at scene until after crash, television interview; photo (M)

headline: BELGIAN BANK TO ACQUIRE HARBOR CAPITAL MANAGEMENT
abstract: Generale de Banque SA, Belgium's largest bank, will buy Harbor Capital Management Co, a Boston asset management firm, for about $94 million (S)

headline: Time Warner to Remain In Venture With U S West
abstract: Time Warner Inc, after months of hagglng with US West Media Group Inc, says that companies have ended their talks to disband their cable television and entertainment venture; Time Warner says net income in second quarter was $30 million, compared with net loss of $40 million in same 1996 quarter; revenues rose 49 percent, to $3.19 billion, from $2.14 billion; table (L)

headline: NBTY TO PURCHASE BRITISH HEALTH-FOOD RETAILER
abstract: Vitamin maker NBTY Inc says that it agreed to acquire Holland & Barrett, British health-food retailer, from Germany's GEHE AG for $168.8 million (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Cigarette Makers Raise Prices by Average of 7.6%  The nation's largest cigarette makers, taking Wall Street by surprise, raised wholesale prices an average of 7.6 percent, which will translate into a 7-cents-a-pack gain in average retail prices.    The increase, believed to be the industry's largest single such move, is expected to bring in nearly $1.6 billion over the next 12 months. The money could be used for payments on settlements with Florida and Mississippi and one expected with Texas. $(Page A1.$)

headline: Major Shift for Communist China: Big State Industries Will Be Sold
abstract: China's leaders have agreed to sell off most of big state-owned industries, and outline plans at opening of Communist party congress; central theme of meeting is major shift from socialist-style state ownership to system of share-holding in more than 10,000 of country's 13,000 large- and medium-sized enterprises; elder party members object, but Pres Jiang Zemin apparently has persuaded them that China can no longer afford burden of inefficient, money-losing industries; 15th party congress, six months after death of Deng Xiaoping, will showcase Jiang as dominant leader; photo; complex task of shifting to private ownership discussed, along with serious danger that state assets will disappear into pockets of factory managers during transition (M)

headline: The rising tide of oil strikes lifts a floating-platform maker.
abstract: Market Place column on Bouygues Offshore SA, one of handful of oil service companies benefiting from global quest for new oil supplies through deep-sea drilling (L)

headline: Lucent and GTE To Share Contract
abstract: Lucent Technologies Inc and GTE Corp will split $2.9 billion, 10-year Navy contract after AT&T and Bell Atlantic Corp rejected their shares of agreement; contract is to improve Nay's voice, video and data transmission networks (S)

headline: Cambodia: Quandary for Diplomats
abstract: Foreign embassies in Cambodia, already beginning to cut their aid programs as punishment for coup carried out by Hun Sen, receive surprising letter from Parliament asking for humanitarian assistance; meanwhile, Prince Norodom Ranariddh, ousted as First Prime Minister, asks United States and United Nations for sanctions against Cambodia; Norodom photo (M)

headline: Worldcom To Acquire Compuserve
abstract: Worldcom Inc will acquire Compuserve Corp for nearly $1.2 billion in stock, and then sell on-line company's subscription service to America Online in complex three-way deal; Worldcom will keep high-speed telecommunications lines and Internet gateways of Compuserve, which is largely owned by H & R Block; Compuserve's global computer network will enlarge size and reach of Worldcom's Internet services unit, Uunet Technologies; America Online will sell its Internet telecommunications unit, ANS, to Worldcom to gain Compuserve's 2.6 million subscribers; America Online will also receive $175 million in cash from Worldcom (L)

headline: Key Division To Be Sold By Corning
abstract: Corning Inc, whose name has for decades been synonymous with Pyrex, Corning Ware and other household brands, says it will sell controlling interest in its consumer products business to AEA Investors, a New York investment firm; AEA will pay Corning $975 million in cash for 89 percent of Corning Consumer Products Co (L)

headline: Equity Residential in Deals
abstract: Equity Residential Properties Trust acquires five properties in cash transactions totaling $167 million; properties include 2,188 apartment units (S)

headline: U.S. Agrees To Join Talks On Banning Some Mines
abstract: Clinton Administration, facing growing international pressure, changes course and will join major European allies and scores of other countries in negotiating ban on land mines; decision comes less than two weeks before scheduled talks in Oslo, Norway (M)

headline: Drug Exposes Tied to Death Of a Mexican
abstract: Mexican authorities suspect newspaper publisher Benjamin Flores Gonzalez was shot to death in San Luis Rio Colorado by drug traffickers angered by his vigorous reporting on narcotics trade; paper often printed reports documenting drug corruption among police and other officials (S)

headline: Six Diplomas Later, They're Going Back to School
abstract: Article in occasional series Fresh Start, about personal finance decisions; Panda Kroll and Kevin Volkan, both in their 30's, discuss decision to give up beach cottage and incomes in California to attend graduate schools in Boston; interview; photo (M)

headline: $99 Companion Ticket for Delta Web Users
abstract: Delta Air Lines is offering $99 companion fare to customers who book tickets through the Internet, effective immediately (S)

headline: INVESTMENT FIRM, QUESTOR PARTNERS, TO ACQUIRE SCHWINN
abstract: Investment firm Questor Partners Fund LP plans to acquire Schwinn Cycling and Fitness Inc under agreement with closely held Scott Sports Group Inc; financial terms undisclosed (S)

headline: Photo of Youth Held In Japan Beheading Sets Off Ethics Furor
abstract: Japanese magazine Focus publishes photo of 14-year-old boy charged with strangling and beheading neighbor, Jun Hase, 11; move sets off furor over journalistic ethics in nation protective of children's rights to privacy; Prime Min Ryutaro Hashimoto scores magazine; Government opens probe (S)

headline: ABM INDUSTRIES REPORTS PURCHASE OF OGDEN BUSINESSES
abstract: ABM Industries acquires Ogden Corp's building-maintenance and engineering-services operations in New York City; price not disclosed (S)

headline: Taking In the Sites; On-Line Help With Entrance Exams
abstract: Roundup of World Wide Web sites offering help for students set to take college-entrance and graduate-school entrance exams; table; drawing (M)

headline: 3 Brokerage Firms Cited in Japan Scandal
abstract: Reputed racketeer Ryuichi Koike's lawyer says he was told by Koike's brother that Japanese brokerage firms Daiwa Securities Co, Nikko Securities Co and Yamaichi Securities Co paid off the racketeer last month and charged with blackmailing Nomura Securities Co; Koike's brother says 3 Japanese brokerage firms funneled money through illegal accounts held in other people's names to Koike (S)

headline: Latest Swiss Bank Surprise: Secrets From the Shredder
abstract: Union Bank of Switzerland says it has duplicates of some of documents rescued from shredding by a security guard in January and that it has unearthed evidence 'possibly' related to sale of Jewish property in Berlin during Nazi era; refused for months to publicly discuss contents of files rescued from shredder by security guard (M)

headline: Nomura Securities Fined For Racketeer Dealings
abstract: Nomura Securities Co will be fined total of 200 million yen, or $1.7 million, by Tokyo Stock Exchange and Japan Securities Dealers Assn for illegally channeling funds to racketeer (S)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent                Previous   Year          Yesterday   Day   Ago               PRIME RATE   8.50   8.50   8.25        DISCOUNT RATE   5.00   5.00   5.00        FEDERAL FUNDS*   5.56   5.50   5.20        3-MO.
