headline: Brooks Brothers moves beyond the gray flannel suit.
abstract: Brooks Brothers is striving to update its somewhat stuffy image along with its suits, shirts and ties; Brooks Brothers is spending estimated $1.5 million through end of year on in-house ad campaign; photo (L)

headline: Free-Market Fallout. For This We Won the Cold War?
abstract: William Wolman and Anne Colamosca, authors of The Judas Economy: The Triumph of Capital and the Betrayal of Work, maintain that understanding impact of cold-war victory on United Sattes is key to understanding every major economic trend now in operation in the US; authors maintain that effects are 'barely being felt now' by mid-level American workers, but that economic conditions will get worse as companies start to farm out skilled work to best and brightest persons in places like China, former Soviet bloc and India, which abandoned it Soviet model economy in 1991; authors also warn of possible recession, along with wider gap between rich and poor (M)

headline: Lucent Is Set To Buy Leader In Voice Mail
abstract: Lucent Technologies Inc agrees to pay $1.8 million in cash to acquire Octel Communications Corp; graph (M)

headline: Fantasy Sports Gets New Site On the Web
abstract: CNN and Sports Illustrated enter joint venture on World Wide Web called SportSim, free fantasy sports environment where players can pit their 'dream team' against teams concocted by other players (S)

headline: Markets Gulp After Mahathir Remarks
abstract: KUALA LUMPUR  Malaysia's stock market tumbled hand-in-hand with its currency Monday in the first day of trading after Prime Minister Mahathir bin Mohamad said currency trading "should be made illegal."

headline: Diana Memorial in Central Park
abstract: Episcopal diocese of New York and Cathedral of St John the Divine will sponsor memorial service for Diana, Princess of Wales, in North Meadow of Central Park on Sept 14; Mayor Rudolph Giuliani says city is honored, noting Diana's ties to New York (S)

headline: Stocks Higher in Japan
abstract: Nikkei index of 225 Japanese stock issues is up 140.51 points, at 18,198.72, at midday (Mon, 9/22) (S)

headline: Rhone-Poulenc Results Exceed Expectations
abstract: Rhone-Poulenc SA says that its second-quarter profit rose 20 percent, more than most analysts expected; Rhone, France's biggest drug and chemical company, earned 934 million French francs, or $153 million, in quarter (S)

headline: Homicide Inquiry Is Begun for 7 in Diana's Death
abstract: French judge files preliminary charges against six photographers and motorcyclist whose pursuit of limousine of Princess Diana of Wales, might have caused high-speed car accident in Paris in which she, companion Emad Mohammed al-Fayed and driver were killed; places seven under formal investigation for involuntary homicide and failing to come to aid of victims or impeding rescue efforts; five are released without bail, but two others are ordered to post equivalent of $16,700 and barred from working as journalists for duration of case; prosecutors ask that photographers Romuald Rat and Christian Martinez be held in jail while investigation proceeds; Rat, reportedly among first to arrive on accident scene, is said to have interfered with rescue attempts; photos (M)

headline: Nurse's Murder Throws Britain and Saudi Arabia Into Crisis
abstract: Possible execution of Deborah Parry and sentence of 500 lashes and eight years in prison for Lucille McLauchlan, both British nurses, in Dec 1996 murder in Daharan of Australian nurse Yvonne Gilford have set off serious diplomatic crisis between Saudi Arabia and Britain; British people, led by press, are protesting sentences, Islam's highly secretive trial process and validity of cases against nurses; Saudi officials, in defiant mood fed by brutal criticism of their justice system, say sentences will be carried out if upheld by religious courts; Parry would be first Western woman executed by Saudis; photo (M)

headline: Even action heroes can find themselves foiled by the gadgets they confront.
abstract: Edward Rothstein article on managing technological failures as theme in Air Force One and other films; drawing (M)

headline: Mining Company Posts 7.8% Profit Increase
abstract: Rio Tinto PLC, world's largest mining company, reports first-half profit rose 7.8 percent; profit rose to $595 million, from $552 million a year earlier (S)

headline: Britain Convicts 6 of Plot to Black Out London
abstract: Six men, including former American military explosives expert John Crawley, are convicted of having plotted last year to black out London and most of southeastern England in series of Irish Republican Army bombings of electrical power stations; are sentenced in London to 35 years in prison each; two others are acquitted (M)

headline: Saudi Sentences for 2 Britons May Be Eased
abstract: Saudi officials say controversy over sentencing of two British nurses charged with murder of an Australian colleague in Dhahran may be resolved through payment of compensation by the women to the family of the victim or some other means acceptable to parties in Britain and Australia; nurses say they are willing to pay compensation but still insist on their innocence (M)

headline: Executive Changes
abstract: MERRILL LYNCH & CO., New York, promoted Peter Hoffman and Phil Jones, managing directors, to head the group that arranges sales of convertible securities and derivatives for corporate clients. They will lead Merrill's equity-linked origination group, succeeding Lee Cole, who left last month to help rival Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Inc. build its convertibles business.     UNITED TECHNOLOGIES CORP., Hartford, named Charles H. Noski executive vice president and chief financial officer, succeeding Stephen F. Page, who left earlier this year to become president and chief executive of the Otis Elevator Company, a division of United Technologies.

headline: McDonald's Brazil Plans
abstract: McDonald's Corp plans to invest more than $500 million over next four years to expand Brazilian operations (S)

headline: Westminster Funeral
abstract: Diana's funeral will be held Saturday at Westminster Abbey, where sovereigns are crowned. She is to be buried at her ancestral home.    Article, page A10.

headline: Serious New Setback for Mir: Oxygen Sources Break Down
abstract: Main systems for producing oxygen aboard Mir space station break down, presenting three-man crew with fresh setback; NASA says mishap is serious but crew still has enough oxygen to last several days and will try to make repairs; failure to restore flow of oxygen could force crew to return to Earth, dealing humiliating blow to impoverished Russian space program (M)

headline: Pro Net in Talks to Gain 'Strategic Partner'
abstract: Pro Net Inc says it is in talks to enter into a 'strategic combination' with another company; Pro Net lost $40 million, or $4.07 a share, last year on revenue of $103.1 million (S)

headline: KOMAG TO CUT 16% OF ITS U.S. WORK FORCE
abstract: Komag Inc, disk drive components maker, will take charge of $45 million to $60 million to cut 16 percent, or 350 jobs, of its US work force and close two plants in Milpitas, Calif, to streamline it manufacturing (S)

headline: Music for America Online
abstract: America Online Inc enters into three-year partnership with N2K Inc, a retailer of recorded music; deal makes N2K's Music Boulevard exclusive music retailer within America Online's Musicspace and music areas; America Online says it will receive $18 million over span of agreement, with $12 million to be paid by Dec 1 (S)

headline: Sun Life of Canada Settles Policyholder Suit
abstract: Sun Life Assurance Co of Canada says it will pay $65 million (Canadian), or $47 million (US), to settle class-action lawsuit involving 400,000 holders of its life insurance policies; suit was brought after holders who bought policies between 1980 and 1995 were asked to make additional payments after company cut dividends that were intended to cover premiums (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Columbia/HCA Warns Earnings Will Be Lower  The Government inquiry into Columbia/HCA Healthcare and stagnant business at its 342 hospitals will push third-quarter earnings at the troubled health care provider down. The company said that per-share earnings would drop to 20 cents or 25 cents, compared with 46 cents in the quarter a year earlier.    Analysts were surprised by the company's announcement; they had predicted that earnings would exceed 50 cents a share. Columbia shares fell 9 percent. $(Page D5.$)

headline: Shoney's Warns of Possible Debt Default
abstract: Shoney's says it will soon be in default on credit agreements and holds refinancing talks with lenders (S)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent                Previous   Year          Yesterday   Day   Ago               PRIME RATE   8.50   8.50   8.25        DISCOUNT RATE   5.00   5.00   5.00        FEDERAL FUNDS*   5.44   5.47   5.09        3-MO. TREAS. BILLS   5.09   5.07   4.99        6-MO. TREAS. BILLS   5.13   5.12   5.07        10-YR. TREAS. INFL.**   3.51   3.53   N.A.        10-YR. TREAS. NOTES   6.23   6.20   6.60        30-YR. TREAS. headline: Venezuela and Trinidad Square Off Over Oil Treasure
abstract: Long-simmering boundary dispute over petroleum-rich straits and gulf separating Trinidad and Venezuela is flaring up again, with American oil companies caught squarely in middle; altercations in Gulf of Paria have become more and more common, with Venezuelan patrol boats routinely running off or even boarding Trinidadian oil rigs and fishing vessels; American oil companies have large investments in both countries; map (M)

headline: American in Drug Abyss: Guilty? Who Knows?
abstract: James Gordon Williams, American fish importer, has been in prison in Ecuador since September, charged, along with 15 of his friends and business associates, with smuggling drugs and laundering millions of dollars for Cali drug ring, charges he denies; trial is not likely for at least another year; Williams contends United States is using Ecuador to coerce cooperation from him in testifying against his friend, Jose Castrillon Henao, whom Williams defends; Williams claims FBI agents promised to help him if he agrees to testify against Castrillon; FBI spokesman denies this, saying bureau has no jurisdiction outside United States; human rights groups note that nearly half of Ecuador's prison population is being held on drug-related charges, and that 60 percent of its inmates are eventually found not guilty; photo; map (M)

headline: THE DOLLAR SOARS AS EUROPE DOUBTS ITS CURRENCY PLAN
abstract: Dollar surges in value against most most major European currencies on July 14, defying efforts of policymakers in Europe and US to restrain it and reaching highest level in six years against German mark and French franc; rises to nearly 1.8 German marks and more than 6 French francs; surge reflects dollar's expanding role as haven for currency traders skeptical over future of euro--new single European currency scheduled to replace several national denominations in 1999; currency is worth approximately 10 percent more than in early February 1997, when American and European finance ministers declared it had climbed enough and was due for a pause; graphs (M)

headline: Amex Specialists to Cover Options Losses
abstract: American Stock Exchange officials say specialists at exchange will pay for losses incurred when options trading was halted on Sept 16 (S)

headline: Raiding Party In Lebanon Belonged To Elite Unit
abstract: Israeli naval commando unit battered by guerrillas in Lebanon is one of Israel's most acclaimed military forces; unit, known as Flotilla 13, is trained for special missions behind enemy lines; traces heritage to 1945, when commandos sank British patrol boats that were searching for illegal Jewish immigrants; photo (M)

headline: You Gotta Believe
abstract: Graphs show similar performances of Dow Jones industrial average and New York Mets since baseball season began April 1 (S)

headline: Dollar Drops Against Mark After Bundesbank Warning
abstract: US dollar tumbles against German mark and other major currencies after Bundesbank, Germany's central bank, warns that it will monitor exchange rates to see if sagging German currency is fueling inflation (M)

headline: Iberia Air Lines Hires Tiempo BBDO
abstract: Iberia Air Lines names Tiempo BBDO unit of BBDO Worldwide to handle its consolidated domestic and international account, with billings estimated at $30 million; account has been divided between Casadevall Pedreno & PRG and Grey Advertising (S)

headline: Chinese Bank May Buy Stake in Jardine Unit
abstract: Jardine Fleming Group, brokerage firm closely identified with 156 years of British colonial rule in Hong Kong, is negotiating to sell stake in its banking unit to Ka Wah Bank, which is controlled by Chinese government (M)

headline: Spanish Utility Buying A Stake in Brazil
abstract: Group led by Spanish utility Iberdrola SA wins bidding for controlling stake in Cia de Eletricidade do Estado de Bahia, or Coelba, which controls most of electricity market in one of Brazil's biggest states, Bahia; purchase of 65.64 percent stake in Coelba, for $1.6 billion, provides Iberdrola with 2.3 million customers in 413 cities (S)

headline: Gold Prices Hit 11 1/2-Year Low As Reserve Sales Stir Concern
abstract: Gold futures plunge to their lowest price in 11 1/2 years amid speculation that last week's announcement by Australia's central bank that it had sold gold reserves would lead to sales by other nations; gold for August delivery falls $6.20 an ounce, to $319, on Comex division of New York Mercantile Exchange (M)

headline: Cor Shares Rise On New Study
abstract: Shares of Cor Therapeutics Inc surge as new research appears to strengthen company's drive to win approval for its primary heart drug called Integrelin (S)

headline: Cambodian Chief Puts on Show of Government as Usual
abstract: Hun Sen, Cambodia's de facto leader, seeks to legitimize seizure of power with elaborate demonstration of government as usual; newly obedient Parliament convenes and moves toward confirmation of his choice of new co-Prime Minister, Foreign Min Ung Huot (M)

headline: VIEWPOINT; China Needs Market Reform
abstract: Economist Klaus Friedrich article holds China must expand and deregulate financial markets to fulfill its goal of privatizing moribund state-owned industries (M)9

headline: Australia Prices Stake In Telecommunications
abstract: Australia, one of several countries selling all or part of their telecommunications carriers, is asking for between $8.6 billion and $10.2 billion (US) for one-third of Telstra Corp (S)

headline: Treasury and Other Financings Set for This Week
abstract: The Treasury's schedule of financing this week included today's regular weekly auction of new three-  and six-month bills and two-year and five-year notes being auctioned tomorrow and Wednesday.    Traders said the rate on the outstanding three-month bill at the close of the cash market on Friday was 5.10 percent and the rate on the six-month issue at 5.13 percent. In when-issued trading the two-year note was offered at a price to yield 5.91 percent, and the five-year note at 6.14 percent.

headline: Hospital Giant, Under Attack, Sets Shake-Up
abstract: Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corp, facing wide-ranging criminal probe, plans to drastically alter or abandon many of business practices that helped make it world's largest health care company; internal company documents outline plan for culture shift, including sale of home health care business, end to cash-bonus programs, adoption of programs to insure compliance with laws and rules, increase in enforcement staff and end to practice of selling stakes in hospitals to its doctors (M)

headline: Verkhny Lars Journal; Vodka Bottleneck Contains a Volatile Political Mix
abstract: At least 100 truckers are stuck at border crossing between Georgia and Russia, caught in middle of feud over vodka and money; behind gridlock is political battle that highlights difficult relations between Russia and other former Soviet republics; Georgia and other republics still depend on Russia for trade and military help; countries view one another with mistrust and suspicion, and their strategic interests have grown further apart; Russian Pres Boris N Yeltsin is counting on Russian vodka to generate Government revenues, and vowed to block imports; Pres Eduard Shevardnadze of Georgia wants to re-establish his country as center of new Silk Route for traders between Europe and Asia; thus far, negotiations between two countries have failed to produce compromise; photo; map (M)

headline: A Rift in the Chase
abstract: The Swiss banks' listing of dormant accounts from the Nazi era has opened up wide divisions about where the pursuit should lead. Paul A. Volcker, who is heading an investigation of the accounts, objects to a class action suit in New York, saying it could chill Swiss cooperation. But others on his committee disagree.     Article, page 5.

headline: Orders for Durable Goods Climb a Hefty 2.7%
abstract: Commerce Department reports durable goods orders rose 2.7 percent in August, well above analysts' expectations, to nearly $186.6 billion, a record; department revises its orders data for July to show gain of one-tenth of 1 percent instead of decline of three-tenths of 1 percent reported initially; Labor Department says jobless claims fell unexpectedly last week; first-time claims for state unemployment benefits fell by 2,000, to seasonally adjusted 306,000, while total number of jobless workers collecting benefit checks declined to lowest level since September 1989; in previous week, jobless claims fell revised 4,000; National Association of Realtors says sales of existing homes rose 3.3 percent in August, to annual rate of 4.32 million units, highest level in nearly four years (M)

headline: Pound Is Steadier as Britain Denies Change of Euro Plans
abstract: Several British ministers deny there has been any change in Government's policy on European monetary union, causing pound to steady from sharp selloff; dollar is little changed against most other major currencies as traders await important economic reports in Japan and United States as well as possible move on interest rates by Bundesbank (M)

headline: Petersen Reduces Offering
abstract: Petersen Companies reduces amount of its initial public offering to $100 million; original registration estimated offering could raise as much as $172.5 million (S)

headline: Rolf Knie, 75, Elephant Trainer And Swiss Circus Family Leader
abstract: Rolf Knie, master elephant trainer who led Switzerland's foremost circus family for 50 years, dies at 75 (S)

headline: 2 Companies Place Accounts in Review
abstract: Rally's Hamburgers Inc places in review creative and strategic planning portions of its account, with billings estimated at $13 million; account has been handled for last year by Mendelsohn/Zien Advertising; Shell Chemical Co places in review its business-to-business account, with billings estimated at $5 million to $7 million; account has been handled for 18 years by Black, Rogers, Sullivan & Goodnight Inc (S)

headline: Blockbuster's Profit Is Now Seen Plunging
abstract: Viacom Inc says earnings for its Blockbuster Entertainment unit will be far below analyst expectations for second quarter and for full year; company says Blockbuster's cash flow will plummet as much as 72 percent, to $40 million to $50 million in the quarter, from $143 million posted for second quarter last year; Viacom also says it is taking $300 million write-down for overstocked items and to close some stores (L)

headline: U.S. Intelligence Officials Pushed to Focus on China
abstract: United States Congress takes several steps to insure that intelligence officials track China, and particularly its military, more closely; moves seen a sign of new importance Congress is placing on China's growing international power; new steps come as Chinese efforts to influence American domestic politics are at center of Senate hearings into campaign finance irregularities (M)

headline: The Greening of Gambling's Golden Boy
abstract: Steve Wynn, strong-willed gambling industry executive who has built string of hugely successful casinos, is lately flexing his muscle in interests of saving pristine waters of Lake Tahoe; Wynn, who has sprawling home on lake and serves on Tahoe Regional Plannning Board, helped push through new ban on personal watercraft that dump large amounts of fuel into water; board was established by Congress, California and Nevada to balance development and environmental protection; photos; Wynn, who is losing his sight to retinitis pigmentosa, discusses commitment to preservation, saying Tahoe reminds him of Adirondack Mountains where he spent childhood summers; biographical profile (L)

headline: Software Producers See Gold in a Tax Overhaul
abstract: Companies that produce computer software for preparing tax returns hope to profit from high-visibility of sweeping tax changes approved by Congress; see increased complexity of tax code attracting new users (M)

headline: GEC ALSTHOM WANTS ROLE IN BID FOR WESTINGHOUSE UNITS
abstract: GEC Alsthom says it wants to join with Framatome Connectors France SA, state-controlled nuclear-energy company, to bid for energy operations of the Westinghouse Electric Corporation; Westinghouse plans to spin off most of its industrial units this year to focus on broadcasting (S)

headline: Sales of New Homes Up 6.1%, Showing Firmness for Housing
abstract: Commerce Department reports sales of new single-family homes rose 6.1 percent in June 1997, suggesting housing market entered third quarter on firm footing; charts (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Business Digest for August 30

headline: Pension Concerns Move to the Picket Line
abstract: Labor unions say that their members are pressing to preserve and enhance pension benefits; in traditional, defined benefit-pension plans, investment risks are borne by employer and retiree gets a check for life; over last two decades, trends has been toward defined-contribution plans like profit-sharing and 401(k)'s, in which workers bear investment risk and are not guaranteed fixed amount for life; graph (L)

headline: Albright Insists Netanyahu Undercuts Talks
abstract: Secretary of State Madeleine K Albright says faltering efforts to revive talks between Israel and Palestinians have been undercut by Prime Min Benjamin Netanyahu's promise to build 300 new homes for Israeli settlers in West Bank; Netanyahu made no mention of new homes in telephone call he had with Albright just hours before he made his pledge public; Albright says announcement complicates American efforts to broker new talks (M)

headline: SOURCE MEDIA IN $35 MILLION DEAL FOR BRITE VOICE ASSETS
abstract: Source Media Inc agrees to acquire certain electronic publishing assets of Brite Voice Systems Inc for $35 million (S)

headline: France to Sell Large Stake In Telecom
abstract: French Government will sell up to 38 percent of France Telecom SA for about 76 billion francs ($12.5 billion) in one of world's biggest initial public offerings; announcement ends months of speculation about new Socialist Government's intentions for the company; new Prime Minister Lionel Jospin has insisted there will be no privatization of companies; Governemnt says public offering of France Telecom will not amount to privatization because Government will keep majority stake (M)

headline: Deal for Miami Building
abstract: Crescent Real Estate Equities Co agrees to buy office tower in Miami, Fla, for about $132 million from Prudential Insurance Co of America (S)

headline: River Rises. So Does German Mettle.
abstract: Residents of Hohenwutzen and other parts of eastern Germany are girding to battle expected flooding by Oder River, which has devastated swaths of Central Europe and claimed 100 lives; map; photo (M)

headline: Israel to Build Dam on Disputed Land Claimed by Syria
abstract: Israel will build dam on Yarmuk River, inside boundary of land claimed by Syria, even though step is bound to worsen prospects for peace between two countries; site is a mile upstream from that selected by previous Labor Party Government, which was not in disputed territory; officials say selection of new site is aimed at underscoring Prime Min Benjamin Netanyahu's rejection of Syria's demands that Israel withdraw from Golan Heights to line that divided two countries at outset of 1967 war; maps (M)

headline: Mexico's Privately Run Highways Prove a Costly Failure
abstract: Highways and bridges built in Mexico over the last decade with $12 billion in private money have turned into a financial debacle, with tolls so high that Mexican drivers shun them; Government will mount $7.5 billion bailout to re-nationalize 23 of the private roads and 2 bridges, which carry virtually no traffic and face mounting maintenance crisis; Government remains committed to privatization process nevertheless; map (M)

headline: For Many Small Businesses, The Labor Pool Is Shallow
abstract: Small businesses are having trouble attracting qualified workers, particularly in rural communities with small labor pools; owners report raising wages or benefits to attract workers, becoming more flexible with work schedules and advertising jobs over much wider areas; table; photo (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Inflation Remains Benign, And Wall Street Applauds  Consumer prices rose only one-tenth of 1 percent in June, generating further optimism that the economy can continue to enjoy steady growth and low unemployment, without the need for interest-rate increases.

headline: DIARY
abstract: REBIRTHING PAINS  Apple Makes Its Peace  Apple Computer and its archrival Microsoft exchanged words last week -- harmonious ones, for a change. In a stunning alliance, Microsoft agreed to invest $150 million in the struggling Apple, and to cooperate on several fronts. That offered Apple a much-needed vote of confidence. Microsoft apparently concluded it would pay too high a price if it let Apple die, since Microsoft is the largest seller of programs for Macintosh computers. And cleaning its own house, Apple changed its board, bringing in Steven P. Jobs, its co-founder, below, to a more official role and sweeping out A. C. Markkula Jr., another co-founder and power broker. Mr. Jobs joins the board with a number of industry and investment veterans, including Lawrence J. Ellison, chairman of the software company Oracle and a critic of Microsoft. The changes mean that virtually every major computer hardware and software company -- many of which had been fighting each other -- have entered into the Apple camp. Apple's stock jumped on the news, but gave up some of its gains in Friday's market selloff.     THE BUDGET DEFICIT   A Monster at Bay  The Government's budget deficit is dwindling to a mere $37 billion this year, from $107 billion in 1996. That will bring it to its lowest level since 1974, President Clinton forecast. The strong economy and high tax receipts -- thanks in part to increases passed in 1990 and 1993 -- brought a great improvement even before the balanced-budget agreement he signed into law last week had a chance to take effect. Economists said the budget deal would control the deficit in coming years, however, when the gap between revenue and spending would otherwise begin widening.

headline: Ulster Catholic Considers a Bid For Presidency Of the South
abstract: John Hume, most influential and prominent mainstream Roman Catholic leader in Northern Ireland, may run for Presidency of Irish Republic; says officials of Ireland's two largest parties have offered to make him their candidate (M)

headline: 4 Intertwined Lives, Shattered by Bombing
abstract: Israeli family that ran produce business at Jerusalem market hit by suicide bombers ends mourning period for relative killed in blast; shares hospital vigil for two other relatives with family of Arab worker hurt in blast; photos (L)

headline: $100 Million Settlement Seen In Tenet Suits
abstract: Tenet Healthcare Corp agrees to pay about $100 million to former patients who contend that company and some affiliated doctors illegally imprisoned them in psychiatric hospitals in order to obtain their insurance benefits; doctors also agree to pay former patients about $20 million in compensation; suits were brought by about 700 former patents in two Texas state courts, and settlements, which were reached in recent weeks, include strict terms imposed by Tenet and doctors to keep details secret; activities covered by settlements took place under former management of company, which was then known as National Medical Enterprises; Tenet is starting aggressive negotiations to acquire Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corp, nation's largest hospital chain (M)

headline: People Soft Names A New Agency
abstract: People Soft Inc, software company, Pleasanton, Calif, names San Francisco office of Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising to handle its account, which had been at W B Doner & Co, Baltimore, since April 1995 (Advertising column) (S)

headline: Ford Might Build New Asia Plant
abstract: Ford Motor Co and its Japanese affiliate, Mazda Motor Corp, may set up new Asian auto plant, expanding their production in the region (S)

headline: DURAMED TO MAKE PRESCRIPTION DRUG FOR PARKE-DAVIS
abstract: Duramed Pharmaceuticals Inc enters long-term agreement to make a name-brand pharmaceutical for Parke-Davis unit of Warner-Lambert Co; financial terms undisclosed; Duramed says it has extended marketing and distribution agreement with Johnson & Johnson's Ortho-McNeil unit for some products; financial terms undisclosed (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Earnings Rise at Citicorp And at Chase Manhattan  The nation's biggest banks, Chase Manhattan and Citicorp, reported big gains in earnings for the second quarter despite disappointments in their credit card businesses.

headline: In Ulster Drama, a U.S. Player Is Hopeful About Peace
abstract: George Mitchell, American chairman of Northern Ireland peace talks, expresses hopes as IRA cease-fire takes hold, interview in Belfast (S)

headline: Disappointing Auction Trims Bond Prices
abstract: Prices of Treasury securities drop moderately, after disappointing Government auction of new two-year notes; price of 30-year bond falls 13/32, to 99 29/32; yield rises to 6.38 percent from 6.35 percent on Sept 22 (M)

headline: Equity and Convertible Debt Offerings Scheduled
abstract: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:    Arden Realty Corp., Beverly Hills, Calif., 10 million shares. Lehman Brothers.

headline: An F.D.A. Panel Approves a New Biotechnology Drug
abstract: Advisory panel to FDA unanimously recommends approval of biotechnology drug produced by Idec Pharmaceuticals Corp and Genentech Inc for treatment of form of non-Hodgkins lymphoma that is slow-growing but fatal and incurable cancer of immune system; drug, Rituxan, is recommended for treating so-called low-grade, or follicular B-cell, non-Hodgkin's lymphoma (M)'

headline: NEWCOURT CREDIT AGREES TO BUY COMMCORP FINANCIAL
abstract: Newcourt Credit Group agrees to acquire Commcorp Financial Services for about $260 million (S)

headline: Inflows Show That Investors Are Still Bullish on Mutual Funds
abstract: Mutual fund investors celebrated new high reached by stock market in July by adding to investments in equity funds; several mutual fund companies, including Fidelity Investments and Vanguard Group, say July will probably rank as second-best month of 1997, and will be far better than year-earlier period, when sharp drop in stock market brought funds flows to halt; Investment Company Institute reports equity funds took in $16.6 billion in new money in June, down from $20.5 billion in May (M)

headline: Eurotunnel Stocks Gain On News of Extension
abstract: Stocks of Eurotunnel PLC and Eurotunnel SA jump after France and Britain offer to extend its right to operate English Channel tunnel, allowing debt reorganization to save companies from bankruptcy (S)

headline: Tokyo Cracks Down on Yamaichi Securities
abstract: Japanese authorities arrest five current and former employees of Yamaichi Securities Co and ban firm from underwriting Government bonds as they investigate accusations that brokerage firm made illegal payofffs of $653,000 to corporate racketeer Ryuichi Koike; photo (M)

headline: Misael Pastrana Borrero, 74, President of Colombia in the 70's
abstract: Misael Pastrana Borrero, president of Colombia from 1970 to 1974, dies at age 74; photo (M)

headline: Murdoch Partner Is Said to Want Half of Dodgers
abstract: Rupert Murdoch's plan to buy Los Angeles Dodgers for his Fox sports and television ventures may encounter hurdle; John C Malone, chief executive of Tele-Communications Inc and Murdoch's partner in one sports venture, reportedly plans to claim right to buy half of team if sale goes through; this could make it more difficult for Murdoch, who told Major League Baseball, which must approve sale, that Fox would be sole owner of Dodgers (M)

headline: Helms Panel Moves Swiftly to Approve Envoys and Albright Aides
abstract: Sen Jesse Helms's committee moves swiftly to approve nominees for raft of posts in State Department and at embassies around world; approves 19 nominees, including Felix G Rohatyn to be Ambassador to France, Asst Sec John C Kornblum Ambassador to Germany, James F Collins Ambassador to Russia and Philip Lader Ambassador to Britain; approves nomination to senior State Department posts of Bonnie R Cohen, David Andrews, Marc Grossman, Stanley O Roth and James P Rubin; State Sec Madeleine K Albright notes committee has already approved 57 of 67 people named to diplomatic posts this year (M)

abstract: A partial list for this week.    MONDAY   Anadarko Pete Corp  DTE Energy CO  Duke Pwr Co  Hartford Steam Boiler Inspctn & Insur  Howell Corp   Inco Ltd  Kennametal Inc  KU Energy Corp

abstract: Reynolds Metals Co chairman-chief executive Jeremiah J Sheehan says company will sell or spin off at least part of either its US can or packaging businesses (S)

headline: Stronger Dollar Bolsters Results at Michelin
abstract: Michelin SA says second-quarter sales rose 12.6 percent as stronger dollar helped increase sales in US; sales rose to 20.05 billion francs ($3.19 billion), from 17.81 billion francs in year-earlier second quarter (S)

headline: Holtzbrinck's New Word on U.S. Publishing
abstract: Verlagsgruppe Georg von Holtzbrinck, German media conglomerate, opens automated book distribution complex, Gordonsville, Va, serving its Farrar, Straus & Giroux; Henry Holt, and St Martin's Press units; chairman Dieter von Holtzbrinck holds United States, despite short-term slump, is most important publishing market; photos (M)

headline: S.E.C. Approves New Nasdaq Listing Rules
abstract: Securities and Exchange Commission approves rules that are intended to improve listing standards on Nasdaq National Market and Nasdaq Small Cap Market (S)

headline: On Borneo, Anger at Lack Of Haze Help
abstract: KUCHING, Malaysia  The island of Borneo, with its millions of acres of rain forest, has long been touted in promotional brochures and tourist guidebooks as the lungs of the earth.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Home Depot in Deal To Settle Sex Bias Suit   Home Depot has agreed to pay $87.5 million and change its job assignment and promotion practices. The settlement by the building materials retailer stems from a suit filed by women in its West Coast division who contended they were assigned to jobs at cash registers rather than put on the selling floor.

headline: A Gentler Hand at Columbia's Helm
abstract: Profile of Dr Thomas F Frist Jr, new chmn of Columbia/HCA Healthcare (M)

headline: Protestants in Ulster Call Off Parades in Catholic Areas
abstract: Protestant Orange Order, in concession intended to prevent renewed sectarian violence in Northern Ireland, says that it will not hold parades through areas where Roman Catholic residents have threatened to block them (M)

headline: Ontario to Shut 7 Border Nuclear Reactors
abstract: Ontario Province (Canada) is shutting down 7 of its 19 operating nuclear reactors, all within 100 miles of United States border, after internal report finds Ontario Hydro, owned and run by province, is so badly managed it compromised safety of entire nuclear power system; will spend $2.2 billion over next four years to replace lost energy, using existing fossil fuel generating stations; will spend $1.5 billion to overhaul dozen reactors on shores of Lake Ontario and Lake Huron that will continue to operate; company chairman William A Farlinger says closed reactors will be brought back on line if move is cost effective, news conference; says rates will not rise; Allan Kupcis has resigned as Ontario Hydro president; map; photo (M)

headline: After 9 Months, AT&T President Quits Under Pressure
abstract: John R Walter resigns abruptly as president and chief operating officer of AT&T Corp; Walter, whose contract calls for him to succeed Robert E Allen as chief executive next January, quits under pressure after AT&T's board tells him that they lost faith in his performance and that he will not get top job; for nine months of work, Walter will get one-time payment of $3.8 million, plus $22 million in compensation for leaving his previous job as chief executive of printing company R R Donnelley & Sons; Allen will stay on as chief executive while board conducts search for his successor; AT&T's general counsel John D Zeglis will take over Walter's duties, though not his title, as head of operations; George M C Fisher, chief executive of Eastman Kodak, recently joined AT&T's board and is said to have been first choice to succeed Allen before company hired Walter; photos (L)

headline: Outbreaks Of Violence Continue In Bosnia
abstract: Rock-throwing Bosnian Serbs force withdrawal from Brcko of United Nations team that came to see whether it was safe for unarmed international police monitors to return to city; no one is hurt in incident; blast in Banja Luka kills one person and seriously wounds two others and raises fears among some NATO aides of more violence in areas taken over by forces loyal to Bosnian Serb Pres Biljana Plavsic; Momcilo Krajisnik, Serb member of Bosnia's Presidency, scores NATO presence and warns of more violence against NATO-led force; map (M)

headline: INSO STOCK PLUMMETS AFTER WARNING ON REDUCED PROFIT
abstract: Shares of Inso Corp lose nearly half their value after company says it expects second-quarter earnings to be less than a third of what analysts expect; shares fall $9.6875, to $11.0625 (S)

headline: Making Sure War Crimes Aren't Forgotten
abstract: Article profiles David J Scheffer, US Ambassador at Large for War Crimes; entirely new position, brainchild of Sec of State Madeleine K Albright, is aimed at giving war crimes, genocide and crimes against humanity higher priority in American foreign policy, separating it from State Department's bureau overseeing human rights generally; his inaugural trip to Rwanda, where Hutu extremists slaughtered thousands of Tutsi in 1994 discussed; photo; map (M)

headline: Sons' Military Weigh-In Pulls Korean Candidate From Lead
abstract: Revelation that South Korean Presidential candidate Lee Hoi Chang's two sons were excused from military service for being underweight has caused his poll ratings to plummet from first place to third place among four leading candidates (M)

headline: Fitch Ratings Agency in Merger Talks
abstract: Fitch Investors Service LP says it is in merger talks with IBCA Ltd of London in hopes of creating credit-rating agency to challenge industry leaders; IBCA is majority owned by Fimalac SA (S)

headline: Israel and Arabs Welcome U.S. Push but With Different Agendas
abstract: Israelis and Palestinians welcome new American initiative aimed at pushing two sides more swiftly toward peace, but they present rival views about what should receive highest piority under reinvigorated diplomacy; each side wants American envoys to put pressure on other side to make good on its commitments; it is notable that neither Yasir Arafat nor Prime Min Benjamin Netanyahu recoiled in public at criticism that was directed at both sides by Secretary of State Madeleine K Albright; new American plan will urge Israelis and Palestinians to negotiate more quickly on major issues that must be addressed in final peace settlement, rather than using interim accords to address issues that could be more easily resolved (M)

headline: Hewlett-Packard Reports Mixed Results
abstract: Hewlett-Packard Co earnings in quarter ended July 31 of $617 million compared with $425 million a year earlier; revenue grew 15 percent, to $10.5 billion, compared with $9.1 billion a year earlier; table (L)

headline: Families Go to Guam To Claim Their Dead
abstract: Grieving family members rushed to Guam to claim the remains of relatives killed in the Korean Air crash early Wednesday that left 225 people dead.     Somehow, 29 survived, some with surprisingly light injuries. ''A couple of people walked out with minor burns and minor cuts,'' said a United States Navy petty officer who helped at the scene. ''I couldn't understand how anyone could survive.''

headline: Miscellany
abstract: * Bozell Worldwide, New York, part of Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt, agreed to acquire a majority interest in ADV/Vazquez S.A. de Publicidad, Buenos Aires. Terms were not disclosed.

headline: French Premier Finds Honeymoon in Eclipse
abstract: France's new Socialist Prime Minister, Lionel Jospin, is already being criticized by opponents for not trying hard enough to cut Government deficit and by supporters for not doing more about jobs; is to some extent victim of expectations created by his campaign that he would end unpopular austerity measures adopted by former Prime Min Alain Juppe to qualify France for common European currency (M)

headline: GE CAPITAL IN $950 MILLION DEAL WITH LEUCADIA
abstract: GE Capital Corp will buy Leucadia National Corp's Colonial Penn automobile insurance unit for $950 million (S)

headline: U.N. Says Congo Blocks Investigation of Reported Massacres
abstract: United Nations officials say Pres Laurent Kabila's Government is blocking international investigation of reported massacre sites in eastern Congo, demanding that team's leader, Roberto Garreton, be replaced and its task redefined (M)

headline: REXEL AGREES TO BUY 2 ELECTRICAL PARTS DISTRIBUTORS
abstract: Rexel Inc acquires closely held electrical parts distributors Pacific Electrical Supply Inc and Taylor Electric Supply Inc for about $40 million (S)

headline: APS HOLDING TO CLOSE 15 STORES AND ELIMINATE SOME JOBS
abstract: APS Holding Corp, auto parts distributor in Houston, Tex, says it will close 15 stores and 50 warehouses in effort to return to profitability; company will cut substantial number of jobs but does not provide details (S)

headline: Carbide's Chief Bets Some Pay On Performance
abstract: Union Carbide Corp chief executive William H Joyce says he will give back his base salary in year 2000 if company fails to earn $4 a share that year, which is expected to be tough one for giant chemical company; Joyce and 15 other executives will get extra money if they exceed figure of $4 a share; three analysts surveyed by First Call predict Union Carbide will earn $4.08 a share in 1999; they do not provide estimate for 2000; photo (L)

headline: Pro Bono Accounts
abstract: * The March of Dimes Greater New York Chapter to GRW Advertising, New York.

headline: Raids Across Border From Colombia Keep Panama on Edge
abstract: Panama, faced with influx of Colombian refugees, guerrillas and paramility groups that has led to skirmishes, kidnappings and seizures of property, orders armed force of over 1,200 men to remote Darien region along its border with Colombia; map (M)

headline: Allied Signal Agrees to Sell 2 Auto Units
abstract: Allied Signal Inc agrees to sell its automotive seat belt and air bag operations to Breed Technologies Inc for $710 million in cash; Allied Signal is the nation's largest seat belt manufacturer and the third-largest supplier of air bags; says it regards units as low-margin, cyclical businesses (M)

headline: Wrong Address
abstract: New York Times is looking for stories on embarrassing experience of sending computer message to wrong destination; drawing (S)

headline: Hicks, Muse Is Said To Be Near a Deal For SFX in a Move To Create Radio Giant
abstract: Hicks, Muse, Tate & Furst expected to acquire SFX Broadcasting Inc, and become No 1 radio company in nation; SFX, nation's eighth-largest radio company, is expected to command $1 billion to $1.2 billion in cash, and assumption of its $920 million in debt; SFX owns 71 stations clustered in mid-sized cities; Hicks, Muse already owns 241 radio stations; over all, more than 2,100 radio stations have changed hands in deals worth about $15 billion since Federal Communications Commission lifted many restrictions on station ownership last year; photo; graph (M)

headline: A Pill's Heart Benefits Help the Bottom Line
abstract: Bayer Aspirin is seen making modest comeback, after being outgunned by newer painkillers and underpriced by generic and private labels; Bayer aspirin's market share in United States plummeted from 20 percent in late 1960's to low of 4.5 percent in 1994; two things are at heart at Bayer aspirin's recovery from sick bed: American rights to Bayer name and trade mark were returned--after hiatus of 78 years--to Bayer AG, Germany company committed to promoting its namesake; at same time, American marketing team, taking advantage of scientific evidence that aspirin is the only headache medicine that also helps prevent blood clots and heart disease, comes up with breakthrough selling strategy; they advertise Bayer for 'powerful pain relief, and so much more'; chronology of Bayer aspirin's history; photos; chart (M)

headline: Sears Agrees to Stop Recruiting at Ward
abstract: Sears, Roebuck & Co agrees to stop recruiting salaried managers at Montgomery Ward Holding Corp while Montgomery Ward is in bankruptcy-law proceedings (S)

headline: New Service Tracks Web Use
abstract: Alexa Internet Co offers Internet users more imformation about popularity and location of pages they view; service, which works with Internet browsers offered by Netscape Communications Corp and Microsoft Corp, focuses on relatively new idea of assisting users in navigating World Wide Web (S)

headline: U.S. in Spat With Mexico Over Identity Of Drug Lord
abstract: United States Drug Enforcement Administration aide angers Mexican officials by confirming that man who died after cosmetic surgery was fugitive drug baron Amado Carrillo Fuentes; expects bloody succession battle; Mexican Amb Jesus Silva Herzog scores DEA and its head, Thomas Constantine, holding confirmation should be up to Mexico, which awaits genetic test results; State Department backs away from DEA stand, awaiting confirmation from Mexico (M)

headline: Traveling Clintons Frolic On European Playground
abstract: Pres Clinton and family, in Spain for NATO summit meeting, spend afternoon on royal yacht with King Juan Carlos and Queen Sofia; photo (M)

headline: Cable Venture Formed by 2 Industry Giants
abstract: Time Warner Inc and Tele-Communications Inc agree to create new joint venture that will own cable systems and to expand existing partnership; moves will also allow both companies to reduce debt on their balance sheets; two giant cable operators will create cable company in Texas by pooling roughly half a million subscribers each (S)

headline: Bennett A. Brown, 68, Southern Banking Executive
abstract: Bennett A Brown, former chief executive of Citizens and Southern National Bank of Atlanta, Ga, dies at age 68 (M)

headline: But No State of Emergency Yet : Fire Haze a Disaster, Indonesia Declares
abstract: KUCHING, Malaysia  As this smokebound city endured another day of choking fumes Thursday, neighboring Indonesia declared a national disaster and called on "all levels of society" to mobilize against the forest fires that have left several countries in the region under a thick, gray haze.

headline: Columbia/HCA Cites Talks With Potential Buyers
abstract: Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corp president Jack Bovender says company has received expressions of interest from number of potential buyers of portions of business, but it currently is interested only in selling its home care operations; adds company is not currently negotiating with any of potential bidders (L)

headline: Housing Construction Up in July in Canada
abstract: Housing starts in Canada rose 2.7 percent in July from June because of rise in multiple-unit construction; starts in July totaled 144,700 units, up from 140,900 in June (S)

headline: Executive Changes
abstract: MATTEL INC., Los Angeles, the toy maker, named Bruce L. Stein chief operating officer. Mr. Stein, 42, will retain his position as president of Mattel Worldwide. His new duties include overseeing Mattel's Fisher-Price unit.

headline: France Said to Balk At 2d Bosnia Raid, Calling It Too Risky
abstract: United States aides say France, whose officers command NATO troops that patrol Pale, Bosnia, area, resists as too risky US pressure to arrest prominent Bosnian Serbs in area accused of war crimes; say continue presence of ex-Pres Radovan Karadzic and Gen Ratko Mladic undermines peace efforts; map (M)

headline: Europe Floor Deal Approved by U.S.
abstract: Tarkett AG says Federal Trade Commission has approved its plan to buy floor-covering business of French plastics maker Sommer Allibert SA, leaving only German antitrust authorities to clear the purchase; if German regulators approve, Tarkett will double its sales; Tarkett has offered to pay 955 million marks ($522 million) for the business (S)

headline: 3 More Held In the Inquiry Into the Crash
abstract: French police detain three more photographers who snapped pictures of car wreck that killed Diana, Princess of Wales, after chase in Paris; three turn themselves in; they and six others under investigation have denied being near Mercedes when it rammed support pillar in tunnel at high speed; photo agency owner says two of his photographers took pictures and left before police arrived; Francois Levy says he sped through tunnel just ahead of Mercedes, saw headlights of two motorcycles on either side of it, and saw one motorcycle make fishtail maneuver in front of Mercedes; says Mercedes then veered back and forth, he heard crash, and then two motorcycles sped away past him (S)

headline: COMMERCIAL BANK OF NEW YORK BEGINS AN EXPANSION
abstract: Commercial Bank of New York acquires First Bank of the Americas for $48 million in cash; this will give Commercial Bank eight branches in New York City and Long Island; BanBogota Inc, First Bank's parent and the United States unit of Banco de Bogota of Colombia, will retain international and auto loans and other assets (S)

headline: After a Night of Parties, Nothing Feels Different
abstract: Vignettes of scenes in Hong Kong in final hours leading up to transfer of power to China after 156 years of British colonial rule; photos (M)

headline: Militia Attack in Lebanon Kills 6 and Sets Off a Battle
abstract: Militiamen commanded by key ally of Israel shells port city of Sidon, 25 miles south of Beirut, killing at least six peopleand wounding more than three dozen; is deadliest attack against Lebanese civilians in more than year, and is first on Sidon since Israel's air and artillery assault into Lebanonin April 1996; appears to be response to roadside bombing attributed to Islamic guerrillas that killed three Lebanese civilians; photo; map (M)

headline: Diana Photo Restarts Debate Over Lack of Restrictions on Internet Postings
abstract: Publication on Internet of fake photo purporting to show Diana, Princess of Wales, as she lay dying after auto crash and photo's publication by French newspaper set off new controversy over ease of disseminating inaccurate data over Internet; incident says much about how traditional media handle Internet's speculative data and underscores public appetite for information about Diana's death; Rotten Dot Com, anti-censorship group that published image, notes it never claimed photo was real (M)

headline: Daniel J. Lyons, 92, Insurance Executive
abstract: Daniel J Lyons, former chairman of Guardian Life Insurance Company of America, dies at age 92 (S)

headline: KLM May Sell 19% Stake Back to Northwest Airlines
abstract: Northwest Airlines Corp and KLM Royal Dutch Airlines are close to ending their two-year-old legal battle by agreeing to have Dutch carrier sell its 19 percent stake in Northwest back to United States company; settlement could end bitter boardroom and courtroom fight over KLM's investment in Northwest that at times has threatened to undermine their operating alliance, which is one of most successful in airline industry (M)

headline: A Stalemate In Cambodia
abstract: Seth Mydans analysis of confused situation in Cambodia following reports of downfall of Khmer Rouge leader Pol Pot (M)

headline: Corrections
abstract: Correction of map accompanying Sept 7 article about hotel companies Starwood Lodging Trust and Patriot American Hospitality; map overstated number of hotels managed by Patriot American and located some hotels incorrectly

headline: Latest Earnings Epitomize Shift In Chip Industry
abstract: Intel Corp and Texas Instruments Inc post profits above analysts' forecasts; Intel says earnings rose 58 percent, to $1.65 billion, compared with last year's second quarter; Texas Instruments' second-quarter earnings surged to $249 million, up from $76 million in year-earlier period; Texas Instruments' revenue increased 6.7 percent, to $2.56 billion from $2.40 billion a year earlier; Intel's revenue climbed 29 percent, to $5.96 billion; tables (L)

headline: Computer Services Companies Plan Merger
abstract: Affiliated Computer Services Inc to buy Computer Data Systems Inc for stock valued at $325 million and assume $48 million in debt (S)

headline: SENSORMATIC POSTS $35 MILLION LOSS AND DISMISSES 1,200
abstract: Sensormatic Electronics Corp takes $34.6 million charge in its fourth quarter and says it will dismiss 19 percent of its work force, or 1,200 workers, suspend its quarterly dividend and sell some businesses (S)

headline: Alcoa Income Climbs 57%; Shipments Offset Price Drop
abstract: Aluminum Co of America says earnings rose 57 percent in second quarter; net income was $207.6 million, up from $132.2 million in same 1996 quarter; sales rose to $3.47 billion, from $3.4 billion; table (M)

headline: Mercury, Mostly Gone From Bay in Japan, Still Poisons Town's Life
abstract: Four decades after mercury poisoning made Minamata, Japan, synonymous with environmental disaster, prefectural government has declared mercury levels in fish from Minamata Bay now meet safety standards; net that cordoned off Bay's fish from surrounding sea since 1974 is being removed, and commercial fishing should resume in Fall 1997; to many Japanese, announcement marks symbolic end to saga that helped awaken world to evils of pollution and led Japan to question ethic of growth at any cost; photos; map (L)

headline: Don't Call Us . . .
abstract: New York Times is looking for stories on wannabes who give such poor job interviews that they know they will never be hired; drawing (S)

headline: Japanese Economy Continues Recovery
abstract: Bank of Japan says Japan's economy continues to recover, though rise in sales taxes in April is keeping reins on growth (S)

headline: ASTRONAUT ERROR DEEPENS ANXIETIES ON SPACE STATION
abstract: Astronaut aboard Mir space station mistakenly disconnects critical cable, disabling guidance system that enables Mir to gather solar energy and causing another crisis for troubled-plagued craft; crew turns off lights and climate-control systems to conserve power; Russian officials refuse to say which astronaut made mistake; say mishap is not life-threatening; NASA announces that it has granted permission for American member of crew, Michael Foale, to train for lengthy space walk to restore power from Mir's Spektr module, which was damaged on June 25 in collision with unmanned cargo craft; diagram; photos (M)

headline: Another Official Leaves Columbia/HCA
abstract: Jamie Hopping, president of Collumbia/HCA Healthcare Corp's Western division who helped build company's business in Florida, resigns; Columbia spokesperson declines to comment on whether successor has been chosen (S)

headline: Chief of W. R. Lazard Resigns Amid Rift
abstract: W R Lazard & Co chief executive and co-chairwoman Marianne Spraggins resigns amid rift over how to revamp securities firm (S)

headline: Netscape Says It Will Unbundle Web Browser Software
abstract: Netscape Communications Corp is expected to once again make its popular Navigator World Wide Web browsing software available as stand-alone product; had bundled Navigator with several other software products (S)

headline: At Closed-End Funds, A Big Push to Open Up
abstract: Managers of closed-end mutual funds that have been trading at a discount to net asset value have been under pressure to 'open' their funds; conversion from closed fund to open fund can mean windfall for shareholders; graphs (L)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent                Previous   Year          Yesterday   Day   Ago               PRIME RATE   8.50   8.50   8.25        DISCOUNT RATE   5.00   5.00   5.00        FEDERAL FUNDS*   5.63   5.45   5.56        3-MO. headline: Pol Pot Trial Far From Villagers' Minds
abstract: Residents of villages once used by Khmer Rouge as killing fields focus on economic survival and see politics as distant game; show little interest in Khmer Rouge's show trial of former leader Pol Pot; photo (M)

headline: Some large clients including Mastercard and Aamco settle on agencies for their accounts.
abstract: Several big national advertisers made decisions late last week on accounts with total billings estimated at $125 million to $135 million; biggest was Mastercard International, which named McCann-Erickson Worldwide to handle domestic creative portion of its account, with billings estimated at $100 million; other accounts noted (L)

headline: Responding to Britain's Sorrow, Queen Will Address the Nation
abstract: Buckingham Palace, stung by charges that royal family is unmoved by enormous public grief over death of Diana, Princess of Wales, announces that Queen Elizabeth II will return to London from Scotland one day early, and address nation on eve of funeral; unexpected statement says family is hurt and that Diana's sons have wished to remain with their father and grandparents in quiet haven of Balmoral Castle, where Queen is helping children come to terms with their loss; photos, one of family looking over floral tributes left outside Balmoral and another of scene in London; Prime Min Tony Blair talks with Prince Charles and later says it is unfair to criticize family; Prince Andrew and Prince Edward joins mourners at St James Palace; Buckingham Palace will also fly Union Jack for first time, at half-staff, on day of funeral in response to anger at sight of empty flagpole, which traditionally only flies royal standard when monarch is in residence (M)

headline: ATKINSON MULLING POSSIBLE SALE OR MERGER
abstract: Guy F Atkinson Co has hired Salomon Brothers Inc to advise it on strategic and financial alternatives, including possible sale, merger or recapitalization of the company, which filed for bankruptcy in August (S)

headline: 2 Agencies Revamp Interactive Activities
abstract: Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising revamps Saatchi & Saatchi Interactive, which becomes autonomous shop renamed Darwin Digital; Coby O'Brien, senior vice president and director of Saatchi Interactive, becomes president and chief executive at Darwin; Audrey Fleisher joins Darwin as executive creative director; Young & Rubicam Inc creates integrated interactive agency by combining existing interactive operations of its Young & Rubicam Advertising and Wunderman Cato Johnson units; new unit to be called Brand Dialogue; J Michael Boh, executive vice president and chief operating officer at Media Circus, is promoted to president; he succeeds Douglas Kern, who resigned (S)

headline: Shopping for U.S. Insurer, Dutch Giant Buys in Iowa
abstract: ING Groep NV, Dutch financial giant, agrees to buy Equitable of Iowa Companies for $2.2 billion in cash and stock, as well as to assume $400 million in debt, effectively doubling size of its American life insurance business to more than $20 billion (Market Place column) (L)

headline: Unit of Duke in Deal With Providence Gas
abstract: Duke Trading and Marketing LLC, unit of Duke Energy Corp, signs three-year contract to administer gas-supply agreements of Providence Gas Co; terms of deal not disclosed; Providence Gas, unit of Providence Energy Corp, receives Rhode Island regulatory approval for three-year rate freeze and immediate rate reduction of 5 percent (S) O

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Deal Is Reached to End Strike Against U.P.S.  Teamsters' union officials said that they and the United Parcel Service had reached an agreement to end the 15-day strike by 185,000 workers that largely crippled the world's largest package delivery company.    The officials said they expected the strikers to return to work tomorrow. First, however, two union committees -- including the bargaining committee -- must approve the agreement. $(Page A1.$)

headline: Making Those Good Causes Do What the Donor Intended
abstract: Advise for donors on insuring that charities use their gifts as they intend in light of recent Connecticut court ruling that donors have no standing to sue; over 40 states have similar laws aimed at keeping donors from pestering charities (M)9

headline: Ogilvy & Mather Gets Perrier Account
abstract: Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide is named to handle creative portion of worldwide Perrier sparkling water account; billings estimated at $40 million to $50 million (S)

headline: WELLSFORD TO ACQUIRE VALUE PROPERTY FOR $180 MILLION
abstract: Wellsford Real Properties Inc to acquire Value Property Trust for $180 million in cash and stock (S)

headline: Protests Follow Death of Official Kidnapped by Basque Rebels
abstract: Death of Miguel Angel Blanco, 29-year-old town councilman in Ermua, Spain, who was kidnapped and fatally shot by Basque terrorists, touches off new protests against terrorism throughout Spain; tensions are rising, particularly in Basque City of Pamplona, where riot policemen struggled to control angry crowds; thousands take protests to streets in various cities for fourth consecutive day; map; photo (M)

headline: Half a Million Fans Help the Pope Beat the Heat in Paris
abstract: Pope John Paul II begins visit to Paris with festive outdoor encounter with 500,000 young people from around the world whom Roman Catholic Church authorities invited to meet him and ponder Christian message for modern world; 77-year-old Pope appears stooped under 90-degree heat, but refreshed by warm welcome from cheering masses; this is sixth trip he has made to France during his papacy; last one was in 1980 (M)

headline: Pepsico Spinoff Date Set
abstract: Pepsico Inc. said today that it had received approval from the Securities and Exchange Commission to spin off its restaurant business to shareholders and that the spinoff would occur on Oct. 6. Under the spinoff plan, Pepsico shareholders of record as of Sept. 19 will receive one share in the new restaurant company, Tricon Global Restaurants Inc., for every 10 Pepsico shares they hold.

headline: Disney Is Said To Pursue A Music Label
abstract: Walt Disney Co is close to deal to acquire Mammoth Records for between $20 million and $25 million; Mammoth's other suitors reportedly include Philips Electronics NV's Polygram unit and Michael P Schulhof; Mammoth's prime attraction to Disney is its owner, Jay Faires, who is regarded as up-and-coming executive who could fill Disney's music management void (S)

headline: BellSouth Seeks Added Florida Service
abstract: BellSouth Corp says it has applied to begin offering long-distance phone service to its customers in Florida, fifth state in company's nine-state territory where it has made such a filing (S)

headline: Unexpected Rise in Jobless Rate Spurs a Rally for Bonds
abstract: Unexpected jump in jobless rate touches off rally in Treasury bond market; 30-year bond yields 6.62 percent (S)

headline: Israel Releases Some Palestinian Funds, but Sticking Points Remain
abstract: Israel, citing partial cooperation from Palestinian Authority, will pay part of money owed Palestinians that was frozen as punishment after July 30 suicide bombing in Jerusalem market that killed 16 people; Prime Min Benjamin Netanyahu says Israel will not call complete halt to financial blockade until Palestinian leader, Yasir Arafat, heeds Israel's demands for widespread crackdown on Islamic militants (M)

headline: GRANCARE AND LIVING CENTERS RENEGOTIATE MERGER PLAN
abstract: Grancare Inc and Living Centers of America Inc change terms of planned merger; under revised agreement, Living Centers shareholders will receive $40.50 a share in cash for about 90.5 percent of their shares and will keep remainder of their stock in recapitalized company; merger will create second-biggest US nursing-home chain (S)

headline: Software programs to help buyers make decisions about insurance and health care needs.
abstract: Patent and Trademark Office awards patent to Ryan Evalulife Systems Inc that covers software program to help individuals choose universal life insurance policy; Health Share Technology Inc is assigneed patent that covers software that compares quality and cost of health care at hospitals to determine which are most competitive (L)

headline: Pioneer Growth Fund
abstract: Interview with Pioneer Growth Fund manager Jeff Poppenhagen on his successful investment strategy; he stresses investing in industry leaders; graphs; photo (M)

headline: TCI Prepares for Yet Another Complex Spinoff
abstract: Tele-Communications Inc for second time in two years is spinning off clutch of noncore businesses into separate company; new company, TCI Ventures, is oddball, if high-profile collection of investments that Tele-Communications Inc has made over years in cable-related businesses; Tele-Communications chairman John C Malone believes spinoff is a way to get more value from assets that he believes have been neglected by investors and overshadowed by Tele-Communications' prime business, ownership of cable systems with 14 million customers; table (L)

headline: Safer by the Dozen
abstract: Roundup of mutual fund news; Morningstar Inc study finds investor can cut risks, but also lower returns, by increasing portfolio of mutual funds to about dozen; finds greatly increasing number of funds does little to further cut risk (M)

headline: Accounts
abstract: * Carpet and Rug Institute, Dalton, Ga., to the Leo Burnett Co., Chicago, as the first agency to handle its account. Billings were estimated at $100 million over four years.    * DLJ Direct, New York, the on-line brokerage service of Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Inc., to Romann & Tannenholz, New York, as its first agency. Billings were estimated at $10 million.

headline: Anti-Dumping Duties Against Japanese
abstract: International Trade Commission votes 3 to 0 to back imposition of punitive anti-dumping duties against Vector supercomputers produced by NEC Corp and other Japanese manufacturers; commission finds that Cray Research, supercomputer manufacturing unit of Silicon Graphics Inc, was financially injured by pricing practices of Japan's supercomputer producers; Commerce Department says Fujitsu Ltd is hit with dumping tariffs totaling 173.08 percent and all other Japanese manufacturers will face tariff amounting to 313.54 percent of value (S)

headline: 2 Logistics Companies Are Acquired by Hays
abstract: Hays PLC has bought two logistic companies from Mayne Nickless Ltd--FDS of France and Van der Heijden of Belgium--for 72 million pounds, or $115.6 million (S)

headline: PACIFIC ENTERPRISES AND ENOVA TO BUY AIG TRADING
abstract: Enova Corp and Pacific Enterprises will acquire AIG Trading Corp for $190 million in cash (S)

headline: Dollar Falls Against the Mark On Hint of German Rate Rise
abstract: US dollar falls against German mark after Bunkesbank president Hans Tietmeyer hints that it might soon raise interest rates (M)

headline: Some big financial guns attack a proposal on derivatives by the accounting standards board.
abstract: Market Place column on efforts of some large American financial institutions to block proposed new accounting rule that would require companies to show derivative securities on their balance sheets; Financial Accounting Standards Board, which seeks to adopt rule this fall and make it effective in 1999, had hoped that its softening of rule in many areas would be enough to prevent widespread opposition (M)

headline: Hewlett Revamps Low-End Product Line
abstract: Hewlett-Packard Co displays revamped line of mulitmedia personal computers selling for less than $1,000 in latest effort to increase sales and satisfy demand for cheaper machines (S)

headline: Though many investors find that the new tax law helps, some strategies will quietly lose out.
abstract: New tax law, which will benefit most investors, will be painful for some; effects on pension funds that invest in shares of foreign companies, investors who engage in short selling and companies that invest stocks of other corporations discussed (Market Place) (M)

headline: Andersen Appoints New Managing Partner
abstract: Arthur Andersen & Co names Jim Wadia as worldwide managing partner; he suceeds Richard Measelle, who will retire after eight years on the job (S)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent                Previous   Year          Yesterday   Day   Ago               PRIME RATE   8.50   8.50   8.25        DISCOUNT RATE   5.00   5.00   5.00        FEDERAL FUNDS*   5.56   5.61   5.33        3-MO. TREAS. BILLS   4.98   4.95   5.12        6-MO. TREAS. BILLS   5.13   5.12   5.25        10-YR. TREAS. INFL.**   3.59   3.58   N.A.        10-YR. TREAS. NOTES   6.38   6.36   6.87        30-YR. TREAS. headline: John Eichorn Jr., 73, Executive Of Utility Company in Boston
abstract: John F Eichorn Jr, retired chairman and chief executive of Eastern Utilities Associates who played significant role in completing Seabrook nuclear plant in New Hampshire, died on Aug 19 at age 73; photo (M)

headline: Arafat Must Take Greater Steps To Halt Terrorism, Albright Says
abstract: US Sec of State Madeleine Albright, at start of first official visit to Middle East, makes public show of support for Israel and for Israeli victims of Palestinian terror and accuses Palestinian leader, Yasir Arafat, of not doing nearly enough to crack down on support network for terrorists, news conference, Jerusalem; says it is essential that Israeli-Palestinian security cooperation be serious, sustained and effective; insist on preservation of Oslo accords, and need for both sides to keep commitments, including two further Israeli troop withdrawals from West Bank; urges Prime Min Benjamin Netanyahu to refrain from unilateral actions that would pre-empt peace talks; reportedly warn him privately against putting too much pressure on Arafat, since it could force him to defy Israelis; comments are sharply criticized by senior Palestinian official as wholeheartedly one-sided; photo (M)

headline: Dow Plunges 132.63 Points On Concerns Over Earnings
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average drops 132.63 points, to 7,719.28, drop of 1.69 percent; investor concern over third-quarter earnings by multinational companies is factor; table (M)

headline: A Market Oblivious To Gravity
abstract: Market Place column on Dow Jones industrial average surpassing 8,000; says average has doubled in less than 30 months, and over last 12 months, index has risen 50 percent; some analysts comment on reasons for huge increase (L)

headline: AMGEN SHARES FALL ON PROJECTIONS OF SLOW DRUG SALES
abstract: Stock of Amgen Inc slips 12 percent after company says it expects sales of its Neupogen and Epogen drugs to slow during rest of year (S)

headline: Real Capitalism Breaks Japan's Old Rules
abstract: As Japan searches for path to 21st Century it is moving in direction of American-style capitalism amid consensus that old economic and political systems are ill-suited for future; since country has managed to create industrial economy while preserving much of civility and security typical of agrarian societies, fundamental question is whether it can move to more market-oriented system without disrupting social bonds and sense of community that for centuries has been at root of its society; many wonder whether capitalism will lead to layoffs, inequality, crime and society that values wealth more than cooperation and social responsibility; experts say more labor mobility and freer markets, while creating greater economic opportunity and efficiency, may also continue to erode traditional Japanese gentility; photos (M)

headline: All Play, No Work
abstract: He is the phantom employee: Someone in the office who routinely comes in, turns on the computer, drapes a jacket over the back of the chair and then vanishes, leaving everyone else to do the work (or not). Is this your boss, or a co-worker? Did he get his royal comeuppance? Send your best stories to On the Job, Money and Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Or send them by E-mail to onthejob@nytimes.com. Include your telephone number. All submissions become the property of The Times and may be republished in any medium.

headline: More Israelis Questioning Military Presence in Southern Lebanon
abstract: Simmering debate over whether Israel should keep its troops in southern Lebanon gains new strength following disastrous rout of Israeli commando team deep in Lebanese territory on September 5; police and security officers maintain high alert in Jerusalem, site of recent suicide bombings; security forces continue rounding up suspected Palestinian militants in West Bank, with more than 100 reported in detention; investigators say they have no information about three men who blew themselves up, or about two others who struck Jerusalem market on July 30 (M)

headline: Japan Considers Opening the Veiled Corporate Ledger
abstract: Japan's plan to deregulate financial services industry and new corporate corruption scandals are putting pressure on companies to provide more accurate and abundant data to investors and regulators and on Government to increase oversight; many companies are discussing how to modernize outdated accounting systems, install stronger internal controls and better serve shareholders (M)

headline: READER'S DIGEST EXPECTS EARNINGS TO FALL SHORT
abstract: Raeder's Digest Association says earnings in 1997 fiscal year will be lower than expectations; is halving its dividend, to 22.5 cents a share, because of continuing problems attracting customers (S)

headline: Philip Morris U.S.A. Gets New Chief for Tough Times
abstract: Michael E Szymanczyk, newly designated US tobacco chief of Philip Morris Companies, is expert on retail sales and distribution; experts say that is focus that company will need to sell cigarettes in uncertain future when tobacco companies may be bound by harsh advertising restrictions and Federal regulations; Szymanczyk on Sept 17 was unexpectedly named to replace James J Morgan, who will retire Nov 1 as president and chief executive of Philip Morris USA (M)

headline: Art That Condemned Apartheid Will End Its Exile
abstract: Painting by Ronald Harrison that depicts African National Congress president Chief Albert J Luthuli as crucified Christ and white government officials as Roman soldiers, smuggled to England in 1962 after it was banned in South Africa, is being returned to South Africa; Harrison recalls being repeatedly arrested and tortured after painting was exhibited around Europe to raise money for anti-apartheid activities, interview; photo (M)

headline: Swiss Envoy Asks U.S. Judge To Dismiss a Suit Against Banks
abstract: Swiss Amb Alfred Defago has sent letter urging Judge Edward R Korman to dismiss class-action suit accusing Swiss banks of retaining Holocaust victims' assets; holds suit interferes with voluntary efforts to account for World War II-era funds (S)

headline: People
abstract: * Iain Newton and Stacey Lesser, vice presidents and senior brand planners at Kirshenbaum Bond & Partners, New York, were promoted to head the planning group as planning director and deputy planning director, respectively. They assume duties from Nigel Carr, now general manager of the agency's new office in San Francisco.

headline: Mexico's Official Embrace of Press Chills as a Publisher Is Fined
abstract: Juan Francisco Ealy Ortiz, publisher of Mexico City daily El Universal, is convicted of tax fraud, but jail sentence is commuted to small fine; Pres Ernest Zedillo brought case to show he was serious about cutting off informal privileges and subsidies extended to press in exchange for press support for Government; Ealy Ortiz responded by transforming pro-Government paper into feisty critical broadsheet (M)

headline: PALFED DISCLOSES MERGER TALKS WITH UNNAMED PARTNER
abstract: Palfed Inc says that it is in merger discussions with unnamed partner; Palfed's stock rises $1.25 to $21.50 (S)

headline: Shutdown at Oil Refinery Puts Pressure on Gasoline Prices
abstract: Gasoline prices surge after Shell unexpectedly closes part of Pernis refinery; other futures trading (S)

headline: A New National Geographic
abstract: Yvonne R Freund letter reports there is litt current interest in old National Geographic magazines at schools and libraries (S)

headline: Natural Gas Prices Up Sharply On Concerns Over Stockpiles
abstract: Natural gas prices rise sharply on New York Mercantile Exchange on concerns that supplies of fuel are not being stockpiled fast enough to prepare for winter heating season (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: VALUE ASSET MANAGEMENT INC., Westport, Conn., a unit of BankBoston Corp., acquired Harris, Brettall, Sullivan & Smith Inc., a money management company based in San Francisco, for undisclosed terms.     BAY APARTMENT COMMUNITIES INC., San Jose, Calif., acquired two apartment complexes in Southern California for $71.2 million.

headline: United Airlines is moving its transcontinental service to a different terminal at Kennedy
abstract: United Airlines is moving and embellishing its transcontinental airline service at Kennedy International Airport; starting Sept 9, United will operate all of its 14 daily flights between Kennedy and San Francisco and Los Angeles from Gates One, Two and Three in Terminal Six, former Trans World Airlines terminal; Grand Hyatt in Hong Kong has renovated its business center, on lobby level; Travelers at Changi Airport in Singapore with time to spare can divert themselves with free two-hour tours sponsored by local travel interests; Virgin Group's Virgin Atlantic Airways has big plans for 16 Airbus A340-600's it recently leased; aircraft, which Virgin will begin to fly in 2002, will feature new premium class of service (Business Travel column) (L)

headline: Diet Centers Reconsider Prescription Drug Use
