abstract: Some commercial diet centers that had hoped that prescription diet pills would provide quick fix for their sagging sales are reconsidering their positions on dispensing medications after popular combination of two such drugs was linked to rare heart ailment; one chain of centers, Jenny Craig Inc, says it is recommending that doctors at its centers stop prescribing drug combination, while another, Nutri-System Inc, says it is reviewing its position; reactions are prompted by reports that combination of drugs fenfluramine and phentermine, known as fen-phen, may damage heart valves (L)

headline: World News Briefs; German Leader Prepares To Seek a Fifth Term
abstract: German Chancellor Helmut Kohl prepares to seek fifth term; is moving to define agenda for national elections in 1998 (S)

headline: Protective Life Will Buy Credit Life Insurer
abstract: Protective Life Corp will buy John Alden Financial Corp's Western Diversified Group (S)

headline: Disputed commercial wins a TV award as quarrel is resolved.
abstract: Advertising spot for Home Box Ofice wins first Emmy Award to be presented to television commercial; humorous spot was centered on chimpanzees being studied by scientist Jane Goodall; commercial described Goodall as an 'HBO viewer since 1978,' though Advertising Age and USA Today reported last fall that Goodall does not actually watch HBO; and voice identified as hers in the ad was not; HBO commercial drew complaints about its accuracy; photo (L)

headline: After Crime, She Made a New Life, but Now Faces Deportation
abstract: Article describes plight of 32-year-old Xuan Wilson, Vietnam immigrant who came to US at age of four, and curently faces deportation as minor offender under new immigration policy; photo (M)

headline: Irvine Apartment Deal
abstract: Irvine Co plans to raise its 58 percent stake in Irvine Apartment Communities Inc, buying up to one million more common shares for over $30 million (S)

headline: British Air Preparing for 3-Day Walkout
abstract: Flight attendants of British Airways announce plans for 72-hour strike starting on July 9; Tony Blair, first Labor Party Prime Minister in 18 years, has no intention of trying to mediate dispute; British Airways says it does not expect any further talks and is preparing for a strike (L)

headline: Where Stalinist Youth Roared, Limousines Purr
abstract: Artek Youth Camp, Yalta, Ukraine, which long served former Soviet Union's Young Pioneers, now caters to children of new rich; Communist rituals are gone, but vestiges of old Artek remain; many of campers are still sent by trade unions or farm collectives; map; photo (M)

headline: DuPont to Invest $1.7 Billion in Pioneer Hi-Bred
abstract: E I du Pont de Nemours & Co will invest $1.7 billion in Pioneer Hi-Bred International Inc, paying $104 per share for 20 percent of stock and control of two seats on Pioneer's board; move will create powerful rival to Monsanto and others in fast-growing business of genetically engineered agriculture (M)

headline: Equity Offerings Set This Week
abstract: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:    A Consulting Team Inc., New York, an initial public offering of 1.8 million shares. Robinson-Humphrey Co.

headline: Accounts
abstract: * Shoplink Inc., Westwood, Mass., to Orsatti & Partners, Boston, and Brandscape, New York, as the first agencies to handle advertising for the shopping-by-computer service. Billings were estimated at $3 million to $5 million.

headline: A Medium at Its Best, When Not at Its Worst
abstract: Muted television coverage of funeral of Diana, Princess of Wales, contrasted sharply with full week of jabbering that had preceded it, bringing coverage full circle; during period between her death and funeral, television quickly moved from best to worst of what medium can do (TV Critic's Notebook); photos (M)

headline: Sanyo Securities Shares Fall on Article on Debt
abstract: Sanyo Securities Ltd shares plunge in wake of report that it asked life insurers to extend repayment of subordinated loans; company says that it did not make such request this month, but that 1994 restructuring plan includes periodic loan extensions from life insurers (S)

headline: Young & Rubicam Consolidates Duties
abstract: Young & Rubicam Inc has consolidated domestic media buying operations of three agencies--Y&R Advertising, Wunderman Cato Johnson and Media Edge--under Media Edge name (S)

headline: Other Nations Call New U.S. Terms for Mine Ban Unacceptable
abstract: Diplomats drafting treaty to ban land mines say conditions set by US to become signatory are unacceptable; US proposals would allow deployment of anti-personnel mines to protect tank mines, would give country right to withdraw from treaty in time of war and postpone effective date of treaty for nine years (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: PERFORMANCE FOOD GROUP CO.,  Richmond, a wholesale food distributor, agreed to acquire AFI Food Service Distributors Inc. of Elizabeth, N.J., a closely held company, for undisclosed terms.     HARRIS CORP.,  Melbourne, Fla., a maker of communication and electronic products, declared a 2-for-1 stock split and raised its common stock dividend by 16 percent, to 44 cents a share on a presplit basis.

headline: Palestinians Protest Over Arafat and Gaza Security Force
abstract: Thousands of Palestinians, demonstrating growing anger over brutality of Palestinian Authority security forces, chant angry slogans at funeral of Palestinian in Gaza City who died after being beaten by security men; 37 people are injured in clashes between Israeli soldiers and Palestinians in Hebron; photo (M)

headline: CONTAINER SHIP FLEET CONSOLIDATION IS SET
abstract: General Electric Co and Sea Containers Ltd will combine their container ship operations to cut costs and increase profits; joint venture, to be called GE Seaco Services Ltd, will operate one of world's biggest fleets of marine-freight containers; GE Capital will receive 70 percent of any profit from existing operations and Sea Containers will get 30 percent (S)

headline: Unexpected Fall In Jobless Claims
abstract: Labor Department reports that number of workers applying for state unemployment benefits fell 22,000 last week to seasonally adjusted 277,000, lowest level in more than 23 years; analysts had expected jobless claims to rise; four-week average for new jobless claims, a less volatile gauge, fell to 325,750 from 340,750 the previous week (S)

headline: Woolworth Gives Up on the Five-and-Dime
abstract: Woolworth Corp says that it will close all 400 of its remaining five-and-dime stores; closings by 117-year-old store were widely expected and encouraged by Wall Street, but they underscore how much American retailing has changed in last two decades as its oldest icons have faded or died; among discount stores, Woolworth is only last, if most prominent, victim of larger and stronger competitors like Wal-Mart, which offer more selection, quicker checkout and often lower prices; Woolworth stores will be closed in stages; first to be closed will be in metropolitan New York by end of year; photo (M)

headline: German Buyer Seeking 43% Stake in Grundig
abstract: German investment company Bayerische Wagnisbeteiligungsgesellschaft GmbH says it is in talks to buy 43 percent of German consumer electronics maker Grundig AG currently held by London investment bank Botts & Co (S)

headline: Million Join March Against Basque Terrorism in Spain
abstract: Crowds estimated at more than one million people march in central Madrid and Barcelona, Spain, in demonstration against terrorism following murder of 29-year-old town councilman Miguel Angel Blanco by Basque separatists; photo (M)

headline: To Fight Outlaws, Brazil Opens Rain Forest to Loggers
abstract: Brazilian Government, faced with rampant illegal logging, will open timber reserves in Amazon rain forest to commercial loggers in what it describes as project to combine economic potential with controlled development; says it will use reserves to demonstrate that logging practices can sustain surrounding communities and environment (M)

headline: Maxwell House promotes a partnership with Habitat for Humanity in a national campaign.
abstract: Maxwell House Coffee Co, division of Philip Morris's Kraft Foods, is beginning national television campaign to promote its partnership with Habitat for Humanity to build 100 houses across country in 100 days; it is largest such initiative between a corporation and Habitat; Maxwell House is donating $2 million to organization over next two years and will create additional ads; campaign was created by Ogilvy & Mather (L)

headline: BCE'S BELL CANADA IS PLANNING TO CUT 2,200 JOBS
abstract: BCE Inc's Bell Canada unit is expected to reduce costs by almost $100 million a year by eliminating at least 2,200 administrative and management jobs by end of September; Bell Canada tells employees country's largest phone company has lost 33 percent of long-distance market since it was opened to competition in 1992 (S)

headline: BANKBOSTON TO EXIT THE INDIRECT AUTO LOAN BUSINESS
abstract: BankBoston Corp will quit indirect auto loan business by Oct 13; move will eliminate 57 jobs (S)

headline: Kohl's Pains: Lagging East, Inflation, The Jobless
abstract: German Chancellor Helmut Kohl's political woes intensify with release of new data showing unemployment at record levels, inflation rising and signs that eastern Germany is falling further behind west in economic growth; figures follow summer of squabbling among his supposed political allies (S)

headline: 5 on Bankruptcy Panel Cleared in Conference-Call Case
abstract: Five members of National Bankruptcy Review Commission who took part in July 24 telephone conference call that was once thought to have possibly violated Federal rules have been cleared of any wrongdoing by group's general counsel; ruling clears way for commission to render its recommendations to Congress about possible changes in bankruptcy laws as originally scheduled on Oct 20 (M)

headline: Utne Reader Seeks Investors; Sale Is Possible, but Unlikely
abstract: Eric Utne, founder and chairman of Utne Reader, says publication is looking for an investor; Utne says he will consider selling publication outright but that such a purchase is unlikely (M)

headline: Financial Officer Out at Columbia
abstract: Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corp says that its first chief financial officer, Robert Stearns, who began work just three weeks ago, had resigned (S)

headline: SHELL, TEXACO AND SAUDI CONCERN TO FORM VENTURE
abstract: Shell Oil Co, Texaco Inc and Saudi Aramco, Saudi Arabia's state-owned oil company, agree to combine their Eastern and Gulf Gulf Coast US refining and marketing businesses; new venture will continue to market gasoline under both Texaco and Shell brands through thousands of independent wholesalers and retailers (S)

headline: PAYLESS SHOESOURCE TO BUY BACK $150 MILLION IN SHARES
abstract: Payless Shoesource Inc to buy back $150 million worth of stock; has completed earlier $150 million stock buyback (S)

headline: Expected Oil Bonanza Fails to Materialize
abstract: Western oil companies have become frustrated in their attempts to go forward with multi-billion projects to tap Russia's vast oil deposits as capitalism continue to take root in Russia; sensing an improving economy, some Russian companies are trying to get out of existing deals with Western partners or seeking to renegotiate better terms; status of some major oil projects in Russia discussed; table; map; photos (L)

headline: G.E. Reviewing Credit Dispute
abstract: GE Capital files court papers disclosing investigation into whether it illegally collected credit-card debts from more than 17,000 customers who filed for personal bankruptcy; company is one of several accused of exploiting customers by having them sign agreements to repay outstanding balances on cards after filing for bankruptcy; law requires creditors to include agreements in debtor's file (S)

headline: Dollar Climbs Against Mark On German Economic Data
abstract: US dollar rises against mark after reports of falling prices in Germany's two biggest states ease speculation that Bundesbank, country's central bank, might soon raise interest rates (M)

headline: Tower Air goes after competitors by emphasizing safety.
abstract: Tower Air, which lost business in wake of Valujet Airlines and Trans World Airlines crashes, has switched to advertising campaign that stresses airline is large enough to perform own aircraft maintenance; seeks to reassure travelers about low-fare airline's safety; photo (M)

headline: Albanian Strongman Orders His Forces to Encircle Capital
abstract: Albanian Pres Sali Berisha calls for armed forces to encircle Tirana, even though his army has evaporated and his control over own armed guard is uncertain; Prime Min Bashkim Fino, whose party won election, countermands order; armed groups confront each other after midnight in standoff in center of city, but apparently no shots are fired; other armed groups surround Fino's office, but eventually disappear; Berisha refuses to say when he will resign, news conference; photo (M)

headline: Equity Schedule For the Week
abstract: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:    Applied Graphics Technologies Inc., New York, 5 million shares. Cowen & Co.

headline: Software as Traffic Manager
abstract: Check Point Software Technologies to introduce software program that helps companies manage flood of Internet traffic into their corporate networks; such bandwidth management tools let network managers assign priorities to corporate computer users and types of traffic they get (S).

headline: Trial of a Drug Czar Tests Mexico's New Democracy
abstract: Gen Jesus Gutierrez Rebollo, highest-ranking Mexican official ever tried on narcotics charges, is six months into proceedings against him; proceedings have provoked tensions both inside military and out, and are posing watershed test for Mexico's simultaneous effort to implant fledgling democracy and pursue troubled war on drugs; Gutierrez Rebollo has promised to fill out his vague accusations against Mexican elite by naming names; but minutes before his testimony, authorities barred reporters from proceedings and defense lawyers postponed his appearance; photo (M)

headline: At Lun Fat's, It All Seems Small Noodles
abstract: Hong Kong's new status as part of China changed little on surface of bustling city, but it registered, with bits of uncertainty and anxiety, in minds of many ordinary people; restaurant owner Cheung Kee-hwa comments (M)

headline: Coca-Cola Chief Is Hospitalized
abstract: Coca-Cola Co's chairman and chief executive Roberto Goizueta has been hospitalized for treatment of localized malignant lung tumor (S)

headline: Stripping Away Layers of a Wistful Anti-Nazi Myth
abstract: New city-sponsored permanent exhibition at former Gestapo headquarters, Cologne, Germany, is subjecting city's Nazi era history to unaccustomed scrutiny and challenging city's image as anti-Hitler bastion; documents history of city's persecution of Jews, Gypsies and slave laborers; photo (M)

headline: In Great Pomp, Calcutta Buries A Modest Nun
abstract: Mother Teresa makes her last journey through streets of Calcutta, city to which she gave her life for more than six decades; body of humble nun is borne to her funeral on Indian Army gun carriage, escortd by mounted Bengal lancers and helicopter overhead; hers is first state funeral accorded a private Indian citizen since death of Mohandas K Gandhi in 1948; crowds observing procession are thinner than expected; photos (L)

headline: Empire's Sunset? Not Just Yet.
abstract: The handover of Hong Kong re-moves from British rule 6.3 million people, reducing Her Majesty's pos-sessions to a scattering of outposts and islands. But it can still be said that the sun does not set on the British Empire. At every moment, at some far-flung corner of the revolv-ing globe, it is daytime in a place where the Union Jack flies.    Britain now nine inhabited territories, with a total population of about 200,000, and a few tinier uninhabited holdings.

headline: Federal Grand Jury Subpoenas 4 Columbia/HCA Employees
abstract: Four employees involved in obtaining reimbursement from Medicare for hospitals operated by Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corp have been subpoenaed to testify before Federal grand jury in Florida; employees, including managers from company's office in Orlando, have been involved in preparing reports to Government about hospital expenses; Federal prosecutors are investigating whether Columbia hospitals illegally inflated those cost reports for purpose of increasing reimbursement from Medicare (L)

headline: Indonesian Currency Surges on Support Vow
abstract: Indonesian rupiah surges as much as 2.4 percent against US dollar as Finance Minister Marie Muhammad pledges to maintain trading system for the currency (S)

headline: Measuring Productivity in the 90's: Optimists vs. Skeptics
abstract: Analysis of controversy among economists about measuring true economic productivity; Federal Reserve chairman Alan Greenspan, along with Wall Street bulls and corporate executives, argue that new electronic technologies have been harnessed in workplace, fostering ongoing gains in American productivity, even though these gains are not reflected in official broad statistics; economist Stephen S Roach suggests optimists are 'mining' data for favorable results; graph (M)

headline: Swiss to Give First Payouts To Survivors Of Holocaust
abstract: Holocaust compensation fund set up by Swiss industries and banks is set to give some $1,000 each to aged Jewish Holocaust survivors in Eastern Europe; list was drawn up by American Joint Distribution Committee from names supplied by field workers in 14-nation region; fund may eventually aid more than 40,000 people in region (M)

headline: Jitters Stall Market Rally and Dow Drops 127.28 Points
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average falls 127.28 points, or 1.6 percent, to 7,893.95; Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks loses 1.5 percent, falling 14.30 points, to 925.05, and Nasdaq composite index slips 1.3 percent, or 21.34 points, to 1,607.36; chart (L)

headline: General Mills Seeks New Creative Ideas
abstract: General Mills Inc is seeking creative ideas from DDB Needham Chicago and Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising for cereal brand, Golden Grahams, that is handled by Campbell Mithun Esty; billings estimated at $20 million (S)

headline: People
abstract: * Judson C. Green was named vice president for national sales and general manager of the New York office of the Network of City Business Journals, a division of American City Business Journals, owned by Advance Publications. She succeeds Kerry Ann Clawson, who joined Northwest Airlines World Traveler magazine, New York, published by Meredith Corp., as publisher. Ms. Green had most recently been publisher of Inside Media, New York, a Cowles Media publication that closed.    * Craig A. Apatov was named senior vice president for strategic marketing at the Weather Channel, Atlanta, a unit of Landmark Communications, succeeding Ellen Turner, who left. Mr. Apatov had been senior vice president and general manager for corporate marketing for Turner Broadcasting System, Atlanta, owned by Time Warner Inc.

headline: Madelon Talley, 65, a Pioneer On Male-Dominated Wall Street
abstract: Madelon DeVoe Tally, investment manager who was one of Wall Street's first female executives, died on July 18 in car accident near Wyndam, NY; she was 65; photo (M)

headline: At I.M.F.'s Urging, Romania Shelves Copter Deal
abstract: Romania, at IMF insistence, shelves $1.4-billion deal to purchase 96 US Cobra attack helicopters from Bell Helicopter Textron; Bell and US military officials had told Romania deal would help country join West, but NATO has turned down bid and IMF has warned about heavy costs for shaky economy (S)

headline: ISRAEL SELLS MERRILL LYNCH 12% OF PHONE COMPANY
abstract: Israel sells 90.6 million shares of Bezeq Ltd, representing 12.4 percent stake in telephone company, to Merrill Lynch & Co for $250 million (S)

headline: A Toast, of Sorts, To Simmons Durham
abstract: Brown-Forman Beverages Worldwide expands its relationship with Simmons Durham, awarding agency domestic advertising responsibilities for four brands of distilled spirits (S)

headline: Equity Office Properties to Absorb Beacon
abstract: Equity Office Properties Trust, which Sam Zell has already fashioned into nation's largest publicly traded office real estate empire, announces plans to acquire Beacon Properties Corp, its nearest competitor, in merger valued at about $2.9 billion plus debt (L)

headline: Some news organizations take umbrage at rating their on-line sites.
abstract: Members of group of major news organizations, which includes Time Inc, Cable News Network, The New York Times Co, Wall Street Journal and Associated Press, say they will allow their on-line editions to be rendered invisible to some Internet users rather than conform to rating system that screens material dealing with sex or violence; group says it supports open access to information on the Internet; drawing (L)

headline: International Paper to Cut Staff by 10%
abstract: International Paper Co says it will sell $1 billion in assets and cut 9,000 jobs, or more than 10 percent of its work force, as it seeks to improve profitability in an increasingly competitive industry; company says bulk of job cuts will come as workers are transferred when International Paper sells some units; to pay for reorganization, company says it took $535 million in charges before taxes, or $385 million after taxes, against second-quarter earnings; as a result, it posts loss of $419 million in quarter, compared with profit of $99 million in year-earlier quarter; without the charges, company earned $59 million, exceeding analysts' estimates; table; graphs (L)

headline: Korean-Americans Assist an Ailing Envoy From the North
abstract: Kim Hyonh U, North Korea's Ambassador to UN hospitalized in New York since August 12 without medical insurance or financial help from impoverished Government, has reportedly received pledges of aid from Korean-Americans (M)

headline: U.S. CAN SAYS IT WILL SELL A UNIT, NOT THE WHOLE COMPANY
abstract: US Can Corp will sell its metal-services division and take other measures to raise shareholder value, contrary to speculation that it is looking for buyer for entire company (S)

headline: U.S. Links Top Bosnia Serbs to Attacks
abstract: United States concludes that senior Bosnian Serb leaders are orchestrating attacks on NATO troops and senior Administration officials say that NATO will retaliate if incidents continue (M)

headline: Spain's Largest Bank Is Expanding in Brazil
abstract: Banco Santander SA, Spain's biggest bank, says its Banco Geral do Comercio unit will pay $500 million for controlling stake in Brazil's Banco Noroeste (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: NATIONAL HEALTHCARE L.P., Murfreesboro, Tenn., said it would spin off its real estate assets and convert its remaining long-term health-care business to a new corporation, creating two companies.     MERCHANTS NEW YORK BANCORP INC., said it would split its common stock two-for-one, increase its quarterly dividend by more than 14 percent, to 40 cents from 35 cents a share, and buy back up to 5 percent of its common stock.

headline: In TV's Dull Summer Days, Plots Take Wing on the Net
abstract: Serious television fans turn to Internet and each other's creativity to resolve popular prime-time cliffhangers on their own during summer rerun season; emerging electronic genre, known as 'fan fiction,' has spawned hundreds of World Wide Web sites and Internet discussion groups; photo (M)

headline: Investors Get Easier Access To Treasuries
abstract: US Treasury announces several measures to make it easier and less expensive for small investors to buy and sell Government securities; Treasury says its bills, bonds and notes can now be bought simply by debiting a bank account and can be sold without going through a bank or broker (L)

headline: MARKET TIMING
abstract: MONDAY  The Agriculture Department releases its weekly progress report on seven crops.    TUESDAY  The Labor Department reports the second-quarter employment cost index.  The Conference Board releases its consumer confidence index for June.  Mitsubishi Bank/Schroder Wertheim releases its weekly retail sales report.  LJR Redbook Research releases its weekly retail sales index.

headline: War and Peace Over an Israeli Dinner Table
abstract: Profile of Friedgut family, which spans broad spectrum of Israeli society and is often heatedly divided on peace issues; family members agree since Jerusalem bombing that Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat toys dangerously with Israeli peace partners in resisting demands for tougher action against Islamic militants; some say Prime Min Benjamin Netanyahu is too insensitive to challenges Arafat faces from internal opponents; photos (M)

headline: Steel Mini-Mill Planned
abstract: Steel Dynamics Inc plans to build minimill in the Midwest for about $250 million (S)

headline: Edward Scripps, 88, Who Built A Chain of Mostly Small Papers
abstract: Edward Wyllis Scripps, newspaper exec and philanthropist who built publishing company independent of his family's newspaper empire, dies on Sept 4 at age 88; he was chmn and pres of Scripps League Newspapers from 1931 to 1996; he built chain to 51 publications, mostly small newspapers; photo (S)

headline: Foreign Business Pushes Siemens Profits Up 10%
abstract: Siemens AG says third-quarter net income rose greater-than-expected 10 percent; profit rose to 625 million marks ($349 million) from 568 million marks a year earlier (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Ford Sales Increase More Than Expected  Ford Motor said that its United States sales rose more than expected in July, led by continued gains in its pickup trucks and sport utility vehicles.    The company's overall sales rose 5.1 percent; analysts had expected sales to rise 1 to 2 percent. Ford said domestic car sales fell 5.3 percent, while sales of pickup trucks, sport utility vehicles and mini-vans rose 14.9 percent. The report rounded out a fairly strong month for the American auto makers. General Motors sales also rose, though Chrysler's sales fell. $(Page D4.$)    Economic Index Is Unchanged  The index of leading economic indicators registered no increase in June despite the continued surge in stock prices, perhaps signaling that any rebound in growth in this year's second half would be modest. $(D4.$)

headline: Clinton Won't Attend
abstract: White House says Pres Clinton will not attend funeral of Princess Diana of Wales in London on September 6, which will not be state funeral (S)

headline: Stocks Rise, Continuing A Rebound
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average rises 114.74 points, or about 1.5 percent, to 7,918.10; Nasdaq composite index rises 31.19 points, or 2 percent, to 1,600.71; Standard & Poor's index rises 1.5 percent, or 13.52 points, to 926.01 graph (L)

headline: XPEDITE SAYS AN ACQUISITION OFFER HAS EXPIRED
abstract: Xpedite Systems Inc says $340 million acquisition offer by some senior executives and venture capitalists has expired; says group, which includes UBS Partners LLC and Fenway Partners Inc, failed to extend its offer (S)

headline: Tandy Is Selling Stake in a Unit
abstract: Tandy Corp to sell 19 percent of Computer City to Eureka Ventures (S)

headline: High-Technology Job Fair Is Now an Industry in Itself
abstract: Demand for computer professionals is so great that it has created new industry: high-tech job fairs; competition is cutthroat; corporate recruiters report that when they participate in one fair, they inevitably are offered steep discount at competing ones; some job fair entrepreneurs seem to wait until competitor has advertised fair, then schedule theirs day earlier; practically every job fair company has its own World Wide Web site, and many have links to large Internet career sites; photo (M)

headline: Business Best Sellers
abstract: HARD COVER    THIS MONTH - LAST MONTH  +1 - 3 THE DILBERT FUTURE by Scott Adams (Harper Business, $25). Satire about the 21st century.

headline: Saudi Terrorists Are Stalking U.S. Troops, a General Warns
abstract: Marine Corp Lt Gen Anthony Zinni, Pres Clinton's choice to head United States Central Command, including forces in Persian Gulf, tells Senate committee at confirmation hearing that terrorist groups regularly stalk United States troops in Saudi Arabia; says military has acted to protect troops, notably by moving most away from urban areas; says vigilance has thwarted some planned attacks (M)

headline: Dart Reaches Settlement With Haft Family
abstract: Dart Group agrees to pay $52.4 million to Robert, Gloria and Linda Haft as part of settlement to end Haft family's control of Dart; accord brings Dart closer to settlement under which founder Herbert Haft will retire (S)

headline: Under Raging Volcano, Montserrat People Chafe
abstract: Two years of volcanic eruptions and resulting social upheaval have left some 4,000 people remaining on Montserrat, British colony, feeling neglected and and at odds with Britain and their local government; officials face choice of evacuating island entirely or spending heavily to develop northern end of island in hopes that volcano will quiet and population return; map; photo (M)

headline: Chrysler Sales Were Off 4% in June, Less, Though, Than Expected
abstract: Chrysler Corp reports 4 percent sales drop for June, its fifth straight monthly decline, but demand for its pickup trucks and mini-vans is so strong that overall decline is less than Wall Street analysts had feared; compared with June 1996, car sales dropped 14.8 percent in June, while sales of pickup trucks, mini-vans and Jeeps rose 2.5 percent, setting monthly record; Toyota reports 2.3 percent drop in sales compared with year earlier, though Honda sales rose 8.9 percent and Nissan is up 2.4 percent; graph; photo (L)

headline: PHYSICIAN SALES AND SERVICES BUYS RADIOLOGY CONCERN
abstract: Physician Sales and Services Inc acquires S&W X-Ray Inc for undisclosed amount (S)

headline: With Nearly 100 Dead, Floods Keep Raging in Central Europe
abstract: Torrential rains cause severe flooding across Central Europe, killing at least 100 people in Czech Republic and Poland; authorities fear dikes shielding eastern German plain might not hold; concern centers on Oder River along Polish border in eastern German state of Brandenburg; map (M)

headline: Asia's Economic Tigers Growl At World Monetary Conference
abstract: Asian leaders attending world finance meeting in Hong Kong vent frustrations against global markets, asserting that foreign investors and Wall-Street type trading triggered crisis in Southeast Asia; Malaysian Prime Min Mahathir Mohammed levels most extreme criticism; accuses great powers of pressing Asian countries to open markets, then manipulating their currencies to eliminate them as competitors; says most forms of currency trading should be made illegal; participants indicate they may slow or reverse economic liberalizations that have opened economies to global forces; warn proposals within International Monetary Fund requiring further relexation of investment rules worldwide would put additional stress on economies already straining to adjust to globalization; photos; graph (M)

headline: Credit Suisse to Acquire 25% Stake in Insurer
abstract: Swiss financier Martin Ebner says that he will accept Credit Suisse's stock offer for his 25 percent stake in Winterthur Insurance Co (S)

headline: G.E. Executives Get New Posts
abstract: General Electric Co names Eugene F Murphy vice chairman, corporate executive officer and director; W James McNerney Jr will succeed Murphy as head of GE Aircraft Engines unit; David L Calhoun replaceds McNerney as head of GE Lighting; other shifts also noted (S)

headline: Pomp Bars Poor at Mother Teresa's Rites
abstract: Mother Teresa was buried yesterday in Calcutta, India, after a funeral largely closed to the poor she had devoted her life to helping.    In six hours of ceremonies that began with a military escort from a quiet convent church and ended with a Gurkha rifle salute over her tomb, the nun was honored with both pomp and sorrow by her city, her adopted country and the world.

headline: Trizec Hahn to Sell Stake in Clark USA
abstract: Trizec Hahn Corp will spin off 46 percent stake in oil refiner Clark USA Inc to focus on expanding its real estate portfolio (S)

headline: America Online to Maintain 2 Services
abstract: Executives insist that things will not change much for Compuserve's 2.6 million subscribers as America Online proceeds to acquire Compuserve's on-line business; America Online says it has no plans yet to merge Compuserve's base of subscribers with its own membership of more than nine million (M)

headline: Whistle-Blower Lawsuits Aim At Big Provider Of Health Care
abstract: More than a dozen people associated with Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corp have secretly filed separate lawsuits against company under Federal whistle-blower laws, contending that company has engaged in variety of schemes to defraud national health care programs like Medicare; sealed lawsuits were filed long before Federal agents raided Columbia last month (L)

headline: Stocks Wrap Up Brisk July, But Dow Slides 32.28 Points
abstract: Stock prices rise, capping spectacular July run that took main indexes to record highs; Dow Jones industrial average falls 32.28 points, to 8,222.61, but broader market gains modestly; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rises 2 points, to record 954.29, and Nasdaq composite index gains 5.76 points, to 1,593.81 (M)

headline: Boeing Has Its Feet on the Ground
abstract: Boeing Co is branching out into new areas; company has announced number of new ventures--such as selling corporate jets and training pilots--that suggest that it has decided to stay close to its aerospace roots; most of Boeing's revenues come from sale of commercial airplanes, although pending acquisition of McDonnell Douglas will make military and aerospace sector a bigger contributor to its bottom line; Lawrence W Clarkson, president of Boeing Enterprises, comments; Boeing reports second-quarter net income of $334 million on revenues of $9.29 billion; table; drawing; photos (L)

headline: War Crimes Sentence Stokes Serb Defiance
abstract: The United Nations war crimes tribunal sentenced a Bosnian Serb, Dusan Tadic to a 20-year prison term for his part in an ''ethnic cleansing'' campaign in the Bosnian war.     The sentencing in The Hague, Netherlands, was the tribunal's first after a full trial. The judge said that Mr. Tadic had shown a pattern of brutality toward his former neighbors.

headline: China Will Lend Thais $1 Billion
abstract: China will extend $1 billion in special credit to Thailand (S)

headline: NORTHERN TELECOM TO HIRE 1,000 IN MONTREAL EXPANSION
abstract: Northern Telecom Ltd to hire 1,000 high-technology employees and spend $196 million in Montreal over four years to expand output of high-speed fiber optic equipment to supply communications companies worldwide; will build Montreal plant and update and expand existing operations (S)

headline: Clinton Administration Tightens Rules on Supercomputer Sales to 13 Foreign Groups
abstract: Clinton Administration, addressing concerns over sale of American supercomputers to Russia and China, adds 13 foreign organizations to list of groups involved in secretly producing nuclear weapons that will require special Federal approval to buy American technology; Commerce Under Sec William A Reinsch says six organizations in Russia and China will be listed and that additional names will soon be added (M)

headline: Italy Is Selling Yellow-Pages Publisher
abstract: Italian Treasury will sell yellow-pages publisher Seat SpA to group headed by Banca Commerciale Italiana SpA, rejecting bid from ITT Corp; Banca Commerciale's group offers $950 million for 61.7 percent stake held by Government; sale is latest step in Italian Government's program of selling holdings in telecommunications industry (S)

headline: INTERNATIONAL PAPER TO SELL RIGHTS TO 175,000 ACRES
abstract: International Paper Co to sell management rights to 175,000 acres of timberland in western Pennsylvania and New York to Forest Investment Associates for up to $200 million (S)

headline: Nationsbank Confirms a $1.2 Billion Deal for Montgomery
abstract: Nationsbank Corp confirms that it has agreed to buy Montgomery Securities for $1.2 billion; deal comes as Nationsbank, along with many big commercial banks, is seeking to provide equity research and capital raising increasingly demanded by its clients (L)

headline: Cantor Fitzgerald Drops Belgian Bonds
abstract: Cantor Fitzgerald LP, securities brokerage firm, has halted its operations in Belgian bond market; no reason for end of activity is given (S)

headline: America Online Backs Off Plan To Give Out Phone Numbers
abstract: America Online, responding to consumer outrage and mounting concerns about privacy in cyberspace, abandons plans to begin providing lists of its customers' telephone numbers to telemarketers and other direct-sales peddlers; reversal comes less than 24 hours after plans become widely known through news accounts and on-line postings; America Online draws immediate fire from politicians and privacy-rights groups; case illustrates need for increased Government oversight of buying and selling of copious consumer information gathered in course of everyday commerce (L)

headline: Deal Is Expected to Win U.S. Seal of Approval
abstract: Experts say proposed merger of Lockheed Martin and Northrop Grumman is unlikely to face serious regulatory challenge because of Clinton Administration policy of explicitly supporting consolidation of military suppliers (L)

headline: Jeers Sting Mir Mission Control, Which Bemoans a Money Pinch
abstract: Astronauts repair computer that sent Mir space station whirling blindly and use thruster rockets on Soyuz space capsule to nudge Mir back into orbit and align it so that batteries can start absorbing solar energy; Russian Mission Control aide, Viktor Blagov, frustrated by problems with Mir and attention problems attract, breaks space agency's stoic silence and complains about money shortage that barred regular replacement of Mir's computer parts before they died; parts of Mir's main computer have not been changed or repaired in station's 11 years in orbit (M)

headline: Barnett Banks In Florida Said To Seek Buyer
abstract: Barnett Banks, largest banking company in Florida, has decided to auction itself off to highest bidder; most likely buyers are seen as Nationsbank Corp and Suntrust Banks, which both have large operations in Florida; Barnett is expected to sell for $12 billion to $14 billion, which would be most ever paid for bank company (L)

headline: Albright Asks Israel to Take A 'Time Out' on Settlements
abstract: Sec Madeleine Albright calls on Israel to take 'time out' from unilateral actions, such as expanding settlements, to create climate in which negotiations with Palestinians can succeed; she speaks in Jerusalem, day after underscoring American support for Israeli view that Palestinians have not done enough to guarantee security; Albright meets with Yasir Arafat in Ramallah and tells him he must make much harder, sustained effort to crack down on terrorism; photo; reports he has promised to do so; Netanyahu Government objects to her call to Israel to stop whatever Palestinians see as 'provocative'; Albright says there is much work to be done to get peace process back on track (M)

headline: Nycomed and Amersham In $1.9 Billion Merger
abstract: Nycomed, a Norwegian drug company, will merge with Amersham International PLC of Britain in $1.9 billion transaction involving exchange of stock; Nycomed's shareholders will control 53 percent of newly formed company, Nycomed Amersham (S)

headline: 2 Acquisitions In Britain
abstract: Publicis Group acquires Kelly Weedon Shute; Diefenbach Elkins to acquire Davies Baron (S)

headline: Arms Ban Leaves Owners Feeling Pistol-Whipped
abstract: Shooting enthusiasts in Bisley, Eng, for annual target shooting competition, premiere event of its kind, are upset over current and pending laws to tighten curbs on gun ownership; map; photo (M)U

headline: Soybean Prices Drop Sharply After Big Planting Is Reported
abstract: Soybean futures prices plunge after Agriculture Department reports unexpectedly large spring plantings, making it likely that this year's crop will set a record and that supplies will be ample (M)3

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Worst One-Day Selloff In 6 Years Wallops Stocks  Was the stock market simply due for a pause? Or were rising interest rates in the bond market and a falling dollar to blame? Whatever the reason, the market plummeted. The Dow plunged 247.37 points, or 3.1 percent, to 7,694.66, its worst setback in percentage terms since November 1991.

headline: Sale of U.S. Nuclear Fuel Plants Raises Host of Conflicts
abstract: Article on proposed privatization of United States Enrichment Corp, little-known Government-owned enterprise that supplies bulk of uranium fuel used by nuclear power plants in America; Federal Government could garner almost $2 billion, but sale raises thorny questions about protecting domestic source of uranium fuel and securing substance from terrorists; option of selling in one piece or parceling out shares in public offering also touches off backbiting among potential purchasers, union and managers; Lockheed Martin and other companies with experience in nuclear power ponder bids, but drawing most attention is Pleiades Group, consortium that includes Robert Mosbacher, James A Baker and his son Jamie Baker and Alexader Shusterovich, who has ties to Russian counterpart of USEC; photos; map showing worldwide market shares of five consortiums that produce all of enriched uranium for commercial reactors; USEC itself operates plants in Kentucky and Ohio, and reported earnings of $250 million on revenues of $1.578 billion in fiscal year ended June 30 (M)

headline: U.S. Petroleum Data
abstract: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization             Aug 22   Aug 15   Aug 23          1997   1997   1996       Gasoline production, daily   8.0   7.9   7.8       Distillate production, daily   3.4   3.3   3.2       Gasoline stocks   189.5   187.8   196.5       Distillate stocks   126.0   123.2   105.7       Crude imports, daily   8.0   8.9   8.4       Product imports, daily   2.0   2.1   2.1       Crude stocks   309.3   316.2   318.8       Crude production, daily   6.3   6.3   6.4       Refinery utilization (%)   99.4   98.4   93.8          Source: American Petroleum Institute

headline: Refugees From Congo Give Vivid Accounts of Killings
abstract: Hutu refugees at camp in Loukolela, Congo Republic, give vivid accounts of massacres by Tutsi-dominated forces of Laurent Kabila, President of Congo, formerly Zaire; Kabila and Government have repeatedly denied persistent reports that Rwandan-supported army massacred Rwandan Hutu; fears mount that, while international forensic team remains blocked in Congo capital of Kinshasa, Kabila Government may be cleaning up suspected massacre sites and rounding up potential witnesses; map; photo (M)

headline: Saving Those Senior Discounts
abstract: Eric Mihan Jr letter on Ted M Levine's July 27 article questioning need to offer elderly senior discounts; drawing (S)

headline: Checkers Chooses Crispin Porter
abstract: Checkers Drive-In Restaurants, Clearwater, Fla, selects Crispin Porter & Bogusky, Miami, to handle creative and media portions of its account, with billings estimated at $10 million; creative portion had been handled for seven months by Mendelsohn/Zien Advertising, Los Angeles (Advertising column) (S)

headline: Cell Phones Make Nokia a World Player
abstract: Nokia, Finland's home-grown electronics company, has become one of world's leading makers of cellular phones by continually upgrading technology of its products; Nokia's share of 1996 worldwide cellular phone shipments was 20.4 percent; Nokia 9000 Communicator, portable phone and computer in one, discussed; graph; photos (L)

headline: As Gaza Stagnates, Arafat Is Blamed as Well as Israel
abstract: The Sullen Zone, special report on Gaza, where most residents have seen no improvement in their lives, three years after nominal peace with Israel made possible the rule of Yasir Arafat; refugee camps remain mired in squalor, work is scarce, detention by Palestinian security agencies can come swiftly, and courts do little to prevent beatings or extended jail time without charges; only people flourishing are members of Palestinian elite, those who are rich and close to Arafat; their garish living habits are galling to majority of Gazans, who continue to live in poverty; Gazans who were ecstatic to get Israeli troops off their streets now must deal with Palestinian troops that throw people into jail for even perceived slights against Palestinian Authority; as result, new mood in Gaza damns Israel and Arafat in almost equal measure; photos; map (L)

headline: International Petroleum To Get Offer From Sands
abstract: Sands Petroleum AB of Sweden will offer 1.525 billion kroner ($192.5 million) to acquire International Petroleum Corp; new company would be named A H Lundin Oil AB (S) y

headline: PHILIP MORRIS'S KRAFT UNIT SELLS ITS SYRUP BUSINESS
abstract: Philip Morris Companies' Kraft Foods unit sells its Log Cabin syrup business to Aurora Foods Inc for $220 million in cash (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: BRIDGESTONE/FIRESTONE INC., Nashville, a unit of Bridgestone Corp., plans to build a $435 million passenger and light-truck tire manufacturing plant in Aiken County, S.C.    NOVARTIS CONSUMER HEALTH INC., Summit, N.J., a drug-making unit of Switzerland's Novartis A.G., has sold 14 over-the-counter drugs to Heritage Consumer Products L.L.C. for $20 million.    J. BAKER INC., Canton, Mass., a clothing retailer, plans to add 35 to 40 stores to its chain of about 450 Casual Male Big and Tall stores by the end of its fiscal year in February.

headline: Drumming Up Business to Survive in a World Without Cold War
abstract: Many of country's national laboratories that were set up during or after World War II as part of nuclear weapons program are still involved in weapons research, but many are also teaming up with companies in private sector to do research with direct commercial applications; with cold war over, some of labs have lost financial support, while other have managed to justify increased spending; current commercial projects at national laboratories--Sandia, Argonne, Brookhaven, Idaho Engineering, Lawrence Livermore, Los Alamos and Oak Ridge--discussed; chart; photos (L)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent                Previous   Year          Yesterday   Day   Ago               PRIME RATE   8.50   8.50   8.25        DISCOUNT RATE   5.00   5.00   5.00        FEDERAL FUNDS*   5.50   5.59   5.21        3-MO. TREAS. BILLS   4.84   4.78   4.89        6-MO. TREAS. BILLS   4.96   4.94   5.02        10-YR. TREAS. INFL.**   3.61   3.58   N.A.        10-YR. TREAS. NOTES   6.07   6.12   6.67        30-YR. TREAS. BONDS   6.36   6.39   6.90        TELEPHONE BONDS   7.48   7.48   7.93        MUNICIPAL BONDS***   5.46   5.48   5.88          *Estimated daily average, Dow Jones Markets  **Realized dollar amount rises with inflation  ***Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer  Sources: Salomon Brothers and Dow Jones Markets for Treasury's bellwether bonds, notes and bills

headline: PHILIP MORRIS PLANS TO CONSERVE CASH FOR SETTLEMENT
abstract: Philip Morris Companies will not increase its quarterly dividend so it can conserve cash for tobacco industry's proposed national settlement of health-related lawsuits (S)

headline: Reader's Digest Chief Hires Ex-Executives
abstract: Stephen R Wilson, chief financial officer and executive vice president of Reader's Digest Association, has left company along with senior vice presidents Glenda K Burkhart and Paul A Soden; George V Grune, who was reappointed chief executive last month, has hired some ex-executives; Wilson has been replaced as chief financial officer by George S Scimone, who was vice president and controller of the company; other executives who will rejoin company include John Bohane, Peter J Davenport and Marcia M Lefkowitz (M)

headline: Year of the Trojan Horse
abstract: News analysis of China's resumption of sovereignty over Hong Kong after 156 years of British colonial rule; most important question is not how China will change Hong Kong but how Hong Kong will change China--and world beyond; Hong Kong could end up being colossal Trojan horse that could threaten life style and leadership of Chinese Communist Party leaders (M)

headline: Yeltsin Vows To Clean Up Privatization In Russia
abstract: Pres Boris N Yeltsin of Russia criticizes handling of two recent, highly contested sales of state property and vows to do better in future; places blame for difficulties on Alfred R Kokh, who resigned as head of state property committee that handled sales; says privatization must be 'honest, open and legal'; so far, privitization in Russia has been marked by blatant favoritism and multiple abuses (M)

headline: Spain Says It Will Sell Another 35% of Endesa
abstract: Spanish Government will begin selling up to 35 percent of Endesa SA, nation's largest power company; stake value is $7.48 billion and it represents Spain's biggest sale of state assets (S)

headline: A few big winners are seen in front-office software stocks.
abstract: Market Place column on front-office software stocks; says many analysts say so-called front-office applications, like sales force automation and customer support programs, are fastest-growing segment of software industry; companies discussed include Siebel Systems Inc, Vantive Corp, Scopus Technology Inc, Clarify Inc and Remedy Corp (L)

headline: SERVICEMASTER UNIT BUYS ROLLINS LANDSCAPING DIVISIONS
abstract: Rollins Inc sells its Orkin landscaping and lawn care divisions to Servicemaster LP's Trugreen-Chemlawn unit; terms undisclosed (S)

headline: Goldman Sees a Record Year As Quarterly Profit Rises 58%
abstract: Goldman, Sachs & Co says earnings before taxes rose 58 percent in third fiscal quarter ended Aug 31; company earned $932 million compared with $589 million a year earlier; revenue rose nearly 52 percent, to $2.23 billion from $1.47 billion (M)

headline: Israeli Market Seems Solid Despite Turmoil
abstract: Political unrest has had little effect on Israeli stocks and even less on portfolio managers, who remain optimistic about Israeli companies in future; graphs (L)

headline: Home Buyers Find the Bidding Wars Are Back
abstract: Bidding wars for homes are breaking out again in some United States areas where prices had been weak for years, as competing buyers push selling prices well beyond asking price; prices are rising modestly nearly everywhere, with 80 percent of metropolitan areas showing price rises that exceed inflation rate, up from 54 percent in 1994 and 30 percent in 1990; biggest gains are at high-end of market; map; graphs; photo (M)

headline: Clinton Again Waives a Penalty on Foreign Companies in Cuba
abstract: Pres Clinton waives for third time provisions of 1996 law that lets Americans sue foreign companies for using American property confiscated by Cuba; cites progress in rallying allies to isolate Cuba and to press Cuba for democratic reforms; Rep Benjamin Gilman scores move; says pending bill would take away President's right to waive parts of law (M)

headline: Microsoft Takes a Stake in Progressive Networks
abstract: Microsoft Corp makes 10 percent investment in Progressive Networks as part of agreement to support Progressive's audio and video technical standards for the Internet; financial terms undisclosed (M)

headline: Digital Equipment Moves Account
abstract: Digital Equipment Corp and Young & Rubicam Advertising say that after four years they mutually agreed to terminate their relationship on company's domestic personal computer business; account, with billings estimated at $15 million to $20 million, is moved without review to DDB Needham New York (S)

headline: Delay Expected In Nickel Project
abstract: Inco Ltd says protracted approval process will probably delay start of production at its giant Voisey's Bay, Newfoundland, nickel mine until late 2000 (S)

headline: Alan J. Charig, 70, Pursuer of Dinosaurs, Dies
abstract: Alan J Charig, paleontologist, dies at age 70 (M)

headline: 3 Law Firms Agree to Pay $8 Million to Avoid Suits
abstract: Law firms Fried, Frank, Harris, Shriver & Jacobson, Rogers & Wells and Winthrop, Stimson, Putnam & Roberts that were involved in Towers Financial Corp bankruptcy have agreed to pay more than $8 million to avoid facing potential lawsuits that they were negligent in agreeing to turn over some of that company's assets to John Hall, businessman who had earlier been convicted of felony charges; none of law firms admit any liability (M)

headline: Japanese Stocks Lower
abstract: Japan's Nikkei stock index is down 75.90 points, or four-tenths of 1 percent, at 18,659.27 at midday on Sept 4 (S)

headline: Who Says Microsoft Stock Is Too High?
abstract: Soaring price of Microsoft Corp stock discussed in light of company's own view that stock is overvalued; graph (M)

headline: Rubin to Press Central Banks to Disclose Financial Data
abstract: US Treasury Sec Robert E Rubin, in Clinton Administration's first major response to Southeast Asian currency crisis, says that US will press governments and central banks around the world to disclose more financial data that most nations routinely keep secret; American initiative, which could meet considerable resistance from Asian nations whose currencies have been under attack, stems from discovery that Thailand's central bank kept secret data that would have warned international investors of country's impending crisis (L)

headline: 2 G.I.'s Are Hurt Confronting Pro-Karadzic Bosnian Serbs
abstract: Hundreds of angry Serbs armed with stones and firebombs confront US peacekeeping troops who are seeking to wrest control of Brcko's police station from forces loyal to wartime Bosnian Serb leader Radovan Karadzic; NATO peacekeeping troops disperse crowds and repel mob that had besieged 40 international police officers in their headquarters; two US soldiers are slightly hurt; NATO operation to secure police station for supporters of Bosnian Serb Pres Biljana Plavsic illustrates volatility of conditions as peacekeepers take more aggressive role in Bosnia; photo (M)

headline: SPECIALTY FOODS WANTS TO SELL STELLA, ITS CHEESE MAKER
abstract: Specialty Foods Corp is seeking to sell Stella Foods, fifth-largest cheese maker in nation, as it focuses on baked goods and specialty meats (S)

headline: Productivity Up; What It Signals Is Still Debated
abstract: US Labor Department reports productivity grew in second quarter at annual rate of 2.7 percent, far better than six-tenths of 1 percent estimate issued last month by department's Bureau of Labor Statistics; new figure represents fastest quarterly growth since late 1993; graph (L)

headline: Ore-Ida Foods Begins Review of Accounts
abstract: Ore-Ida Foods specialty products division of H J Heinz Co begins review on its account for frozen pasta and snacks; billings estimated at $5 million (S)

headline: In Thailand, Once Asia's Tiger, Anger Boils
abstract: Anger has been building in Thailand since economy crashed this summer after decade of heady growth; Bangkok is on edge and military leaders have taken extraordinary step of announcing that they do not plan coup, once standard procedure for resolving Government crises; frustration with Government reflects failure of political structure to modernize along with rapid growth; increasingly influential middle class with new values is challenging ruling patriarchy, which has largely degenerated into culture of corruption; proposed new Constitution, drawn up with extensive public input, is first to stress civil liberties and government accountability; photo (M)

headline: Burmah Castrol to Sell Unit
abstract: British oil company Burmah Castrol PLC agrees to sell Columbia Cement, its US adhesives unit, to TACC International Corp for 15 million pounds ($24.1 million) (S)

headline: Israeli Closing of Bethlehem Brings Tensions to a Boil
abstract: Palestinian youths protesting Israeli military blockade of Bethlehem, imposed after July 30 suicide bombing in Jerusalem market, clash with Israeli forces; Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat says he has restored enough security cooperation with Israelis to enable State Sec Madeleine K Albright to visit area to shore up flagging peace efforts; Israelis dispute stand, holding Palestinian Authority spurs street protests against closing of West Bank and Gaza Strip; map; photo (M)

headline: For Most People, Selling a House Will Be Less Taxing
abstract: Article on new Federal tax law focuses on specifics of capital gains tax reduction when selling a home (L)

headline: Usinor Sees Partner In Cockerill of Belgium
abstract: Usinor Sacilor SA, France's biggest steelmaker, says it is interested in partnership with Cockerill Sambre SA, Belgium's biggest steelmaker; Usinor also reports 4 percent decline in first-half profit, to 801 million francs, or $133 million, from 833 million francs in year-earlier period (S)

headline: Citibank Consolidates, Stunning Madison Ave.
abstract: Citibank, in probably largest shift in history of Madison Avenue advertising agencies, announces consolidation of virtually all its worldwide advertising and direct marketing assignments at single agency company, Young & Rubicam Inc; annual billings estimated at between $500 million and $700 million; bank and agency officials comment (Advertising column); photo (M)

headline: Apple Shifts Ways It Sells Computers
abstract: Apple Computer Inc plans to simplify how it sells computers to dealers to put its products in more stores; moves include adding 100 people to work closely with dealers and cutting amount of unsold inventory that can be returned to Apple (S)

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.    MONDAY   None     TUESDAY   Federal Open Market Committee meets  Housing Construction July

headline: NORTH KOREANS QUIT ARMS TALKS OVER DEFECTIONS
abstract: North Korea withdraws from long-standing negotiations over its exports of missiles in protest against Clinton Administration's decision to grant asylum to its Ambassador to Egypt, Chang Sung Gil, and his brother, Chang Sung Ho; negotiations were to begin in New York City on Aug 28; defections also appear to throw into question whether broader talks including North Korea, South Korea, US and China to negotiate formal end to Korean War will take place (M)

headline: Half-Year Net Up 47% At German Publisher
abstract: German publishing and broadcasting company Axel Sporinger Verlag AG had 47.2 percent increase in net income for first half of 1997; profits rose to 118.5 million marks ($65.1 million) from 80.5 million a year earlier, while revenue climbed to 2.22 billion marks ($1.22 billion) from 2.13 billion, a 4.5 percent rise over first six months of 1996 (S)

headline: Why just watch 'E.R.' when you can talk about it at the same time.
abstract: World Wide Web site co-sponsored by NBC and Warner Brothers Television drew viewers to participate in 'simulchat' as much-publicized live season premiere of ER was broadcast; excerpts from that dialogue; drawing (M)

headline: Judge Reaffirms Encryption Case Ruling
abstract: Federal Judge Marilyn Hall Patel rules that Government attempts to restrict export of data-scrambling software are unconstitutional restriction on freedom of speech; ruling reaffirms ruling she made last year that could undermine Clinton Administration plan to force US companies to develop data-encryption systems that would permit Government agencies to eavesdrop on data and voice communications; new ruling comes in suit filed by a University of Illinois at Chicago mathematician and Electronic Freedom Foundation, group promoting civil liberties; suit contends that Government controls are unconstitutional (S)

headline: Starwood Lodging Signs $540 Million Westin Hotels Deal
abstract: Starwood Lodging Trust will acquire Westin Hotels and Resorts, latest in growing list of hotel consolidations as industry enjoys record profits; Starwood will pay about $540 million in cash and stock and assume more than $1 billion in debt; combined company will operate under name Western Hotels and Resorts Worldwide Inc (M)

headline: Hotels in New York and Los Angeles offer regional alternatives in their business suites.
abstract: Sheraton Manhattan Hotel will reopen on August 4 after extensive renovation, offering special rate of $189 a night through Sept 7 (S)

headline: Correction
abstract: An article last Sunday about a fight for control of Shoney's Inc. misstated the surname of the owner of 18 Shoney's restaurants in the Knoxville area in Tennessee. He is William Baugh, not Ball.

headline: A New National Geographic
abstract: Letter by former National Geographic editor Bill Garrett recalls scene at magazine during 1980's, when cirulation was at all-time high of 11 million (S)

headline: Consumer Credit Growth Stalls As Demand for Car Loans Drops
abstract: Federal Reserve reports borrowing by American consumers unexpectedly stalled in June 1997, as demand for auto financing and personal loans declined for first month in more than four years; chart (S)

headline: Manila Rally Opposes Moves By Ramos to Seek a New Term
abstract: Two hundred thousand Filipinos rally in Manila to oppose efforts by Pres Fidel V Ramos to seeks another six-year term as President; Ramos pledges not to seek re-election (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: F.T.C. Is Investigating Intel's Business Practices  Chip maker Intel said that the Federal Trade Commission has begun an investigation of the company's business practices.     The investigation is separate from an inquiry under way by the commission regarding Intel's proposed acquisition of Chips & Technologies Inc. [Page D2.]

headline: Treasury Securities Dip in Price
abstract: Prices of US Treasury securities turn slightly lower in subdued trading; 30-year bond slips 2/32, to 100 20/32; yield is 6.58 percent, up from 6.57 percent on July 7; graph (L)

headline: Technology Focus For Ketchum Unit
abstract: Ketchum Public Relations Worlwide, Omnicom Group unit, forms worldwide practice specializing in public relations for technology companies after acquiring Crescent Communications and Thomas Associates; names Susan Thomas director of practice (S)2

headline: Newsletters Find Haven on Line
abstract: Newletters business is $5-billion-a-year industry that employs more than 65,000 people among its 10,000 titles; at its core, successful newsletter attracts subscribers willing to pay premium prices by offering information they cannot get elsewhere; Internet presents challenge for newsletter publishers, who must pursue a goal of getting people to pay for what they read; David Foster, president of Newsletter Publishers Assn, estimates that 40 percent of newsletter companies operate sites on Web; photo (M)

headline: New Tax Law Takes Aim at Estee Lauder
abstract: Floyd Norris (Market Watch) column discusses capital gains portion of new tax law signed yesterday by President Clinton; says legislation was impacted by stock sale by Estee Lauder and her son, Ronald, following initial public offering by Estee Lauder Companies in 1995; says new capital gains provision is aimed at curbing practice known as shorting against the box, legal technique Lauders used to avoid paying $95 million in capital gains tax; tactic described; new law, which would affect other families as well, makes taxes certain only if family member dies at certain date; Lauder case was extensively discussed when Clinton Administration proposed legislation to prevent people from doing same thing; relevant section of tax bill concerns what are called 'constructive sales,' namely transactions that have same economic effect as selling stock but that previously escaped taxation; photos of Estee Ronald (M)

headline: Stocks in Doldrums as Dow Falls 77.35
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average falls 77.35 points, or nearly 1 percent, to 7,782.22; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index loses 7.14 points, to 913.02, and Nasdaq composite index falls 10.27, to 1,591.30; table (L)

headline: How the Biggest Investors Are Forcing the Issues
abstract: Letter by Ned Regan on Aug 3 article on search for perfect corporate board; discusses public pension funds' interest in improving corporate governance (S)

headline: Little Shaken, Small Investors Say Stock Plunges Are to Be Expected
abstract: Small investors seem unfazed by recent 247-point drop in Dow Jones industrial average; feel similar market adjustments have repeatedly occurred in long bull market that many analysts say began in 1982; few of the dozens of investors interviewed believe that market is seriously ailing, and many of them display a degree of self-assuredness that seems to border on arrogance (M)

headline: Executive Changes
abstract: FIGGIE INTERNATIONAL INC., Willoughby, Ohio, named Glenn Lindemann, president of its Scott Aviation unit, to be Figgie's new president and chief executive, filling a vacancy created by the resignation of its former chief executive in January.

headline: Indonesia Floats the Rupiah, And It Drops More Than 6%
abstract: Indonesia's currency falls more than 6 percent against American dollar after Indonesian central bank allows it to float, joining other Southeast Asian nations in bowing to market forces (M)

headline: One Oregon Agency Acquires Another
abstract: Karakas VanSickle Ouellette Advertising and Public Relations will acquire AKA Inc Advertising & Sass; terms not disclosed (Advertising Column) (S)

headline: With Golan's Layers of Loyalties, Who's a Spy?
abstract: Druse residents of Golan Heights, discontent with Israeli rule, are angry over arrest of Ilham Abu Salah, suspected of spying for Syria; most consider themselves Syrians and are staunchly anti-Israel; map; photo (M)

headline: Burma-Shave Rhymes Are Reborn for TV
abstract: Burma-Shave, bygone brand that is as warmly recalled for its advertising as its attributes, is being reintroduced with advertising campaign that seeks to strike contemporary note while evoking nostalgia for 1970's; American Safety Razor Co plans television campaign that will herald arrival in stores of expanded line of Burma-Shave products; TV commercials were developed by Abramson Ehrlich Manes; photo (L)

headline: Palladium Falls 4% as Russia Makes First Shipment of Year
abstract: Palladium falls 4 percent after Russian exports resume for first time this year, ending impasse that depleted stockpiles and sent prices to 17-year highs; September palladium falls $6.35, to $148.40 an ounce on New York Mercantile Exchange (M)

headline: Mother Teresa, Hope of the Despairing, Dies at 87
abstract: Mother Teresa, Roman Catholic nun who won 1979 Nobel Peace Prize for work among poorest of world's poor, dies of cardiac arrest at age 87 in Calcutta, India, where she lived since her work with destitute began five decades ago; had been in failing health for past year; ethnic Albanian, founder of Order of the Missionaries of Charity, was revered in India, where she worked for 68 years and became citizen; was honored internationally for compassionate, effective way she set up and oversaw projects to provide care and comfort to very poor and sick; she was born Agnes Bojaxhiu in August 1910 to Albanian parents in Skopje, capital of Macedonia; highlights of her life, especially work in slums of Calcutta, discussed; photos (L)

headline: Sony Plans to Expand San Diego Plant
abstract: Sony Corp says that it plans $60 million expansion of its Sony Technology Center in San Diego, adding more than 450 jobs to current work force of 4,000 (S)

headline: In East Africa, Panel Tackles War Crimes, and Its Own Misdemeanors
abstract: Corruption and general inconvenience of being in Arusha, Tanzania, have hurt Criminal Tribunal for Rwanda, but 21 suspects are in custody, including some of highest-ranking officials of Hutu-dominated Government whose soldiers reportedly carried out massacres of ethnic Tutsi in 1994; map; photo (M)

headline: Pakistan Asks India to Open No-War Talks
abstract: Pakistan Prime Min Nawaz Sharif invites India to open negotiations on non-aggression pact between two countries, who have fought each other in three wars since independence 50 years ago (S)

headline: Era May Be Ending for Big Local Banks
abstract: Nationsbank's $15.5 billion acquisition of Barnett Banks sent strong signal of the end of regional banking as handful of national giants emerge; Barnett's sale is resounding affirmation of business sense behind dozens of acquisitions and other moves that it used to build itself into Florida's biggest bank; chart (L)

headline: On the Office PC, Bosses Opt For All Work, and No Play
abstract: Employers, both in Federal and private sector, are cracking down on use of computer games, personal E-mail and recreational Web surfing, which they see as undermining productivity that personal computer was supposed to bring to world of work; management measures include monitoring employees' computer files, tracking their electronic footprints across World Wide Web and even passage of amendments by Congress that would ban game-playing on personal computers in Federal offices; photo (M

headline: Bosnia Ruling On Vote Issue Brings Protest By Officials
abstract: Several senior officials working for Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe panel overseeing Bosnian elections threaten to resign because panel head Robert Frowick overturned ruling annuling votes cast in Pale for Radovan Karadzic's Serb Democratic Party; Frowick holds ruling could jeopardize safety of group's staff members counting votes in Pale (M)

headline: Xerox Earnings Increase by 15%, but Stock Falls
abstract: Xerox Corp says earnings rose 15 percent in second quarter; net income increased to $337 million from $293 million a year earlier; revenue grew 3 percent, to $4.36 billion from $4.22 billion; shares fall $1.50, to $78.50 (M)

headline: World Criminal Court Having a Painful Birth
abstract: Legal experts from around world are meeting at United Nations on blueprint for world's first permanent international criminal court, to judge most terrible of mass crimes, in preparation for treaty conference set for June 1998 in Rome; outlook for court, which has won backing of Clinton Administration and most governments, has improved; Gabrielle Kirk McDonald, American participant in talks, comments; Clinton aide David Scheffer says US wants Security Council to decide what cases court hears, view opposed by most other nations (M)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Table shows key interest rates

headline: Betsy's Place: An Oasis Fit for Bogart
abstract: Interview with Elizabeth Haskell, improbable American expatriate in her late 50's who is proprietor of Betsy's Place, small, elegant hotel in Tbilisi, Georgia; photo (M)

headline: TARRANT ENDS BID FOR ASSETS OF B.U.M. INTERNATIONAL
abstract: Tarrant Apparel Group says its bid to acquire assets of clothing maker B.U.M. International Inc, which is in bankruptcy, is rejected by bankruptcy court judge; US Bankruptcy Court approves reorganization plan by B.U.M.'s unsecured creditors committee (S)

headline: Musical Chairs And Fund Returns
abstract: Letter by Robert F Hesse on June 15 article on sector fund problems; says funds that experience low rate of manager changes produce best returns (S)

headline: Sappi in Deal to Create European Paper Giant
abstract: Sappi Ltd agrees to pay almost $1.3 billion for nearly all of KNP Leykam of Austria, creating Europe's largest maker of fine-grade papers used in magazines and annual reports (S)

headline: IRI of Italy to Get $2.2 Billion Credit
abstract: Istituto per la Ricostruzione Industriale, Italian state holding company, will receive credit of 3.875 trillion lire ($2.2 billion) from Treasury for ceding its 61.3 percent stake in Stet SpA, Italian state telecommunications company; Stet will be merged with its main operating company, Telecom Italia SpA, this month and resulting company will be sold later this year (S)

headline: Unraveling a Gene Researcher's Potential
abstract: Profile of Hyseq Inc, gene research firm, whose stock will be offered to public for first time this week; company hopes to raise $35.75 million; expected stock price is $12 to $14 a share; chart (M)

headline: Rwanda's War Role May Haunt Congolese
abstract: Announcement by Rwanda that its military planned and directed Congolese insurrection from its start in October 1996 is seen undermining the political position of rebel leader and new Congo Pres Laurent Kabila; map (M)

headline: Earnings Exceed Forecasts At Three Brokerage Houses
abstract: Merrill Lynch & Co, Paine Webber Group and Travelers Group, which owns Smith Barney Inc, report second-quarter earnings that exceed expectations; profit at Merrill Lynch rose 11 percent; earnings in quarter, which ended June 27, rose to record $481 million from $433 million a year earlier; revenue after interest expenses increased 17 percent, to record $4 billion from $3.4 billion; Paine Webber's earnings were up less than 1 percent; net income climbed to $93.1 million from $92.2 million in year-earlier quarter; revenue, net of interest expenses, rose 2.8 percent, to $975.9 million from $949.6 million; earnings at Travelers climbed 15 percent, led by growing profits at Smith Barney brokerage firm and Travelers' insurance units; net income increased to $662.9 million from $575.7 million in year-earlier quarter; revenue rose 10 percent, to $5.97 billion from $5.43 billion; earnings from operations at Smith Barney rose 1 percent, to $232.4 million from $229.8 million (L)

headline: Free vs. Managed Trade: A Question of Goals
abstract: Leonard S Stein letter discusses Kenneth Lewis July 13 article on free trade (S)

headline: Ousted Head Of Fund Says He'll Return
abstract: Louis G Navellier, nearly four months after being ousted as manager of mutual fund he founded, says he has won back right to oversee the fund's portfolio; trustees of Navellier Aggressive Small Cap Equity fund, as it was known in March when board removed Navellier, have agreed to resign after returning the contract to manage portfolio to Navellier (M)

headline: 5 Years After 'Black Wednesday, 'Mood of Acceptance Takes Hold : Britain and Euro:Not 'If' but 'When'
abstract: LONDON  It was a day no one in Britain will forget. Fighting massive speculation in the financial markets, the government jacked up interest rates by 50 percent in a desperate bid to defend the pound, only to let the nation's currency crash hours later.

headline: Columbia/HCA Directors Sued By Pension Fund
abstract: H Carl McCall, New York State Comptroller and trustee for New York State public pension fund, sues 11 current and former Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corp executives and directors, saying that they allowed criminal fraud to flourish throughout the company; McCall contends company executives engaged in several unlawful activities, including illegal billing of Federal Medicare program, improperly offering jobs or perquisites to executives at hospitals Columbia was trying to acquire, and insider trading; suit names entire board, including current chairman Thomas F Frist Jr; it also names Richard L Scott, who resigned as chairman and chief executive last month; Columbia itself is only nominal defendant, meaning McCall is not planning to seek any financial settlement; suit is specifically trying to obtain compensation from 11 executives and directors (L)

headline: U.S. Looks at Columbia/HCA Elderly Programs
abstract: Federal prosecutors have obtained evidence that some hospitals owned by Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corp may have improperly billed Government for costs related to series of programs operated by Columbia/HCA to attract elderly as patients; such programs have long been critical component of company's competitive strategy, and have been used at Columbia hospitals to expand their outreach to elderly (L)

headline: Israel and Palestinians to Meet Next Week in New Talks
abstract: Israel and Palestinians will resume new peace talks on October 6; announcement follows meeting with US Sec of State Madeleine K Albright in New York (M)

headline: Drug's Failure Hurts Sanofi Shares
abstract: Shares of Sanofi SA plunge, a day after it says its drug Skelid proved ineffective in trials for treating osteoporosis in post-menopausal women (S)

headline: Giant Reinsurer to Move Into Primary Sales
abstract: Munich Re, world's largest reinsurer, says it will merge two subsidiaries with Victoria Holding AG, creating primary insurance group that would compete with Allianz AG; merger would create Germany's second-largest seller of primary insurance (S)

headline: SMARTALK TO BUY RIVAL MAKER OF TELEPHONE CARDS
abstract: Smartalk Teleservices Inc says it will buy Conquest Telecommunications Services Corp in deal worth about $66.6 million (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: TABACALERA S.A., -- Madrid, a tobacco company, said its Tabacalera Cigars International S.A. subsidiary had agreed to buy Max Rohr Importer Inc., a cigar company, for $53 million.    C-COR ELECTRONICS INC., -- State College, Pa., a maker of electronic equipment, said it would close its Fremont, Calif., digital fiber optic business and lay off workers there over the next nine months.

headline: MADGE NETWORKS TO DISMISS A THIRD OF ITS WORKERS
abstract: Madge Networks NV will dismiss about 500 people, or a third of its work force, and narrow its focus in effort to halt two years of mounting losses; Madge reports second-quarter loss of $6.7 million, bringing its total losses to $22.5 million in last two years (S)

headline: Strong Economic Data Send Bonds Sharply Lower, Stocks Less So
abstract: Strong economic reports lead to sharpest selloff in bond market in more than year; yield on benchmark 30-year Treasury bond jumps to 6.45 percent; graph; Dow Jones industrial average closes up 28.57, at 8,194; July report shows unemployment rate down to 4.8 percent, with 316,000 new nonfarm jobs; purchasing managers' report shows factory index up to 58.6 (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Home Depot in Deal To Settle Sex Bias Suit  Home Depot has agreed to pay $87.5 million and change its job assignment and promotion practices. The settlement by the building materials retailer stems from a suit filed by women in its West Coast division who contended they were assigned to jobs at cash registers rather than put on the selling floor.

headline: Wheat Up on Talk of El Nino And Expected Sales to Egypt
abstract: Wheat prices climb to highest level in more than three months on fears that El Nino weather current will cut overseas production, and also on expectation that Egpyt will buy US wheat; coffee prices rise on strike prospect in Brazil; other commodities prices (S)

headline: I.M.F. Chief Vouches for Thai Reforms
abstract: International Monetary Fund says Thailand is meeting conditions for $17.2 billion rescue package, disputing reports that fund might deny aid if officials stalled on revamping nation's finances (S)

headline: Saatchi Canada Acquires an Agency
abstract: Saatchi & Saatchi Canada acquires Campaign Communications in Vancouver, British Columbia; terms undisclosed (S)
